An Indian mountain chain.

A range of mountains located to the north of the Narmada River.

The Vindhya Mountains are a complex, broken chain of mountain ridges, hill ranges, highlands, and plateau escarpments in west-central India.

A village.

A city ruled by King Meru before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell.
The four results of the hearer’s path.
The third level of the fourth concentration.
In the Sarvāstivada tradition, the highest of the three paradises that correspond to the fourth dhyāna in the form realm.
Twelfth god realm of the form realms, meaning “Great Fruition,” it is the third of the three heavens that make up the fourth dhyāna heaven in the form realm. Also called Asaṃjñisattva.

The twelfth of the heavens of the form realm. Rebirth there is the karmic result of accomplishing an ordinary form of the fourth meditative absorption. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-273 .
Twefth god realm of form, meaning “great fruition.”
Second of three heavens of gods on the fourth concentration level.
A class of gods who inhabit one of the levels in the highest heaven of the realm of form.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, third of three levels of the fourth dhyāna realm.
Twelfth heaven of the form realm, it is the third of the three heavens that make up the fourth dhyāna heaven in the form realm.

Lit. “Those in the Great Result.” The twelfth of the seventeen heavens of the form realm; also the name of the gods living there. In the form realm, which is structured according to the four concentrations and pure abodes‍, or Śuddhāvāsa‍, it is listed as the third of the three heavens that correspond to the fourth of the four concentrations.
Eighth of the eight progressive sections of clear realization.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife.
The three myrobalan plants: chebulic myrobalan (Skt. harītakī), beleric myrobalan (Skt. vibhītaka), and emblic myrobalan (Skt. āmalakī).
The combination of Phyllanthus emblica, Terminala chebula, and Terminalia bellerica.
A park in Sustained by Fruition.
A forest of the asuras.
This substance has not been identified.
An acceptable form of medicine for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
A realm inhabited by garland-bearer gods.
Effect, result, fruit.
The Sanskrit is also used for a porridge made from other grains.
A dish of rice cooked in milk that the Buddha was offered to break his fast after six years of austerities.
A river that flows down from the lake Anavatapta.
A city.
Name of an important Buddhist site in Andhra, near Amarāvatī.
An acceptable form of food for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
Symptom that may be evidence of an illness considered an impediment to ordination.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1011 .
Also translated as “non-decrease and non-increase.” See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-061-016.html#UT22084-061-016-29 .
The name of a karmic wind involved in the formation of an embryo in its seventeenth week.
Name of a yakṣa general.
One of the five yakṣa generals.

Śākya Yeshé, commonly known by the title Drokmi Lotsāwa, was a Tibetan translator and important figure in the Lamdré (Tib. {lam 'bras}) lineage. Drokmi’s dates are uncertain, but Tibetan literature offers a range of possible dates beginning in 990 and ending in 1074.\nFor a hagiography of Drokmi, see Stearns 2010, pp. 83–101. For an academic appraisal of his life and works, see Davidson 2005, pp. 161–209.
Drokmi Śākya Yeshé, the great 11th century translator from Lhatsé in Western Tsang.
992 or 993 to 1043 or 1072; Tibetan translator (of an early phase of the later translation period) and important figure in the Lamdré ({lam 'bras}) lineage.
A city in Videha.
Tib. is unrecorded in Negi. Skt. spṛkkā might possibly be Trigonella corniculata (McHugh, 2008, p 180, n30).
In Āyurvedic medicine, taila can be used both internally and externally. It is produced by boiling herbs in edible oil, such as sesame seed oil.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Janendra.
The 550th buddha in the first list, 550th in the second list, and 543rd in the third list.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Mārakṣayaṃkara.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Vimuktaketu.
A buddha in the distant past. Also the name of a prince in the distant past.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Kṣemapriya.
A buddha from the past.
Son of the buddha Cīrṇabuddhi.
Attendant of the buddha Guṇāgradhārin.
A bodhisattva present in the circle around Śākyamuni.
Name of a nāga king; name of Rāvaṇa’s son in the Rāmāyaṇa.
The 75th buddha in the first list, 75th in the second list, and 76th in the third list.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Duṣpradharṣa.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Kusumanetra (196 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.

A bacterial infection of the skin, also called Ignis Sacer and St. Anthony’s Fire. The Tibetan means “fireflames.” Its worst form as described in the sūtra is “necrotizing fasciitis,” when the skin and flesh beneath blacken and die; it can lead quickly to death.
An illness such as measles or rubella, considered an impediment to ordination.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1011 .
Tib. is unrecorded in Negi. Skt. spṛkkā might possibly be Trigonella corniculata (McHugh, 2008, p 180, n30).

(1) The long Prajñā pāramitā (https://read.84000.co/translation/toh8-1.html), which contains 100,000 ślokas; (2) the Mahā pari nirvāṇa (https://read.84000.co/translation/toh119.html–https://read.84000.co/translation/toh120.html), which contains 100,000 testaments given by the Buddha at the time of his pari nirvāṇa; (3) the Ratna kūṭa (https://read.84000.co/section/O1JC114941JC14667.html), which contains 100,000 distinct names of the Buddha; (4) the Avataṃsaka (https://read.84000.co/section/O1JC114941JC14666.html), which contains 100,000 aspirations; and (5) the Laṅkāvatāra (https://read.84000.co/translation/toh107.html-https://read.84000.co/translation/toh108.html), which contains 100,000 discourses that are ways of subjugating the rākṣasas. These five sets of 100,000 features are also said to correspond to the Buddha’s body, speech, mind, qualities, and activities, respectively.
Literally “worth a hundred thousand.”

(1) The long Prajñā pāramitā (https://read.84000.co/translation/toh8-1.html), which contains 100,000 ślokas; (2) the Mahā pari nirvāṇa (https://read.84000.co/translation/toh119.html–https://read.84000.co/translation/toh120.html), which contains 100,000 testaments given by the Buddha at the time of his pari nirvāṇa; (3) the Ratna kūṭa (https://read.84000.co/section/O1JC114941JC14667.html), which contains 100,000 distinct names of the Buddha; (4) the Avataṃsaka (https://read.84000.co/section/O1JC114941JC14666.html), which contains 100,000 aspirations; and (5) the Laṅkāvatāra (https://read.84000.co/translation/toh107.html-https://read.84000.co/translation/toh108.html), which contains 100,000 discourses that are ways of subjugating the rākṣasas. These five sets of 100,000 features are also said to correspond to the Buddha’s body, speech, mind, qualities, and activities, respectively.
A great bodhisattva.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Ratnaskandha (301 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Dharmeśvara.

A past world where the Tathāgata Glorious Secret lived along with the bodhisattva Smṛtibuddhi, a past incarnation of the bodhisattva Prajñākūṭa.
Earth, water, fire, and wind.
The four “main” or “great” outer elements of earth, water, fire, air, and (when there is a fifth) space.
The four great or gross elements are earth, water, fire, and air.
The four elements composing the physical world: earth, water, fire, and air.
The four major elements here are air, fire, water, and earth. The fifth element of space is often added to this list.
The four great elements are earth, water, fire, and wind. They are called “great” because they are found in the external world as well as inside the bodies of beings.

The four great elements of earth, water, heat, and wind do not refer to the coarse entities by the same name, but rather to minimal entities characterized by specific features (such as “hardness” for the earth element) and specific functions (such as “supporting” for the earth element). These elements are usually believed to be in principle invisible; all primary rūpa (“form/materiality”) is in principle invisible, while visibility is a type of secondary rūpa, which depends on the four great elements but is not to be confused with them.

Depending on the context, may translate either: (a) Skt. mahābhūta, Tib. {'byung ba chen po}, the four “main” or “great” outer elements of earth, water, fire, air, and (when there is a fifth) space; or: (b) Skt. dhātu, Tib. khams, the “eighteen elements” introduce, in the context of the aggregates, elements, and sense-media, the same six pairs as the twelve sense-media, as elements of experience, adding a third member to each set: the element of consciousness (vijñāna), or sense. Hence the first pair gives the triad eye-element (caksur dhātu), form-element (rūpadhātu), and eye-consciousness-element, or eye-sense-element (caksur vijñāna dhātu)—and so on with the other five, noting the last, mind-element (manodhātu), phenomena-element (dharma dhātu), and mental-sense-element (mano vijñāna dhātu).
One of the rāśis.
A buddha realm.

A buddha realm.
A realm in the distant past.
Name of a bodhisattva only mentioned in one other sūtra.
A buddha realm.
An emanated mountain on the trunk of Airāvaṇa.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Son of the buddha Pratibhānakūṭa.
A female bhūta or any nonhuman female being; in some mantras it seems to be used as a proper name.
‟Tamer of Spirits,” the titular deity of the Bhūtaḍāmara Tantra; a wrathful form of Vajrapāṇi.
Earth, water, fire, and wind. Also called “four elements.”
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.

‟Lord of Bhūtas,” one of the eight bhūta kings.
An epithet of Caṇḍakātyāyanī.
‟Lord of Bhūtas,” one of the eight bhūta kings.
Name of place in the Adumā region.

This is likely an alternate Tibetan translation for the Sanskrit phrase *bhūtagraha, more commonly rendered in Tibetan as {'byung po'i gdon}. The phrase shares semantic resonances with the compound bhūta grahāviṣṭa/{'byung po'i gdon gyis non pa} and the Sanskrit bhūtāveśa, all of which refer to being possessed by a class of spirit (bhūta/{'byung po}).
A specific class of nonhuman supernatural beings, or a term for spirits in general.
This can be a general name for spirits or demons, but is also used specifically for ghosts.
A class of spirits; in the Bhūta ḍāmara Tantra this term can refer to all nonhuman beings, including gods.
The name of a certain brahmin who lived in Rājagṛha.\nNot to be confused with Bhūta, the name of a merchant and a dog, and a certain class of evil beings.

A ghost in the Indian tradition, sometimes haunting houses where they were killed. They can appear in human or animal form. They cast no shadow and their feet are always backward. In Hindi they are called bhoot.

The name of a certain householder’s dog and the name given to the lost infant it carried home to its owner one night, which would one day be reunited with his birth mother.\nAlso the name of a certain brahmin who lived in Rājagṛha, and the name of a certain class of evil beings.
A term for the mind’s propensity to be diffused outward and to engage in saṃsāric phenomena.
Son of the buddha Śāntagati.
This is a straight walkway used for walking meditation, usually around forty feet long and often raised above the level of the ground. Monks walk up and down the length of it.
An acceptable form of shelter for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
This is a straight walkway used for walking meditation, usually around forty feet long and often raised above the level of the ground. Monks walk up and down the length of it.

The son of the court priest in Kapilavastu, the Buddha’s home town. Also called Kālodāyin (black Udāyin) because of his dark skin. He and his wife Guptā became monk and nun. He became an arhat who was a skilled teacher. However he also figures prominently in accounts of inappropriate sexual behavior that instigated vinaya rules. He and Guptā are also said to have conceived a son after their ordination.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A king of Vatsa, contemporary of the Buddha; also, a king based in Ujjain, contemporary of the Buddha.
Śrāvaka arhat.
One of the kings of Nepal, possibly Udayadeva of the seventh century; a legendary king before the time of the Buddha.
The pupil of the Buddha who is said to be foremost in inspiring faith among laypeople.
A hearer disciple of the Buddha.
Name of an ascetic in a story the Buddha tells.
King of the country of Suvīra during the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
King of Vatsa during the time of Buddha Śākyamuni. Also rendered here as “Udayana.”
A village or town in Kosala. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-1909 .
One of the notorious “group of six” monks whose antics and heavy-handed interference prompted a great many of the Buddha’s injunctions on conduct.
A bodhisattva.
The Sanskrit cyavana can also have the specific connotation of “dropping” to a lower state of rebirth upon passing away.
Birthplace of the buddha Anavanata.
A goddess.
Tenth of the ten recollections.
A sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Fifth of the six aspects of perception.
The aspect of Māra that is death itself.
This is the figurative or embodied demon of death.
Ruler of the hells.
Another name for King Yama (Skt. yamarāja; Tib. {gshin rje rgyal po}), the deity who judges the dead and rules over the hell realms of the underworld.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Priyaṅgama.

The name of the dhāraṇī that confers rebirth in Sukhāvatī taught by the Buddha Śākyamuni in The Noble Dhāraṇī “Essence of Immeasurable Longevity and Wisdom.” Also the name of a buddha traditionally equated with Amitābha or Amitāyus. Also called Dundubhi svara rāja.
A buddha.
The 64th buddha in the first list, 64th in the second list, and 65th in the third list.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Howling Hell. Alternatively referred to as Impossible to Die ({gsod med}) in the Tibetan text.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A goddess of pestilence; pestilence personified.
Realm of a tathāgata.
Duratikramā (Difficult to Transcend) is a buddhafield inhabited by the Buddha Lotus Body Blooming from the Light of the Dharma.
One of the garuḍa kings.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the garuḍa kings.
Birthplace of the buddha Dharmamati.
A type of garuḍa: a divine creature with the body of a giant bird.
One of the garuḍa kings.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the uṣṇīṣa kings attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the garuḍa kings.
Golden-fronted leafbird.
A town near Rājagṛha, it is home to the brahmin Tiṣya, father of Śāriputra Upatiṣya.
A species of reeds; according to Monier-Williams, the Arundo tibialis, or Karka.

A village presumed to be near Pāṭaliputra (present day Patna) but whose exact location is unknown. Rendered in Tibetan in other texts as {sgra can} or {chu bo can}. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-012.html#UT22084-072-012-52 .
(1) A wandering mendicant. (2) A mendicant living in Nālandā.
A great bodhisattva.
A type of worm ({srin bu}) that lives in and feeds on the body.
The 265th buddha in the first list, 264th in the second list, and 264th in the third list.
A legendary king before the time of the Buddha.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Gandhahastin.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Amitasvara (712 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Mother of the buddha Oghajaha.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Siṃhagati.
Son of the buddha Vimalakīrti.
A buddha.
Third of the ten powers of the tathāgatas.
A great bodhisattva.
Sixteeenth of the eighteen distinct qualities of the buddhas.
Literally, “what do you think about this?”
As one of the twelve aspects of the Dharma, it means accounts of the lives of past buddhas and bodhisattvas.\nSee also “twelve wheels of the Dharma.”
Son of the buddha Mahendra.
Son of the buddha Raśmijāla.
Lit. “Desireless level.” The sixth of the ten levels traversed by all practitioners, from the level of an ordinary person until reaching buddhahood. See “ten levels.”
Name of the sixth level attainable by bodhisattvas, from which point there is no more rebirth. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1282 .
Consort of Red Acala.
One of the goddesses in the maṇḍala of Vajrasattva.
A deity representing the faculty of taste.
A deity personifying the true nature of the faculty of taste.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
First of the five fetters associated with the lower realms.
One of the three root afflictions that bind beings to cyclic existence.
One of the three poisons (triviṣa), together with hatred and confusion, that bind beings to cyclic existence.
Passion, attachment, and/or lust. One of the affective behavior patterns or “afflictions” known as the three poisons.
One of the six root afflictions (Skt. mūlakleśa), often listed as one of the three poisons (Skt. triviṣa) along with anger (Skt. dveṣa) and delusion (Skt. moha).

One of the three basic mental afflictions (together with aversion and confusion) within which all other mental afflictions can be subsumed. The term rāga comes from the root rañj, which can also have the sense of “to color,” thus making it possible to create significant double-meanings in Sanskrit (rakta can thus mean “impassioned,” but also “red” or “blood”). Liberated beings are often described as vītarāga, “free from attraction.”
A mountain.
One of the three realms of saṃsāra (the other two being the form and formless realms).
In Buddhist cosmology, it is our sphere of existence where beings are driven primarily by the urge for sense gratification.

One of the three realms of saṃsāra, it is comprised of the traditional six realms of saṃsāra, from the hell realm to the realm of the gods, including the human realm. Rebirth in this realm is characterized by intense cravings via the five senses and their objects.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
One of the four parasites that are said to be inside the birth canals of women.
Another name of the king Mādhava.
God of love; the name of a vetāla.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
This term more literally translates “desire for passion” or “desire for sex.”
First of the five obscurations.
A realm inhabited by garland-bearer gods.
A type of worm ({srin bu}) that lives in and feeds on the body.
One of the seven types of ḍākinīs.
A forest near the village Icchānaṅgalā.
A village.
A pleasure grove in Promotion
A forest in Shining in Manifold Ways.
A mudrā gesture formed with both hands, representing male and female sexual organs in the state of arousal.
A treatise on love.
A river in the Swan Forest.
‟Goddess of Desire,” one of the eight great bhūtinīs as well as one of the eight great yakṣinīs.
An epithet of a Hindu god, Kubera.
Another name of Kāmadeva, the god of erotic love.
Literally “Lord of Desire.” Name of Kubera/Vaiśravaṇa, who presides over the Desire Realm.
The name of a yakṣiṇī.
One of the two kṣetras.
The worlds where beings are reborn through their karma, from the hells up to the Para nirmita vaśa vartin paradise.
Of the three realms of existence, the realm whose beings are tormented by desire and attachment to material substance.

This realm is composed of the six classes of existence: hell beings, pretas, animals, humans, asuras, and devas. These are all existences where a being is reborn through karma. In the two higher realms beings are reborn there through the power of their meditation.

One of the three realms of saṃsāra, it is comprised of the traditional six realms of saṃsāra, from the hell realm to the realm of the gods, including the human realm. Rebirth in this realm is characterized by intense cravings via the five senses and their objects.

In Buddhist cosmology, our sphere of existence where beings are driven primarily by the urge for sense gratification and attachment to material substance. It is one of the three basic divisions of the realms of existence that constitute saṃsāra. The other two are the form realm and the formless realm. See Gethin 1998, 116–18.

In Buddhist cosmology, this is our own realm, the lowest and most coarse of the three realms of saṃsāra. It is called this because beings here are characterized by their strong longing and attachment to the pleasures of the senses. The desire realm includes hell beings, hungry ghosts, animals, humans, asuras, and the lowest heavens of the gods. Located above the desire realm is the form realm and formless realm.
A city in the asura realm called Moon Garland.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
The lowest of the three planes of existence, where coarse desires for all the sense objects are present.
Desirable objects of the five senses: form, sound, smell, taste, and touch.
Visibles, sound, scent, taste, and tangibles.
The five sense pleasures are pleasing visual objects, sounds, fragrances, tastes, and tactile sensations.
In the sense of enviable.
An emanated forest created upon the shoulders of Airāvaṇa.
One of the pratyeka buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A member of the Śākya clan.
Mvy
Tenth of the thirty-two major marks.
The span between the tips of two arms extended to either side.
The name of a bodhisattva prophesied to become the tathāgata presiding over the buddhafield Full of Pearls after the tathāgata King of Jewels passes into parinirvāṇa.
Attendant of the buddha Anuddhata.
A type of spirit whose description is very similar to pretas (Tib. {yi dags}). It is possible that this term is a translation of preta, and it appears to be essentially synonymous with it.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
A great bodhisattva.
An epithet of a buddha.
When capitalized this term is an epithet of the Buddha.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
A grove in the forest known as Incomparable.
“Mixed Grove.” One of the four heavenly groves outside the city of Sudarśana on Mount Meru.
A mountain on the continent of Kuru.
Name of a rākṣasī and Dharma protector.
A forest on the third asura level, Excellent Abode.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
A monk, main character of the sūtra Purification of Karmic Obscurations.
Literally, “Pūraṇa, descendant of Kāśyapa,” he was one of the six tīrthika teachers contemporaneous with Śākyamuni.
(1) A ṛṣi in the past ({'drob skyong gi bu}). (2) A ṛṣi ({'od srung}). (3) A buddha in the past ({'od srung}). (4) Another name of Mahākāśyapa ({'od srung}).
Father of the buddha Pramodyakīrti.
Worldly activities such as social gatherings and performances that distract one from the Buddhist path.
A type of power place where yogins and yoginīs congregate.
These are the formations of the body, the speech, and the mind.
Fourth of the five psycho-physical aggregates.
Lit. “limitless volitional factors.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
The second of the twelve links of dependent origination. See “dependent origination.”

The various conditioning factors and circumstances that affect rebirth, including primarily (but not only) karma. Formative factors also constitute one of the five aggregates and figure as one of the links in the twelve links of dependent arising to account for how karma eventually leads to rebirth.

One of the five aggregates, second of the twelve links of dependent origination, and in the context of the aggregates sometimes also called “volitions,” “volitional formations,” or “compositional factors,” these are complex propensities that bring about action. This term may also refer to composite objects or conditioned things in the generic sense.

This term denotes the deep-seated predispositions inherited from past actions and experiences, some of which function in association with mind, while others do not. Karmic predispositions are critical to the Buddhist understanding of the causal dynamics of karma and conditioning. It is the collection of such countless predispositions by afflicted mental states that constitutes the obscuration of misconceptions concerning the known range of phenomena, the total eradication of which occurs only when full awakening or buddhahood is achieved.

In its most general usage this term refers to any phenomenon has been formed, conditioned, or dependently brought into being. It is this broad use of the term that is used in the Bhava saṅkrānti sūtra when King Bimbisāra asserts that “formations are empty” ( https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-063-007.html#UT22084-063-007-52 ). The same term is also used to describe the second of the twelve links of dependent origination (pratītya samutpāda) and also the fourth of the five aggregates, where the term has a more specific usage related to those teachings.

Second of the twelve links of dependent origination. This term denotes the deep-seated predispositions inherited from past actions and experiences, some of which function in association with mind, while others do not. Formative predispositions are critical to the Buddhist understanding of the causal dynamics of karma and conditioning. It is the collection of such countless predispositions by afflicted mental states that constitutes the obscuration of misconceptions concerning the known range of phenomena, the total eradication of which occurs only when full enlightenment or buddhahood is achieved.

The Sanskrit term saṃskāra varies according to context. It literally means something that “causes aggregation” or “causes to be put together.” In a general sense it refers to any phenomenon that comes into being on the basis of causes and conditions. In more specific usage it is also the term describing the fourth of the five aggregates and the second of the twelve links of dependent origination. Although both of these latter uses have their own technical contexts, in both cases the term carries a more active and volitional aspect and refers to the formative factors, mental volitions, and other supporting factors that perpetuate birth in saṃsāra.
The factual perceptions of that which is impermanent, painful, unclean, and devoid of self.
A bodhisattva.
Eighth of the eight aspects of liberation. Also the ninth of the nine serial steps of meditative absorption.
An advanced state of meditation corresponding to the ninth anupūrva vihāra samāpatti (the attainment of (nine) successive stages); the state of the eighth vimokṣa (liberation).

The nine perceptions of the repulsive state of the body after death are here listed as the perception of a bloated corpse, the perception of it chopped in half or the cleaned-out-by-worms perception, the perception of it as putrid, the bloodied perception, the black-and-blue perception, the savaged perception, the torn-asunder perception, the bones perception, and the burnt-bones perception.

The nine contemplations of impurity, as described in https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-180 , are as follows: (1) contemplation of a bloated corpse, (2) contemplation of a worm-infested corpse, (3) contemplation of a bloody corpse, (4) contemplation of a putrefied corpse, (5) contemplation of a blue-black corpse, (6) contemplation of a devoured corpse, (7) contemplation of a dismembered corpse, (8) contemplation of a skeleton, and (9) contemplation of an immolated corpse.\nFor Pāli and Sanskrit sources relevant to the nine contemplations of impurity, see Dayal (193)2: 93–94.

The six aspects of perception, as enumerated in https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-184 , are: (1) perception of impermanence, (2) perception of suffering, (3) perception of non-self, (4) perception of unattractiveness, (5) perception of death, and (6) perception of disinterest in all mundane things.
Third of the five psycho-physical aggregates.
A “ruler of the world” who belongs to the class of the māras.

Lit. “Perceptionless Beings.” A heavenly realm listed in this text between the twelfth heaven of the form realm, Bṛhatphala, and the five Pure Abodes of the form realm, known collectively as Śuddhāvāsa.

This refers to the category of beings abiding in the fourth and highest level of the formless realm. These are either the gods that abide there or persons who have reached this state though meditative equipoise. This state is also referred to as the “peak of existence” (bhavāgra; {srid rtse}) and is located at the apex of saṃsāra. Abiding there, such beings do not experience perceptions and yet cannot be said to be without perceptions.
The fourth meditative state pertaining to the formless realm.
Seventh of the eight aspects of liberation. Also the eighth of the nine serial steps of meditative absorption.
The highest of the four divine attainments (absorptions) of the formless realm.
The highest of the four formless realms, so termed because conceptions are weak in it, but not entirely absent.
A formless state, either a meditative state or its resultant realm of existence, i.e., a class of deities of the formless realm.
The highest of the four heavens of the formless realm, so termed because conceptions there are weak but not entirely absent. Also called “the peak of existence.”
Name of the fourth of the four formless realms and of the fourth formless meditative absorption, so termed because conceptions are weak in it, but not entirely absent.

The highest of the four divine concentration realms in the formless realm, and the fourth of the four formless absorptions. The other three are infinite space, infinite consciousness, and nothingness.

The highest of the four formless realms. The term also refers to the class of gods that dwell there and the name of the fourth of the four formless absorptions. The other three realms are the station of endless space, the station of endless consciousness, and the station of nothing-at-all.
The highest of the four formless realms, so termed because conceptions there are weak but not entirely absent.
Fourth of the four formless absorptions.
Fourth of the four meditative absorptions.
Twelfth god realm of the form realms, meaning “Beings without Concepts,” it is the third of the three heavens that make up the fourth dhyāna heaven in the form realm. Also called Bṛhatphala.

Lit. “Perceptionless Beings.” A heavenly realm listed in this text between the twelfth heaven of the form realm, Bṛhatphala, and the five Pure Abodes of the form realm, known collectively as Śuddhāvāsa.

A class of beings in the form realm, and the thirteenth heaven of the form realm on a level just below the devas of the Pure Abodes. The Insentient Beings are characterized by having a body but no conscious experience at all; this state is the karmic result of an ordinary or worldly form of the fourth meditative absorption called the attainment of the meditative state without consciousness. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-14 .
An ordinary or worldly form of the fourth meditative absorption. It is variously interpreted as a positive attainment or a counterfeit state of liberation (see Buswell and Lopez 2014, 67).
Lit. “Perceptionless.” See “Asaṃjñisattva.”
One of the gods’ realms, literally “Without Consciousness.”
Fourth of the four types of formless meditative absorptions (caturārūpyasamāpatti, {gzugs med snyoms 'jug bzhi}) (Rigzin 369).
Lit. “limitless perception.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
The third of the five aggregates that comprise a living being (form, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness).
The mental processes of recognizing and identifying the objects of the five senses and the mind. Third of the five aggregates.
One of the five aggregates. It is also one of the five mental omnipresent (sarvatraga, {kun 'gro}) mental factors that necessarily accompany any cognition.
One of the five aggregates, sometimes also called “recognition” or “discrimination,” this refers to the discriminative power of the mind in relation to objects.

The term is used in an ordinary sense in Sanskrit to mean “notion,” “sign,” “conception,” “clear understanding.” It is also used more specifically in Buddhist scholastic contexts in the phrase “the aggregate of perceptions” (saṃjñāskandha).

Often this term is translated as “perception” or “discrimination” when it is included as the third of the five aggregates, in which case it refers to the mental function of differentiating and identifying objects according to their qualities. Thus it does not refer to the perceptions of the senses but to the conceptual notions or labels that are ascribed to sense perceptions before they may be conceived by the rational mind. In this sense, they are not really concepts or thoughts either, but rather the fundamental units ascribed to phenomena by the dualistic mind in order to form conceptual thoughts about them. Thus we have translated this as a “notion,” as the verses of the Bhava saṅkrānti sūtra emphasize the insubstantiality of the names as mere notions ascribed to phenomena, which exist as nothing other than a designation imputed by the mind.
A yakṣiṇī invoked in magical rites.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The demon who assailed Śākyamuni prior to his awakening; any demonic force; the personification of conceptual and emotional obstacles.
Someone for whom there are factors that prevent giving rise to the vows (Kalyāṇamitra, folio 292.a.4).
Those who are expert in monastic discipline.
A term used to designate someone who is a master of Buddhist monastic discipline.
Birthplace of the buddha Vajrasaṃhata.
The section of the Buddha’s teachings that focuses on conduct.
The Buddha’s teachings that lay out the rules and disciplines for his followers.
“Discipline”; one of the Three Baskets (Tripiṭaka), the Vinaya is the body of literature on monastic discipline and training.
One of the three piṭakas, or “baskets,” of the Buddhist canon. It codifies the disciplined conduct and training of monks and nuns.
One of the three Piṭakas, or “Baskets,” of the Buddhist canon; the one dealing specifically with the code of the monastic disipline.
The vows and texts pertaining to monastic discipline. One of the three piṭakas, or “baskets,” of the Buddhist canon, the one dealing specifically with the code of monastic discipline.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the vidyārājas dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A householder who was the Buddha in a former life.
Attendant of Prince Siddhārtha.
Seventh of the eighteen distinct qualities of the buddhas.
First of the four supports for miraculous abilities.
The Bodhisattva’s charioteer.
Attendant of the buddha Janendrakalpa.
One of the four bases of miraculous power.
An afflictive emotion. In other contexts also for the Tib. {sred pa}.
One of the notorious “group of six” monks whose antics and heavy-handed interference prompted a great many of the Buddha’s injunctions on conduct.
A monk absent from an official saṅgha function, such as the purification, must send word he will consent to any actions taken in his absence. Such consent is sent by proxy.
The assembly hall of the gods.
The dome-shaped assembly hall where Indra teaches the Dharma located on the southwest side of Mount Meru.

Conditioned phenomena, as described in https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-415 , include the following: the world system of desire, the world system of form, the world system of formlessness, and likewise, the five psycho-physical aggregates, the four meditative concentrations, the four immeasurable aspirations, the four formless meditative absorptions, and similarly, all those [aforementioned] attributes extending from the four applications of mindfulness, up to and including the eighteen distinct qualities of the buddhas.\n(See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-408 ).
One among a list of sixteen uṣṇīṣa buddhas named after the sixteen emptinesses.
Seventh of the eighteen aspects of emptiness.
One of the fourteen emptinesses and eighteen emptinesses.
Refers to all phenomena produced by causes and conditions.
Composed of constituent parts, whether physical or temporal; dependent on causes.
This term refers to composite objects in the generic sense. In other contexts, it can also refer to “formations.”
Refers to phenomena that are not produced by causes and conditions, such as nirvāṇa.

This phrase occurs throughout a number of Perfection of Wisdom discourses and several other sūtras (Apple 2014). See, for example, the Vajracchedikā Prajñāpāramitā §7https://read.84000.co/translation/toh14.html (Harrison 2006, p. 145).

Unconditioned phenomena, as described in https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-416 , include the following: Non-arising, non-abiding, non-disintegration, and non-transformation with respect to all things, and similarly, the cessation of desire, the cessation of hatred, the cessation of delusion, the abiding of phenomena in the real nature, reality, the expanse of reality, maturity with respect to all things, the real nature, the unmistaken real nature, the inalienable real nature, and the finality of existence.\n(See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-408 ).
Not composed of constituent parts; not dependent on causes.
One among a list of sixteen uṣṇīṣa buddhas named after the sixteen emptinesses.
Eighth of the eighteen aspects of emptiness.
One of the fourteen emptinesses and eighteen emptinesses.
Not composed of constituent parts; not dependent on causes.
Refers to phenomena that are not produced by causes and conditions.
Princess of Takṣaśīla, child of Padmagarbha, mother of Kātyāyana, and spouse of Riu. During the Buddha’s time she defeated all the scriptural exegetes from neighboring lands in debate.

A collection of seventeen sūtras on a range of themes, compiled as a separate collection. Today, this collection only exists in Chinese translation, although several of the individual scriptures exist in Sanskrit and in Tibetan translation.

An anthology of Great Vehicle Sūtras. A collection of seventeen sūtras under this title is available in Chinese translation, but The Questions of Sāgaramati is not included among them. It is thus likely that there were more than one anthology using this title.
Fourth of the four kinds of disease.
A class of spirits causing imbalance of all three humors.
A term in the Suśrutasaṃhitā that denotes a dangerous illness that results when all three humors are out of balance.
Symptom that may be evidence of an illness considered an impediment to ordination.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1011 .
One of the seven great rishis of ancient India. Also known as the father of Paraśurāma, the sixth incarnation of Viṣṇu.
A rishi who was a pupil of Vyāsa, the first master of the Sāmaveda and the source of the Mīmāṃsā tradition.

Another name of Maudgalyāyana, one of the Buddha’s two principal pupils. Kolita was the name of his home village, or was (according to The Chapter on Going Forth) a name given by his relatives meaning “born from the lap” [of the gods].
An asura.
Son of the buddha Gandheśvara.
A divine river whose gold is believed to be especially fine.
A buddha from the past.
A buddha in the distant past.
An eastern buddha realm.
Legendary river carrying the remains of the golden fruit of a legendary jambu (rose apple) tree.

The rivers that flow down from the immense lake at the foot of the legendary Jambu tree, including the Ganges. The fruits of that tree are golden and are carried down by the rivers through Jambudvīpa.
Legendary river carrying the golden fruit fallen from the legendary jambu (“rose apple”) tree. This term is used as an adjective for the gold found in rivers.

The name of the southern continent in Buddhist cosmology, which can mean the known world of humans or more specifically the Indian subcontinent. A gigantic, miraculous rose-apple (jambu) tree at the source of the great Indian rivers is said to give the continent its name.
The “Rose-apple continent,” a name for the human world in the ancient Indian cosmology, it can be translated perhaps as “this earth,” or even as “India.”

The continent (dvīpa) on which we live which, according to ancient South-Asian cosmology, is shaped like a jambū fruit (probably Syzygium cumini, the jambolan, Malabar plum, or Java plum; or possibly S. amarangense, the Java apple, rose-apple, or wax jambu).

“Rose-Apple Continent,” the name of the southern continent in Buddhist cosmology, which can mean the known world of humans or, more specifically, the Indian subcontinent. A gigantic miraculous rose-apple (jambu) tree at the source of the great Indian rivers is said to give the continent its name.

The name of the southern continent in Buddhist cosmology, which can mean the known world of humans or more specifically the Indian subcontinent. In the Kāraṇḍavyūha, Sri Laṅka is described as being separate from Jambudvīpa. A gigantic miraculous rose-apple tree at the source of the great Indian rivers is said to give the continent its name.

The name of the southern continent in Buddhist cosmology, signifying either the known human world, or sometimes more specifically the Indian subcontinent. The name comes from the jambu (“rose apple” or “black plum”) tree said to grow near Lake Anavatapta in the continent’s northern mountains, considered to be the source of the four great rivers of India.

The name of the southern continent in Buddhist cosmology, which can signify either the known human world, or more specifically the Indian subcontinent, literally “the jambu island/continent.” Jambu is the name used for a range of plum-like fruits from trees belonging to the genus Szygium, particularly Szygium jambos and Szygium cumini, and has commonly been rendered “rose apple,” although “black plum” may be a less misleading term. Among various explanations given for the continent being so named, one (in the Abhidharmakośa) is that a jambu tree grows in its northern mountains beside Lake Anavatapta, mythically considered the source of the four great rivers of India, and that the continent is therefore named from the tree or the fruit. Jambudvīpa has the vajrāsana at its center and is the only continent upon which buddhas attain awakening.
A forest in Born in a Lap.
An alternative name for Jambudvīpa (“Rose-Apple Continent”), which means “Rose-Apple Banner.”
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Light of the World.
Mahākātyāyana’s name when he becomes a buddha in the distant future. Also rendered in Sanskrit in a shorter form as “Jāmbūnadābhāsa,” (Tibetan remains the same).
A particularly pure gold or golden color.
A particularly high quality of gold mined from the Jambu River.
A river.
Mother of the buddha Puṣpaketu.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Manujacandra.
A legendary river carrying the remains of the golden fruit of a legendary rose-apple (jambu) tree.
Name of a mythological river that carries the remains of the golden fruit of the legendary jambu (rose apple) tree.
Attendant of the buddha Amoghadarśin.
Birthplace of the buddha Nakṣatrarāja.

Legendary river carrying the golden fruit fallen from the legendary jambu (“rose apple”) tree. This term is used as an adjective for the gold found in rivers. When used as an adjective, the Sanskrit is jāmbūnada.
An island to the north of Jambudvīpa.
An ocean far off the coast of Jambudvīpa.
The length of a year as experienced by a sentient being born on Jambudvīpa in the desire realm.
The term for the world in which we live, this is the southern continent in traditional Buddhist cosmography.
“Rose Apple Island,” this was the name commonly used for one of the four great continents of ancient Buddhist cosmology, generally understood to refer to the Indian subcontinent.

The continent on which we live, according to ancient South-Asian cosmology. It is the southernmost of the four continents surrounding Mount Sumeru, the mountain at the center of our world system. It is shaped like a jambū fruit.

The continent (dvīpa) on which we live, which according to ancient South-Asian cosmology is shaped like a jambū fruit (probably Syzygium cumini, the jambolan, Malabar plum, or Java plum; or possibly S. amarangense, the Java apple, rose apple, or wax jambu).

The southern continent where humans live according to ancient South Asian cosmology. For one explanation of the name, see Exposition of Karma, Toh 338, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh281.html. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-122 in the present text.

The name of the southern continent in Buddhist cosmology, which can mean the known world of humans or, more specifically, the Indian subcontinent. In the Karaṇḍavyūha Sūtra, Sri Lanka is described as being separate from Jambudvīpa. A gigantic miraculous rose-apple tree at the source of the great Indian rivers is said to give the continent its name.

The name of the southern continent in Buddhist cosmology, which can signify either the known human world, or more specifically the Indian subcontinent, literally “the jambu island/continent.” Jambu is the name used for a range of plum-like fruits from trees belonging to the genus Szygium, particularly Szygium jambos and Szygium cumini, and has commonly been rendered “rose apple,” although “black plum” may be a less misleading term. Among various explanations given for the continent being so named, one (in the https://read.84000.co/translation/toh4089.html ) is that a jambu tree grows in its northern mountains beside Lake Anavatapta, mythically considered the source of the four great rivers of India, and that the continent is therefore named from the tree or the fruit. Jambudvīpa has the vajrāsana (“seat of awakening”) at its center and is the only continent upon which buddhas attain awakening.
A particularly fine type of gold deposited in the Jambū river, sometimes said to be remains of the fruits from the rose-apple trees growing there which fall into the river and are consumed.
Mother of the buddha Vaidya.
Caves on the northern border of the Middle Country earlier in the current eon, during the time of the Buddha Kāśyapa.
An alternative name for Jambudvīpa meaning “rose-apple banner.”
Syzygium cumini. At present mainly called the jambul tree, it is the Indian version among the various species of rose apple trees.
A river that runs in the heavenly realms.
A celestial river flowing from Mount Sumeru.
A river whose gold is believed to be especially good.
A divine river whose gold is believed to be especially fine.
Syzygium cumini according to the Pandanus Database of Plants.
Legendary river carrying the remains of the golden fruit of a legendary jambu (rose apple) tree.

The name of the southern continent in Buddhist cosmology, which can signify either the known human world, or more specifically the Indian subcontinent, literally “the jambu island/continent.” Jambu is the name used for a range of plum-like fruits from trees belonging to the genus Szygium, particularly Szygium jambos and Szygium cumini, and has commonly been rendered “rose apple” although “black plum” may be a less misleading term. Among various explanations given for the continent being so named, one (in the Abhidharmakośa) is that a jambu tree grows in its northern mountains beside Lake Anavatapta, mythically considered the source of the four great rivers of India, and that the continent is therefore named from the tree or the fruit. Jambudvīpa has the vajrāsana at its center and is the only continent upon which buddhas attain awakening.
A mythical, divine river.
A hearer.

Son of the high brahmin Grasping of Rājagṛha. As he was lying ill, Venerable Śāriputra gave him a teaching on the four immeasurables. Admonishing Venerable Śāriputra for a lack of foresight, the Buddha then gave him an additional teaching on the four noble truths, leading him to manifest the resultant state of a non-returner and take rebirth as a god.
A certain high brahmin of Rājagṛha, father of Son of Grasping.
“A rapacious animal living in fresh or sea water, any large fish or marine animal (crocodile, shark, serpent, Gangetic alligator, water elephant, or hippopotamus)” (Monier-Williams).
A buddha realm.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Gaṇimuktirāja.
The 228th buddha in the first list, 227th in the second list, and 227th in the third list.
Can also mean to memorize, retain, or grasp.
The Buddha’s cousin and one of his ten principal pupils, he was renowned for his clairvoyance. Often translated elsewhere as {ma 'gags pa}.
A bodhisattva.
Śrāvaka arhat.
Name of the ninety-eighth meditative stability.
Lit. “pacifier of all obstruction and stopping.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
Third of the four noble truths.
A king; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Seventh of the eleven aspects of knowledge.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ketu.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
The third Noble Truth, equivalent to nirvāṇa.
A class of vidyādharas.
11th century translator and teacher of Guhya samāja tantra.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
Listed in The Question of Mañjuśrī as the ninth of the thirty-two signs of a great being.
Twentieth of the thirty-two major marks.
A cupola covering each of the four gates of the maṇḍala.
A yakṣiṇī.
One of the eight nāga ladies.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva.
Mother of the buddha Surabhigandha.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Kusumanetra.

A bodhisattva layman of Vaiśālī, who is saved by Vimalakīrti from being fooled by Māra posing as Indra. This bodhisattva is mentioned in Mvy, No. 728, and in the Rāṣṭra pāla paripṛccha (Toh 62, in the Ratnakūṭa; see Lamotte, p. 204, n. 120 and Vienna Buddhist Studies Translation Group, trans., https://read.84000.co/translation/toh62.html#UT22084-042-003-39 , 1.2).
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Yaśottara.
‟Protectress of the World,” one of the eight great bhūtinīs.
One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife.
Attendant of the buddha Ratnaprabha.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Sthāmaprāpta.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Subāhu (462 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Gods, asuras, humans, animals, hungry ghosts, and hell beings.
Life as a being in hell, an animal, a ghost, a human, an asura, and a god.
The possible six types of rebirth in any of the six realms of cyclic existence.
The six destinies correspond to the six realms of Buddhist cosmogony (i.e., gods, demigods, humans, animals, hungry ghosts and hell beings).
A bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Pūritāṅga.
Buddhas have transcended rebirth as a god, human, hell being, animal, and spirit.
These comprise the gods and humans in the higher realms within saṃsāra, plus the animals, ghosts, and denizens of hell in the lower realms.
These comprise the gods and humans of the higher realms within saṃsāra, along with the animals, hungry spirits, and hell beings of the lower realms.

A shorter form of the six classes of beings, these are: (1) hell beings, (2) anguished spirits, (3) animals, (4) human beings, and (5) gods. The fifth category is divided into gods and demigods when six realms are enumerated.

These comprise gods and humans of the higher realms within cyclic existence, along with animals, starving spirits, and the hell dwellers, whose abodes are identified with the lower realms. It is also common to divide the god realm in two, the gods and the asuras, making up six realms or classes of beings ({'gro ba drug}, ṣaḍgati or {rigs drug}, ṣaṭkula).
Attendant of the buddha Dṛḍhasaṅgha.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Maṇicandra.
A bodhisattva.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
These comprise the gods and humans in the higher realms within saṃsāra, plus the animals, ghosts, and denizens of hell in the lower realms.
A bodhisattva.
A night goddess at the bodhimaṇḍa.
Birthplace of the buddha Sthitagandha.
Name of a dance instructor in a story Buddha tells.

Literally, “Dravidian mantra words.” The Bodhisattvabhūmi https://read.84000.co/translation/toh4037 defines Dravidian mantras as strings of syllables with no specific semantic domain. The fact that these mantras are specifically identified as “Dravidian” (Skt. drāmiḍa; Tib. {'gro lding}) points to their origin among the speakers of Dravidian languages in South India.
(1) A country of the Deccan region of India. (2) A kingdom in southern India.
One of the prominent peoples of the Indian Subcontinent who were already present there prior to the arrival of the Aryans in around 1500 ce.

Another name for the Dravidian, non-Aryan people and language(s) of South India and northern Sri Lanka. Dramiḍa (actually spelled drāmiḍa in the Sanskrit of the quote from this text in the Śikṣāsamuccaya) is the origin of the word Tamil; other Dravidian languages are Telugu, Malayalam, and Kannada.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
A realm inhabited by garland-bearer gods.
A nāga. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2561 .
One of the notorious “group of six” monks whose antics and heavy-handed interference prompted a great many of the Buddha’s injunctions on conduct.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Mahāsthāman.
The hundred-and-third buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Yaśadatta.
A shell used as a coin.

The Tibetan term {'gron bu} is generally restricted to “cowry shell,” but the term hiraṇya more typically refers to “gold coins” and can be applied to any form of currency, which includes cowry shells.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Vratasthita.

Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Resolver of Doubts Regarding Transgressing All Vows.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Anantavikrāmin (214 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Meaning “gentle or beautiful voice,” this is an alternative name for Mañjuśrī. It is synonymous with Mañjughoṣa, which is also translated into Tibetan as {'jam dbyangs}. See also “Mañjuśrī.”
Son of the buddha Mahātejas.
A great bodhisattva.
The bodhisattva of wisdom; one of the bodhisattvas in the retinue of the Buddha.
The bodhisattva who is considered the embodiment of wisdom. Also known as Mañjuśrī kumāra bhūta.
A disciple of Āryadeva.
The bodhisattva Mañjuśrī; literally “Youthful Mañjuśrī.”
Bodhisattva of wisdom and one of the Buddha’s principal interlocutors in many sūtras.
Mañjuśrī who takes the form of a youth, an epithet by which the well-known bodhisattva is often referred.
An epithet of the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī, meaning “the youthful Mañjuśrī.” Mañjuśrī is one of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha and the embodiment of wisdom.
The bodhisattva who is considered the embodiment of wisdom, with the additional honorific title for a young man. Also rendered here as “Mañjusvara” and “Mañjuśrī.”

Mañjuśrī who takes the form of a youth, an epithet by which the well-known bodhisattva is often referred. He is considered to be the embodiment of the transcendent perfection of insight and is portrayed wielding a sword in his right hand that cuts through delusion and a volume of the Prajñā pāramitā sūtra in his left that contains teachings on transcendent insight.

Mañjuśrī is one of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha and a bodhisattva that embodies insight. He is a major figure in the Mahāyāna sūtras, appearing often as an interlocutor of the Buddha, as in the case of this text. In his most well-known iconographic form, he is portrayed bearing the sword of insight in his right hand and a volume of the Prajñā pāramitā sūtra in his left. In addition to the epithet Kumārabhūta, which means “having a youthful form,” Mañjuśrī can also take on the epithets Mañjughoṣa, Mañjusvara, and Pañcaśikha.

The eternally youthful crown prince (kumārabhūta), so called because of his special identification with the Prajñā pāramitā, or Transcendence of Wisdom. He is the only member of the Buddha’s retinue who volunteers to visit Vimalakīrti, and he serves as Vimalakīrti’s principal interlocutor throughout the sūtra. Traditionally regarded as the wisest of bodhisattvas, in Tibetan tradition he is known as {rgyal ba'i yab gcig}, the “sole father of buddhas,” as he inspires them in their realization of the profound. He is represented as bearing the sword of wisdom in his right hand and a volume of the Prajñā pāramitā sūtra in his left. He is always youthful in appearance, like a boy of sixteen.

Evolved from the gandharva Pañcaśikha in early Buddhism, which remains one of Mañjuśrī’s alternate names. Pañcaśikha was a gandharva who lived on a five-peaked mountain, and who brought the Buddha information on what was occuring in the paradises. Mañjuśrī is the first prominent bodhisattva after Maitreya in the early Mahāyāna sūtras, where he is known as Mañjughoṣa (“Having a Beautiful Voice”). He came to embody wisdom, and became one of the eight great bodhisattvas. In the early tantras he was the lord of one of the three buddha families. In the Sanskrit version of the sūtra, Kumārabhūta is a separate word rather than a compound with his proper name. This means that it could be the second of his names, and it is glossed as meaning “always young.” Alternatively it could be treated simply as an adjective, as in “the youth Manjuśrī.”
Name of a bodhisattva.
A term of address for the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī, who is considered the embodiment of wisdom.
Toh 360.https://read.84000.co/translation/toh360.html
A great bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva and one of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha Śākyamuni, he is considered the embodiment of wisdom.
One of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha, the embodiment of wisdom. In this text, he is one of the main interlocutors of the Buddha.
A great bodhisattva, one of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha, the embodiment of wisdom. Also called here Mañjuśrī kumāra bhūta, literally “Youthful Mañjuśrī.”

One of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha, the embodiment of insight (prajñā). In Tibetan tradition he is known as {rgyal ba'i yab gcig}, the “sole father of buddhas,” as he inspires them in their realization of the profound. He is represented as bearing the sword of insight in his right hand and a volume of the Prajñā pāramitā sūtra in his left.

Mañjuśrī is one of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha and a bodhisattva who embodies insight. He is a major figure in the Mahāyāna sūtras, appearing often as an interlocutor of the Buddha, as in the case of this text. In his most well-known iconographic form, he is portrayed bearing the sword of insight in his right hand and a volume of the Prajñā pāramitā sūtra in his left. In addition to the epithet Kumārabhūta, which means "having a youthful form," Mañjuśrī can also take on the epithets Mañjughoṣa, Mañjusvara, and Pañcaśikha.

The eternally youthful crown prince (kumārabhūta), so called because of his special identification with the Prajñā pāramitā, or Transcendence of Wisdom. He is the only member of the Buddha’s retinue who volunteers to visit Vimalakīrti, and he serves as Vimalakīrti’s principal interlocutor throughout the sūtra. Traditionally regarded as the wisest of bodhisattvas, in Tibetan tradition he is known as {rgyal ba'i yab gcig}, the “sole father of buddhas,” as he inspires them in their realization of the profound. He is represented as bearing the sword of wisdom in his right hand and a volume of the Prajñā pāramitā sūtra in his left. He is always youthful in appearance, like a boy of sixteen.

An epithet of Mañjuśrī.
Attendant of the buddha Mahātejas.
An alternative name for Mañjuśrī, meaning, “gentle or beautiful voice.”
The 583rd buddha in the first list, 582nd in the second list, and 575th in the third list.
“One with a sweet voice,” an epithet of the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī. The name is also written as “Mañjusvara.”
Attendant of the buddha Candrārka.
One of the peaceful forms of Mañjuśrī.

Birthplace of the buddha Apagatakleśa.
Attendant of the buddha Dharma pradīpākṣa.
Name of a bodhisattva.
Gandharva king present at the teaching of the sūtra.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the goddesses invited to partake in the oblation offering.
One of the four guardian goddesses who can be indicated to a fellow practitioner by her pledge sign.
One of the grahas.

The five great fears are “the fear concerning livelihood, fear of disapproval, fear of death, fear of bad transmigrations, and fear that is timidity when addressing assemblies.” (Powers 1995, p. 316, n. 19).
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Suśītala.
The destruction of a world system at the end of an age.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Pūritāṅga.

According to various purāṇas and the Atharvaveda, our world system is divided into fourteen worlds: the seven (higher) worlds consist of the earth and the heavenly realms above, and the seven netherworlds are subterranean realms.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Jayanandin.

Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Lokajyeṣṭha (699 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.

Gain (Tib. {rnyed pa}; Skt. lābha) and loss (Tib. {ma rnyed pa}; Skt. alābha), fame (Tib. {snyan pa}; Skt. yaśas) and lack of fame (Tib. {ma snyan pa}; Skt. ayaśas), praise (Tib. {bstod pa}; Skt. praśaṃsā) and blame (Tib. {smad pa}; Skt. nindā), pleasure (Tib. {bde ba}; Skt. sukha), and sorrow (Tib. {sdug bsngal}; Skt. duḥkha).

Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Praśāntagati.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Puṇya pradīpa rāja (837 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
The 710th buddha in the first list, 709th in the second list, and 699th in the third list.
Birthplace of the buddha Asaṅgamati.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Mañjughoṣa.
The 182nd buddha in the first list, 181st in the second list, and 181st in the third list.

An unidentified mantra deity. The Sanskrit could be corrupt.
A buddha.
