A collective name for desire, hatred, and delusion.
The three main affective behavior patterns, or “afflictions,” namely ignorance, desire, and anger.
One of the great piśācīs.
Holarrhena pubescens.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
This word can mean “poison,” and it can also refer to a class of spirits associated with poisons.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Raśmi.
Buddhas discipline in ways that are unequivocally gentle, unequivocally harsh, and both gentle and harsh.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Damajyeṣṭha (834 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Apagatakleśa.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Mañjughoṣa.
Son of the buddha Sudatta.
Attendant of the buddha Hutārci.

In the list of buddhas from whom Śākyamuni received the Samādhirāja this name appears twice, perhaps in error. Translated the first time in Tibetan as {shin tu dul ba'i sems}, and the second time as {dul bar sems}.
A brahmin devotee of Buddhism.
Father of the buddha Aśokarāṣṭra.
Attendant of the buddha Sthāmaprāpta.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Son of the buddha Praśāntagātra.
Mother of the buddha Ratnaprabha.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Rāhu.
The 942nd buddha in the first list, 941st in the second list, and 932nd in the third list.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Samadhyāyin.
One of the pratyeka buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.

In the list of buddhas from whom Śākyamuni received the Samādhirāja, this name appears twice, perhaps in error. Translated the first time in Tibetan as {dul rab}, and the second time as {shin tu dul}.
A certain gandharva king, father of Princess Suprabhā.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the seven types of ḍākinīs.
A Hindu goddess.
A Buddhist goddess.
Another name for the channel carrying semen.
A Buddhist goddess.
A rākṣasī in the Mahā māyūrī vidyārājñī (Toh 559). https://read.84000.co/translation/toh559.html
“The great conch shell.” One of the four great treasures and the being who presides over it.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
A pond on Equal Peaks.
An ocean between Kuru and Godānīya.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
(1) A king in the future. (2) A ṛṣi.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
“The conch shell.” One of the four great treasures and the being who presides over it.

Seventy-first of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata. This design of the conch is represented separately from the Dharma conch found at the apex of the hierarchy of merit described in The Question of Mañjuśrī.
‟Lord of the Cremation Ground,” one of the eight bhūta kings.
A piece of cloth that covers corpses being carried to a cremation ground and that remains draped over them on the funeral pyre.
One of the grahas.
A cremation ground, or place for discarded corpses.
A type of power place where yogins and yoginīs congregate.
Son of the buddha Śuddhaprabha.
A king of the swans.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Four ages of human life in Jambudvīpa including the age of perfection, age of threefold endowment, age of twofold endowment, and age of strife.
A nāga king who became a pupil of the Buddha. Gandhara scultpures represent his conversion.

Sanskrit dictionaries also define the word as “gum benzoin” (not to be confused with the unrelated chemical, benzoin) and the Shisham or Indian Rosewood tree (Dalbergia sissoo). However, in this sūtra this is evidently referring to a kind of sandalwood (Santalum album). The name, which means “following time,” refers to the long-lasting scent of the wood. In other texts kālānusāri candana is translated as {dus kyi rjes su 'brang ba}.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
(1) A brahmin living in the country of King Piṇḍavaṃśa. (2) A brahmin who is the Buddha in a past life.
A buddha in the distant past. BHS: Triyadhva prabha ghoṣa.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
“The Lamp of the Lightning of the Wisdom of the Three Times.” The name of a ray of light.
Mother of the buddha Smṛtiprabha.
Mahāvyutpatti 360.
A group of world realms in the eastern direction.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The eightieth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS: Triyadhva pratibhāsa prabha.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A bodhisattva.
The past, present, and future.
A town in Videha.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the grahas.
The seventh of the nine forms of Durgā, also worshiped in tantric Buddhism.
Also called gum benzoin and gum benjamin. Not to be confused with the unrelated chemical called benzoin. It is the resin of styrax trees.
The least auspicious in the cycle of four eons.
A forest in Dwelling on Forest Riverbanks.
A world system.

This term literally means an “untimely death.” In both Buddhist and non-Buddhist South Asian literature, human beings are said to be allotted a certain lifespan, and that lifespan is a function of the age in which they live. In the current age, the full human lifespan is said to be one hundred years. Thus any death that occurs before one has lived out an entire one hundred years is technically considered an “untimely death.” The list of various “untimely deaths” in Buddhist literature generally includes tragic and unnatural ways of dying such as drowning, contracting a sudden illness, being burned to death, etc.
Father of the buddha Kusuma.
A lotus pool in Lateral.
The 871st buddha in the first list, 870th in the second list, and 860th in the third list.
The 125th buddha in the first list, 125th in the second list, and 126th in the third list.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Anupamavādin (675 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
The 208th buddha in the first list, 207th in the second list, and 207th in the third list.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A mountain in Kuru.
A term in the Suśrutasaṃhitā that denotes a dangerous illness that results when all three humors are out of balance.
Son of the buddha Dṛḍhasaṃdhi.
Son of the buddha Pradyota.
A mountain in Moving in the Wink of an Eye.
A river on Saṅkāśa.

One of “the four medicines.” “Food fit for a time” is food eaten between dawn and noon, the appropriate time according to the monastic code. It refers mainly to maṇḍa (scum of boiled rice), odana (boiled rice gruel), kulmāsa (sour gruel), and māṃsapūpā (meat cake). It is medicinal in that it is primarily aimed at combating the “illness” of hunger. An acceptable form of medicine for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
A bodhisattva.
The six seasons are early winter, late winter, spring, summer, monsoon, and fall.
A forest upon Mount Playful in Sudharma.
One of the pratyeka buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the śrāvakas; a vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the four pīṭhas.
Modern-day Jalandhar of the Punjab region.
An Indian master, whose precise dates are unknown, and who wrote a commentary on the Entry into Laṅka Sūtra.
Jasminum grandiflorum according to the Pandanus Database of Plants.
“Flaming Mouth.” One of the eight nāga queens.
Jasminum grandiflorum.

Jasminum grandiflorum. Also known as Spanish or Catalonian jasmine, even though it originates in South India. Particularly used as offerings in both Buddhist and Hindu temples. In other sūtras, jāti is translated as {sna ma}.
Sesbania sesban.
One of the “four sisters” invoked in a mantra.
This seems to be another name of Jambhala.
God of wealth.
One of the gods of wealth.
Legendary river carrying the remains of the golden fruit of a legendary jambu (rose apple) tree.
The continent to the south of Mount Sumeru, according to Abhidharma cosmology, which is the continent (dvīpa) on which we live.

The name of the southern continent in Buddhist cosmology, signifying either the known human world, or sometimes more specifically the Indian subcontinent. The name comes from the jambu (“rose apple” or “black plum”) tree said to grow near Lake Anavatapta in the continent’s northern mountains, considered to be the source of the four great rivers of India.
The southernmost continent of the four continents, the “Rose Apple Continent” inhabited by human beings. Our current world system.

An alternative name for Jetavana Park in Śrāvastī, the capital of Kosala, which had been owned by Prince Jeta. Anāthapiṇḍada bought it from him at a high price in order to offer it to the Buddha as a place to house the monks during the monsoon period, thus creating the first Buddhist monastery.

A grove owned by Prince Jeta in Śrāvastī, the capital of the kingdom of Kośala (presently an area within Uttar Pradesh). It was bought by Anāthapiṇḍada and became the monastery that the Buddha spent most rainy seasons in, and is therefore the setting for many sūtras.

A park in Śrāvastī, the capital of Kosala, which had been owned by Prince Jeta. Anāthapiṇḍada bought it from him at a high price in order to offer it to the Buddha as a place to house the monks during the monsoon period, thus creating the first Buddhist monastery. Also known as Jetadhvaja. Other sūtras translate as {rgyal bu rgyal byed kyi tshal}.

A short form of Jetavana, a park in Śrāvastī, the capital of Kosala, which had been owned by Prince Jeta. Anāthapiṇḍada bought it from him at a high price in order to offer it to the Buddha as a place to house the monks during the monsoon period, thus creating the first Buddhist monastery.
Syzygium cumini.
An Indian paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries and named as one of the translators of this sūtra.
A Kashmiri scholar-monk who worked on many translations at Samyé, Tibet, upon the invitation of the Tibetan king Tri Ralpachen (ca. 806–38).
An Indian preceptor from Kashmir who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries. He was a frequent collaborator of Yeshé Dé.

A Kashmiri preceptor who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries. He worked with several Tibetan translators on the translation of various sūtras. He is also the author of the https://read.84000.co/translation/toh4233.html , which is contained in the Tengyur ({bstan 'gyur}) collection.

Jinamitra was invited to Tibet during the reign of King Trisong Detsen ({khri srong lde btsan}, r. 742–98 ce) and was involved with the translation of nearly two hundred texts, continuing into the reign of King Ralpachen ({ral pa can}, r. 815–38 ce). He was one of the small group of paṇḍitas responsible for the Mahāvyutpatti Sanskrit–Tibetan dictionary.

An Indian Kashmiri paṇḍita who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries. He worked with several Tibetan translators on the translation of several sūtras. He is also the author of the Nyāya bindu piṇḍārtha (Toh 4233)https://read.84000.co/translation/toh4233.html, which is contained in the Tibetan Tengyur ({bstan 'gyur}) collection.
One of the great piśācīs.
One of the nāga kings.

A nāga king who in the lifetime of the previous buddha had cut down a tree and had therefore been reborn as a nāga. Residing in Taxila, he is said to have miraculously extended himself to where the Buddha was present. This tale is found represented in ancient sculpture.
A nāga king.
A nāga king. The Tibetan {e la'i gdong} seems to reflect elamukha rather than the attested elavarṇa.
A nāga king.
Antilope cervicapra, also known as the Indian antelope. The male is called eṇa and the female eṇī. Aiṇeya therefore means “an attribute of the female black antelope.”
Name of a nāga lady from a previous eon.
Unidentified.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the eight great śrāvakas.
Cinnamomum camphora.
A merchant who met the Buddha.
Dalbergia lanceolaria.
A city near Sarnath, where the Buddha gave his first sermon; this name can be applied also to the surrounding country or district. The name is rendered elsewhere in this translation as “Kāśī.”
A disciple of the Buddha.
A monk (bhikṣu) and disciple of the Buddha.

The brother of Nadīkāśyapa and Uru vilvā kāśyapa. A practitioner of fire offering at Uruvilvā (Bodhgaya), he and his two hundred pupils were converted to becoming bhikṣus of the Buddha. He and his brothers and their pupils were the third group to become followers of the Buddha after his enlightenment.
A mountain near the city of Gayā.

A sacred hill immediately to the south of the city of Gayā. Its name means “Gayā head,” and may derive from pre-Buddhist legends of a buried, reclining giant—in one version, a demon king called Gayāsura who was immoblised by Viṣṇu, and in another a saintly prince called Gaya; this hill marks the position of his head, with other features of the landscape in the region associated with other parts of his body.
A mountain.

Site of a stūpa where the Buddha instructed the thousand monks from Uruvilvā by displaying three miracles, thereby freeing them from the wilds of saṃsāra and establishing them in the utterly final state of perfection and the unsurpassably blissful state of nirvāṇa.

A sacred hill immediately to the south of the city of Gayā. Its name means “Gayā Head,” and may derive from pre-Buddhist legends of a buried, reclining giant—in one version, a demon king called Gayāsura who was immobilized by Viṣṇu, and in another a saintly prince called Gaya; this hill marks the position of his head, with other features of the landscape in the region associated with other parts of his body.
The name of the town that lies close to the site of the Buddha’s enlightenment.

Alternate name of Gayākāśyapa, the brother of Nadīkāśyapa and Uruvilvākāśyapa. A practitioner of fire offering at Uruvilvā (Bodhgaya), he and his two hundred pupils were converted to becoming bhikṣus (monks) under the Buddha. He and his brothers and their pupils were the third group to become followers of the Buddha Śākyamuni after his awakening.
Close Śravaka disciple of the Buddha.

The brother of Nadīkāśyapa and Uruvilvākāśyapa. A practitioner of fire offering at Uruvilvā (Bodhgaya), he and his two hundred pupils were converted to the Dharma, becoming bhikṣus (monks) under the Buddha. He and his brothers and their pupils were the third group to become followers of the Buddha Śākyamuni after his awakening. Also known as Mahāgayākāśyapa.

Indian (possibly Bengali) paṇḍita (994–1043) who visited Tibet three times; teacher of Drokmi Śākya Yeshé; a complex personality and a key figure in the transmission to Tibet of the Hevajra materials later incorporated in the Lamdré (Tib. {lam 'bras}) tradition.
An ancient city in North India, located in the modern state of Bihar.
City in Magadha, now in the Indian state of Bihar, on the left bank of the River Nairañjanā (parts of which are now called the Lilaja and Phalgu), a tributary of the Ganges.

One of the sacred towns of ancient India, south of the Ganges in present-day Bihar. In the Buddha’s lifetime, this was in the kingdom of Magadha. Uruvilvā, the area including Bodhgaya where the Buddha attained enlightenment, is nearby to the south, upriver from Gayā.
A wooden gong used to summon monks.
An elongated, shoulder-held wooden bar (or beam) struck with a wooden stick to call the monastic community to assembly.
A lake in Godānīya.
Name of a region in present-day eastern Afghanistan and northwestern Pakistan.
The river Ganges in India.
A yakṣa.
God of wealth.
One of the yakṣa kings.
Name of a yakṣa general.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the yakṣa kings.
A brahmin devotee of Buddhism.
One of the yakṣa kings.
Hearer present in the circle around Śākyamuni.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the distinguished brahmins of Mathurā.
(1) A disciple of the Buddha from Sūrpāraka ({gang po}). (2) A disciple of the Buddha from Kuṇḍopadhāna ({gang po}). (3) A haṃsa ({gang ba}). (4) A buddha in the past ({rdzogs ldan}).
One of the eight principal nāga kings. More commonly translated in other sūtras as {rgya mtsho}.
A rich man who was Upālin in a former life.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The Ganges River in India.
The sacred river of North India.
The major river in North India and, according to Buddhist cosmology, one of the four sacred rivers that flow through the southernmost continent of Jambudvīpa.

The name of a nun who commits to the practice of the six perfections and worships the Buddha with golden-colored flowers. The Buddha predicts her future awakening as the buddha Suvarṇapuṣpa, during the eon called Tārakopama.
Mother of the buddha Vairocana.
A forest in Dwelling on Summits.
The river Ganges in India.
The river Gaṅgā (personified).
The sacred river of North India.
Generally considered the most sacred river in India.
One of the three branches of the river Gaṅgā in its early course.
The most important holy river in India, more commonly known in English as the Ganges.

The Gaggarā lotus pond was excavated by Queen Gaggarā of Campā, the capital of Aṅga, and the groves of flowering trees along its banks became a popular location for wandering teachers and ascetics to take up residence. The Pāli dictionary of proper names notes that the Buddha took up residence on the banks of the Gaggarā pond several times, and a number of discourses in the Pāli nikāya tradition were taught in this location. Pāli: gaggarāpokkharanī; Chinese: 伽伽靈池.
The river Ganges.
The sacred river of North India.
A city in Godānīya.
Name of a yakṣa general; brother of Maṇibhadra in the Mahā māyūrī vidyārājñī (Toh 559).https://read.84000.co/translation/toh559.html
Hearer present in the circle around Śākyamuni.
A buddha in the past.
A wealthy householder in Rājagṛha whom the Buddha prophesied would become the future Buddha Pūrṇa.
One of the first to join the Buddha’s renunciate order. He followed his friend Yaśas into the Buddhist order.
(1) A disciple of the Buddha from Sūrpāraka ({gang po}). (2) A disciple of the Buddha from Kuṇḍopadhāna ({gang po}). (3) A haṃsa ({gang ba}). (4) A buddha in the past ({rdzogs ldan}).

Śrāvaka disciple of the Buddha noted for his ability as a preacher of the Hinayāna teaching, especially skillful in the conversion and training of young monks; also known as Pūrṇa maitrāyaṇī putra. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-060-005.html#UT22084-060-005-934 .

At least five different disciples of the Buddha in the canonical texts have this name, but the Pūrṇa in this text is likely to be the eminent disciple of the Buddha from Kapilavastu, nephew of Ājñātakauṇḍinya who ordained him, and described as the foremost disciple in explaining the doctrine.

A monk and disciple of the Buddha. At least six different disciples in the canonical texts have this name (see https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-047-001.html#UT22084-047-001-2361 ), but the Pūrṇa in this text is likely to be the same Pūrṇa as in The Deeds of Pūrṇa (see https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-047-001.html#UT22084-047-001-2356 ).

A person who is eight steps away in the arc of their development from becoming an arhat (Tib. {dgra bcom pa}). Specifically, this term refers to one who is on the cusp of becoming a stream-enterer (Skt. srotāpanna; Tib. {rgyun du zhugs pa}) and is the first and lowest stage in a list of eight stages or classes of a noble person (Skt. āryapudgala). The person at this lowest stage in the sequence is still on the path of seeing (Skt. darśanamārga; Tib. {mthong lam}), and then enters the path of cultivation (Skt. bhāvanāmārga; Tib. {sgoms lam}) upon attaining the next stage, that of a stream-enterer (stage seven). From there they progress through the remaining stages of the śrāvaka path, becoming in turn a once-returner (stages six and five), a non-returner (stages four and three), and an arhat (stages two and one). This same “eighth stage” also appears in set of ten stages (Skt. daśabhūmi; Tib. {sa bcu}) found in Mahāyāna sources, where it is the third step out of the ten. Not to be confused with the ten stages of the bodhisattva’s path, these ten stages mark the progress of one who sequentially follows the paths of a śrāvaka, pratyekabuddha, and then bodhisattva on their way to complete buddhahood. In this set of ten stages, a person “on the eighth stage” is similarly one who is on the cusp of becoming a stream-enterer.

Selflessness in this context‌ implies the lack of inherent existence in personal identity and also in physical and mental phenomena. Śrāvakas are said to expound the doctrine of selflessness only in terms of the absence of personal identity, while pratyekabuddhas additionally realize the emptiness of external phenomena, composed of atomic particles. However, unlike bodhisattvas they do not realize that the internal phenomena of consciousness too are without inherent existence.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Surabhigandha.

The fourfold division of “noble” (i.e., realized) beings: stream enterer (srotaāpanna), once-returner (sakṛdāgāmin), non-returner (anāgāmin), and worthy one (arhat). They are “pairs” because in each of the four categories one first enters the path of that stage, and subsequently attains its fruit.
Also translated as “individual” or “personal identity.”
The Himalayan mountain range.
Mountains in the north of Jambudvīpa.
Monarch of the city of Campā before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
The Himalayas.
Synonymous with Himagiri. This “mountain” is actually the entire Himalayan range.
Name of a yakṣa general in the Mahā māyūrī vidyārājñī (Toh 559). https://read.84000.co/translation/toh559.html
A nāga king.
A mountain.
The Himalaya mountain range.
“Snowy mountain,” the name of a mountain range and the god who personifies it.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
An alternative name for the Himalayas.
A yakṣiṇī invoked in magical rites.
One of the eight great bhūtinīs; also one of the eight great yakṣiṇīs.
One of the grahas.
A deity representing the element of wind.
A deity personifying the true nature of the element of wind.
A famous Puranic rishi of India, who features particularly in the Vaishnavite literature.
An alternate spelling of Bharga, a country during the time of Buddha Śākyamuni that had its capital at Mount Śiśumāri.
One of the ancient sages.

The nine dramatic moods, contained in the sixty-four crafts, comprise those of (1) grace (śṛṅgāra, {sgeg pa}); (2) heroism (vīra, {dpa' ba}); (3) ugliness (bībhatsa, {mi sdug pa}); (4) ferocity (raudra, {drag shul}); (5) joviality (hāsya, {bzhad gad}); (6) fearsomeness (bhayānaka, {'jigs rung}); (7) compassion (karuṇā, {snying rje}); (8) awesomeness (adbhūta, {rngam pa}); and (9) peace (śānta, {zhi ba}).\nOn all these and related matters, see Jamgon Kongtrul TOK Book 6, Pt.1: 311–315.
‟Lord of Dance,” most often the dancing form of Avalokiteśvara; in the Bhūta ḍāmara Tantra, he is a dancing form of Śiva.
A monastery in Mathurā predicted by the Buddha to be built a hundred years after his nirvāṇa.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the sons of Kubera.
A certain nāga king and the hermitage that bears his name.
One of the two brothers in Mathurā who were predicted by the Buddha to build a monastery in the future.
The wild dance of wrathful male deities associated with the charnel ground.
A part of Bengal bordering Orissa, also the name of the dynasty that ruled there.
A type of vīṇā.
One of the sages (ṛṣi).
“Gautama” refers to Siddhārtha Gautama, the name of the historical Buddha. “A child of Gautama” denotes one of his followers.
Refers to Siddhārtha Gautama, the name of the historical Buddha.
A past life of the buddha Candrārka (252 according to the third enumeration).
One of the names of the Buddha, especially during his earlier life as an ascetic.
The family name of the Buddha Śākyamuni, it is often used by those who are not his followers.
Siddhārtha Gautama is the most common given name used for Buddha Śākyamuni prior to his enlightnement.

One of the seven great rishis of ancient India. Author of some of the vedas. His Dharmasūtra specified renunciation as yellow robes, shaved head, and being called a bhikṣu. Buddha Śākyamuni was his descendant.
The 850th buddha in the first list, 849th in the second list, and 839th in the third list.
A nāga king.
The name of the clan of the buddha Pradīpa (963 according to the third enumeration).
Lit. “impossible to be cut.”
Demon causing disease; disease personified.
One of the six outsider teachers.

The son of a poor brahmin farmer who lived outside of Rājagṛha, he mistook Nirgrantha Jñātiputra for Buddha Śākyamuni and became Nirgrantha Jñātiputra’s student. He then took refuge in the Buddha, Dharma, and Saṅgha shortly before his death. Also called “Nirgrantha Kāśyapa,” or simply “Kāśyapa,” his given name.
One of the six teachers at the time of the Buddha.
One of the six philosophical extremists who lived during the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
A group of ascetics common in the Buddha’s time, widely believed to refer to the early Jain community.
Also known as the Mahāvīra, the founder of the Jaina sect.
In Buddhist usage, a non-Buddhist religious mendicant, usually referring to Jains, who eschews clothing and possessions.
A type of non-Buddhist religious mendicant who eschews clothing and possessions. Often considered another name for the early Jain tradition.
In Buddhist literature this term often refers to followers of the Jain religion, but it can also refer to members of any other “naked ascetic” order.

The Tibetan means “naked one,” and the Sanskrit “without possessions” or “without ties.” In Buddhist usage, a non-Buddhist religious mendicant who eschews clothing and possessions, often referring to Jains.

The Sanskrit term means “without possessions” or “without ties” and the Tibetan means “naked one(s).” In Buddhist usage, it refers to non-Buddhist religious mendicants, especially Jains, who eschew clothing and possessions.

In Buddhist texts, a term often used to refer to the community around the Jain teacher Jñātiputra, but can refer to the Jain tradition generally. Their practices, as presented in Buddhist literature, focused on intense asceticism as a means to mitigate the consequences of past actions and on nonaction as a means to prevent future ramifications.
This seems to be the name of an island, but is rather dubious.
In Buddhist usage, a non-Buddhist religious mendicant, usually referring to Jains, who eschews clothing and possessions.
A goldsmith, the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 49.
A buddha realm.
A mountain in Jambudvīpa.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A buddha realm.
One of the twenty-seven realms of the Heaven Free from Strife.
Mahāvyutpatti 7587.
A bodhisattva.
Birthplace of the buddha Madhuvaktra.
The 538th buddha in the first list, 538th in the second list, and 531st in the third list.
A householder in Kauśāmbī who provided a garden for the Buddha and his monks to reside.

A garden in Kauśāmbī that the householder Ghoṣila donated to the Buddhist saṅgha. This Tibetan rendering of Ghoṣilārāma only appears in The Hundred Deeds, and the precise correlation between the Tib. {las rig} and the standard Sanskrit for this location remains unclear.
A householder in Kauśāmbī who provided a garden for the Buddha and his monks to reside.
Mother of the buddha Viśiṣṭa svarāṅga.
Attendant of the buddha Adīnaghoṣa.
Mother of the buddha Somacchattra.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Āśādatta.
Mother of the buddha Ghoṣadatta.
Mother of the buddha Dundubhi megha svara.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Amitasvara.
The 752nd buddha in the first list, 751st in the second list, and 741st in the third list.
Attendant of the buddha Aridama.
Mother of the buddha Mañjughoṣa.
A leading nāga.
The capital city of one of the subterranean paradises inhabited by nāgas.

An outcaste woman; one of the female deities in the retinue of Hevajra; the mystic heat below the navel, personified as a goddess; one of the five ḍākinīs visualized on the prongs of the vajra scepter.
The lowest of the untouchables in the Indian caste system.
A member of the lowest social classes in ancient Indian caste society.
The name of a past sage who was one of the Buddha’s previous incarnations.
Also rendered here as “outcast.”
The lowest of the untouchables in the social system of ancient India.
An outcaste or a member of the lowest (and despised) castes in Indian society.
One of the lower social classes that are outside, and beneath, the four castes.
The lowest and most disparaged class of people within the caste system of ancient India, they fall outside of the caste system altogether due to their low rank in society.

The translation of this term remains tentative but is read here as a potential translation of the Sanskrit compound *grahaprācurya in which the Tibetan has employed an incorrect grammatical particle. An alternate translation that favors the meaning that the term {'jebs pa} bears in Tibetan and the Tibetan reading of the compound indicates that this could be either a collective noun or a proper name that translates as “Pleasing to the Grahas.”
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Amitayaśas.
A son of King Sarvārthasiddha.
A thus-gone one of the past.
‟One with the Terrible Face,” one of the eight demonesses who inhabit the eight great charnel grounds.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
A type of worm ({srin bu}) that lives in and feeds on the body.
A class of demonic, possessing beings.
An evil spirit that causes seizures and insanity.
A planet (personified); a class of spirits responsible for epilepsy and seizures.
A type of evil spirit known to exert a harmful influence on the human body and mind. Grahas are closely associated with the planets and other astronomical bodies.

A class of nonhuman beings able to enter and possess the human body; a class of beings, such as Rāhu, that cause solar and lunar eclipses; a planet (this category includes the sun and the moon but excludes the earth); a planet or planetary influence personified.

A class of nonhuman beings able to enter and possess the human body. They have a harmful effect on physical and mental health, and are specifically said to cause seizures and insanity. Often this term is used to broadly refer to multiple classes of beings who can affect a person’s physical and mental health.
A village or town. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2037 .
Seventy-third of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
The first wife of a certain householder of great means who lived before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
One of the goddesses invited to partake in the oblation offering.
A buddha of the northwest.
A buddha realm.
Another name of the river Ganges.
A buddha realm.
A great bodhisattva.
Lit. “With a Single Umbrella.” A buddha in a world system called Vaśībhūtā, in the intermediate northwest direction.
{gdugs gcig} is an archaic word for “day.”
A buddha realm.
A mango grove.
The 158th buddha in the first list, 157th in the second list, and 157th in the third list.
A buddha.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Abhyudgataśrī (159 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.

First of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata. In general Indian iconography it is a symbol of protection and royalty. In Buddhism it symbolizes protection from blazing heat of afflictions, desire, illness, and harmful forces, just as a physical parasol protects one from the blazing sun or the elements. It is also included in the eight auspicious emblems.
Birthplace of the buddha Atibala.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Nārāyaṇa (99 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
One of the great piśācīs.
Father of the buddha Asaṅgamati.
Birthplace of the buddha Anihata.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Highly Renowned.
The 38th buddha in the first list, 38th in the second list, and 39th in the third list.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ratnaprabha.
One of the kings of the piśācas.

Literally meaning “five heats” or “fivefold ascetic practice,” within Brahamanical sources this term refers to the ascetic practice of sitting at the center of four fires during the hot season in India, with the sun above equaling five.
The sixth of the hot hells. In later Tibetan translations it is “hot” ({tsha ba}).
A river.

Child of householders in Śrāvasti, he was born “corpulent, full-fledged in skin, flesh, and blood.” He leapt from a boulder at the sight of the Buddha but was unharmed due to the Buddha’s blessing. Having then heard the Dharma from the Buddha, he went forth and manifested arhatship.
Hyperanthera moringa.
Luffa aegyptiaca.
Attendant of the buddha Deśāmūḍha.
A dye or paint prepared from the gall stones of cattle.
One of the grahas.
Cyperus rotundus.
(in the expressions ava tāra na labhate, {glags mi rnyed}, “no opportunity for … to impinge upon …”).
Father of the buddha Siṃhadaṃṣṭra.
Scindapsis officinalis.
The 359th buddha in the first list, 358th in the second list, and 353rd in the third list.
In Rājagṛha, a certain elephant trainer for King Bimbisāra. His son was Citra Mounted on an Elephant.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
A bodhisattva.
A yakṣa. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2415 .
One of the great piśācīs.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Vigatamala.
Forty-third of the eighty minor marks.
A great bodhisattva.
A city.
A monk. Interlocutor of the Buddha in the Questions of Pūrṇa sūtra.
Attendant of the buddha Campaka.
A son of King Ikṣuvāku.
One of the rāśis.
Ninth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
Birthplace of the buddha Puṇyahastin.

One of the seven treasures of the cakravartin king. The precious elephant is described as having magical abilities and sometimes as having six tusks. A passage about the precious elephant is found in Toh 95, The Play in Full, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh95.html#UT22084-046-001-98. See also Toh 4087, the Kāraṇa prajñapti, folio 119.b.https://read.84000.co/translation/toh4087.html
A teacher.
A nāga king.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Amitalocana.
The 290th buddha in the first list, 289th in the second list, and 289th in the third list.
Father of the buddha Kṣemottamarāja.
A virtuous nāga king.
A city.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Gandhahastin.
Father of the buddha Praśāntagātra.
A class of vidyādharas.
One of the celestial bodhisattvas.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Vratanidhi.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Sthitārtha buddhi (639 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Vaidya.
Birthplace of the buddha Nāgaprabhāsa.
Son of the buddha Jyotiṣka.
Ninth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Saṃpannakīrti.
Identified as Goparāja, early sixth century, of the imperial Gupta dynasty.
One of the eight yakṣa generals.
Taurus (zodiac sign and constellation).
Monks’ robes are to be sewn into large sections from small patches of cloth rather than bolts of cloth.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Asaṅgamati.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Suraśmi.
One of the “twelve branches of excellent speech.”
One among the twelve sections of scripture.
One of the twelve branches of Buddhist scriptures.
Literally, “foundation of the narrative.” One of the twelve aspects of the wheel of Dharma.
Introductory part of a sūtra .
Literally, “foundation of the narrative.” One of the twelve aspects of the wheel of Dharma.
The introductory section of a sūtra or other Buddhist scripture that establishes the time and setting of the discourse.
As one of the twelve aspects of the Dharma, it means the introductions to teachings.\nSee also “twelve wheels of the Dharma.”
The introductory sections of a sūtra. Literally it can mean “cause.” One of the nine aspects of the Dharma according to this sūtra. More commonly there are said to be twelve that include these nine.
Attendant of the buddha Nāganandin.
An island in or near the kingdom of Kaliṅga. “Begburchepa” is a phonetic rendering of the Tibetan, which has no known Skt. equivalent and is unclear in meaning.
One of the goddesses in the maṇḍala of Vajrasattva.

A world system formed by four great island continents. In this world system, a central mountain, Sumeru, is surrounded in the four cardinal directions by Jambudvīpa (our world) in the south, Godānīya in the west, Uttarakuru in the north, and Pūrvavideha in the east.
The four continents surrounding Mount Meru that make up a world system.
Refers to any world or group of worlds illumined by one sun and moon, its own Mount Meru, continents, desire, form, and formless realms, etc. Also rendered here as world realm.
The four continents surrounding Mount Meru that make up a world system.

According to traditional Indian cosmology, our own Sahā world system is said to comprise four continents, namely, Pūrvavideha in the east, Jambudvīpa in the south, Aparagodānīya in the west, and Uttarakuru in the north.

According to traditional Indian cosmology, our human world of “patient endurance” (sahālokadhātu, {mi mjed 'jig rten gyi khams}) is said to comprise four continents, namely, Pūrva videha in the east, Jambu dvīpa in the south, Apara godānīya in the west, and Uttarakuru in the north. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1116 .

According to Abhidharma cosmology, each world system has four continents surrounding a central Mount Meru: to the east, Videha ({lus 'phags po}, “superior body”); to the south, our continent of Jambudvīpa ({'dzam bu gling}, “Rose Apple Continent”); to the west, Apara godānīya ({ba glang spyod} “Rich in Cattle”); and to the north, Uttarakuru ({sgra mi snyan}, “Unpleasant Sound”).
Birthplace of the buddha Pradyota.
Also rendered in this translation as “externally added.”
The 341st buddha in the first list, 340th in the second list, and 335th in the third list.
Attendant of the buddha Siṃhadatta.
A class of vidyādharas.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Jyotiṣprabha.
Mother of the buddha Sañjayin.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Flash of Lightning. Likely an alternate name for the thus-gone one King of the Tip of the Lamp of Lightning.
Son of the buddha Sujāta.
Father of the buddha Rāhu.
Birthplace of the buddha Candrodgata.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Amitābha.
Mother of the buddha Oṣadhi.
The name of a bodhisattva in the Buddha’s audience.
Attendant of the buddha Pratibhānakūṭa.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Prabhāsthita kalpa (415 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A buddha from the past.
Son of the buddha Tiṣya.
Lit. “lightning flash.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one King of the Tip of the Lamp of Lightning.
The 128th buddha in the first list, 128th in the second list, and 129th in the third list.

“Light of Lightning.” Name of the universe where, according to the Buddha Śākyamuni’s prophecy, the girl Vimalaśraddhā will finally reach full enlightenment under the name of the Thus-Gone One Raśmivyūha.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha.
A king in a kalpa in the distant past.
A bodhisatva great being.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Howling Hell.
A sea to the north of Jambudvīpa.
A nāga who visits Saṅkāśa Mountain.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Flash of Lightning.
Name of the fortieth meditative stability.
Lit. “lamp of lightning.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
The 254th buddha in the first list, 253rd in the second list, and 253rd in the third list.
Father of the buddha Dyutimat.
Son of the buddha Arthavādin.
Name of a meditative stabilization.
‟One with Flashing Fangs,” one of the eight demonesses who inhabit the eight great charnel grounds.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
Mother of the buddha Vidyutketu.
Father of the buddha Meghasvara.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Kusumaparvata.
Symptom that may be evidence of an illness considered an impediment to ordination.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1011 .
Mother of the buddha Muktiskandha
Son of the buddha Prabhākara.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Brahmaghoṣa.
Birthplace of the buddha Vaiḍūryagarbha.
A thus-gone one who taught the King of the Array of all Dharma Qualities to Vajrapāṇi.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one King of the Tip of the Lamp of Lightning.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva.
The wife of the son of the brahmin Agnidatta.

The seven harmonious tones of the musical scale, contained in the sixty-four crafts, are (1) the [peacock-like] sixth tone (ṣaḍja, {drug ldan}); (2) the [ox-like] sage tone (ṛṣabha, {drang srong}); (3) the [goat-like] third tone (gandhāra, {sa 'dzin}); (4) the [crane-like] middle tone (madhyama, {bar ma}); (5) the [cuckoo-like] fifth tone (pancama, {lnga pa}); (6) the [horse-like] clear tone (dhaivata, {blo gsal}); and (7) the [elephant-like] base tone (niṣāda, {'khor nyan}).\nOn all these and related matters, see Jamgon Kongtrul TOK Book 6, Pt.1: 311–315.
A grove in Garland of Splendor.
Attendant of the buddha Jñānakośa.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Guṇottama.
The 959th buddha in the first list, 958th in the second list, and 949th in the third list.
A palace in another world in the distant past.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.

The Hundred Deeds appears to list him as one of the attendants of the queen in Śrāvastī during the time of the Buddha. Elsewhere he and his associate Datta are remembered as a ministers or attendants (sthapati) to King Prasenajit.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell.
A country.
One of the six tīrthika teachers contemporaneous with Śākyamuni. Teacher and head of the Ājīvika sect.
A brahmin.
Lightning; also lightning personified.
Tibetan translator (fl. late eighth–early ninth centuries).
Mother of the buddha Śaśiketu.
Son of the buddha Maṇḍita.
A sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
A disciple of the Buddha.
One of the sages (ṛṣi).
One of the ancient sages, one of the composers of the Vedic hymns.
One of the seven great rishis of ancient India, said to have composed part of the Rigveda.
(1) A ṛṣi in the past. (2) The brother of Bharadvāja, a disciple of the Buddha Vipaśyin. (3) The family name of an old ascetic.
The word Vāsiṣṭha, lit. “the descendant of Vasiṣṭha (an ancient ṛṣi),” is used “in polite address to anyone without regard to ancestry” (BHSD q.v.).
The name of one of the great sages of ancient India; one of the composers of the Vedic hymns. In Pali sources, a figure named Vāseṭṭha (Skt. Vasiṣṭha) also appears as a young brahmin. Pali Vāseṭṭha.
Attendant of the buddha Anantavikrāmin.
A country mentioned in the story of the physician Ātreya and the story of King Māndhātṛ.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya guru vaiḍūrya prabha rāja sūtra.

This term refers here to the ten divine qualities listed in the text: (1) divine lifespan, (2) divine complexion, (3) divine power, (4) divine happiness, (5) divine lordship, (6) divine form, (7) divine sound, (8) divine smell, (9) divine taste, and (10) divine touch. They can be divided into two groups of five, the latter five being the pleasures of the five senses ({'dod yon lnga}).

A monk who has been ordained for at least ten years yet still cannot recite thePrātimokṣasūtraor its supplements and is thus not entitled to grant entry into the order, grant ordination, accept charge of novices, give refuge, or live independently.
A holy site blessed by the presence of sages.
One of the eighteen nikāya schools.
A lost verse text possibly included in the Kṣudraka piṭaka of the Mūla sarvāstivādins.
A senior student of the Buddha.
A title used when addressing the most venerable bhikṣus.
A monk of seniority within the assembly of the śrāvakas.
A monk who possesses the qualities of stability and skill.

Literally “one who is stable” and usually translated as “elder,” a senior monastic teacher in the early Buddhist communities. Also became the name of the Buddhist tradition within which the Theravāda developed.

The term is used to designate a senior monk. The sixteen great arhats, or sixteen noble elders (āryasthavira), were the successors of the Buddha’s teaching after he passed. They promised to preserve the teaching until the coming of the future Buddha Maitreya. They are on the path of seeing of the arhat path. Each arhat lived in a specific place: (1) Aṅgaja on Mt. Kailash; (2) Ajita in the Crystal Wood of Sages; (3) Vanavāsin on Mt. Saptaparṇa; (4) Mahākālika in Tāmradvīpa; (5) Vajrīputra in Siṃhaladvīpa; (6) Śrībhadra on Yamunādvīpa; (7) Kanakavatsa in Kashmir; (8) Kanakabharadvāja in the Western continent of Godānīya; (9) Bakula in the northern continent of Uttarakuru; (10) Rāhula in Priyaṅgudvīpa; (11) Cūḍapanthaka on Mt. Gṛdhrakūṭa; (12) Piṇḍolabharadvāja in the eastern continent of Pūrvavideha; (13) Mahāpanthaka in Trayatriṃśa; (14) Nāgasena on Mt. Meru; (15) Gopaka on Mt. Bhihula; (16) Abhedya in the Himālayas.
Third level of the asuras.
In getting ordained, a monk pledges to make do with a restricted set of supports that conduce to the holu life. These fall into four categories: clothing, shelter, food, and medicine.
A goddess.
One of the two principal bodhisattvas in Sukhāvatī, and prominent in Chinese Buddhism. In Tibetan Buddhism, he is identified with Vajrapāṇī, though they are separate bodhisattvas in the sūtras.
Attendant of the buddha Praśāntagātra.
The hundred-and-ninth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS in verse: Parārtha savihāra śirī.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Father of the buddha Sthitagandha.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
Birthplace of the buddha Meghasvara.
To experience the same type of conditions.
Body, speech, and mind.

The gods who live in Śuddhāvāsa heavens, the five “pure abodes” that form the highest realms that constitute the realm of subtle form (rūpadhātu) and which comprise the fourth of the meditative concentrations (dhyāna).
The five highest of the heavens that constitute the form realm.
Five realms above the four form realms into which only noble beings are born.
Realms associated the fourth concentration into which only noble beings are born.
The abodes inhabited by anāgāmins (“non-returners”) who are on the path to arhathood.
Pure abode, said of a heaven, or five heavens, in which dwell the gods so called. The pure abodes among the form realms, where only non-returners are reborn.

These realms and abodes denote the hierarchy of the gods who, in the manner of human beings and antigods, partake of the higher realms (svarga, {mtho ris}) of rebirth, but nonetheless remain trapped within cyclic existence. The gods altogether comprise (i) six god realms within the world system of desire, commencing with Catur mahā rāja kāyika and Trayas triṃśa, and concluding with Yāma, Tuṣita, Nirmāṇa rata, and Para nirmita vaśa vartin; (ii) the twelve Brahmā realms, extending from Brahmakāyika through Brahmapurohita, Mahā brahmā, Parī ttābha, A pramāṇābha, Ābhāsvara, Parītta śubha, A pramāṇa śubha, Śubha kṛtsna, An abhraka, and Puṇya prasava to Bṛhat phala, which are attained corresponding to lesser, middling, and higher degrees of the four meditative concentrations; and (iii) the five Pure Abodes at the pinnacle of the world system of form, extending from Avṛha, through Atapa, Su dṛśa, and Sudarśana to Akaniṣṭha. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1427 and https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1582 . This hierarchy is conveniently illustrated in the form of a chart. See, for example, Dudjom Rinpoche (1991): 14–15.
The “Pure Abode” heaven; a name for the five highest levels of existence within the form realm.
A form-realm paradise that is never destroyed during the cycles of the destruction and creation of the universe.
The five highest of the paradises that constitute the realm of form, which are above the paradises of the realm of desire in which our world is situated. Also translated as {gtsang ris}.
The highest division of the realm of form, comprising its five highest heavens; also used as the name of the gods living there. The name is rendered elsewhere in this translation as “Śuddhāvāsa.”

Literally "the pure abodes," this term refers to the highest series of five heavenly abodes of the form realm (rūpadhātu) and is equated with the fourth level of meditative concentration (dhyānabhūmi). A form of this term frequently appears as a member of the compound {gnas gtsang ma'i ris} or śuddhāvāsakāyika, which translates as "the gods of the Śuddhāvāsa realms."

Lit. “Those in the Pure Abodes.” The five Pure Abodes are the highest heavens of the form realm and result from mastery of the fourth meditative absorption. They comprise the heavens of Avṛha, Atapa, Sudṛśa, Sudarśana, and Akaniṣṭha. The Pure Abodes, or Śuddhāvāsa, are never destroyed during the cycles of the destruction and creation of the universe. Rebirth there is the karmic result of accomplishing the fourth concentration.

The five Pure Abodes are the highest heavens of the form realm and result from mastery of the fourth meditative absorption. They comprise the heavens of the Insentient Beings, Unlofty Heaven, Sorrowless Heaven, Heaven of Sublime Vision, Heaven of Great Vision, and Highest Heaven. The Pure Abodes are never destroyed during the cycles of the destruction and creation of the universe. Rebirth there is the karmic result of accomplishing the fourth meditative absorption.

Newly ordained monks are not allowed to live independently until they have passed ten years as a monk and possess one of twenty-one sets of five qualities described in “The Chapter on Going Forth.” Until that time, they are obliged to live as apprentices or journeymen to a refuge so that they may learn and become established in the conduct expected of a Buddhist renunciate.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1229 .
Lit. “intent on not relying on a dwelling.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Lit. “not relying on a dwelling.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Gagana.
Name of the thirty-second meditative stability.
Lit. “not relying on a dwelling.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
First of the ten powers of the tathāgatas.
A river.
A learned brahmin and author of “Māṭhara’s Treatise.” He was also the grandfather of Upatiṣya, that is Śāriputra.
Second of the ten powers of the tathāgatas.

This terms refers to all that is unreasonable and cannot be expected to occur. Among the ten powers of a Buddha, the first is knowing what is tenable and untenable (Skt. sthānāsthāna, Tib. {gnas dang gnas ma yin}), i.e., the natural laws that govern the world in which we live.
A goddess in one of the maṇḍalas of Amoghapāśa.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A bodhisattva; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Name of the sixty-seventh meditative stability.
Lit. “homeless practice.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A buddha.
“Unlocated Display.” The name of a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse Anālayaviyūha.
Son of the buddha Gagana.
An ancient city corresponding to the modern Thaneswar in Haryana, India.
A nāga king.

One of five types of disciplinary acts meted out by the saṅgha. A monk may be suspended on one of seven grounds: failing to acknowledge an offense; refusing to amend or rehabilitate one’s behavior; deviant views; being overly belligerent and quarrelsome; creating the circumstances for a quarrel; maintaining overly close relations with nuns, unruly people, and ne’er-do-wells; and refusing to let go of a Dharma matter that has been peacefully resolved.
That is to say, negativity of body, speech, and mind.
Refers to the very existence of the body, voice, or mind. As long as they are there, there are all the problems of life.

Twenty-four sites on the Indian subcontinent that are considered particularly powerful for the practices of the Yoginī Tantras. These map to twenty-four places on the human body in conjunction with the yogic practices of the perfection stage.
Text by Sahajavajra (Toh 2227).https://read.84000.co/translation/toh2227.html
A bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Vratanidhi.
Father of the buddha Padmahastin.
Father of the buddha Dṛḍhasvara.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Śrīgupta.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Priyaprasanna.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Prajñāgati.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ratnapradatta.
Father of the buddha Bhāgīratha.
Attendant of the buddha Sthāmaśrī.
Attendant of the buddha Sūryapriya.
A monk who gives you instruction for even a single day. One of five types of instructors named by the Buddha when asked to elaborate on the role of an instructor.
One of the Four Great Kings, the protector of the east.

One of the Four Mahārājas, he is the guardian deity for the east and lord of the gandharvas. Also the name of the king of the geese that was a previous life of the Buddha as described in the Jātakas. In other sūtras, more commonly translated as {yul 'khor srung}.
Name of the eighty-first meditative stability.
Lit. “without anything to rest on” (Conze: “All Stability Stopped”). Name of a meditative stabilization.
A forest in Sunrise in Kosala. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-1910
A type of power place where yogins and yoginīs congregate.

This terms refers to all that is reasonable and can be expected to occur. Among the ten powers of a Buddha, the first is knowing what is tenable and untenable (Skt. sthānāsthāna, Tib. {gnas dang gnas ma yin}), i.e., the natural laws that govern the world in which we live.

In “The Chapter on Going Forth,” Kalyāṇamitra reads this as an abbreviation of “refuge instructor” (Tib. {gnas kyi slob dpon}). A “refuge” or “refuge monk” is one who has passed ten years as a monk and possesses five qualities and is thus fit to guide new monks, grant ordination, and instruction. In “The Chapter on Going Forth,” the Buddha says a monk who has been ordained five years may be considered “independent” enough to travel independently between monsoons. Though the text does not address the issue, a monk of five years ordination would not, in ordinary circumstances, acts as a refuge instructor.
A yakṣa king associated with wealth and often identified with Kubera/Vaiśravaṇa.
An ocean mentioned here as the source of coconuts.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
A buddha realm.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Vigatabhaya.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Sthāmaśrī (743 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.

Nine points of reference that inflame one’s anger and hostility: (1) my enemy has harmed me, (2) is harming me, and (3) will harm me; (4) my enemy has harmed my friend, (5) is harming my friend, and (6) will harm my friend; (7) my enemy has assisted other enemies, (8) is assisting other enemies, and (9) my enemy will assist my other enemy.
A town in Videha.
A realm that neighbors the Hell of Intense Heat.
A class of beings said to dwell in the north, under the jurisdiction of the great king Vaiśravaṇa.

Lists of the generals of the yakṣas are frequent in Buddhist scripture. They can variously consist in five, eight, twelve, or twenty-eight yakṣas. The list of names given here appears to be unique to this sūtra. They are Siṅgala, Dharma Protector, Successful, Victorious, Bull Ear, Jewel Ear, Dharma Endowed, and Uplifted by Dharma.
An alternate title for The Detailed Account of the Previous Aspirations of the Thus-Gone Bhaiṣajya guru vaiḍūrya prabha.
Leaders of armies of yakṣas.
The palace of Indra.
This list of eight yakṣa ladies is probably unique to this sūtra. They are Aśiḍi, Many Sons, Hanging Down, Fully Hanging, Terrible, Fierce Lady, Small Club Holder, and Sky Dweller.
Female yakṣas, a class of semidivine beings that haunt or protect natural places and cities. They can be malevolent or benevolent, and are known for bestowing wealth and worldly boons.

A class of nonhuman beings that haunt or protect natural places and cities. They can be malevolent (hence the Tibetan translation {gnod sbyin}, meaning “harm giver”) or benevolent and are known for bestowing wealth and worldly boons.

A class of semidivine beings that haunt or protect natural places and cities. They can be malevolent or benevolent, and are known for bestowing wealth and worldly boons. They are associated with Kubera, the god of wealth, who is often counted as their king.

A class of supernatural beings that are often represented as the attendants of Vaiśravaṇa, the god of wealth, but the term is also applied to spirits. Although they are generally portrayed as benevolent, the Tibetan translation means “harm giver,” as they are also capable of causing harm.

A class of nonhuman beings that haunt or protect natural places and cities. They can be malevolent or benevolent, and are known for bestowing wealth and worldly boons, or alternatively, for creating obstacles and causing harm. They are often represented as the attendants of the god of wealth.

A class of semidivine beings said to dwell in the north, under the jurisdiction of the Great King Vaiśravaṇa. They are associated with water, fertility, and trees, and treasure, and are said to haunt or protect natural places as well as towns. Yakṣa can be malevolent or benevolent, and are known for bestowing wealth and other boons.

Yakṣas are ambivalent nature spirits. According to Indian mythology, they inhabit trees, ponds, and other natural places, and serve as guardians of a certain locale. They possess magical powers, are shapeshifters, and can appear as helpful to and protective of the Buddha, his disciples, and the teachings. They can also be malevolent forces that create obstacles and illness. They are one group among the aṣṭasenā, eight groups of nonhuman beings said to have been present when the Buddha preached the Mahāyāna sūtras.
Maliciousness, malevolence, vindictiveness.
The second among the three mental misdeeds.
Second of the five obscurations. Also translated here as “malice.”
Second of the five obscurations; ninth of the ten non-virtuous actions; second of the four knots. Also translated here as “harmful intention.”
An acid river in the hell Forest of Continuous Flames
A female yakṣa.
A class of beings belonging to the realm of Kubera, the god of wealth.
A bodhisattva present at the sūtra’s teaching.
A class of demonic beings.

An obscure Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit term. Sanskrit equivalent: avastāraka. Translated into Tibetan as “suppressor, one who presses down on someone.” Presumably from avastṛ (“to cover over, as with a blanket”).
Ca. eleventh century. An early Tibetan master of the Nyingma tradition.
One of the seven golden mountains.

The innermost of the seven golden mountain ranges that encircle Sumeru, in the center of the disk of the world. It is presented differently in other systems; for example, it is sometimes the fourth of these mountains.
A measure of length equal to four cubits; also, a measure of angular distance (translated here as an “angular yoke”).

The translator of Nyen, Darma Drak. He accompanied Ra Lotsawa ({rwa lo tsA ba}, 1016–1128?) to India where he stayed twelve years. Darma Drak is credited with translating Prajñākaramati’s commentary on the Bodhicaryāvatāra, as well as texts on Kālacakra and Tārā, and other works.
Father of the buddha Apagatakleśa.
One of the six tīrthika teachers contemporaneous with Śākyamuni. According to some, one and the same with Mahāvira, the last Tīrthaṅkara of the Jains.
One of the pratyeka buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
(1) A city. (2) A river.
Name of a past king, a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.

A city of the (past) ninety-first eon and the birthplace of Buddha Vipaśyin. In The Hundred Deeds, two women offered Vipaśyin food there and made prayers, resulting in their rebirths as Buddha Śākyamuni’s mother Mahā māyā and his aunt Māyā.
Carrying out virtuous actions as an antidote to past negative deeds.
Son of the buddha Pratibhāna cakṣus.
In this text, refers to reciprocally determined constructs deriving from dualistic thought that are transcended in wisdom.

The third of the four ages of human life in Jambudvīpa. In this age humans are endowed with two quarters, or half of the good qualities that they had during the age of perfection.

Mahāvyutpatti 1717.
Also rendered here as “without duality,” “nonduality,” “nondual.”

This is synonymous with reality, voidness, etc. But it must be remembered that nonduality does not necessarily mean unity, that unity is only one of the pair unity-duality; hence nonduality implies nonunity as well. This point is obscured by designating this nondual philosophy as “monism,” as too many modern scholars have done.
A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
A part of Bengal bordering Orissa, also the name of the dynasty that ruled there.

A type of sandalwood that is reddish in color and has medicinal properties. It is said to have the finest fragrance of all sandalwood. In the Mahāvyutpatti it is translated as {sa mchog}, which means “supreme earth.” Later translations translate gośirṣa literally as “ox-head,” which is said to refer to the shape or name of the mountain where it grows. Appears to be red sandalwood, though that appears separately in the list of incenses.
Son of the buddha Amṛtaprabha.

This is a protective clothing, made of closely interwoven strands, strapped around the body. In the Mahāyāna sūtras, it can be understood symbolically: the strands are the six perfections interlocking in a way that nothing can get through them. The strands bound together in the protective clothing may also be the net of interlocking beings occasioning a bodhisattva’s never-failing empathy.
A river in the south of Jambudvīpa.

The family name of the historical Buddha. Gautama means “descendant of Gotama,” while his clan name, Gotama, means “Excellent Cow.” When the Buddha is addressed as Gautama in the sūtras, it typically implies that the speaker does not share the respect of his disciples, who would rather refer to him as the “Blessed One” or another such epithet.

As described in https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1121 , they comprise attachment to the world system of form, attachment to the world system of formlessness, fundamental ignorance, pride, and mental agitation. Asaṃkhyeya and other specific, extremely large numbers that have separate values and are not actually synonymous with “infinite” are left untranslated in contexts where the difference between them is a salient factor. On the number asaṃkhyeya (“incalculable”), see also Abhidharmakośa 3.93.

The name of a certain kind of kalpa that literally means “incalculable.” The number of years in this kalpa differs in the various sūtras that give it a number. Also, twenty intermediate kalpas are said to be one incalculable kalpa, and four incalculable kalpas are one great kalpa. In light of that, those four incalculable kalpas represent the kalpas of the creation, presence, destruction, and absence of a world. Buddhas are often described as appearing in a second “incalculable” kalpa.

This eon is literally called “incalculable” but nevertheless has a calculated span of time and therefore, to avoid confusion, its Sanskrit name is used here. The number of years in an asaṃkhyeya eon differs in various sūtras. Twenty “intermediate eons” are said to be one asaṃkhyeya eon, and four asaṃkhyeya eons are one great eon (mahākalpa). In that case those four asaṃkhyeya eons represent the eons of the creation, presence, destruction, and absence of a world. Therefore buddhas are often described as appearing in a second asaṃkhyeya eon.
A distinct number. 1 to the power of 60, according to the Abhidharmakośa.
The name of a nakṣatra. There are two Phalgunī, the “former” (Skt. pūrvā; Tib. {gre}) and the “latter” (Skt. uttarā; Tib. {dbo}).
The name of a nakṣatra.

The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Delta Leonis in the occidental tradition.

A famous Tibetan scholar who was active in the late eleventh to early twelfth centuries. His most famous work was the Bstan rim chen mo (Stages of Doctrine), a detailed compendium of Buddhist doctrines.

The six great cities of the Middle Country are frequently mentioned in Buddhist literature. The Mahā parinirvāṇa sūtra lists them as Śrāvastī, Sāketa, Campā, Vārāṇasī, Vaiśālī, and Rājagṛha.
Name of a city built for Puṇyaraśmi’s enjoyment by his father, King Arciṣmān.
A realm of the ever-infatuated gods.
Birthplace of the buddha Kanakamuni.
A place near Bodhgaya.

A great bodhisattva.

A Hindu deity.
A night goddess in Bodhgaya.
Birthplace of the buddha Maitreya.
A buddha realm.
Euphemism for sexual intercourse.
The 640th buddha in the first list, 639th in the second list, and not listed in the third list.
