The name of the mountain where the bodhisattva Avalokiteśvara dwells (Edgerton 354.2). A city ruled by King Mahendra before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.

A mountain in South India, presently known as Potikai, that was of great importance to both Tamil Buddhists and Śaivists (who saw it as the residence of Śiva, known as Lokeśvara). This is the first mention in a sūtra that has identified Avalokiteśvara with this mountain as his residence rather than the pure realm of Sukhāvatī. However, in this sūtra the verse appears to locate it in the ocean, while the prose appears to describe it on land. In Tibet and China, Potalaka was believed to be an island. In Tibet it is usually referred to by the shortened form Potala.
Another name of the king Mahendra.
An area in Kuru.
Sixty-second of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
Drugu is the name of an ancient people living in north west Tibet.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
“Unfailing Success” seems to be an epithet applied to some emanations of Avalokiteśvara, especially to Amoghapāśa.
A medicine deity; a bodhisattva who seeks a prophecy from Śākyamuni.
A buddha.
A class of vidyādharas.
A buddha.
Someone who has attained supernatural powers.
A magical power or accomplishment; any accomplishment in general.
Accomplished being; also a class of semidivine beings similar to vidyādharas.
The 691st buddha in the first list, 690th in the second list, and 681st in the third list.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the pratyeka buddhas in the maṇḍala of Mañjuśrī.
A class of powerful semidivine beings. In its ordinary sense of “accomplished” and so forth, this word is always translated here according to context.
A “Great Sorcerer,” a master of the esoteric teachings and practices of Mahāyāna Buddhism.
An accomplished being; a class of semidivine beings.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK; a brahmin statesman.
A class of beings said to dwell in the east under the jurisdiction of the great king Dhṛtarāṣṭra. They are so named because they have testicles (aṇḍa) shaped like jars (kumbha).
A kind of demon. The name uses a play on the word āṇḍa, which means egg but is a euphemism for testicle. Thus, they are often depicted as having testicles as big as pots (from khumba, or “pot”).

A class of supernatural being. The name uses a play on the Sanskrit word āṇḍa, which means “egg” but is a euphemism for testicle. Thus, they are often depicted as having testicles as big as pots (Sanskrit: khumba).

A disease-causing demon, with an etymology of “little warm egg,” also used for benevolent deities. However, the Tibetan term used in the Kāraṇḍavyūha is more commonly used (as in the Mahavyutpatti concordance) to translate kumbhanda, a humanoid being with an animal’s head that dwells in the sea.

A class of evil being commonly mentioned alongside yakṣas, piśācas, bhūtas, etc.; Virūḍhaka is sometimes named as the lord of the kumbhāṇḍa, as is Rudra; also associated with the māras (Edgerton 187.2); a type of yakṣa having a human body but an animal head; a type of preta (Rangjung Yeshe Dictionary).

A class of dwarf beings subordinate to Virūḍhaka, one of the Four Great Kings, associated with the southern direction. The name uses a play on the word āṇḍa, which means “egg” but is also a euphemism for a testicle. Thus, they are often depicted as having testicles as big as pots (from khumba, or “pot”).
Forty-fourth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
One of the four main types of enlightened activity.
Birthplace of the buddha Amoghadarśin.
Birthplace of the buddha Prasannabuddhi.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Kṛtāntadarśin.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Mahita (254 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Dharmabala (786 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Supriya (879 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Samṛddhajñāna (671 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Cakradhara (950 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Birthplace of the buddha Satyaketu.
A forest in Moving Mind.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Satyaketu.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Udgata (804 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Birthplace of the buddha Chedana.
A lake on Utterly Delightful to Behold.
Father of the buddha Kanakaparvata.
Name of a monk from a previous eon.
Attendant of the buddha Praśāntadoṣa.
A city where the Buddha descended from the heaven of the Thirty-Three gods.
The 763rd buddha in the first list, 762nd in the second list, and 752nd in the third list.
Father of the buddha Prasannabuddhi.
Son of the buddha Ratnavyūha.
Father of the buddha Aśoka.
Son of the buddha Ratnacandra.
Mother of the buddha Asaṅgakīrti.
Mother of the buddha Laḍitakrama.
Modern Vārāṇasi.
Mother of the buddha Jyotiṣka.
Son of the buddha Prabhākośa.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Ratnākara (153 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
The king of the Kośala kingdom (located in Northern India, in present day Uttar Pradesh) and Vimalaśraddhā’s father.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Puṣpaketu (525 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Son of King Arāḍa Brahmadatta of Śrāvasti. Later, as king he gave all servants in his lands permission to join the Buddhist order if they wished.
King of the country of Kośala, he reigned in the city of Śrāvastī. Sometime enemy of King Brahmadatta (present), with whom he eventually reconciled.
King of the country of Kośala, he reigned in the city of Śrāvastī (located in Northern India, in present-day Uttar Pradesh) at the time of the Buddha.

King of the country of Kośala, he reigned in the city of Śrāvastī. In this sūtra, Surata humbles him and then becomes one of his teachers. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-043-008.html#UT22084-043-008-11 .
“Power of Splendor,” Puṇyabala’s father.
A king based in Ujjain, contemporary of the Buddha.
The 949th buddha in the first list, 948th in the second list, and 939th in the third list.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Pūjya (787 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.

It is not clear who these five are. The Ratna ketu dhāraṇī (Toh 138) mentions the “five yakṣa generals” and gives six names: Āṭavaka/Bhīṣaṇaka, Chinnasrotas, Jñānolka, Saṃjñika, and Tṛṣṇājaha. See The Ranaketu Dhāraṇī, https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-056-006.html#UT22084-056-006-1398.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
Father of the buddha Āśādatta.
Name of a yakṣa.
Epithet of Vaiśravaṇa.
Another term for the yakṣa subjects of Vaiśravaṇa.
A class of nonhuman beings, usually identified with the yakṣas.
A subclass of yakṣas, but much of the time used as an alternative name for yakṣas.
A type of nonhuman being frequently found in the entourage of Vaiśravaṇa (Kubera), the lord of wealth.
Attendants of Kubera, the god of wealth, and the guardians of his treasures. They live in the Himalayas at the source of the Ganges on the mountain that has been identified with Kailash.
A class of devas that, like the yakṣas, are ruled over by Kubera, but are also said to be his most trusted helpers. It is said that they protect his hidden treasures and live in mountain caves.
Another term for the yakṣa subjects of Kubera.
Semidivine beings closely related to or identical with yakṣas, who, like them, live in the realm of Kubera.
A class of devas that, like the yakṣas, are ruled over by Kubera, but are also said to be his most trusted helpers.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Mahāraśmi (395 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Anantarūpa.
A spell. Although a technical term in its own right, it is also at times used interchangeably with the terms dhāraṇī and dhāraṇīmantra, vidyāmantra, etc.

A formula of words or syllables that are recited aloud or mentally in order to bring about a magical or soteriological effect or result. The term has been creatively etymologized to mean “that which protects (trā) the mind (man)”.
One of five types of instructors named by the Buddha when asked to elaborate on the role of an instructor.
One of ten different kinds of verbal phrase or statement (Skt. pada) mentioned in this text.
Literally “an instrument of thought,” it is usually a brief verbal formula used in multiple repetitions, usually beginning with oṁ and in essence a salutation to a particular deity.
One of the grahas.
A river in Enjoyment of Scents.
A mountain in the eastern sea beyond Jambudvīpa.
A class of bird deities.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Replete.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Vidyuddatta.
The name of a tathāgata presiding over a buddhafield to at the zenith above the buddhafield Full of Pearls.
A goddess.
Mother of the buddha Sūryaraśmi.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
Son of the buddha Padmagarbha.
Mother of the buddha Ugradatta.
Birthplace of the buddha Prabhaṃkara.
In a story the Buddha tells, this was the name of our continent countless eons ago.

A king of Suvarṇadvīpa who figures in a prophecy made by the teacher Sañjayin that convinces Śāriputra and Maudgalyāyana of his prescience. This in turn gives them conviction to seek out the Buddha as Sañjayin advised they should.
The thus-gone one residing in the buddhafield Heaped with Jewels and Full of Perfume.
The name of a buddha in the above direction.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva present in the Buddha’s assembly. His name means, “Brilliant Light Rays of the Collection of Fine Gold.”
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
Name of a buddha of the past.
Father of the buddha Akṣobhyavarṇa.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Infinite Purity.
A forest on Tamer of Deer Enemies.
Birthplace of the buddha Vajradhvaja.
A world system.
A peacock who was the Buddha in a former life.
A peacock king who appears periodically in Buddhist literature. One of the past lives of Śākyamuni.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Firelight.
One of the two auxiliary melāpakas.
A region of Southeast Asia visited by Indians.

Home of King Suvarṇapati who figures in a prophecy made by Śāriputra and Maudgalyāyana’s teacher Sañjayin that convinces them of their teacher’s prescience, which in turn gives them conviction to seek out the Buddha as Sañjayin advised they should.
A nāga king.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Meteor.
Birthplace of the buddha Kāñcanaprabha.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ratnadeva.
The 614th buddha in the first list, 613th in the second list, and 607th in the third list.
A forest of the asuras.
A village or town.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
A buddha realm.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A park in Attached to That.
A park in Sustained by Fruition.
A world system.
Birthplace of the buddha Jyotiṣka.
A buddha.
Birthplace of the buddha Siṃhapārśva.
The world of the past buddha Mervabhyudgata rāja.
Golden-complexioned nun who achieved arhatship during the time of Buddha Śākyamuni, due to the intercession of a previous incarnation of Venerable Ānanda during the time of Buddha Kāśyapa.
(1) A river on Cakravāḍa. (2) A sea between Godānīya and Kuru.
Mother of the buddha Dṛḍhasvara.

Lit. “The One Who Had the Golden Flowers.” Future name of the nun Gaṅgadevī when she becomes a bodhisattva in the buddhafield of Akṣobhya, and also when she becomes a buddha, during the eon called Tārakopama.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Firelight.
A goddess.
A god.
The name of an apsaras.
A river at Radiant Streams.
Mother of the buddha Yaśomati.
A buddha.
One of the uṣṇīṣa kings attending the delivery of the MMK.
King and sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
A buddha in the distant past.
The 129th buddha in the first list, 129th in the second list, and not listed in the third list.
Birthplace of the buddha Sadgaṇin.
An island in the eastern sea beyond Jambudvīpa.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
Sometimes called the “golden ground,” or “universal base,” “The mythological basis of our known world. It is made of gold and situated below Mount Sumeru” (Rangjung Yeshe Dictionary).
Birthplace of the buddha Ratnayaśas.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Glory of the Exalted King of Palmyra Trees.
A great bodhisattva.
Birthplace of the buddha Padmagarbha.
A buddha realm in the east.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
Mother of the buddha Atiyaśas.
‟Golden One,” one of the eight great yakṣiṇīs.
The name of a river.
Name of a sage, a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Rāhuguhya.
A world realm in the eastern direction. Also called Kanaka vimala prabhā.
A world realm in the eastern direction. Also called Kanaka vimala prabhā vyūha.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with Moon.
The name of a bodhisattva. “Glorious Golden Light.”
The name of a buddha in the southwestern direction.

A courtesan’s daughter, central figure of The Miraculous Play of Mañjuśrī sūtra. Her name means “Glorious Light of Supreme Gold.” The Sanskrit name is reconstructed from the Tibetan and is not attested (see https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-046-002.html#UT22084-046-002-571 ).
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Mokṣadhvaja.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Hitaiṣin.
One of King Bimbisāra’s daughters.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Dṛḍhasaṃdhi.
The 664th buddha in the first list, 663rd in the second list, and 655th in the third list.
Birthplace of the buddha Brahmā.
A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
A park in another world in the distant past. The name as given in verse. In prose it is called Suvarṇa puṣpābha maṇḍala.
Mother of the buddha Sūryaprabha.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Brahmaghoṣa.
Name of a king who was the previous incarnation of the bodhisattva Maitreya.
A nāga king.
Forest on the third asura level, Excellent Abode.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
A vast array of many masses of world realms in the distant past.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
Son of the buddha Prāmodyarāja.
A buddha of the past.
A nāga king.
A holy site blessed by the presence of sages.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Atibala.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Guru of the Moon.
A bodhisattva present in the circle around Śākyamuni.
The 2nd buddha in the first list, 2nd in the second list, and 2nd in the third list.
Fifth of the seven buddhas of the past, and second in this kalpa. Also rendered “Kanaka.”
Fifth of the seven tathāgatas/buddhas. Identified in other texts as the second buddha to appear in the present eon.
Name of a buddha who preceded Śākyamuni, usually counted as the second buddha of the current fortunate eon, Śākyamuni being the fourth.
Name of a former buddha usually counted as the second of the first four buddhas of the present Good Eon, the other three being Krakucchanda, Kāśyapa, and Śākyamuni.

The fifth of the seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. The second buddha in this Bhadraka eon that we are in. In the White Lotus of Compassion Sūtra, Buddha Ratnagarbha specifically prophesies that the third of Ratnagarbha’s thousand vedapāṭhaka pupils will be this buddha. He also earlier prophesies that his fifteenth brother will be a buddha who has that name.
The realm of the Buddha Śantābha.
Son of the buddha Kṛtavarman.
A pore on Avalokiteśvara’s body.
One of the pratyeka buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK. Possibly also a shortened form of the name of the tathāgata Kanakamuni.
The buddhafield of the Thus-Gone One Supari kīrtita nāma dheyaśrī rāja.
A nāga king.
A class of evil spirits.
A kind of female evil spirit or sorceress.
A generally malevolent class of semi-divine being.
A class of spirit beings typically associated with violent sorcery rites.
A spirit one can request, by making offerings, to destroy others. Usually female, with this sūtra having the sole instance of a male entity. There are also references to humans who have this power.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Jñānaprāpta (680 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A great bodhisattva.
The Vedic afterlife presided over by the lord of death, Yama, and inhabited by the ancestors (pitṛ).\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-008.html#UT22084-072-008-6 .
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
One of the great mātṛs.
Deity invoked to summon and subdue Karṇapiśācī.
Another name of Yama.
The lord of death, who judges the dead and rules over the hells.
The lord of death in Indian mythology, who judges the dead and rules over the hells and the realm of the hungry ghosts.
This refers to hungry ghosts, or pretas. Yāma ({gzhin rje}) is the Lord of Death.
This is a reference to the world of the pretas.
The world of the dead, another term for the realm of anguished spirits.
In this text, another name for the hungry ghost realm; Yama is also sometimes said to preside over the hell realms.
The realm of the Lord of Death is another name for the realm of hungry ghosts or pretas. This term is also the name of the Vedic afterlife inhabited by the ancestors (pitṛ).

The preta realm, or the realm of ghosts, where Yama, the Lord of Death, is the ruler and judges the dead. Yama is also said to rule over the hells. This term is also the name of the Vedic afterlife inhabited by the ancestors (pitṛ).

The land of the dead ruled over by the Lord of Death. In Buddhism it refers to the preta realm, where beings generally suffer from hunger and thirst, which in traditional Brahmanism is the fate of those departed without descendants to make ancestral offerings.
Wrathful aspect of Mañjuśrī; also the namesake mantra.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Howling Hell.
From Vedic times, the Lord of Death is the one who directs the departed into the next realm of rebirth.
The lord of death in Indian mythology, who judges the dead and rules over the hells and the realm of the hungry ghosts.
The lord of death, who judges the dead and rules over the hells; the realm of Yama is synonymous with the world of the pretas.
Usually the Lord of Death who directs the departed into the next realm of rebirth, but here refers to the Lord of the hungry ghost realm.
The god of death who rules over the realm of the pretas; a vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi; one of the kings of rākṣasas.
Another name for King Yama (Skt. yamarāja; Tib. {gshin rje rgyal po}), the deity who judges the dead and rules over the hell realms of the underworld.
One of seven golden mountains enumerated in Abhidharma cosmology.
Name of a class of gods, as well as one of the ranges of mountains around Sumeru.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
A nāga king.

The Sanskrit may also refer to a weapon or a plow repurposed as a weapon, which would make sense in the context of the short list of weapons (34–43) found among the eighty designs, although the Tibetan meaning itself doesn’t connote this secondary meaning. Here its image is the fortieth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
A village or town.

Edgerton favors the theory according to which poṣa/posa should be derived from puruṣa; however, the Tibetan translation reflects a different etymologization of the term that must have been current at the time of the Tibetan translations of Sanskrit texts. Pāli etymologies also suggest a link to the idea of “nourishing” (attabhāvassa posanato poso), and therefore we have preferred to follow traditional etymologies that better reflect how the South Asian and Tibetan masters understood the term.
Attendant of the buddha Vaidyarāja.
A certain householder who was fourth among those in the apostolic succession that carried on the Buddha’s teachings after his parinirvāṇa.
The eight vows kept by laypeople on the four sacred days of the month: full, new, and half-moon days. Alternate form is upoṣadha ({gso sbyong}).
A king, the father of King Māndhātṛ.

These are the eight upavasatha vows, similar to the commitments of a monk, but maintained only for one day. On such days one pledges: (1) not to kill, (2) not to steal, (3) not to engage in sexual intercourse, (4) not to lie, (5) not to partake of any intoxicants, (6) not to sing or dance, (7) not to eat after noon, and (8) not to use high seats or luxurious beds.
The saṅgha’s confession ceremony; the bi-monthly monastic gathering for the restoration of virtues and purification of negativies as prescribed by the Buddha (Rigzin 454).
A twice monthly ceremony performed by monks, nuns, and novices in which the ordained confess and remedy transgressions of their vows, thereby purifying and restoring the vows.

The fortnightly ceremony during which ordained monks and nuns gather to recite the Prātimokṣa vows and confess faults and breaches. The term is also sometimes used in reference to the taking of eight vows by a layperson for just one day, a full-moon or new-moon day.

A group of eight vows taken for one day on certain days of the month to emphasize purity. They include the traditional five “lay precepts,” plus the vows not to sit on high cushions or thrones, not to eat at inappropriate times, not to wear adornments, and not to engage in or listen to song and dance.

The ceremony performed every new and full moon day by monastics, in which they confess any faults or transgressions and recite the prātimokṣa. It also refers to the one-day practice adopted by lay people in which they practice restraint according to the eight poṣadha vows and which may also include fasting. See introduction ( https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-074-003.html#UT22084-074-003-4 ).

A group of eight vows taken for one day on certain days of the month to restore one’s connection to the virtuous path. The Tibetan translation glosses the practice (rather than translating the original Sanskrit) as “reviving (virtue) and purifying (nonvirtue).” The vows include the traditional five “lay precepts,” plus the vows not to sit on high cushions or thrones, not to eat at inappropriate times, and not to engage in or listen to song or dance.

A class of beings, literally, in Sanskrit, “the sons of Danu.” They are enemies of the devas and often associated with the asuras. Under the leadership of Bali, they took over the world, creating a golden age, until they were tricked by Viṣṇu in the form of a brahmin dwarf. A version of that legend is described in a prominent passage in the Kāraṇḍa vyūha Sūtra ( https://read.84000.co/translation/toh116 , Toh 116), the principal Avalokiteśvara sūtra.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Howling Hell. Also known as No Death.
A deity representing the element of water.
A deity personifying the true nature of the element of water.

A formal act of the saṅgha in which the motion suffices, with no need to formally state the act. Such an act is employed before a candidate for ordination is asked about private matters pertaining to his fitness for ordination.
A buddha.

For someone to be accepted into the Saṅgha, and for any other action that needs the assent of the Saṅgha, first a motion (jñāpti; {gsol ba}) is presented to the community, for example, a certain person’s wish for ordination. The motion would be followed by three propositions, in which is it said that all who assent should remain silent. If no one speaks up after the third proposition, the motion is passed. The Tibetan translated it literally as “supplication and fourth.”

A formal act of the saṅgha that requires an initial motion followed by the statement of the proposed act, repeated three times. Such an act is required for several proceedings—among other occasions, to fully ordain someone, or to officially admonish an intransigent monk.
A formal act of the saṅgha that requires an initial motion followed by the statement of the proposed act. Such an act is needed to grant the vows of full ordination to a nun, among other occasions.
A formal request, e.g., that a postulant be accepted into the renunciate order or that a monk serve as preceptor granting ordination, etc.
Thirty-eighth of the eighty minor marks.
Symptom of a cholera-like illness considered an impediment to ordination.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1011 .
Name of a class of gods in the desire realm. There is also an associated heavenly realm, the Realm of the Thirty-Three Gods, which is named after these.
The paradise of Indra.
The second of the four ages of human life in Jambudvīpa. In this age humans are endowed with three quarters of the good qualities that they had during the age of perfection.
A forest in Dwelling in One Direction.
Father of the buddha Vimalakīrti.
Qualities of an arhat who has the three knowledges ({rig pa gsum}): knowledge of divine sight, knowledge of previous lifetimes, and knowledge of the cessation of outflows.
The 793rd buddha in the first list, 792nd in the second list, and 782nd in the third list.
“Lord of Speech,” epithet of Mañjuśrī.
This is an honorific term describing the Buddha Śākyamuni’s speech that invokes the use of {sgra rgyan} (śabdālaṁkāra), a term that signifies the use of various aspects of poetic speech.
A buddha.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Sixty-eighth of the eighty minor marks.
Translation tentative.

The “twelve branches of excellent speech” or the “twelve categories of the Buddha’s teachings” are discourses (Tib. {mdo'i sde}, Skt. sūtra), verse narrations (Tib. {dbyangs kyis bsnyad pa'i sde}, Skt. geya), prophecies (Tib. {lung du bstan pa'i sde}, Skt. vyākaraṇa), poetic verses (Tib. {tshigs su bcad pa'i sde}, Skt. gāthā), aphorisms (Tib. {ched du brjod pa'i sde}, Skt. udāna), ethical narrations (Tib. {gleng gzhi brjod pa'i sde}, Skt. nidāna), narrative discourses (Tib. {rtogs pa brjod pa'i sde}, Skt. avadāna), parables (Tib. {de lta bu byung ba'i sde}, Skt. itivṛttaka), past-life stories (Tib. {skye pa'i rabs kyi sde}, Skt. jātaka), extensive sayings (Tib. {shin tu rgyas pa'i sde}, Skt. vaipulya), marvels (Tib. {rmad du byung ba'i chos kyi sde}, Skt. abidhutadharma), and resolutions (Tib. {gtan la bab par bstan pa'i sde}, Skt. upadeśa).
Refers to the discourses of the Buddha.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Forty-sixth of the eighty minor marks.
A buddha in the past.
Foremost among the Buddha’s pupils in analytic reasoning.
An area in Kuru.
A monk (bhikṣu) and disciple of the Buddha.
One of the Buddha’s foremost hearer disciples.
Name of an elder and senior disciple of Buddha Śākyamuni.
Śrāvaka arhat.
One of the disciples of the Buddha.
A great śrāvaka included in the audience of this sūtra.
Foremost among the Buddha’s pupils in analytic reasoning.
A senior student of Buddha Śākyamuni, famous for his analytical knowledge.
Persons with stunted growth who exhibit general sluggishness due to hypothyroidism.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Sudarśana.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Region of Joyous Radiance.
An epithet attributed to the great seer Vyāsa.
One of the “twelve branches of excellent speech.”
As one of the twelve aspects of the wheel of Dharma, it means the explanation of details in the teachings and is synonymous with Abhidharma.

One of the nine aspects of the Dharma according to this sūtra. More commonly there are said to be twelve that include these nine. It means “the explanation of details in the teachings” and is synonymous with abhidharma.
Eleventh of the twelve branches of the scriptures.
One of the twelve branches of Buddhist scriptures.
As one of the twelve aspects of the Dharma, it means the explanation of details in the teachings and is synonymous with Abhidharma.\nSee also “twelve wheels of the Dharma.”
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Victorious.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Nāgadatta.
Attendant of the buddha Mayūra.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Uttīrṇapaṅka.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Ornamented by Pure Conduct.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Bodhidhvaja.
The 821st buddha in the first list, 820th in the second list, and 810th in the third list.
The 825th buddha in the first list, 824th in the second list, and 814th in the third list.
The 930th buddha in the first list, 929th in the second list, and 920th in the third list.
Consort of White Acala.
A deity representing the faculty of sight.
A deity personifying the true nature of the faculty of sight.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Vairocana.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Dharaṇīśvara.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Subhadra (493 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
One of the three root afflictions that bind beings to cyclic existence.
One of the three poisons (triviṣa), together with greed and hatred, that bind beings to cyclic existence.
Delusion, stupidity, closed-mindedness, and/or mental darkness. One of the affective behavior patterns or “afflictions” known as the three poisons.

One of the three poisons ({dug gsum}) along with aversion and attachment which perpetuate the sufferings of cyclic existence. Delusion is the obfuscating mental state which obstructs an individual from generating knowledge or insight, and it is said to be dominant characteristic of the animal world in general.
A mountain range surrounding the hell of Embers Within.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
Fifth of the ten recollections.
An offering of edibles to a deity or spirit.
An offering of edibles to nonhuman beings, usually including lower orders of spirits.
An offering of food; unlike homa, bali is not offered into the fire but is placed on the altar and later eaten or distributed.
An offering made to a deity or spirits; bali may be elaborate with food, incense, lamps, etc., but this term may also denote, in the MMK at least, a sacrificial cake similar to the Tibetan torma.

An offering, originating in the vedic tradition, traditionally made out of uncooked food and performed at the home prior to cooking a meal by arranging portions of the ingredients and then casting them outside or into the sacred fire. Also translated here as “uncooked offering.”

Bali wrested control of the world from the devas, establishing a period of peace and prosperity with no caste distinction. Indra requested Viṣṇu to use his wiles so that the devas could gain the world back from him. He appeared as a dwarf asking for two steps of ground, was offered three, and then traversed the world in two steps. Bali, keeping faithful to his promise, accepted the banishment of the asuras into the underworld. A great festival is held in Bali’s honor annually in South India. In the Kāraṇḍavyūha, he abuses his power by imprisoning the kṣatriyas, so that Viṣṇu has cause to banish him to the underworld.
(1) A lake on Equal Peaks. (2) A river on Saṅkāśa.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
These are composed of the five highest paradises in the form realm: Akaniṣṭha, Sudarśana, Sudṛśa, Atapa, and Avṛha.
The five realms associated with the fourth concentration, into which only noble beings are born.
The five highest of the paradises that constitute the realm of form, which are above the paradises of the realm of desire in which our world is situated. Also translated as {gtsang ris}.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Suvarṇottama (655 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
One of eight children, a daughter, of King Siṃhahanu of Kapilavastu.
These are composed of the five highest paradises in the form realm: Akaniṣṭha, Sudarśana, Sudṛśa, Atapa, and Avṛha.
The five highest of the paradises that consitute the realm of form, which is above the paradises of the realm of desire in which our world is situated.
Traditionally “one who is learned in the Vedas.” The Tibetan means “one who keeps pure and clean.”
A yakṣa appearing in some of the paintings of Amoghapāśa. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-092-001.html#UT22084-092-001-5249 .
Mother of the buddha Jñānaruta.
The name of a bodhisattva. “Highest Summit.”
Name of a village chief in a story Buddha tells.

The three robes (Skt. tricīvara, Tib. {chos gos gsum}) of the fully ordained are the lower robe (Skt. antarvāsa, Tib. {mthang gos}) wrapped around the waist, the outer or upper robe (uttarāsaṅga, {bla gos}) covering the upper body, and the ceremonial robe (saṃghāṭī, {snam sbyar}).
Name of a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
The 585th buddha in the first list, 584th in the second list, and 578th in the third list.
A buddha in the past.
Son of the buddha Laḍita.
Attendant of the buddha Vibhakta jñā svara.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Prajñākūṭa.
The 159th buddha in the first list, 158th in the second list, and 158th in the third list.
Material, or manifested existence; in Sāṃkhya philosophy this term denotes matter as opposed to consciousness. The term pradhāna is used synonymously with prakṛti in the Sāṃkhya system.
Father of the buddha Jyeṣṭhadatta.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Balanandin (363 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Son of the buddha Marutskandha.
Mother of the buddha Jyeṣṭhadatta.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Vararuci (228 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Son of the buddha Jyeṣṭhadatta.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Jyeṣṭhadatta.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Pūjya (925 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A garuḍa.
The 609th buddha in the first list, 608th in the second list, and 602nd in the third list.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Brahmā.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
Birthplace of the buddha Siṃhagati.
The second of the seven buddhas of the past.
One of the six buddhas who preceded Śākyamuni in this Fortunate Eon.
The name of the one-syllable mantra of Mañjuśrī—bhrūṁ—and also of the form of Mañjuśrī that it invokes.
A temple in Khotan.
A series of verses that were supposed to prevent dangers.
A temple in Khotan.
A dwelling place of monks.
A term denoting a permanent structure built to house members of the monastic saṅgha
An acceptable form of shelter for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
Either a temple or monastery. In Buddhism it was originally a residence used during the monsoon for the otherwise wandering bhikṣus.
Originally a place where the wandering “viharin” monks would stay during the monsoon only, they later developed into permanent domiciles for monks.
The second of the seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. The Tibetan translation could also be read as “one with a crown protuberance.”
Father of the second buddha Kusuma.
A great bodhisattva.
Attendant of the buddha Nārāyaṇa.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ratnakīrti.
The 81st buddha in the first list, 81st in the second list, and 82nd in the third list.
Son of the buddha Hitaiṣin.
A great bodhisattva.
Son of the buddha Kāñcanaprabha.
Birthplace of the buddha Ratnaprabha.
The 297th buddha in the first list, 296th in the second list, and 296th in the third list.

A gandharva who was very prominent in early Buddhism and is featured on early stupa reliefs playing a lute and singing. He would come to Buddha Śākyamuni, who was not portrayed as omniscient, to inform him of what was occuring in the paradises. He also accompanies Indra on a visit to the Buddha and plays music to bring the Buddha out of his meditation. He performs the same role in the Mahāyāna sūtra The White Lotus of Compassion. He was portrayed as living on a five-peaked mountain, and appears to be the basis for Mañjuśrī, first known as Mañjughoṣa (Beautiful Voice) with Pañcaśikha still being one of Mañjuśrī’s alternate names. In this sūtra he is clearly distinct from Bodhisattva Mañjuśrī.
A buddha.
One of the śakras.
Attendant of the buddha Lokottīrṇa.
“Crown Ornament Holder.”
A god of the Brahmā realms.
A deity in Brahmā’s paradise. Also the name of a past buddha. Also the name of a Mahābrahmā in the upward direction at the time of Buddha Mahābhijñā jñānābhi bhū.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Priyaprasanna (991 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
One of the gandharva kings.
A certain young gandharva allied with the god Śakra.
A gandharva king who is employed by Śakra to serve the Buddha. He is sometimes said to be a form of Mañjuśrī or historically to have been his original identity.
A buddha.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A nāga king.
The 1003rd buddha in the first list, 1002nd in the second list, and 993rd in the third list.

The uṣṇīṣa, described in this text as “raised” (Skt. unnata) is one of the most prominent of the thirty-two signs of a great being and is often placed first or last in the list. In its simplest form it is an elevated shape of the head, like a turban (the Sanskrit term uṣṇīṣa in fact means “turban”), or more elaborately a dome-shaped extension. The extension is described as having various magical attributes such as emitting and absorbing rays of light or reaching such an immense height that the gods are incapable of flying over it.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the eight tathāgatas
A name common to thirty buddhas in the past. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-5316 .
The second of the seven tathāgatas/buddhas. Identified in other texts as the penultimate buddha to appear in the eon that preceded the present one.
A deity in Brahmā’s paradise. Also the name of a past buddha. Also the name of a Mahābrahmā in the upward direction at the time of Buddha Mahābhijñā jñānābhi bhū.
One of the tathāgatas. The second of the seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. Identified in other texts as the penultimate buddha to appear in the eon that preceded the present one.

In early Buddhism the second of seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. The first three buddhas—Vipaśyin, Śikhin, and Viśvabhuk—appeared in a kalpa earlier than our Bhadra kalpa, and therefore Śākyamuni is more commonly referred to as the fourth buddha. Also translated elsewhere as {gtsug ldan}; the Mahāvyutpatti also translates as {gtsug tor can}.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
One of the eight uṣṇīṣa kings.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
One of the goddesses (possibly a male deity) in the maṇḍala of Mañjuśrī. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-088-038.html#UT22084-088-038-762 .
One of the mantra deities.
One of the eight uṣṇīṣa kings.
A class of fully awakened nonhuman beings, especially the chief eight among them.
The shorter name for the dhāraṇī after which this text is named.
A goddess. See .
The raised extension on the crown of a tathāgata’s head, usually listed among the thirty-two signs of a great being.
One of the physical marks of a buddha that takes the form of the elevated shape of the crown of his head or an extension rising upwards from it.
A protuberance on the head of a buddha; this term may also refer to beings who have this protuberance, known as uṣṇīṣa kings or uṣṇīṣa-tathāgatas.

A feature of the head often depicted as a topknot or a protrusion on the crown, sometimes understood as describing the lofty shape of the head; the Sanskrit term signifies that the head is “like a turban.” One of the thirty-two marks of a great being.

One of the thirty-two signs of a great being. In its simplest form it is that the head has a heightened or pointed shape (like a turban). More elaborately it refers to a dome-shaped extension of the top of the head, or even to an invisible extension of immense height.

Listed in The Question of Mañjuśrī as first of the thirty-two signs of a great being. In its simplest form it is a pointed shape of the head like a turban (the Sanskrit term, uṣṇīṣa, in fact means “turban”), or more elaborately a dome-shaped extension. The extension is described as having various magical attributes such as emitting and absorbing rays of light or reaching an immense height.
A yakṣiṇī. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2556 .
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
‟Fierce Kātyāyanī,” one of the eight kātyāyanī spirits.
Another name for Caṇḍa mahā roṣaṇa’s consort.
A goddess in one of the maṇḍalas of Amoghapāśa.
Blissful heat cultivated in the completion stage of tantric practice.
A member of the lowest social classes in ancient Indian caste society.
Another name for the channel carrying semen, used when it carries menstrual blood.

An outcaste woman; one of the female deities in the retinue of Hevajra; the mystic heat below the navel, personified as a goddess; one of the five ḍākinīs visualized on the prongs of the vajra scepter.
The chief deity of the CMT.
King of Ujjayinī, in Śiṃśapā Forest, where Buddha Śākyamuni sometimes dwelt. Also called just “Pradyota.”
The chief deity of the CMT.
A king based in Ujjain; a contemporary of the Buddha.
A mountain.

The Sanskrit has the meaning of both a club or mace-like weapon, and a pestle used for grinding, which as a cylinder of wood or stone can also be utilized as a weapon. The former meaning makes sense in the context of the short list of weapons (34–43) found among the eighty designs, although the Tibetan has the meaning of “pestle.” Mahāvyutpatti no. 5890 equates {gtun shing} with musala. Here its image is the forty-first of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
Commiphora mukul Engl, a type of myrrh commonly known as Indian bdellium.
One of the auxiliary charnel grounds.
“Lord of All Animals,” an epithet of the god Śiva.
Crocus sativus, the plant and the pollen of the flowers.
A holy site blessed by the presence of sages.
Birthplace of the buddha Prāṇītajñāna.
Attendant of the buddha Manojñavākya.
Third of the pure abodes, meaning “attractive.”
A class of gods who inhabit the third of the “pure abodes.”
The third highest of the five Śuddhāvāsa paradises, the highest paradises in the form realm.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, third of the five so-called pure realms of the form realm.

The highest of the three paradises that correspond to the second dhyāna in the form realm. In other contexts, the Tibetan {'od gsal ba} usually refers to Ābhāsvara, and the Tibetan {gya nom snang ba} would refer to Sudṛśa.

Lit. “Good Looking.” The fifteenth of the seventeen heavens of the form realm; also the name of the gods living there. In the form realm, which is structured according to the four concentrations and pure abodes‍, or Śuddhāvāsa‍, it is listed as the third of the five Pure Abodes.
One of the five pure abodes.
The fifteenth heaven of the form realm.
The third of five realms associated with the fourth concentration into which only noble beings are born.
Fifteenth god realm of form, meaning “Sublime Vision,” it is the third of the five “pure abodes” in the form realm.
The third highest of the seventeen paradises in the form realm, and therefore the third of the five Śuddhāvāsika (pure abode) paradises.

One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology belonging to the form realm. The fourth-highest heaven of the Pure Abodes. Non-returners and those who have mastered the fourth meditative absorption are reborn there. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-280 .
Attendant of the buddha Suceṣṭa.
A disciple of the Buddha.
A monk (bhikṣu) and disciple of the Buddha.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Another name for Dravya Mallaputra, a disciple of the Buddha.
A country.
A tribe or clan.
Name for a country and the people who reside there.
A kingdom of ancient India situated to the North of Magadha.
A certain country during the time of the Buddha in which Kuśinagarī was located.
The 815th buddha in the first list, 814th in the second list, and 804th in the third list.
The city of Ujjayinī, located in the province of the same name. The Sanskrit Ujjayinī is commonly translated into Tibetan as {'phags rgyal}.
One of the five vital airs, centered in the throat.
A type of gem, presumably red as in the blossoms of the kiṃśuka tree.
A river in Khotan.
Unidentified.
A great bodhisattva.
Name of a buddha realm in the east where the buddha Unobstructed Glorious King of Medicine resides.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya guru vaiḍūrya prabha rāja sūtra.
The planet Mercury; a legendary king before the time of the Buddha; a south Indian king, the son of Śaṅkara.
Deities associated with the planets.
Eclipse; a class of spirits causing possession.
A demon that causes an eclipse; a spirit that causes possession; a planet.

A class of nonhuman beings able to enter and possess the human body; a class of beings, such as Rāhu, that cause solar and lunar eclipses; a planet (this category includes the sun and the moon but excludes the earth); a planet or planetary influence personified.
Name of a bodhisattva.
One of the grahas.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the kings of the rākṣasas.
A skill taught to brahmins and kings that may relate to finance or grammar.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-142 .
A river in the northern continent of Kuru.
In the context of sentient beings being “immeasurable.” One of the ten topics to be expounded to the bodhisattva who has perfected application.
Son of the buddha Padmagarbha.
The Skt. vimāna suggests the “mount” or “chariot” of the gods, namely of the sun and moon. It can be a celestial palace ({gzhal med khang}).
Father of the buddha Mahāsthāman.
These palaces served as both vehicles and residences for deities.

Vimāna, translated here as “airborne palace,” can mean a divine chariot or palace, or a combination of the two, as in this translation. These flying palaces of the deities are well known in Indian mythology. Burnouf translates as “chariots”; Kern has “aerial cars.”
Father of the buddha Ketu.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Abhaya.
These palaces served as both vehicles and residences for deities.
A location in Supreme Strength.
A forest in Total Pleasure.
Here refers to a palace of the gods (devavimāna). Alternatively, it can refer to a chariot or self-moving aerial car.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Pratimaṇḍita.
Paranirmitavasavatti, the highest of the group of four heavens immediately above the peak of Mount Meru.
“Controlling Others’ Emanations,” the sixth heaven of the desire realm.
Gods of the sixth and highest-level god realm within the desire realm.

The deities of this, the sixth level of the gods of the desire-realm, appropriate and enjoy the magical creations of others; hence their name, literally, “who assume control of the emanations of others.” Their abode contains all the wonders created elsewhere and is referred to as a standard of splendor.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
The sixth and highest of the six heavens of the desire realm.
“Controlling Others’ Emanations,” the sixth heaven of the desire realm.
The highest of the six heavens of the desire realm, its inhabitants enjoy objects created by others.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, highest of the six heavens of the desire realm. The inhabitants enjoy objects created by others, then dispose of them themselves.
The highest paradise in the desire realm, named “power over the emanations of others” because its inhabitants have that power.
A class of gods who inhabit the highest of the six heavens of the desire realm. The inhabitants enjoy objects created by others, then dispose of them themselves.
“Ruling Others’ Emanations.” The highest paradise in the desire realm, so named because the inhabitants have power over the emanations of others. Also called Vaśavartin.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, highest of the six heavens of the desire realm. The inhabitants enjoy objects created by others, then dispose of them themselves.
Lit. “Those Who Control What Is Created by Others.” The sixth and highest heaven in the desire realm, so named because the inhabitants have power over the emanations of others.

The sixth and highest of the heavens of the desire realm. The inhabitants enjoy objects created by others and dispose of them themselves. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-195 .
The principal deity in the paradise of the same name, which is the highest in the desire realm. Also called Vaśavartin.
(1) One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell. (2) One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
A bodhisattva and the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 31.
Name of a buddha realm in the east where the buddha Exceedingly Widely Renowned Glory resides.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Pradānakīrti.

This term denotes “anything other than the unconditioned expanse of reality” and so forth. Konow (1941), pp. 36–37, translates this term as “being-something-else.” Lamotte (op. cit. p. 1673) suggests “other existence.”
One of the great mātṛs.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Sucittayaśas.
One of the mantra deities.
Birthplace of the buddha Balatejojñāna.
Attendant of the buddha Candana.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Kusumarāṣṭra.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Siṃhagati.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Father of the buddha Baladatta.
A future buddha.
A nāga king; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
“Not Able to Be Harmed by Others”; a previous buddha.
‟Never Conquered by Another,” one of the eight bhūta kings.
The ninety-ninth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
The 131st buddha in the first list, 131st in the second list, and 131st in the third list.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Dṛḍha (37 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A buddha in the past.
One of the eight yakṣa generals.
One of the goddesses invited to partake in the oblation offering.
Symptom that may be evidence of an illness considered an impediment to ordination\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1011 .
A lotus pond on the fifth minor mountain on Lofty Summit.
Name of a prince in a story the Buddha tells; a former incarnation of the buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.

An ocean of universes that includes our Sahā universe of a thousand million worlds and the even greater assembly of universes called Prabhāsa vairocana. It has elsewhere been interpreted to be an alternative name for the Sahā universe.
Imposed on a monk who incurs a second similar saṅgha stigmata offense while serving his probation.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.

The largest and most detailed of the six extant vinaya recensions. Substantial fragments have survived in Sanskrit, and much of it was translated into Chinese by Yijing in the eighth century, but the Tibetan translation in the Kangyur is the fullest version. It is also the only vinaya corpus to have been translated into Tibetan.
“Sucker,” a class of malevolent spirits.
Lit. “bent, crooked.” In this tantra, this refers to the primary side channel that runs to the right side of the central channel.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A bodhisattva.
A female kumāra.
One of the great mātṛs.
One of the seven yakṣiṇīs.
A king.
May also refer to practitioners who deliberately act like children; see https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-057-004.html#UT22084-057-004-1317 .
One of the two auxiliary pīlavas.
One of the previous incarnations of Māra.
Another name of Karttikeya, the god of war.
A short form of the name Candraprabhakumārabhūta.
Another name for Kārttikeya/Skanda, the son of Śiva.
When referring to a worldly deity, this name/epithet usually applies to Skanda.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the grahas; the Gupta emperor Kumāragupta II; an ascetic statesman.

Apart from the usual meaning and usages (such as being a title of Mañjuśrī, etc.), this also seems to be the name of a class of nonhuman beings. The term is rendered elsewhere in this translation as “divine youth.”
A class of godlings, probabably related to yakṣas.
One of the gods’ realms; also used as the name of the gods living there.
An ancient king, contemporary of the Buddha.
A skill taught to brahmins and kings that may relate to finance or grammar.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-142 .
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Abhijñāketu.
An individual who is well versed in a particular textual lineage or lineages.
Thirty-sixth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
Sagittarius (zodiac sign and constellation); also the name of an ancient king.
The 401st buddha in the first list, 400th in the second list, and 394th in the third list.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Baladatta (425 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
The 886th buddha in the first list, 885th in the second list, and 876th in the third list.
Father of the buddha Abhedyabuddhi.
Birthplace of the buddha Vāsava.
A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
Attendant of the buddha Śāntatejas.
Birthplace of the buddha Kṣemaṃkara.
Attendant of the buddha Siṃhaketu.
Birthplace of the buddha Jyotiṣka
Mother of the buddha Sumedhas.
Son of the buddha Brahmaghoṣa.
Mother of the buddha Guṇatejas.
Birthplace of the buddha Brahmaghoṣa.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Nakṣatrarāja.
A buddha.
Birthplace of the buddha Puṣpaprabha.
Mother of the buddha Saṃjaya.
Birthplace of the buddha Sarvatejas.
Mother of the buddha Śrotriya.
Mother of the buddha Dharmakūṭa.
Son of the buddha Avabhāsadarśin.
Attendant of the buddha Mokṣavrata.
Birthplace of the buddha Nārāyaṇa.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Prabhaṃkara (46 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Birthplace of the buddha Sūryapriya.
Son of the buddha Pradyotarāja.
Mother of the buddha Amitāyus.
Son of the buddha Guṇākara.
Father of the buddha Mahādarśana.
Father of the buddha Vikrīḍitāvin.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Vikrāntadeva.

In Buddhist cosmology, the sphere of existence one level more subtle than our own (the desire realm), where beings, though subtly embodied, are not driven primarily by the urge for sense gratification.

One of the three realms of saṃsāra, this is a realm of subtle materiality presided over by Brahmā. Beings reborn in this realm are free from the coarse attachments of the desire realm but retain a subtle level of materiality.
A ruler of the Heaven Free from Strife.
First of the five fetters associated with the higher realms.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Vararūpa.
