The second of the three realms where living beings transmigrate.
One of the three realms of saṃsāra, characterized by subtle materiality and the lack of coarse desire as in the desire realm.
Eighteen paradises that comprise the realm of form, into which beings are reborn through the power of meditation. It is higher than the realm of desire, where beings are reborn through karma.

In Buddhist cosmology, the sphere of existence one level more subtle than our own (the desire realm), where beings, though subtly embodied, are not driven primarily by the urge for sense gratification. It is one of the three basic divisions of the realms of existence that constitute saṃsāra. The other two are the desire realm and the formless realm. See Gethin 1998, 116–18.
First of the five psycho-physical aggregates.
Lit. “eliminating material dirt.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Used to refer to the two form bodies of the Buddha, i.e. the nirmāṇakāya and the saṃbhogakāya.
The dimension of a buddha that corresponds to relative truth and is perceptible to either ordinary beings (nirmāṇakāya) or sublime beings (saṃbhogakāya).
“Form body.” The visible form of a buddha that is perceived by other beings, in contrast to his “Dharma body,” the dharmakāya, which is his enlightenment.
The visible form of a buddha that is perceived by other beings, in contrast to his “dharma body,” the dharmakāya, which is the eternal, imperceptible realization of a buddha.

The form or physical body of a buddha, as opposed to the Dharma body or dharmakāya. In Buddhist philosophy, the form body was eventually divided into two kinds: the nirmāṇa kāya (“emanation body”), which is a physical body, and the saṃbhogkāya (“enjoyment body”), which is an immaterial body seen only by enlightened beings.

According to the Lesser Vehicle, the buddha body of form refers to the thousand buddhas of the Auspicious Eon, including Śākyamuni. In the Great Vehicle, however, the term includes both the buddha body of perfect resource which appears in a pure light form to tenth level bodhisattvas and the buddha body of emanation which manifests physically for the sake of all beings.
Seventh of the twelve sense fields.
The middling type among the three planes of existence, where desire for coarse food or copulation is absent.
A former life of the Buddha, who was a very good-looking person.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Śreṣṭharūpa.
Eighteen paradises that comprise the realm of form, into which beings are reborn through the power of meditation. It is higher than the realm of desire, where beings are reborn through karma.
Mother of the buddha Śreṣṭharūpa.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
One of the Buddha’s former rebirths.

These are typically listed as follows: (1) the equipoise of the sense field of infinite space, (2) the equipoise of the sense field of infinite consciousness, (3) the equipoise of the sense field of nothing at all, and (4) the equipoise of neither perception nor nonperception.
The 570th buddha in the first list, 570th in the second list, and 563rd in the third list.
“Beautiful Array.” One of the bodhisattvas in the entourage of the Buddha Śākyamuni when he taught the girl Vimalaśraddhā.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
One of the three realms. See glossary s.v. three realms ({khams gsum}).
The highest of the three realms within saṃsāra, beings in the formless realm are no longer bound to even the most subtle materiality.

In Buddhist cosmology, the sphere of existence two levels more subtle than our own (the desire realm), where beings are no longer physically embodied, and thus not subject to the sufferings that physical embodiment brings.

In Buddhist cosmology, the sphere of existence two levels more subtle than our own (the desire realm), where beings are no longer physically embodied, and thus not subject to the sufferings that physical embodiment brings. It is one of the three basic divisions of the realms of existence that constitute saṃsāra. The other two are the desire realm and the form realm. See Gethin 1998, 116–18.
A deva or god in the formless realm.
Second of the five fetters associated with the higher realms.
The third and highest of the three realms where living beings transmigrate.
One of the three realms of saṃsāra, characterized by having only a subtle mental form.

In Buddhist cosmology, the sphere of existence two levels more subtle than our own (the desire realm), where beings are no longer physically embodied, and thus not subject to the sufferings that physical embodiment brings. See also “three realms.”
A deva or god in the formless realm.

These comprise the absorptions of (1) the station of endless space, (2) the station of endless consciousness, (3) the station of the nothing-at-all absorption, and (4) the station of neither perception nor nonperception.

These comprise the attainments of (1) the sense field of infinite space, (2) the sense field of infinite consciousness, (3) the sense field of nothing-at-all, and (4) the sense field of neither perception nor non-perception.

These are typically listed as follows: (1) the meditative absorption of the sense field of infinite space, (2) the meditative absorption of the sense field of infinite consciousness, (3) the meditative absorption of the sense field of nothing-at-all, and (4) the meditative absorption of neither perception nor non-perception.

As found listed in https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-174 , these comprise (1) the meditative absorption of the sense field of infinite space, (2) the meditative absorption of the sense field of infinite consciousness, (3) the meditative absorption of the sense field of nothing-at-all, and (4) the meditative absorption of neither perception nor non-perception.\nThe four formless absorptions and their fruits are discussed in Jamgon Kongtrul, TOK Book 6, Pt. 2: 436–438.

These comprise (1) the attainment of the sphere of infinite space, (2) the attainment of the sphere of infinite consciousness, (3) the attainment of the sphere of nothing whatsoever, and (4) the attainment of the sphere of neither perception nor nonperception.
The highest type among the three planes of existence, where form/materiality is either absent or, according to some, present only in its subtlest aspects.

In Buddhist cosmology, the sphere of existence two levels more subtle than our own (the desire realm), where beings are no longer physically embodied, and thus not subject to the sufferings that physical embodiment brings.
These comprise (1) the meditation of infinite space, (2) the meditation of infinite consciousness, (3) the meditation of nothingness, and (4) the meditation of neither perception nor nonperception.
Name of a meditative stabilization.
Lit. “limitless form.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
One of the grahas; also the name of a mahāsiddha.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Victorious Melody.
“Power of Beauty,” the good looking one; Prince Puṇyabala’s oldest brother, who exemplifies beauty.
An absorption.
Name of a meditative absorption.
A world realm in the distant past.
This bodhisattva asks Vimalakīrti the whereabouts of his family, etc., thus prompting the latter’s extraordinary verses on the family and accoutrements of all bodhisattvas (Chap. 8).

Term for a deva belonging to the realm of form, which is the second of the three realms of existence according to Buddhist cosmology, rebirth in which is achieved through mastering meditative techniques known as the four dhyānas or meditative absorptions; this realm has seventeen subdivisions. The beings reborn here possess ethereal physical bodies and experience only three senses: sight, hearing, and touch. Attachment to material objects is in general less than in the desire realm (Skt. kāmadhātu).
One of the five aggregates, that which gives rise to physical qualities.
Physical forms include the subtle and manifest forms derived from the material elements.
The first of the five aggregates: the subtle and manifest forms derived from the material elements.
The first of the five aggregates; but also, in this sūtra, “inner form” within consciousness (see https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-044-003.html#UT22084-044-003-48 ).

The first of the five skandhas, defined in Abhidharma literature as anything composed of the four “great elements” of earth, water, fire, and wind. Often rendered as “matter,” “material form,” or “form.”

The first of the five aggregates, defined in Abhidharma literature as anything comprised of the four major elements (earth, air, fire, and water), either alone or in combination. Also rendered here as “material form.”
This term can also mean “comprehensible speech,” in contrast to {gzung ba med pa'i tshig} (agrahaṇapada) or “incomprehensible speech.” See Negi (1993-2005): 5505.
Name of a nāga king.
To accept (e.g., a person) as a novice.
A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
The term used to describe both the scriptures and the deities of the “five protectress goddesses” popular in the Mahāyāna-Vajrayāna tradition.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Dharaṇīdhara.
A buddha in the distant past.
Lit. “Intelligence of Dhāraṇī.”
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha.
Name of the ninety-fifth meditative stability.
Lit. “dhāraṇī wisdom.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Name of a bodhisattva.
The name of a Bodhisattva. The principal interlocutor of The Teaching on the Great Compassion of the Tathāgata, where he also gives a discourse of his own.
A bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Prabhaṃkara.
Son of the buddha Brahmavāsa.
Son of the buddha Śubha cīrṇa buddhi.

A technical term employed in The Dhāraṇī of the Vajra Quintessence to signify the fact that all phenomena are inherently liberated, and thus bear the intrinsic quality of liberation as their very basis.
Father of the buddha Brahmavasu.
Name of the nineteenth meditative stability.
This is another term used for dhāraṇī that is meant to convey, among other meanings, the idea that a dhāraṇī seals or stamps upon the reciter or the targeted phenomenon the nature that it embodies.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Puṇyapradīpa.
A mnemonic, or a means by which one remembers material.
A method, often in the form of a spell, that leads to the infinite qualities of awakening.

As a magical formula, a dhāraṇī constitutes a gateway to the infinite qualities of awakening, the awakened state itself, and the various forms of buddha activity. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-039-002.html#UT22084-039-002-4 .
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.

The incantations, or spells, are mnemonic formulas, possessed by advanced bodhisattvas, that contain a quintessence of their attainments, not simply magical charms—although the latter are included. The same term in Sanskrit and Tibetan also refers to a highly developed power present in bodhisattvas that is a process of memory and recall of detailed teachings, best translated “retention” in certain contexts.

The term dhāraṇī has the sense of something that “holds” or “retains,” and as such can refer to the special capacity of practitioners to memorize and recall detailed teachings. It can also refer to a verbal expression of the teachings‍—an incantation, spell, or mnemonic formula that distills and “holds” essential points of the Dharma and is used by practitioners to attain mundane and supramundane goals. The same term is also used to denote texts that contain such formulae.

This term has several meanings. Often it refers to a ritual incantation that usually encapsulates the meaning of a longer text. In this sense it is considered to assist in the retention of the text and imbue the one who recites it with a variety of desired powers. At other times this term carries the meaning of “holding” or “retaining,” and so it is frequently used in reference to memory and learning. In the context of this text, the term carries both of these meanings. Finally, this term can also be applied as a classificatory term to Buddhist scriptures that contain one or more such incantations.

Literally, “retention” (the ability to remember), or “that which retains, contains, or encapsulates,” this term refers to mnemonic formulas or codes possessed by advanced bodhisattvas that contain the quintessence of their attainments, as well as the Dharma teachings that express them and guide beings toward their realization. They are therefore often described in terms of “gateways” for entering the Dharma and training in its realization, or “seals” that contain condensations of truths and their expression. The term can also refer to a statement or incantation meant to protect or bring about a particular result. Also translated here as “retention.”

The term dhāraṇī—in some sūtras a mnemonic formula and also the ability of realized beings to retain (√dhṛ) in their transmundane memory any teachings—refers, in its most general use, to dhāraṇīs as understood in the context of the Dhāraṇī genre and Mahāyāna Buddhism. Such dhāraṇīs are divinely revealed prayer formulae that are dedicated to a particular deity and typically include homage, praise, supplication, exhortation to act, and, most importantly, the heart mantra or mantras of the deity. The specific meaning of “retention” is also present in this inasmuch as dhāraṇīs, once obtained, are never lost but stay with the person who obtained them. They function as doors (dhāraṇīdvāra) or access points (dhāraṇīmukha) to infinite qualities of buddhahood. Even shorter mantras, when they are regarded as functioning in this way, can be designated as dhāraṇī.

The ability to remember all Dharma teachings that are heard. In other contexts, a dhāraṇi is a powerful recitation that is a precursor of mantras and is usually in the form of intelligible sentences or phrases that preserve or retain the essence of a teaching. There are two sets of “four retentions” in relation to this text. (A) As explained in the sūtra itself in chapter 24 ( https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-055-001.html#UT22084-055-001-2336 ): the retention, respectively, of teachings on composites, on sounds, on kleśas, and on purifications. (B) As explained in the commentary to the opening of the sūtra (1.2, see https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-055-001.html#UT22084-055-001-93 ): the recited dhāraṇī sentences and phrases themselves, the retention of the memory of the words of all teachings given, the retention of the memory of the meaning of these teachings, and the retention of the realization gained through meditation on that meaning.
One of the vidyārājas dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
“Oblation eater”; another name of Agni, the god of fire.
The name of one of the wrathful forms of Vajrapāṇi; in the Sampuṭodbhava he is also referred to as Krodhavijaya or simply Krodha.
The first of the eight cold hells, named after the cries of the beings within it.
Indian plant; a deadly poison.
A krodha accomplished by the brahmin Pāṇini.
A species of snake, or the poison from this snake.
A mythological poison said to have been produced by demonic forces in their fight against the gods.
A flower belonging to the {lcam pa} family, a type of malva flower used in Tibetan medicine.
Name of a nāga king; a monkey god; Rāma's companion and devotee in the Rāmāyaṇa.
A monkey king (a character in the Rāmāyaṇa).
One of the two pīlavas.
A country in the east of India, roughly corresponding to modern Bengal.
One of the goddesses in the retinue of Heruka.
The wrathful form of Akṣobhya, buddha of the vajra family, who appears in the center of many tantric maṇḍalas. He is typicaly depicted wearing mortuary implements and wreathed in flame.

The wrathful buddha personifying the true nature of all forms and all the sensory fields and elements; a wrathful deity of the vīra type; also an epithet applied to some wrathful deities, especially Hevajra and Saṃvara.
Enhydra fluctuans.
Unidentified river, possibly the Kali Gandaki.
One of the two auxiliary chandohas.
A central Asian region, at times referring to Mongolia.
A nāga.
An unvirtuous nāga king.
A nāga king.
A certain nāga king converted by Mādhyandina during his missionary work in Kashmir.
One of the nāga kings. (Huluḍa is one of several possible spellings.)
From the Chinese 和上 (heshang) derived from the Sanskrit upādhyāya, a senior, learned monk.
A kind of sugar.
Cucumis trigonus; colocynth, a wild bitter gourd, Cucumis colocynthis; the favorite plant of Indra and Varuṇa.
“Mañjuśrī the ever youthful,” a common epithet of Mañjuśrī.
A senior minister at the court of the Chinese king Cayang.
The quality or condition of things as they really are, which cannot be conveyed in conceptual, dualistic terms. Akin to other terms rendered here as “suchness,” “the real,” and “natural state.”
Eleventh of the eleven aspects of knowledge.
The quality or condition of things as they really are, which cannot be conveyed in conceptual, dualistic terms. Akin to other terms rendered here as “suchness,” “the real,” and “natural state.”
A river in Majestic Trees.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
The king of rākṣasas (a character in the Rāmāyaṇa).
With the meaning of “truly, really, indeed.”
Name of Maitreya in a previous lifetime as a bodhisattva.
The Bengali Buddhist master (980–1054) who came to Tibet, and whose pupils founded the Kadampa tradition.

A great fourteenth century (1299–1354) Jonangpa scholar of Sanskrit and translator, student of Dolpopa, who had earlier studied at Sangphu and Sakya. He is best known for his revised translations, made with Sabzang Mati Paṇchen, of the Kālacakra tantra and Vimala prabhā.
A nāga king.
A forest in Promotion.
A river in the Deccan.
A river in Jambudvīpa.
A river in the south of Jambudvīpa.
Dicliptera paniculata .
An island in the sea west of Jambudvīpa.
A deadly poison that originated when the gods and asuras churned the oceans to create the nectar of immortality.
“Black Form.” This seems to be an epithet of Mūrdhaṭaka, one of the wrathful emanations of Mañjuśrī.
One of the sixteen great kingdoms of ancient India.
One of the two kṣetras.

“Beauty of Kāśi.” Princess of Vārāṇasī, child of Brahmadatta (present), who was extraordinarily beautiful and desired by six royal suitors. When her father announced she would choose her own spouse, she “chose” the Buddha, went forth, and manifested arhatship.
One of the sixteen great kingdoms of ancient India.
Country whose capital was Vārāṇasī, in the Buddha’s time it had been absorbed into Kośala. Its monarch was Brahmadatta (past).
Ancient name for Vārāṇasī, the holy city on the banks of the Gaṅgā, this name can be applied also to the surrounding country or district. It lies in modern day Uttar Pradesh, India.
One of the great śrāvakas in the maṇḍala of Mañjuśrī, probably the same one that is listed among the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Name of an elder and senior disciple of Buddha Śākyamuni.
Son of She Who Gathers and grandson of Padmagarbha, he was a highly realized monk of Buddha Śākyamuni’s order. Also rendered here as “Kātyāyanaputra.”
Son of She Who Gathers and grandson of Padmagarbha, he was a highly realized monk of Buddha Śākyamuni’s order. Also rendered here as “Kātyāyanaputra.”
Lit. “Descended from the Sage Kati.” One of the ten principal śrāvaka disciples of the Buddha. He was renowned for his ability to understand the Buddha’s teachings.
Śrāvaka arhat.
One of the Buddha’s foremost hearer disciples.
One of the hearers present during the delivery of the sūtra.
One of the ten principal pupils of the Buddha. He was renowned for his ability to understand the Buddha’s teachings. Also rendered as “Kātyāyana.”
A monk (bhikṣu) and disciple of the Buddha.
Hearer present in the circle around Śākyamuni.
One of the six outsider teachers.
A coin of variable value, sometimes worth as little as a burnt bun and other times equal to twenty gold coins.
A coin that varied in value according as to whether it was made of gold, silver, or copper. It is presumably the latter, lower-value one that is being referred to here.
Strychnos potatorum.
A land to the north of Jambudvīpa.
Tibetan translator (fl. late eighth–early ninth centuries).
Kashmir
This seems to be the ancient name of Arakan, or what is now the Rakhine State in Myanmar.
A mythical Indian bird renowned for its beautiful call. Some dictionaries equate it with the Indian cuckoo (or other Indian songbirds), while other sources will attribute mythical qualities to it.

A bird said to have a song sweeter than any other. Sometimes said to refer to the avadavat, sometimes to the Indian Cuckoo, but used as a simile it is a reference that is partly mythical; the kalaviṅka is said to sing sublimely even before being hatched.

Several species of finch belonging to the genus Amandava, part of the Estrildid finch family (Estrildidae). They are renowned as songbirds, and in Tibetan texts the Sanskrit kalaviṅka was sometimes simply transliterated ka la ping ka, sometimes translated as khu byug, “cuckoo.”

Also called red avadavats, strawberry finches, and kalaviṅka sparrows. Dictionaries have erroneously identified them as cuckoos, and kalaviṅka birds outside India have evolved into a mythical half human bird. The avadavat is a significant bird in the Ganges plain and renowned for its beautiful song.

In Buddhist literature refers to a mythical bird with the head of a human and the body of a bird. The kalaviṅka’s call is said to be far more beautiful than that of all other birds and so compelling that it could be heard even before the bird has hatched. The call of the kalaviṅka is also used as an analogy to describe the voice of the Buddha.

An Indian bird renowned for its beautiful song. There is some uncertainty regarding the identity of the kalaviṅka, as some dictionaries declare it to be a type of Indian cuckoo (probably Eudynamys scolopacea, also known as the asian koel) or a red and green sparrow (possibly Amandava amandava, also known as the red avadavat). Within the Buddhist sūtras, the bird is usually linked to its pleasing or striking voice. In some cases, it has also taken on mythical characteristics, being described as part human, part bird. Here it is the sixteenth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
Convolvulus repens, Ipomoea aquatica.
A bamboo forest near Rājagṛha.

Literally, the “Squirrel Feeding Ground.” A location within the Veṇuvana where the Buddha Śākyamuni stayed. The place received its name from the many squirrels living there, being fed by humans. It should be noted that Tibetan translations misunderstand the Sanskrit term kalandaka to be a kind of bird (Tib. {bya}).

A place where the Buddha often resided, within the Bamboo Park (Veṇuvana) outside Rajagṛha that had been donated to him. The name is said to have arisen when, one day, King Bimbisāra fell asleep after a romantic liaison in the Bamboo Park. While the king rested, his consort wandered off. A snake (the reincarnation of the park’s previous owner, who still resented the king’s acquisition of the park) approached with malign intentions. Through the king’s tremendous merit, a gathering of kalandaka—crows or other birds according to Tibetan renderings, but some Sanskrit and Pali sources suggest flying squirrels—miraculously appeared and began squawking. Their clamor alerted the king’s consort to the danger, who rushed back and hacked the snake to pieces, thereby saving the king’s life. King Bimbisāra then named the spot Kalandakanivāpa (“Kalandakas’ Feeding Ground”), sometimes (though not in the Vinayavastu) given as Kalandakanivāpa (“Kalandakas’ Abode”) in their honor. The story is told in the https://read.84000.co/translation/toh1-17.html (Toh 1, ch.17, Degé Kangyur vol.4, folio 77.b et seq.).

A grove or forest within the Veṇuvana near Rājagṛha, where Buddha Śākyamuni spent several monsoon retreats and delivered many Great Vehicle teachings. In other texts it is known as the Kalandakanivāsa or °nivāpa, the dwelling place or feeding ground of kalandaka—crows or other birds according to Tibetan renderings, but some Sanskrit and Pali sources suggest flying squirrels.
A town in South India.
A buddha.
A country.
One of the two chandohas.
An ancient country on the Coromandel Coast.
An ancient kingdom on the eastern coast of the Indian subcontinent, roughly equivalent to the modern state of Odisha.
An evil king.
Solanum nigrum.
An Indian scholar who was involved in a number of translations during the eleventh century in Tibet.

Indian Buddhist master (713–763) who came to Tibet in the late 8th century. Said to have been assassinated after a debate with the representatives of Chinese Buddhism. A later legend has him return to India and come back in another body in the eleventh century as the master Padampa Sangye.
Solanum nigrum.
Western Assam.
A king of the Kushan empire in the second century ce.
A monk disciple of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
A principal teacher of the monastic saṅgha during the Buddha’s lifetime. Described as pale skinned and with a prominent nose.
Śrāvaka arhat.
A monk (bhikṣu) and disciple of the Buddha.
Hearer present in the circle around Śākyamuni.
One of the disciples of the Buddha.
A monk disciple of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
One of the principal disciples of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
A principal teacher of the monastic saṅgha during the Buddha’s lifetime.
Caves on the northern border of the Middle Country earlier in the current eon, during the time of the Buddha Kanakamuni.
Limonia acidissima according to the Pandanus Database of Plants.
Nerium indicum.
A bird of a red color whose voice has been described as like thunder or the sound of a drum.
An area in Kuru.
Kārttikeya (alt. Skanda) is the son of Śiva and Pārvatī. Like Gaṇapati, Kārttikeya is said to lead the gaṇas in battle against demonic beings and is considered a god of war.
The grass Saccharum spontaneum, native to Indian subcontinent.
Cotton from Vārāṇasī, the capital of the ancient kingdom of Kashi, renowned as the best.
The perennially famous silk from the north Indian city now named Vārānasī/Benares.
Capital of the ancient country of Kāśi, west of Magadha and north of Kośala, where the Buddha first taught the Dharma.
Ancient name for Vārāṇasī, the holy city on the banks of the Gaṅgā, this name can be applied also to the surrounding country or district. It lies in modern day Uttar Pradesh, India.
A country or a city named the same.
Alternative name for the Indian city of Vārāṇasī.
Another name for Vārāṇasī or Benares, a city known for its fine garments and embroidery.
Ancient name for Vārāṇasī, the holy city on the banks of the Gaṅgā, this name can be applied also to the surrounding country or district. It lies in modern day Uttar Pradesh, India.
A city near Sarnath, where the Buddha gave his first sermon; this name can be applied also to the surrounding country or district. The name is rendered elsewhere in this translation as “Kāśī.”

Saccharum spontaneum. A species of tall grass, native to the Indian subcontinent, topped by beautiful long feather-like white panicles. It is used in religious ceremonies, Ayurvedic medicine, and also for making mats, roofs, and so on.
Cinnamomum camphora.
Strychnos potatorum; clearing nut.
One of the members of a group of four monks described in the Vinaya as followers of Devadatta that attempted to create a schism in the Buddhist saṅgha.
One of four cronies of Devadatta.
‟Great Kātyāyanī,” one of the eight kātyāyanī spirits.
‟Violent Kātyāyanī,” one of the eight kātyāyanī spirits.
‟Radiantly Beautiful Kātyāyanī,” one of the eight kātyāyanī spirits.
‟Kātyāyanī Face of Victory,” one of the eight kātyāyanī spirits.
‟Kātyāyanī with Earrings,” one of the eight kātyāyanī spirits.
‟Divine Kātyāyanī,” one of the eight kātyāyanī spirits.
Usually an epithet of the goddess Durgā, in the Bhūtaḍāmara Tantra this term refers to a class of wild and powerful female spirits.
Strychnos potatorum; clearing nut.

An epithet for softness, usually applied to cloth, and probably in reference, directly or metaphorically, to the down of the kācilindika bird. See Lamotte, Etienne. La Concentration de la Marche Héroïque. Bruxelles: Peeters (1975), p. 261, n. 321. The Mahāvyutpatti includes the term using the variant spelling kācalindika.

An epithet for softness, probably in reference, direct or metaphorical, to the down of the kācilindika bird (see Lamotte, Etienne. La Concentration de la Marche Héroïque. Bruxelles: Peeters (1975), p261, n321).
A woman who was the Buddha’s mother in a former life.

A woman who, because she had previously been the Buddha’s mother for five hundred lifetimes, saw him as her son and ran to embrace him. Then, hearing the Dharma from him, she became ordained and manifested arhatship, and the Buddha declared her foremost among nuns who interpret the sūtras.
One of the six tīrthika teachers contemporaneous with Śākyamuni. Also rendered here as “Kakuda, a descendant of Kātyāyana.”
(also Kātyāyana). Disciple of the Buddha noted for his skill in analysis of the Buddha’s discourses and, traditionally, the founder of the Abhidharma.
One of the ten principal pupils of the Buddha. He was foremost in explaining the Dharma.

(also Mahākātyāyana). Disciple of the Buddha noted for his skill in analysis of the Buddha’s discourses and, traditionally, the founder of the Abhidharma. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-060-005.html#UT22084-060-005-936 .
A member of the Śākya clan.
Piper cubeba florence.
A clairvoyant sage who lived with five hundred devotees in the forests of the Adumā region and spent time on the banks of Lake Mandākinī. His nephew was the sage Śaila.
A nāga king.

“One with the Face of Karkoṭa.” One of the eight nāga queens.
Successive incarnations as the heads of the Karma Kagyu tradition, beginning with Dusum Khyenpa ({dus gsum mkhyen pa}, 1110–1193).
(1) The king of the country of Kuru. (2) A king in the past.
An ancient city, capital of Vatsa, located down the Ganges River from Rājagṛha.
Home to a group of troublesome monks who quarreled with monks from Vaiśālī.
An ancient kingdom, northwest of Magadha, abutting Kāśi, whose capital was Śrāvastī. During the Buddha’s time it was ruled by King Prasenajit.
A river on Excellence of Exquisite Intelligence.
A mountain on the northern border of the Middle Country earlier in the current eon, during the time of the Buddha Krakucchanda.
An epithet of the god Śakra .
Alternative name of Śakra, lord of the gods.
Another name of Śakra; see definition for “Śakra.”
(1) A river in the east of Jambudvīpa. (2) A river in the ephemeral hell known as Red.
A rishi, usually said to be identical with Viśvamati, but his son and descendants also carried this name.
Another name for Indra. Kauśika, Śakra, and Indra all refer to the same god, of central importance in the Vedas, who in Buddhist cosmology is regarded as the king of gods in the realm of desire.
One of the five former spiritual friends with whom Gautama had practiced meditation before his awakening.
The court priest in the Buddha’s father’s kingdom, he predicted the Buddha’s enlightenment, and was the first of the Buddha’s pupils to become an arhat.
Alternate name for “Kauṇḍinya.” Literally “of the Kauṇḍinya family.”

The court priest in the Buddha’s father’s kingdom, who predicted the Buddha’s enlightenment. He became one of the Buddha’s five companions in asceticism. They renounced him when he abandoned asceticism but after his enlightenment they became his pupils. Kauṇḍinya was the first to convert to being his pupil and was the first of his pupils to become an arhat. Also called “Kauṇḍinyagotra” and “Ājñāta kauṇḍinya.”
A land to the west of Jambudvīpa.
A stone sometimes identified as cat’s eye.

This stone is not a type of beryl in spite of its name. The Tibetan has adopted the Prakrit form of its name: ke ke ru. It is the third hardest gemstone. It comes in three main varieties: the eponymous yellow or green chrysoberyl; cat’s eye (cymophane), which is light green or yellow with a band of light, resembling a cat’s eye; and the third form, alexandrite, which can change color from red to green to yellow according to the light. All three kinds have been mined since ancient times, in Sri Lanka in particular.
A ṛṣi.
Kesara can be the name of several species of plants.
Mesua ferrea, specifically “Ceylon ironwood,” also called Indian rose chestnut, Cobra’s saffron, and nāgakesara. The flowers are large and fragrant, with four white petals and a yellow center.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
A class of vidyādharas.
Pandanus odoratissimus.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
A land in the south of Jambudvīpa.
A bodhisattva of the past.
Butea frondosa, also known as flame of the forest; a tree with bright red flowers.
A land to the north of Jambudvīpa.
A staff with a single or three pointed tip and a freshly decapitated head, a rotting head and a skull skewered on its shaft.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
Synonymous with Himavat. This “mountain” is actually the entire Himalayan range.
The Himalayan mountain range
An alternative name for the Himalayas.
One of the two auxiliary chandohas.

The sūtra contains the only known reference to a nāga king and kinnara king who both have this name in Sanskrit. The nāga’s name was translated into Tibetan as “hundred mouths” ({kha brgya pa}), and the kinnara as “hundred faces” ({bzhin brgya pa}). Other deities with the name Śatamukha appear in Indian literature.
One of the rāśis.
Place in northwestern India.
The https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_subcontinent
A country.
Father of the buddha Amogharaśmi.
The name of a māra in another world in the distant past.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Varuṇa (72 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Listed in The Question of Mañjuśrī as the fourth of the thirty-two signs of a great being. This sign is not mentioned in any of the other lists of thirty-two that we have investigated.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A type of worm ({srin bu}) that lives in and feeds on the body.
A mountain on the northern border of the Middle Country earlier in the current eon, during the time of the Buddha Kanakamuni.
A buddha realm.
One of the twelve retentions of the bodhisattvas.
A nāga king.

An acceptable form of cloth for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual. In this case, a “fitting color” has equal shades of blue, yellow, and saffron while “ill-colored” means exclusively blue, yellow, or saffron.
A bodhisattva who seeks a prophecy from Śākyamuni.

An acceptable form of cloth for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual. In this case, a “fitting color” has equal shades of blue, yellow, and saffron while “ill-colored” means exclusively blue, yellow, or saffron.
A nāga king.
Birthplace of the buddha Jitaśatru.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Harivaktra (992 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
The seventh of the ten nonvirtuous actions (see ten nonvirtuous courses of action).
An architectural element similar to a pedestal.
Name of a mountain in present day Bihar, possibly at Barabar. The mention of it in this sūtra, as its setting, is the only mention at all in the Kangyur.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha in the realm of Enduring.
Birthplace of the buddha Gaṇiprabha.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Jñānakrama.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Padmaskandha.
Attendant of the buddha Vibhaktatejas.
Mother of the buddha Sūryānana.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Lokapriya.
Attendant of the buddha Vratasthita.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
Son of the buddha Anāvilārtha.
Mother of the buddha Jñānākara.
Father of the buddha Anantavikrāmin.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Atyuccagāmin.
Son of the buddha Mahāsthāman.
Son of the buddha Viśiṣṭa svarāṅga.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Guṇadhvaja.
The 295th buddha in the first list, 294th in the second list, and 294th in the third list.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Oghajaha.
Birthplace of the buddha Śīlaprabha.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Parasites that are said to live in the noses of women.
A type of worm ({srin bu}) that lives in and feeds on the body.
Son of the buddha Brahmaruta.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Kusuma (9) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A country north of India.

An alternative name for the ancient kingdom of Khotan which was located on the southern branch of the Silk Road that passed through the Tarim Basin. The kingdom, which was an important oasis and center for trade, existed during the first millennium ᴄᴇ.

A tribe of people from the northwest of India and central Asia who were significant in ancient India and are described in the Mahābhārata as having taken part in the Kurukṣetra war on the side of the Kurus against the Paṇḍavas. The Purāṇic literature generally describes them in a negative light, as barbarians. They are often mentioned in Buddhist literature and presently maintain Khasa culture in Himachal Pradesh.
The name of a karmic wind involved in the formation of an embryo in its thirty-eighth week.
One of the members of a group of four monks described in the Vinaya as followers of Devadatta that attempted to create a schism in the Buddhist saṅgha.
A mountain off Videha.
A type of worm ({srin bu}) that lives in and feeds on the body.
A yakṣa general.
A yakṣa king.
A yakṣa usually paired with Kharakarṇa.
A measure of capacity for commodities, especially barley, etc. (1 {khal} = 20 bre). See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-212 .
One of the four kinds of food.
The first of the four nourishments.
The objects, sense faculties, and forms of consciousness that are associated with form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and mental phenomena. See also “element.”

One way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements (eye, form, and eye consciousness; ear, sound, and ear consciousness; nose, odor, and nose consciousness; tongue, taste, and tongue consciousness; body, touch, and body consciousness; mind, mental phenomena, and mind consciousness).

The eighteen sensory elements, as listed in https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-151 , comprise (1) the sensory element of the eyes, (2) the sensory element of sights, and (3) the sensory element of visual consciousness; (4) the sensory element of the ears, (5) the sensory element of sounds, and (6) the sensory element of auditory consciousness; (7) the sensory element of the nose, (8) the sensory element of odors, and (9) the sensory element of olfactory consciousness; (10) the sensory element of the tongue, (11) the sensory element of tastes, and (12) the sensory element of gustatory consciousness; (13) the sensory element of the body, (14) the sensory element of tangibles, and (15) the sensory element of tactile consciousness; and (16) the sensory element of the mental faculty, (17) the sensory element of mental phenomena, and (18) the sensory element of mental consciousness.

Eighteen collections of similar dharmas under which all coproduced and unproduced dharmas may be included: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and thought, plus their objects—visible forms, sounds, smells, flavors, tangibles, and dharmas—plus the consciousnesses corresponding to each of the first six. The eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and thought are the basis for the arising of consciousness, though here there is the technical sense of a prior moment in any of the six consciousnesses. The first five consciousnesses depend on the five sense faculties as their basis, while the basis for the thought consciousness can be any of the six consciousnesses but not a sense faculty. Hence thought is classified among the dhātus (“elements”) in the section meant to offer a complete list of the possible bases of consciousness, i.e., what is most frequently listed as the second set of six elements.\nThe term dhātu is explained as having the sense of an ore (gotra), like a mineral ore, hence a point of origin (ākara). The bases are the points of origin for the arising of similar dharmas. The Nibandhana commentary on Distinctly Ascertaining the Meanings explains that the order of enumeration of the eighteen bases can be explained in terms of the specific way in which different sense faculties operate within their domains or in terms of the placement (from higher to lower) of the eye faculty, the ear faculty, and so forth. The Abhidharmakośa https://read.84000.co/translation/toh4089.html explains that the teaching of the bases is for those who are of weaker abilities, since it is very detailed; it is for those who prefer special insight meditation (vipaśyanā), because it contains extensive analysis; and it counteracts a delusion of “self” that is evenly distributed between sentient and nonsentient elements, since the eighteen bases offer an analysis both of form and of mind and mental derivatives.

The eighteen constituents through which sensory experience is produced: the six sense faculties (indriya); the six corresponding sense objects (ālambana); and the six sensory consciousnesses (vijñāna).\nWhen grouped these are: the eye constituent, form constituent, and eye consciousness constituent; the ear constituent, sound constituent, and ear consciousness constituent; the nose constituent, smell constituent, and nose consciousness constituent; the tongue constituent, taste constituent, and tongue consciousness constituent; the body constituent, touch constituent, and body consciousness constituent; the thinking-mind constituent, dharma constituent, and thinking-mind consciousness constituent.\nSee also “constituents.”
The four “great” outer elements (mahābhūta, {'byung ba chen po}): earth, water, fire, and air. See also “element.”
A region in South India.
An island beyond Videha.
The usual four—earth, water, fire, and air—plus space and consciousness.
The 800th buddha in the first list, 799th in the second list, and 789th in the third list.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Mahāraśmi.
The desire realm, form realm, and formless realm.
The formless realm, the form realm, and the desire realm, comprised of thirty-one planes of existence in Buddhist cosmology.
(1) The desire realm (kāmadhātu, {'dod khams}), (2) the form realm (rūpadhātu, {gzugs khams}), and (3) the formless realm (arūpyadhātu, {gzugs med khams}).
A bodhisattva.
The formless realm, the form realm, and the desire realm comprising the thirty-one planes of existence in Buddhist cosmology.
The three realms that contain all the various kinds of existence in saṃsāra: the desire realm, the form realm, and the formless realm.
The three worlds or realms of which all universes are composed: of desire (kāmadhātu), of pure matter (rūpadhātu), and the immaterial realm (ārūpyadhātu).
Usually synonymous with the three realms of desire, form, and formlessness. Sometimes it means the realms of devas above, humans on the ground, and nāgas below ground.

The three worlds are the desire realm (kāmadhātu, {'dod khams}), the form realm (rūpadhātu, {gzugs khams}) and the formless realm (ārūpyadhātu, {gzugs med khams}). These three worlds include all of saṃsāra.

The three realms are the desire realm (kāmadhātu, {'dod khams}), form realm (rūpadhātu, {gzugs khams}) and the formless realm (ārūpyadhātu, {gzugs med khams}), i.e., the three worlds that make up saṃsāra. The first is composed of the six sorts of beings (gods, asuras, humans, animals, hungry ghosts, and hell beings), whereas the latter two are only realms of gods and are thus higher, more ethereal states of saṃsāra. See also three realms of existence.
Desire, anger, and delusion: as a collective term for this common set of the three basic kleśas, this appears to be unique to this sūtra.
Ca. eleventh century; a Tibetan translator who translated ninety-three sādhanas that are grouped together under his name in the Tibetan canon.
Earth, water, fire, and wind. Also called “four great elements.”
A bodhisattva.

One way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements (eye and form, ear and sound, nose and odor, tongue and taste, body and physical objects, and mind and mental objects, to which the six consciousnesses are added). It can also refer to the four elements of earth, water, fire, and wind, or the six elements when space and consciousness are included with those four.

The list of dhātus in the sense of “elements” comprises the four great elements (see “great elements”) of earth, water, heat, and wind, plus space and consciousness, and is a list specifically designed to describe the assemblage of conditions that makes it possible for a new moment of consciousness to arise after the last moment of consciousness at death, i.e., it is meant to explain the process of rebirth.

Often translated “element,” commonly in the context of the eighteen elements of sensory experience (the six sense faculties, their six respective objects, and the six sensory consciousnesses), although the term has a wide range of other meanings. Along with the aggregates (Skt. skandha) and the sense bases (Skt. āyatana), one of the three major categories in the taxonomy of phenomena in the sūtra literature.

One way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements: eye, form, and eye consciousness; ear, sound, and ear consciousness; nose, odor, and nose consciousness; tongue, taste, and tongue consciousness; body, touch, and body consciousness; mind, mental objects, and mind consciousness. These eighteen cognitive elements are listed in The Transcendent Perfection of Wisdom in Ten Thousand Lines, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh11.html#UT22084-031-002-151.

In the context of epistemology, it is one way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements (eye, form, and eye consciousness; ear, sound, and ear consciousness; nose, odor, and nose consciousness; tongue, taste, and tongue consciousness; body, touch, and body consciousness; mind, mental phenomena, and mind consciousness).\nThese also refer to the elements of the physical world, which can be enumerated as four, five, or six elements. The four elements are earth, water, fire, and air. A fifth, space, is often added. The six elements are earth, water, fire, air, space, and consciousness.

Depending on the context, may translate either: (a) Skt. mahābhūta, Tib. {'byung ba chen po}, the four “main” or “great” outer elements of earth, water, fire, air, and (when there is a fifth) space; or: (b) Skt. dhātu, Tib. khams, the “eighteen elements” introduce, in the context of the aggregates, elements, and sense-media, the same six pairs as the twelve sense-media, as elements of experience, adding a third member to each set: the element of consciousness (vijñāna), or sense. Hence the first pair gives the triad eye-element (caksur dhātu), form-element (rūpadhātu), and eye-consciousness-element, or eye-sense-element (caksur vijñāna dhātu)—and so on with the other five, noting the last, mind-element (manodhātu), phenomena-element (dharma dhātu), and mental-sense-element (mano vijñāna dhātu).
A forest that is burned to the ground by Kṛṣṇa and Arjuna in the conclusion to the first book (ādiparvan) of the Mahā bhārata.
One of four cronies of Devadatta.

The Sanskrit term vimāna can refer to a multi-storied mansion or palace, or even an estate, but is more often used in the sense of a celestial chariot of the gods, sometimes taking the form of a multi-storied palace; hence the Tibetan translation, {khang brtsegs}, literally “storied house.”
Refers to Encircled by a Thousand Houses in Ornament of the Mind.
A prince; a previous life of the buddha Śāntagati (701 according to the third enumeraiton).
A pleasure grove in Shaded by Garlands.
A realm in which Musulundha resides.
A mansion in Sudharma.
The palace or meeting-hall of the gods in the Heaven of the Thirty-three.
An acceptable form of shelter for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual. Also estate.
The hamlet from which Maitreya comes.
The modern-day Rāptīnadī. L. Chandra gives Ajiravatī for the Tib. {khyams ldan}.
A hall near Vaiśālī where the Buddha frequently stayed.
A park in Tamer of Madness.
A seaside town in South India.
An acceptable form of shelter for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual. Also, terraced cottage, tower, pavilion, penthouse, etc.

An important early monastery outside of Vaiśālī. The name Kūṭāgāraśālā means “hall with an upper chamber.” It refers to a temple with one ground-floor room and at least one additional upper room within the structure.

Distinctive Indian assembly hall or temple with one ground-floor room and a high ornamental roof, either a barrel shape with apses or, more usually, a tapering roof as a tower dome or spire, containing at least one additional upper room within the structure. Kūṭāgāra literally means “upper chamber” and is short for kūṭāgāraśala (“hall with an upper chamber or chambers”). The Mahābodhi Temple in Bodhgaya is an example of a kūṭāgāra.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
An acceptable form of shelter for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
Phoenix sylvestre Roxb.
A type of worm ({srin bu}) that lives in and feeds on the body.
Son of the buddha Abhyudgata.
A buddha who is not listed in the first or second list but is 771st in the third list.
The 486th buddha in the first list, 485th in the second list, and 479th in the third list.
Father of the buddha Madaprahīṇa.

In Sanskrit, the term is almost synonymous with dveṣa (see “aversion”), but in Tibetan is differentiated following Mahāvyutpatti S. 1945. The present text contains this particular term’s widely quoted canonical gloss. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-046-002.html#UT22084-046-002-173 and https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-046-002.html#UT22084-046-002-547 .

The first buddha of our eon; the fifth buddha of the “seven generations of buddhas” ({sangs rgyas rab bdun}); there are variants of the Sanskrit (Kakutsunda, Kukucchanda) and the Tibetan {log pa da sel} seems to refer to the same buddha.
Monarch ruling over the four continents of human beings.

Also known as Benares, the oldest city of northeast India in the Gangetic plain. It was once the capital of its own small kingdom and was known by various names. It was an important religious center, as well as a major city in India, even during the time of the Buddha. The name may derive from being where the Varuna and Assi rivers flow into the Ganges.
Name of a mountain range in Buddhist cosmology.
Name of a god who personifies a mountain of this name. See Cakravāḍa.
A ring of mountains marking the circumference of the world in ancient Buddhist cosmology.
Means “Great Periphery.” Name of mountain range that surrounds the world according to Buddhist cosmology.
This appears to refer to the great circles of mountains that enclose a thousand worlds, each with its own Cakravāla.
“Great Cakravāla,” an epithet for the ring of mountains forming the periphery of a world system in Buddhist cosmology.
An ocean beyond Videha.
A mountain in this sūtra and many others; but, in systematized Buddhist cosmology, the name of the ring of mountains that surrounds the world.
In Buddhist cosmology, this is commonly described as the outer ring of mountains at the edge of the flat disk that is the world, with Mount Sumeru in the center.
God personifying the ring of mountains surrounding the ocean that encompasses the four continents; the horizontal edge of the world in traditional Buddhist cosmology.

“Circular mass.” In this sūtra it is the name of the outer ring of mountains at the edge of the flat disk that is the world, with Sumeru in the center. However, it is also used to mean the entire disk and the paradises above it. There is also a system where it is the eighth mountain range encircling Sumeru within the ocean.

In Buddhist cosmology this mountain range forms an outer ring at the edge of the flat disk that is the world. These mountains prevent the ocean from overflowing. In other contexts this name can refer to the entire disk of the world, the paradises above it, or, as in the Kṣiti garbha Sūtra, to a mountain that contains the hells, also known as the Vaḍaba submarine mountain of fire.

“Circular Mass.” There are at least four interpretations of what this name refers to. In the Kṣiti garbha Sūtra it is a mountain that contains the hells. It is also equivalent to the Vaḍaba submarine mountain of fire, which is also said to be the entrance to the hells. The term cakravāla is also used to mean “the entire disk of a world,” including Meru and the paradises above it. More commonly, as in this sūtra, it is the name of the outer ring of mountains at the edge of the flat disk of a world, with Sumeru in the center. Yet it is has the nature of heat, like the Mountain Vaḍaba, in that the heat of the ring of mountains evaporates the ocean so that it does not overflow. Also called Cakravāḍa.
A village.

The wrathful buddha personifying the true nature of all forms and all the sensory fields and elements; a wrathful deity of the vīra type; also an epithet applied to some wrathful deities, especially Hevajra and Saṃvara.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
Alternative name for Consuming Blood and Marrow, which is one of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
Illnesses that may be considered an impediment to ordination\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1011 .
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Netra (470 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A mental state that induces one to avoid immoral behavior out of concern for what others will think or say about oneself if one misbehaves.

One of the eleven virtuous mental factors (Tib. {sems byung dge ba}; Skt. kuśalacaitta), a subgroup of the mental states or factors associated with the mind (Skt. caitasika, caitta), according to the Abhidharma. According to Vasubandhu (in his Pañcaskandhaka), {khrel} (“embarrassment” or “shame”) is different from {ngo tsha} (“scruples,” “conscience”) in that it is independent from others’ judgment of one’s behavior, and solely internal, in that it contradicts one’s internalized values. See “guilty conscience.”
Panicum italicum.
King of Tibet (704–754 ce).

Considered to be the third great Dharma king of Tibet, he was the grandson of Trisong Detsen and reigned from 815 to 838 or 841. His reign saw the expansion of Tibet’s political dominion to its greatest extent, and a significant continuation of the “early period” of imperially sponsored text translation, the end of which is traditionally marked by the end of his reign.
King of Tibet who reigned circa 742/55–798/804 ce.
King of Tibet (r. 742–98 ce) under whose auspices the first Buddhist monastery was established and a decades-long program of the translation of Buddhist texts commenced.

Considered to be the second great Dharma king of Tibet, he is thought to have been born in 742, and to have reigned from 754 until his death in 797 or 799. It was during his reign that the “early period” of imperially sponsored text translation gathered momentum, as the Buddhist teachings gained widespread acceptance in Tibet.
Sixty-third of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
A mendicant who is converted by the Buddha. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2054 .
This refers to the habit of copulation, called a dharma perhaps as it is a property/feature that belongs to those who copulate, or in the sense of something that is one’s course of behavior.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Jitaśatru (828 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
The 653rd buddha in the first list, 652nd in the second list, and 644th in the third list.
A nāga who visits Saṅkāśa Mountain.
A goddess associated with Amoghapāśa.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the epithets of Bhūtaḍāmara.
“Great wrath.” This seems to be a synonym of vidyārāja.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi; an epithet of Yamāntaka; an epithet of Yamāri; the name of a boar-faced emanation of Mañjuśrī.
A wrathful deity.
Another paraphrase of the name Amogha krodha rāja, usually referred to simply as Krodharāja.

Amogha pāśa krodha is another paraphrase of the name of Krodharāja as the wrathful form of Amoghapāśa (Amogha pāśa-Krodha rāja). When the name refers specifically to the deity’s mantra, it has been translated as “Wrathful Amoghapāśa.”
One of the wrathful emanations of Amoghapāśa.
A householder.
An epithet of a wrathful form of Vajrapāṇi.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
Another name of Krodhāṅkuśa.
One of the wrathful emanations of Amoghapāśa.
An epithet of Yamāntaka; also the namesake mantra. The name is also written in this translation as “Lord of Great Wrath.”
Seems to be an elaboration of the name Krodhāṅkuśa.
Epithet of Yamāntaka; also the namesake mantra.

“Lord of Wrath,” usually an epithet of Vajrapāṇi but also applied to other wrathful deities, such as the wrathful lords of the four families—tathāgata, lotus, jewel, and vajra. In the AP it is mainly used to refer to the wrathful aspect of Amoghapāśa; in this sense he is called, on at least one occasion, Amogha krodha rāja.
One of the epithets of Bhūtaḍāmara.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
“Wrath,” an epithet of some wrathful male deities, such as Vajrapāṇi.
A wrathful deity, usually on the sambhogakāya level; appears to be synonymous with krodharāja or mahākrodha.
A Buddhist goddess emanating from Tārā.
One of the goddesses in the retinue of Heruka.
Along with Tārā, a female deity visualized in the sādhana of Lavaṇāmbha.
According to Tibetan historical sources, the Nepalese princess who married the Tibetan king Songtsen Gampo. She is believed to have arrived in Tibet in either 632 or 634.
A mahoraga lord.
One of the deified female bodhisattvas; one of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A Buddhist goddess emanating from Tārā.

“Lord of wrath.” In the MMK this term seems to refer in some cases to a whole class of divine beings, which can perhaps be regarded as the wrathful vidyārājas. “Lord of Wrath” elsewhere is an epithet of Yamāntaka.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Mahāyaśas.
A village.
Son of the buddha Tiṣya.
One of the wrathful deities.
A measure of length; also, an angular cubit is the measure of angular distance equal to about 2 degrees.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Dharma pradīpākṣa.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ugratejas.
A sacred diagram that is drawn or constructed for ritual use. The Sanskrit word is derived from the Sanskrit root √yam, “to control.”
The name of a bodhisattva. “Unerring Power.”
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Gamma Pegasi in the occidental tradition.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Alpha Pegasi in the occidental tradition.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Gaṇin.
A brahmin priest who has completed his apprenticeship, and undergone a ritual ablution to mark his graduation.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
A village.
A measure of length from the elbow to the tip of the middle finger.
The word śukra may also refer to the female sexual fluid.
One of the bodhisattva great beings.
One of four parks that surround the city of Radiant.
A mountain to the north of Jambudvīpa.

Several species of finch belonging to the genus Amandava, part of the Estrildid finch family (Estrildidae). They are renowned as songbirds, and in Tibetan texts the Sanskrit kalaviṅka was sometimes simply transliterated ka la ping ka, sometimes translated as khu byug, “cuckoo.”
Attendant of the buddha Śaśivaktra.
Father of the buddha Sūrata.

The Sanskrit term can refer any kind of soup or broth, but especially those made with peas, lentils, etc., with salt and flavoring. The Tibetan appears to have used two words to cover the range of meaning: the obscure {khur ba}, which, according to the Mahāvyutpatti, is the equivalent of the Sanskrit maṇḍa, though that refers to the scum from boiled rice, and {skyo ma}, which is a soup or broth made with flour and water.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Siṃhagati (803 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
One of the eight nāga ladies.
A physical condition considered an impediment to ordination.
Father of the buddha Creator.
Ficus oppositifolia.
A mountain in the hell called Wailer.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK; a king identified as the Vākāṭaka emperor Pravarasena Viṣṇuvṛddha.
A king.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A brahmin.
One of the great mātṛs.
Belonging or relating to the god Viṣṇu; a devotee or follower of Viṣṇu; see “Viṣṇu.”
A householder and magistrate of King Diśāṃpati of Pāṁśula. Father of Guardian of the Flame Govinda.
Short form of “Guardian of the Flame Govinda.”\nNot to be confused with his father the householder Govinda.
The preserver of the universe. He is part of the Hindu triad of gods, with Brahmā the creator and Śiva the destroyer.
One of the primary gods of Hinduism, associated with the preservation and continuance of the universe, held by many as a supreme being.

One of the central gods in the Hindu pantheon today. He had not yet risen to an important status during the Buddha’s lifetime and only developed his own significant following in the early years of the common era. Vaishnavism developed the theory of ten emanations, or avatars, the ninth being the Buddha. His emanation as a dwarf plays an important role in this sūtra. The Sanskrit etymology of the name is uncertain, but it was already in use in the Vedas, where he is a minor deity, and has been glossed as “one who enters (everywhere).”
An epithet of Indra.
One of the five vital airs, diffused throughout the entire body.
Birthplace of the buddha Viśiṣṭa svarāṅga.
Attendant of the buddha Vidyuddatta.
A buddha of the past.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Anuddhata.
A bodhisattva.
Father of the buddha Dharmaprabhāsa.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Durjaya.
Name of a bodhisattva.
The name of a bodhisattva.
One of eight prince brothers in the distant past. Also the name of one of “the sixteen excellent men.”

(1) One of the sixteen bodhisattvas attending this teaching in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni. (2) A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Thus-Gone One Bhaiṣajyarāja who went to meet the Thus-Gone One Samantaraśmi and became the bodhisattva and brahmin householder Samavartin.
The realm of the Buddha Nārāyaṇa.
A great bodhisattva.
The third of the four types of joy.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ṛṣideva.
A monk who has received a punitive act, a probation and penance, must accept a probation that involves rejecting the honors accorded to observant monks and adopting a position of deference.
The realm of the Buddha Divine King of Brahmā’s Splendor
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A king in the distant past.
Son of the buddha Sundarapārśva.
Attendant of the buddha Janendra.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Bhavāntadarśin (128 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
One of the kinnara kings.
Mother of the buddha Anuddhata.
Father of the buddha Ratnottama.
Sixty-eighth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
An outcaste tribe.
One of the goddesses in the retinue of Heruka.

Symptom that may be evidence of an illness considered an impediment to ordination. According to Monier-Williams, any cutaneous disease.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1011 .
A nāga king.
A subdivision of the vaiśya (mercantile) class of traditional Indian society.
Not one of the normal four “castes” of Indian society, but presumably here a term referring to nonmonastics.
A nāga king.
One among the seven treasures of a universal emperor.

One of the seven treasures of the cakravartin king. See also Toh 95, The Play in Full, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh95.html#UT22084-046-001-102. See also Toh 4087, the Kāraṇa prajñapti, folio 124.b.https://read.84000.co/translation/toh4087.html
One of the seven precious treasures of a wheel-turning emperor.
Not one of the normal four “castes” of Indian society, but presumably here a term referring to nonmonastics.

The term “householder” is usually used for wealthy lay patrons of the Buddhist community. It also refers to a subdivision of the vaiśya (mercantile) class of traditional Indian society, comprising businessmen, merchants, landowners, and so on.
A garden frequented by Devadatta and his followers.
One of the two melāpakas.
A river.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
The name of an eon in which the Buddha King of Splendor with Many Glorious Appearances resides.
Literally “heap,” it also means a zodiac sign; in the MMK the meaning extends to cover other categories grouped together with the zodiac constellations.
A park in Moving in the Stream.
Refers to Spacious Palanquin Houses.
One of the kings of Nepal.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
Mother of the buddha Sukrama.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
The 468th buddha in the first list, 467th in the second list, and 461st in the third list.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK; a legendary king before the time of the Buddha.

A bull. Also the second zodiac sign, vṛṣabha, which corresponds to Taurus. Both vṛṣabha and ṛṣabha can be used as respectful epithets implying preeminence, usually in phrases such as “a bull among men” (a frequent epithet of the Buddha), “a bull among sages,” and the like. Here, the bull is the twenty-ninth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
This possibly is another name of Govinda (according to Jayaswal 1934, p. 30), of Maṅgala.
A class of semi-divine bird-like beings.
A supernatural being that is a gigantic bird with humanoid features.
One of the races of supernatural beings said to come to listen to the Buddha’s teachings; it is a bird with humanoid features, gigantic in size.

Lower class of divine beings described as eagle-type birds with gigantic wingspans. They are traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they are said to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.

A mythical bird normally depicted with a sharp, owl-like beak, often holding a snake, and with large and powerful wings. In Buddhism, the symbolism of the garuḍa is generally‌ associated with pristine cognition (it is said that the garuḍa can fly as soon as it is hatched) and with the consuming of afflicted mental states (the holding of a snake in its beak).
A yakṣa appearing in some of the paintings of Amoghapāśa. Also described as “great vajravināyaka” and “great king.” Kelikila is also associated with Śiva and referred to by the name Mahākelikila.
One of the goddesses associated with Amoghapāśa. Kelikilī appears to be a variant of the name Kelikilā, identified by multiple lexicographers as Rati, the wife of Kāmadeva.
A yakṣa appearing in some of the paintings of Amoghapāśa. Also described as “great vajravināyaka” and “great king.” Kelikila is also associated with Śiva and referred to by the name Mahākelikila.
An image of the Buddha.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A fruit that is attractive to behold and has a delicious taste, but is poisonous when eaten.
A type of cymbal.
A musical instrument, of an unidentified kind though sometimes translated “cymbals.”
A disciple of the Buddha.
(1) A village. (2) A forest near the village of Kimpilā.
A brahmin mentioned in connection with what is likely a story of a past life of the Buddha.
Butea frondosa, also known as flame of the forest; a tree with bright red flowers.
One of the lower social classes that are outside, and beneath, the four castes.
An inhabitant of an uncivilized borderland where the Dharma has not been propagated.

This somewhat vague term is applied to people and societies outside the brahmanical fold, i.e., foreigners, indigenous tribal groups, etc. The term is rendered elsewhere in this translation as “barbarian.”
A monk who teaches another to recite even a single verse. One of five types of instructors named by the Buddha when asked to elaborate on the role of an instructor.
A virtuous nāga king.

The Sanskrit term suparṇī in nāga suparṇī graha, translated by the Tibetan term {'dab bzang}, literally means “fine-winged” or “beautiful-leaved.” While this can be an epithet for the mythical garuḍa bird, here it seems to simply describe a general characteristic of the nāga.
Mother of the buddha Marutskandha.
Birthplace of the buddha Arciskandha.
This list of eight nāgas is probably unique to this sūtra. They are Tawny, Scent, Watery, Wrathful, Staircase to Heaven, Staircase to a Vase, Nearby Nāga, and Oḍasuta.
This term, meaning “elephant” in this context‌, is a metaphor, suggesting that those present in the assembly were leaders of considerable stature rather than followers.
A deity.
Attendant of the buddha Balanandin.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Melody of Lions.
Birthplace of the buddha Nāgadatta.
A buddha in a southeastern realm.
A tathāgata mentioned here as one of the thirty-five buddhas of confession.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Marutskandha.
A class of celestial beings.
Father of the buddha Varuṇa.
Birthplace of the buddha Varuṇa.
The 958th buddha in the first list, 957th in the second list, and 948th in the third list.
The 165th buddha in the first list, 164th in the second list, and 164th in the third list.
Mother of the buddha Varuṇa.
Indian commentator (fl. second century).
Mother of the buddha Puṇyabāhu.
The name of a king who reigned over the peaceful, flourishing city Ayodhyā before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
Son of the buddha Varuṇa.
This list of eight nāga ladies may be unique to this sūtra. They are Darkness, Eager to Leave, Seer, Cool, Load Carrying, Speech Strewing, Universal Army, and Gandharva Lady.
A female nāga.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the garuḍa kings.
The 58th buddha in the first list, 58th in the second list, and 59th in the third list.
A Indian author who presumably lived in the ninth century or later. He composed two practices of Tārā preserved in the Degé Tengyur.
Saint, scholar, and mystic of Buddhist India from about four hundred years after the Buddha; discoverer of the Mahāyāna sūtras and author of the fundamental Madhyamaka treatise.

Second- or third-century Indian master whose writings formed the basis for the Madhyamaka tradition. In following centuries there were other masters and authors of the same name, and in Tibet all their works became attributed to one person.
Mesua roxburghii. The Sanskrit literally translates as “nāga flowers.”
A species of euphorbia used in burnt offerings to get rid of nāga influences.
Son of the buddha Toṣaṇa.
Father of the buddha Siṃhabala.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Ratnaruta (466 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
The 163rd buddha in the first list, 162nd in the second list, and 162nd in the third list.
Mother of the buddha Nāgaruta.
The 170th buddha in the first list, 169th in the second list, and 169th in the third list.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Ratnāgni (385 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
One of the ancient dynasties in Madhyadeśa.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Marutpūjita.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Āryastuta (874 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Attendant of the buddha Sthitagandha.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
A female nāga.
A river on Great Slope.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with Honey.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A bodhisattva.
Tibetan translator active during the late eight- and early ninth-centuries. One of the first seven Tibetans to take monastic ordination.
An ocean between Godānīya and Videha.
A son of King Sarvārthasiddha.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Vajrasena.

Among the many magical powers of the nāgas are the ability to produce rain. Presumably this ability is what is meant here by “nāga-power,” although this appears to be the only mention of the term in the Kangyur in connection with clouds and rain.
One of the nāga kings.
Name of a king of a race of supernatural serpents who protect the doctrine.
One of the nāga kings.
A mountain in Living on the Peak.
An ascetic statesman.
One of the seven golden mountains that surround Mount Sumeru.
Father of the buddha Jagattoṣaṇa.
Mother of the buddha Amitabuddhi.
The 557th buddha in the first list, 557th in the second list, and 550th in the third list.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ratnaruta.
Father of the buddha Arhadyaśas.

A class of nonhuman beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. Nāgas are associated with snakes and serpents, and often assume a snakelike appearance.

A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and are said to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents, and are subordinate to Virūpākṣa, the Great King of the West.

Nāgas belong half to the animal realm and half to the god realm (Rangjung Yeshe Dictionary). They are believed to abide in subterranean realms, having control over rain, ponds, rivers, and soil productivity. Some are Dharma protectors, but they can bring retribution if they are disturbed. Often in Buddhist arts and in written accounts, they are portrayed as being half human and half snake (Rigzin 9).

A supernatural being usually depicted as having the top half of a human and the bottom half of a snake. However, the nāga has a myriad of associations within Buddhism and Indian traditions in general; the term may be associated with deities, snakes (more specifically cobras), elephants, subterranean spirits, water spirits, or ethnic groups of people from the Indian subcontinent. In Tibet they became specifically associated with water spirits (klu), and in China they came to be associated with dragons (龍).

A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments where they are known to guard wealth and esoteric teachings. Nāgas are associated with serpents and often assume a snakelike appearance. In Buddhist art and in written accounts, nāgas are regularly portrayed as being half human and half snake, and, as mentioned in this sūtra, said to have the ability to change into human form. Some nāgas are Dharma protectors, but they can also bring retribution if they are disturbed. Nāgas likewise fight one another, wage war, and destroy the lands of others by causing lightning, hail, and flooding.

A mythical being usually depicted as having the top half of a human and the bottom half of a snake. However, the nāga has a myriad of associations within Buddhism and Indian traditions in general; the term may be associated with deities, snakes (more specifically cobras), elephants, subterranean spirits, water spirits, or ethnic groups of people from the Indian subcontinent. In Tibet they became specifically associated with water spirits ({klu}), and in China they came to be associated with dragons. Here the image of the nāga is the twenty-seventh of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
A country corresponding to modern Gujarat.
Devadatta’s companion.
One of four cronies of Devadatta.
A monk who joined Devadatta’s plot against the Buddha.
A Buddhist monk who sided with Devadatta and defended him when the latter’s schemes to usurp the Buddha were exposed.
One of the members of a group of four monks described in the Vinaya as followers of Devadatta that attempted to create a schism in the Buddhist saṅgha.
Hygrophila auriculata.
An asura in one of the variants of the maṇḍala of Caṇḍa mahā roṣaṇa.
A river in the east of Jambudvīpa.
A country that the Buddha frequently visited.
One of the sixteen great kingdoms of ancient India.
An ancient Indian kingdom located somewhere in present day Uttar Pradesh.
An ancient Indian kingdom, in present day Uttar Pradesh. Śrāvastī was its capital.
Also spelled Kosala. An ancient Indian kingdom corresponding to the present-day Awadh in Uttar Pradesh.
An ancient kingdom, northwest of Magadha, abutting Kāśi, whose capital was Śrāvastī. During the Buddha’s time it was ruled by Prasenajit. It presently corresponds to an area within Uttar Pradesh.
One of the two auxiliary kṣetras.
One of the two auxiliary kṣetras.
An ancient kingdom, northwest of Magadha, abutting Kāśi, whose capital was Śrāvastī. During the Buddha’s time it was ruled by Prasenajit.
An acceptable form of cloth for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual. A low-grade cloth made from kotampa fibers or kausheyam silk and linen or cotton weave.
A land in the east of Jambudvīpa.

The hundred sons of King Dhṛtarāśtra, who were the enemies of their cousins, the Pāṇḍava brothers. Their family name means they are the descendants of the ancient King Kur (as were the Pāṇḍava brothers). Their battle is the central theme of the Mahābhārata, India’s greatest epic.

Appears to mean “a person from Kañci.” Unidentified. Possibly a description of Pūrna, who is next in the list of the Buddha’s disciples. Alternatively this may be Kaccāna, also known as Kaccāyana, but principally as Katyayāna, one of the Buddha’s ten principal pupils.
One of the power places.
A famous Tibetan scholar practitioner of the nineteenth century.
The area of Vārāṇasī where Maitreya (as Ajita) is said to have been born.
A village or town. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-3125 .
A land to the north of Jambudvīpa.
A grove in Promotion
A forest in Supreme Strength.
The god of wealth.
An alternate name for the yakṣa Jambhala.
One of the four great kings, also known as Vaiśravaṇa.
A Hindu god of wealth, appearing in the Buddhist pantheon as Vaiśravaṇa.
Also known as Vaiśravaṇa. One among the Four Great Kings, guardian of the north.

Counted among the most famous of the Indian Buddhist Mahāsiddhas and renowned for his association with packs of dogs (kukkura), he is a central figure in a number of tantric lineages, specifically of the Guhya samāja Tantra and Mahā māyā Tantra. He was active sometime between the 8th and 10th centuries.
