A rākṣasī living in Ramayo.
One of the auxiliary charnel grounds.
The name of an Indian preceptor and teacher who lived during the early Sarma ({gsar ma}) period (c. 11th century) and worked on the Tibetan translation of the Mañjuśrīmūlatantra.
When referring to a worldly deity, this name/epithet usually applies to Skanda.
A certain bird that lived on Gandhamādana Mountain, who died with thoughts of joy toward the Buddha and therefore took rebirth as a god.
A buddha.
One of the cold hells.
Birthplace of the buddha Deśāmūḍha.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Dṛḍhasvara.
Mother of the buddha Satyaruta.
A buddha realm.
Son of the buddha Amṛta.
The water plant Nymphae esculenta.
Attendant of the buddha Gaganasvara.
This water lily, Nymphaea pubescens, can be pink or white and is sometimes incorrectly called a lotus. It flowers at night, and therefore is also called “night lotus.”

Nymphaea pubescens. This night-blossoming water lily, which can be red, pink, or white, is not actually a lotus, since it does not have the lotus’s distinctive pericarp. Nevertheless it is commonly called the “night lotus.” It is also known as hairy water lily, because of the hairs on the stem and the underside of the leaves.

Nymphaea pubescens. This night-blossoming water lily, which can be red, pink, or white, is not actually a lotus. It does not have the lotus’s distinctive pericarp. Nevertheless, it is commonly called the “night lotus.” It is also known as “hairy water lily,” because of the hairs on the stem and the underside of the leaves.
Himalayan bird with beautiful bright eyes.
Bird with beautiful eyes that lives on Mount Sumeru.
Specifically, the greater painted snipe (Rostrature benghalensis).
Indian beech tree (pongamia glabra); used medicinally.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A female deity of the lotus family, associated with the activity of enthralling.
One of the sixteen great kingdoms of ancient India.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
In Buddhist cosmology, it refers to (1) the continent to the north of Mount Sumeru, and (2) a land to the north of Jambudvīpa.
The royal family of the Kushan dynasty.
The city where the Buddha entered parinirvāṇa.
Village in the country of Mallā where the Buddha passed into parinirvāṇa.
The one-time capital of ancient Magadha.
A prince who appears in the Jātakas.
A prince who was the Buddha in a former life.
Poa cynosuroides, a species of grass commonly used in religious ceremonies.
A class of vidyādharas.
The capital of the Malla kingdom, and the town, in the vicinity of which the Buddha passed into parinirvāṇa.
Inhalation (one of the four stages during a single breath).
Second of the four noble truths.
Sixth of the eleven aspects of knowledge.
A sage.
The prāṇa channel in the centre of the body.
Also rendered in this translation as “middle channel.”
The body’s main subtle channel (nāḍī), running along the spinal column.
A buddha realm.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A righteous nāga king.
A class of asuras that live on the third level, Excellent Abode.
The son of the god Brahmā.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Jñānarāja (618 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Son of the buddha Sthita vega jñāna.
A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
One of the grahas.
An epithet of Viṣṇu. Sometimes also used as an epithet of Brahmā.

The imaginary defining characteristic corresponds to the attribution of an essence, an inherent entity, to that which is by nature dependent on an other (paratantra) to exist or appear as what it is perceived to be.
Alternative name of the lake Expansive.
Jasminum multiflorum according to the Pandanus Database of Plants.

Trachelospermum jasminoides. It has its name because of its starlike white blossoms. In India it is used in speech as an example of whiteness, i.e., “as white as star jasmine.” Also called downy jasmine, Chinese jasmine, Chinese ivy, and trader’s compass.
A mountain in Kuru.
A forest on Deer Abode.

The Buddha Śākyamuni's attendant who is celebrated for having recited all the Buddha's teachings by memory at the first council of the Buddhist saṅgha, thus preserving the Buddha’s teachings after his parinirvāṇa.

A monk of the Buddha’s order, brother of Devadatta, who for twenty-five years served as the Buddha’s personal attendant. Second in the apostolic succession that carried on the Buddha’s teachings after his parinirvāṇa.

Ānanda, the cousin of Siddhārtha Gautama (the Buddha Śākyamuni). The Buddha’s personal attendant, one of his closest disciples, and also the person who, according to tradition, preserved the oral transmission of the sūtras.

A major śrāvaka disciple of the Buddha; his personal attendant. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-060-005.html#UT22084-060-005-950 and https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-060-005.html#UT22084-060-005-1055 .

Buddha Sākyamuni’s cousin, who was his attendant for the last twenty years of his life. He was the subject of criticism and opposition from the monastic community after the Buddha’s passing, but eventually succeeded to the position of the patriarch of Buddhism in India after the passing of the first patriarch, Mahākāśyapa.

The Buddha Śākyamuni’s cousin, who was his attendant for the last twenty years of his life. He was the subject of criticism and opposition from the monastic community after the Buddha’s passing but eventually succeeded to the position of the patriarch of Buddhism in India after the passing of the first patriarch, Mahākaśyapa.
An emanated monk.
A park in Sustained by Fruition.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell. Appears to be identical with Joyless Thought.
A fifteenth century Sakya scholar, nephew of Ngorchen Kunga Zangpo.
The 651st buddha in the first list, 650th in the second list, and 642nd in the third list.
A mountain in Dwelling on Forest Riverbanks.
A lotus pond on the fifth minor mountain on Lofty Summit.
A park in House of Refined Gold.
An ārāma was a private citizen’s garden, generally found within the limits of a town or city.

Somewhat akin to what in English is expressed by the term “pleasance” (also in its etymology), an ārāma is a pleasant garden, a green habitable space. The Buddha and his disciples are often found to dwell in such ārāmas, and the term is even found in contemporary usage in names of Thai monasteries.
A forest at Sudharma.
A lotus pool in Lateral.
A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
The Buddha’s cousin and attendant who recited the Buddha’s sūtra discourses from memory after the Buddha passed.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Abhedyabuddhi (889 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Ratnapradatta (769 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Attendant of the buddha Avraṇa.
A nāga king.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Priya cakṣurvaktra (748 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.

The 427th buddha in the first list, 426th in the second list, and 420th in the third list. The translation is tentative; {kun gzigs} found in list three corresponds to Samantadarśin, but {kun du gzi brjid} found in list one and two would expect *Samantatejas.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Subuddhinetra (569 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
A king and sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
One of the six teachers at the time of the Buddha.
One of the six philosophical extremists who lived during the time of Buddha Śākyamuni. Also rendered here as “Parivrājaka Gośālīputra.”
One of sixteen realms that surround the Howling Hell.
Literally “olibanum,” this is the code word for the five types of enjoyment derived from the lotus (vagina) of the female consort.
A great bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Puṇyamati.
A buddha.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Suyajña (762 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Suvarṇacūḍa.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Tiṣya (584 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Attendant of the buddha Kāśyapa.
In chapter 44 it is the name of one of the future buddhas of this kalpa. It is also the name of the kalyāṇamitra in chapter 46, the teacher of children.
A buddha.
Name of a gandharva, a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Son of the buddha Sumati.
Here, probably the short form for ālayavijñāna.
Literally, the foundation of all things of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa. Sometimes a synonym for dharmakāya or emptiness.
The subtlemost form of deluded consciousness, which serves as the store-house for karmic seeds, therefore serving as the substratum from which appearances manifest.

Identifiable with ālayavijñāna. However, as reference to the elaborate Vijñānavādin psychology of the “store-consciousness” is out of place in this sūtra, it is here simply translated “subconsciousness.”
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Padmaraśmi (506 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.

The 427th buddha in the first list, 426th in the second list, and 420th in the third list. The translation is tentative; {kun gzigs} found in list three corresponds to Samantadarśin, but {kun du gzi brjid} found in list one and two would expect *Samantatejas.
A bhikṣu who was a pupil of Śāriputra.
One of ten different kinds of verbal phrase or statement (Skt. pada) mentioned in this text.
A buddha who resides in the eastern buddha realm called Blissful.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Asaṅgadhvaja.

Sarvajñādeva was a Kashmiri paṇḍita among the “one hundred” paṇḍitas invited by King Trisong Detsen (r. 756–800 ce) to assist with the translation of the Buddhist scriptures into Tibetan. Sarvajñādeva assisted in the translation of more than twenty-three works, including numerous sūtras and the first translations of Śāntideva’s https://read.84000.co/toh3871.html and Nāgārjuna’s https://read.84000.co/toh4496.html .
Mother of the buddha Śobhita.
A forest in Promotion.
A forest in Distinguished in Many Colorful Ways.
A lake in the realm of the asuras.
One of the Buddha’s former rebirths.
A bodhisattva.
Bauhinia variegata, Phaneria variegata. In other sūtras kovidāra is translated as {sa brtol}.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A buddha who lives in the east in a buddha realm called Elevated by Abiding in Aspiration.
The name of a celestial realm.
The buddha realm of the buddha King of Splendor.
The twelfth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Lit. “Rays All Around.” A bodhisattva from a world system called Ratnāvatī, in the eastern direction, who comes to pay homage and listen to the Buddha.
A park in Sustained by Fruition.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Niyatabuddhi (176 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A buddha realm.
A bodhisattva.
A lotus pond in Delighting in Flower Garlands.
A bodhisattva.
(1) A realm inhabited by garland-bearer gods ({thams cad rab tu dga' bar gnas pa}). (2) A mountain in Promotion ({kun nas dga' ba}).
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
The buddhafield of Vimalakīrtirāja.
Name of buddhafield of Buddha King of Many Arrangements.
Birthplace of the buddha Samāhitātman.
Birthplace of the buddha Vaidyarāja.
A buddha.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Puṣpaketu (184 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A forest in Special Joy.
A buddha.
A yakṣa king.

The third stage in the development and expression of afflictions (Skt. kleśa, Tib. {nyon mongs}), preceded by “latent tendency” (Skt. anuśaya, Tib. {bag la nyal ba}) and “belief” (Skt. dṛṣṭi, Tib. {lta ba smra ba}).
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
The name of a bodhisattva.
A king.

The name of an assembly hall in Śrāvastī. It could be that samanta, meaning “universal,” just refers to the assembly hall in general. However, both the Tibetan and Chinese seemed to translate this word literally, which suggests it may be a proper noun.
A bodhisattva.
The name of a bodhisattva.
Lit. “With Flowers Everywhere.” The tathāgata in the buddhafield Padmavatī.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A great bodhisattva.

These consist of various mental distractions caused by the nine considerations “He has caused, causes, will cause wrong to me. He has caused, causes, will cause wrong to one dear to me. He has served, serves, will serve my enemies.”
Thinking that someone harms oneself, harms someone dear to oneself, or benefits someone dear to oneself, each in the present, past, or future.

In his Gateway to Knowledge, Mipham identifies three groups of three thoughts that inspire aggression: (1–3) the thoughts, “This has hurt me,” “This is hurting me,” and “This will hurt me”; (4–6) the thoughts “This has hurt someone dear to me,” “This is hurting someone dear to me,” and “This will hurt someone dear to me”; and (7–9) the thoughts, “This has helped my enemy,” “This helps my enemy,” and “This will help my enemy” (mi pham rgyam mtsho 1978, p. 74).

These are listed as nine: thinking that one’s enemy has harmed, is harming, or will harm oneself; thinking that one’s enemy has harmed, is harming, or will harm one’s friend; and thinking that someone has helped, is helping, or will help one’s enemy.
Alternative name for Thoroughly Joyous Form.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
(1) A lotus pond in Living by Rājanina ({mthong na kun dga' ba}). (2) A mountain on Vast Garlands of Bliss ({kun nas mthong na dga' ba}).
A buddha realm.
The process of karma and affliction leading to suffering.
Lit. “without defilement.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
The process of karma, afflictions of the mind, and suffering.
The self-perpetuating process of affliction in the minds of beings.
Another term for saṃsāra , this is the counterpart of “purification.”
Saṃsāra, in being nothing but afflicted; its opposite is ‘fully cleansed,’ ‘complete purification.’
A term referring to all the primary and secondary afflictive emotions that completely disturb the mind.
The defilements of causality and emotional states the perpetuate our experience of saṃsāra.

A term meaning defilement, impurity, and pollution, broadly referring to cognitive and emotional factors that disturb and obscure the mind. It is often paired with its opposite vyavadāna, meaning “purification.”

The essentially pure nature of mind is obscured and afflicted by various psychological defilements known as the afflicted mental states, which destroy the mind’s peace and composure. Included among them are the primary afflictions of fundamental ignorance, attachment, aversion, pride, doubt, and twenty subsidiary afflictions.
One of the uṣṇīṣa kings attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A pool in Shaded by Garlands.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Son of the buddha Arajas.
The buddha realm in which Prince Ratnākara will attain awakening.
A world realm in the distant past.
One of the kings of the rākṣasas.
A park in South India.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A town in the south of India.
The name of a karmic wind involved in the formation of an embryo in its tenth week.
A buddha realm.
One of the pratyeka buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A bodhisattva.
A tathāgata mentioned here as one of the thirty-five buddhas of confession.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A bodhisattva.
(1) Name of tathāgata in the western buddhafield Illuminated. (2) A bodhisattva in the southeastern buddhafield Sorrowless.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
The bodhisattva Supreme Scent-Perfused Preacher when he becomes a buddha.
A tathāgata.
A grove in Dwelling on Mixed Riverbanks.
A royal capital in a world in the eastern direction in a past kalpa.
An area in Kuru.
The 200th buddha in the first list, 199th in the second list, and 199th in the third list.

Conveys the relative or conventional view of the world according to the understanding of ordinary unenlightened beings. This is distinguished from the ultimate truth, which conveys the understanding of phenomena as they really are. Saṃvṛti literally means “covered” or “concealed,” implying that the relative reality seen by ordinary beings seems to be convincingly real, but it is ultimately, in its actual state, illusory and unreal.

This denotes the empirical aspect of reality as conventionally experienced through our perceptions, which, in contrast to ultimate reality or emptiness, is considered true only within the relative framework of our own experiences.
Fourth of the eleven aspects of knowledge.
Of seeming and apparent truth or reality.
A proponent of the doctrine of scepticism (vikṣepavāda).
Son of the buddha Puṣpaprabha.
Attendant of the buddha Marudadhipa.
The 316th buddha in the first list, 315th in the second list, and 310th in the third list.
A sage, former incarnation of the Buddha Dīpaṃkara.
A holy site blessed by the presence of sages.
One of the Buddha’s former rebirths.
The name of a karmic wind involved in the formation of an embryo in its second week.
Another name for Kauṇḍinya. As he was the first to understand the Buddha’s teaching on the four truths, he received the name Ājñātakauṇḍinya (“Kauṇḍinya who understood”).
Third of the three faculties.
Second of the three faculties.
Third of the seven buddhas of the past.

The highest of the three paradises that correspond to the second dhyāna in the form realm. In other contexts, the Tibetan {'od gsal ba} usually refers to Ābhāsvara, and the Tibetan {gya nom snang ba} would refer to Sudṛśa.
A pleasure grove in Shaded by Garlands.

A great fourteenth century Jonangpa scholar, practitioner, and translator (1283–1363), who had earlier studied at Sakya, with Butön at Zhalu, and with Tharpa Lotsāwa at Sangphu, before becoming the first major disciple of Dolpopa.
A class of asuras ruled by Overjoyed.
A forest in Dwelling in Forests.
A mountain range surrounding the hell of Embers Within.
A buddha in the distant past.
(1) A forest on the northern face of Sumeru ({yongs su 'dres pa}). (2) A river in Godānīya ({kun tu 'dres pa}).
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Baladatta.
A bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Praśānta.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Siṃhadhvaja.
A bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Janendra (401 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Name of a bodhisattva.
The ground of buddhahood.
Father of the buddha Avraṇa.
The eleventh bodhisattva level.
One of the pratyeka buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
This is the term for the eleventh bodhisattva level. It is also the name of a mansion in the Dharma Discernment hermitage and the name of a Bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A type of worm ({srin bu}) that lives in and feeds on the body.
A follower of a non-Buddhist mendicant movement.
A tīrthika order.
A religious mendicant of the Indian sect founded by Gosāla Maṅkhaliputra.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Jewel Foundation.
A bodhisattva.
Attendant of the buddha Kāśyapa.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ratnaprabhāsa.
A buddha realm.
Mother of the buddha Meruraśmi.
A buddha.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.

The Samanta bhadra caryā praṇidhāna appears in the final part of the Gaṇḍa vyūha sūtra, which itself forms part of the Buddhāvataṃsaka sūtra. It is well-known in Tibet, where it has been the subject of numerous commentaries. It continues to be recited daily in some monastic traditions in Tibet and China. The work also goes under the Sanskrit titles Bhadracari(-ī), and Bhadra caryā praṇidhāna. See Skilling and Saerji 2013, 198 n. 30.
A principal bodhisattva in the Mahāyāna sūtras. Not to be confused with the primordial buddha of the Nyingma tradition.
The buddha who presides over the buddha field Unblinking, the buddha field from which the bodhisatva Akṣayamati has come.
A Buddhist deity; the name of a bodhisattva; also the name of the deity asking Vajrasattva questions at the time of the delivery of the CMT.

Samantabhadra (Entirely Excellent) is one of the eight principal bodhisattvas. He is known for embodying the conduct of bodhisattvas through his vast aspirations, offerings, and deeds on behalf of the benefit of beings.

One of the eight principal bodhisattvas, he figures strongly in the Gaṇḍavyūha (the final chapter of the Avataṃsaka sūtra) and in the Lotus Sūtra. His prominence in these sūtras is the reason why emphasis is placed on Avalokiteśvara’s superiority over him. (Not to be confused with the buddha in the Nyingma tradition.)

Presently classed as one of the eight principal bodhisattvas, he is distinct from the primordial buddha with the same name in the Nyingma tradition. He is prominent in the Gaṇḍa vyūha, and also in https://read.84000.co/translation/toh113.html (Toh 113, Saddharma puṇḍarīka) and The White Lotus of Compassion Sūtra (Toh 111, Mahā karuṇā puṇḍarīka sūtra)https://read.84000.co/translation/toh111.html.
A brahmin mentioned in the context of what is likely a story of a past life of the Buddha.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Immeasurable Light.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Devaruta.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Jñānaratna.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Mahendra (284 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
brgyad stong kun tu skrag pa dang ldan pa
A bodhisattva.
A deva in the retinue of Śakra.
A bodhisattva.
A king; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
“The Victory Banner That Resounds Everywhere with the Sound of the Clouds of the Dharma.” A Bodhi tree in the distant past.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Sārodgata.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Cūḍa (993 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Son of the buddha Śanairgāmin.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Guṇasāgara.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Jñānavikrama (580 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Jñānarata.
Father of the buddha Vratasthita.
Son of the buddha Dṛḍhavrata.
Birthplace of the buddha Ugratejas.
A buddha.
A future buddha.
Mañjuśrī’s name when he becomes a buddha.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Dharaṇīdhara (381 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A buddha realm.
A class of vidyādharas.
A buddha.
Son of the buddha Siṃharaśmi.
A bodhisattva.
A realm of the vessel-bearer gods.
The realm of the Buddha Samantavipaśyin.
A perfume seller, the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 19.
A two-armed lokeśvara emanation of Avalokiteśvara.
Lit. “sees all.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
One of the vidyārājas dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
Son of the buddha Candrodgata.
A bodhisattva.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Padma.
A great bodhisattva.
Attendant of the buddha Candrodgata.
A bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Praśānta.
A buddha realm.
Attendant of the buddha Vṛṣabha.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ojaṅgama.
A city in Godānīya.
One of the eight bhūta kings.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Vijitāvin.
The name of a karmic wind involved in the formation of an embryo in its twenty-second week.
Birthplace of the buddha Ṛṣideva.
A class of gods associated with the Four Great Kings.
A class of traveling ascetics (both male and female) who held a variety of differing non-Buddhist views.
A religious mendicant; in Buddhist texts this is often paired with caraka in stock lists of followers of non-Buddhist ascetic traditions.
Literally, “one who wanders around.” An umbrella term for the class of wandering religious ascetics of diverse religious persuasions who were common at the time of the Buddha.
One of the six outsider teachers.
A class of asuras.
Wandering religious practitioners or śramaṇa, usually referring to non-Buddhists.
An umbrella term for the class of wandering religious ascetics of diverse religious persuasions that were common at the time of the Buddha.
A general term for homeless religious mendicants who, literally, “roam around”; in Buddhist usage the term refers to non-Buddhist peripatetic ascetics including Jains and others.
Evidently a general term for homeless religious mendicants who, literally, “roam around”; in Buddhist usage the term refers to non-Buddhist peripatetic ascetics including Jains and others.

A specific order of mendicants, or a general term for homeless religious mendicants who, literally, “roam around”; in Buddhist usage the term can refer to non-Buddhist peripatetic ascetics including Jains and others.

“Wandering mendicant,” parivrājaka (Sanskrit, wanderer; Pāli, paribbājaka). Refers to a class of Indian religious mendicants holding a variety of beliefs who wandered in India from ancient times, including during the time of the Buddha. These peripatetic ascetics, who included women in their number, engaged with one another in debate on a range of topics. Some of their metaphysical views are presented in the early Buddhist discourses of the Pāli Canon.
Mother of the buddha Gaṇimuktirāja.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Guṇendrakalpa (536 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Sucintita (77 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A buddha in the distant past.
A buddha in the ream All-Seeing.
The name that Adorned with Various Jewels will adopt when she becomes a buddha.
A buddha in the distant past.
A bodhisattva.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Perfectly Pure Abode.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Amarapriya (300 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A complete projection of the mind that has no valid basis in reality.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
Attendant of the buddha Vardhana.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Sthitārtha jñānin (190 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
The view of the perishable collection, doubt, and grasping rules and rituals as absolute.
The three fetters are the belief in self or independent existence, doubt, and clinging to rites and rituals.
Three fetters to be abandoned on the path of seeing: the view of the transitory collection, viewing discipline as supreme, and harboring doubt.
Five fetters to be abandoned: the view of the transitory collection, viewing discipline as supreme, and harboring doubt, desire, and ill will.
Fetters binding one to saṃsāra; they come in groups of three (ignorance, hatred, and desire) or ten.
Synonym of emotional defilements, which lead beings to act negatively and prevent them from acting virtuously, hence keeping them fettered to suffering in their next lives.

A set of ten concepts and emotional reactions that perpetuate one’s continued rebirth in saṃsāra: false attribution of a self based in relation to the aggregates (satkāyadṛṣṭi; {'jig tshogs la lta ba}), doubt (vicikitsā; {the tshom}), privileging rituals and observances (śīla vrata parāmarśa; {tshul khrims dang brtul zhugs mchog tu 'dzin pa}), craving sense pleasures (kāmarāga; {'dod pa la 'dod chags}), malice (vyāpāda; {gnod sems}), craving rebirth in the realm of subtle form (rūparāga; {gzugs la chags pa}), craving rebirth in the realm of the immaterial (arūpyarāga; {gzugs med pa'i 'dod chags}), pride (māna; {nga rgyal}), mental agitation (auddhatya; {rgod pa}), and ignorance (avidyā; {ma rig pa}).

The three fetters, as found in https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1123 , comprise false views about perishable composites, hesitation, and a sense of moral and ascetic supremacy. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1124 .
The name of a meditative absorption.
Birthplace of the buddha Praśānta.
A bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Guṇākara.
Birthplace of the buddha Satyaruta.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
“The Victory Banner That Resounds Everywhere with the Sound of the Clouds of the Dharma.” A Bodhi tree in the distant past.
A buddha realm.
A buddha in the distant past. BHS verse: Samantābhaśiri.
“Shining Banner.” The name of a past kalpa.
A past buddha.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
The realm of the Buddha Stainless Light.
Name of the fifty-third meditative stability.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Lit. “total illumination.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
One of the five celestial bodhisattvas associated with Mañjuśrī.

Kauṇḍinya’s name when he becomes a buddha in the distant future. It will also be the name of five hundred of Śākyamuni’s arhats when they attain buddhahood. Also called “Samanta prabhāsa” and “Samanta prabha.”
A mountain in Kuru.
The name of a future eon, one hundred incalculable eons from now.
A buddha from the past.
A buddha realm.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Dense Cloud.
A bodhisattva.
Name of a future buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
The forms of discipline associated with body and speech, as opposed to mind.
A buddha.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Birthplace of the buddha Ratnaprabhāsa.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with Jewels.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Pratibhāna kīrti (280 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A buddha realm.
A night goddess at the bodhimaṇḍa, the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 35.
A magical tree, the name of which means “completely pleasant array.”
A great bodhisattva.
Crocus sativus, the plant and the pollen of the flowers.
Seventh of the ten nonvirtuous (akuśala) actions, the third of the three related to speech (the first two being slander and harsh speech).
A wrathful deity of the heruka type.
One of the hells.
One of the eight cold hells.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell. Literally, “Cries of Woe” or “Lamenting.”
Fourth of the eight cold hells of Buddhist cosmology. It is named for the sounds its inhabitants make while enduring unthinkable cold.
One of the cold hells
One of the eight cold hells. It is named for the sounds its inhabitants make while enduring unthinkable cold.
The younger brother of Rāma.
Fifth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
One of the kings of Nepal, possibly Vṛṣadeva of the seventh century.
A country corresponding in area to modern Gujarat.
A class of ḍākinīs.
One of the seven types of ḍākinīs.
Name of a rākṣasī and Dharma protector.
The name of the venerable Pradarśa’s father.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
A country corresponding in area to modern Gujarat.
An acceptable form of cloth for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
A popular South Asian sweet.
A kind of sweetmeat made of coarsely ground gram or other pulse or of corn flour, mixed with sugar and spices, and fried in ghee or oil (Monier-Williams).
Another name of Śakuna.
A king in the past. Also referred to as “Mahāśakuni.”
Trachyspermum ammi.
One of the eight nāga ladies.
A deity.
Attendant of the buddha Sāra.
Birthplace of the buddha Puṇyabāhu.
A royal elephant belonging to the stables of King Bimbisāra.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
Attendant of the buddha Sūryaraśmi.
Father of the buddha Trailokyapūjya.
A bodhisattva, the protagonist of this text.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Guṇamālin.
The 469th buddha in the first list, 468th in the second list, and 462nd in the third list.
One of the first to join the Buddha’s order of monks. He followed his friend Yaśas into the Buddhist order.
A merchant.
Hearer present in the circle around Śākyamuni.
A principal bodhisattva in the Mahāyāna sūtras.
Synonym for Subāhu, translated as if it was Subāhu into Tibetan.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK; an ancient king, contemporary of the Buddha.
The 13th buddha in the first list, 13th in the second list, and 13th in the third list.
Father of the buddha Ugratejas.
Someone (usually a bhikṣu) responsible for the building of a new monastery or temple, or for the repair of an existing one (Mahāvyutpatti 8735).
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Saṃjaya.
Attendant of the buddha Mahāraśmi.
Father of the buddha Guṇottama.
A river in the realm of the gods in Dwelling on Summits within the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.

An alternate form of the name Daṇḍapāṇi, a Śākya clan member and the father of Gopā and Yaśodharā. In The Hundred Deeds he is noted as the father of {mda' thogs}, rendered here with the potential back-translation Iṣudhara.

One of the three classes of yakṣas at the base of Sumeru, below the paradises of the mahārājas, as part of the lowest class of paradises in the desire realm. Their name means “those who have basins in their hands.” They are said to be at the very base of Sumeru, and worry that the rising ocean is going to flood them. Because they are continually bailing out water with the basins, they are unable to follow the path to enlightenment.
One of the fathers-in-law of Śākyamuni: the father of Gopā, one of Śākyamuni’s wives.
A great bodhisattva.
Lit. “Lotus Handed.” A bodhisattva from a world system called Bodhi maṇḍalālaṃkāra su rucitā, in the intermediate southeast direction, who comes to pay homage and listen to the Buddha.
A bodhisattva of the southeast.
Name of a class of gods, a group of yakṣa associated with the Four Great Kings.
A bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
Lit. “Jewel Mudrā in Hand.”
One of the bodhisattvas attending this teaching.
A bodhisattva great being present in the audience of this sūtra.
‟Vajra in Hand,” the deity who teaches the Bhūta ḍāmara Tantra; in the first half of this text he is referred to primarily as Vajradhara.
These vajra wielders are like the Vajrapāṇi who was the yakṣa that acted as the Buddha’s bodyguard. In the Mantrayāna there appeared the bodhisattva named Vajrapāṇi.
An important bodhisattva, “Wielder of the Vajra,” whose compassion is to manifest in a terrific form to protect the practitioners of the Dharma from harmful influences.

A figure who takes on numerous identities in Buddhist literature, including a yakṣa bodyguard of the Buddha Śākyamuni, a bodhisattva, and an esoteric Buddhist deity instrumental in the transmission of tantric scripture.

In the sūtra tradition, Vajrapāṇi was a yakṣa who acted as the Buddha Śākyamuni’s bodyguard. Also identified as being a manifestation of Śakra and could appear as a number of vajrapāṇis to guard the Buddha. With the advent of the Mantrayāna he is a bodhisattva. Also a euphemism for Indra or a group of vajra-wielding deities in Indra’s realm.

First appeared in Buddhist literature as the yakṣa bodyguard of the Buddha, ready at times to shatter a person’s head into a hundred pieces with his vajra if he speaks inappropriately to the Buddha. His identity as a bodhisattva did not take place until the rise of the Mantrayāna in such sūtras as the Kāraṇḍavyūha (http://read.84000.co/translation/toh116.html). However, although listed (paradoxically along with Avalokiteśvara) as being in the assembly that hears the teaching of this sūtra, in the sūtra itself he is grouped with the worldly spirits that Avalokiteśvara frightens.
The name of a bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the bodhisattva great beings.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha.
One of the bodhisattvas attending this teaching.
A bodhisattva from Displaying Leonine Power’s buddha realm.

In the Kāraṇḍavyūha he is, as well as being listed as present at Buddha Śākyamuni’s teachings, the one who is described in Śākyamuni’s memories as the bodhisattva who questions Buddha Vipaśyin. He is the principal bodhisattva being addressed by Śākyamuni in chapter 35 of the Avatamsaka Sūtra. In the early tantras he is one of the sixteen bodhisattvas in the dharmadhātu maṇḍala. In the higher tantras he is associated with the ratna family of Buddha Ratnasambhava.
A great bodhisattva.
A head merchant’s son in Dhanyākara.
A great bodhisattva.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A type of worm ({srin bu}) that lives in and feeds on the body.
A great bodhisattva.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi; one of the kings of asuras.
Hand (body part); cubit (unit of length); the eleventh (sometimes thirteenth) lunar asterism.
A type of worm ({srin bu}) that lives in and feeds on the body.
A son of King Ikṣuvāku.
The study of seals and insignia.
Father of the buddha Mayūra.
The name of a nakṣatra.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Alpha Orionis in the occidental tradition.
“Path Bearer.” One of the bodhisattvas in the entourage of the Buddha Śākyamuni when he taught the girl Vimalaśraddhā.
Fourth of the four noble truths.
A sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.

Listed here as the course that is painful and that is slow in superior cognition, the course that is painful and that is quick in superior cognition, the course that is pleasant and that is slow in superior cognition, and the course that is pleasant and that is quick in superior cognition.
A class of asuras.
A mountain.
A sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Also referred to as “knowledge of paths,” it is the knowledge of a bodhisattva.
Second of the eight progressive sections of clear realization.
Also referred to as “knowledge of paths,” it is the knowledge of a bodhisattva.
Second of the eight progressive sections of clear realization.
Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration.
A physical condition considered an impediment to ordination.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
One of the two chandohas.
One of the goddesses invited to partake in the oblation offering.
One of the two chandohas.
A disciple of the Buddha.
One of the disciples of the Buddha.
A monk (bhikṣu) and disciple of the Buddha.
Śrāvaka arhat, one of the sixteen sthavira arhats (see “elder”).
Another name for Cūḍapanthaka, a disciple of the Buddha.
Eighth of the eleven aspects of knowledge.
A buddha realm.
Correct view, intention, speech, actions, livelihood, effort, mindfulness, and concentration. These eight are included in the thirty-seven factors of awakening.

The eight branches of the path, belonging to the thirty-seven aids to awakening, are right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right meditative stabilization.

Refers here to the eightfold path of the noble ones that belongs to the thirty-seven factors conducive to awakening: right view, thought, speech, actions, livelihood, effort, mindfulness, and absorption.
The state achieved by a once-returner.
Second of the four fruits attainable by śrāvakas.
One who has achieved the second of the four levels of attainment on the śrāvaka path, and who will only be reborn in saṃsāra once more.
A practitioner whose level of realization is such that he or she need only take one further saṃsāric rebirth to achieve enlightenment.
The second of the four attainments of śrāvakas, this term is used for those who will take only one more rebirth before attaining nirvāṇa.
Second of the four stages that culminate in becoming an arhat. At this stage, a being will only be reborn once again in the realm of desire.
One who has achieved the second of the four levels of attainment on the śrāvaka path, and who will have only one more rebirth before attaining liberation.
The second level of the four kinds of noble person (āryapudgala, {'phags pa'i gang zag}), who will only be reborn once more before attaining the state of arhat.
The second of the four (or eight) stages of the realization of the supermundane path (and fruit) leading to awakening. See “those who have entered the path of liberation.”
A person who has attained the second of the four stages of spiritual achievement and is considered to be reborn in the realm of desire only one more time.

One of the three types of karma whose results are experience neither in the present nor the next, but the subsequent lives. The other two types are the “karma that ripens in this life” (dṛṣṭa dharma vipāka or dṛṣṭa dharma vedanīya) and the “karma that is to be experienced in the immediately following life” (upapadya vedanīya).
One of the two pīlavas.
A sea between Videha and Jambudvīpa
Unidentified; the Tibetan translation could suggest the island of Langkawi. The Sanskrit text may be corrupt.
A mountain in Pūrvavideha.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
The island of Ceylon.
Present-day Śrī Laṅkā; the capital city of this island.
The island presently called Sri Lanka, it was known as Ceylon while it was a British colony.
A monster in Unbearably Terrifying.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
After a motion is put to the saṅgha, a monk other than the petitioner must make a move to act on the motion.
The monk that moves the saṅgha act on an aspirant’s request to join the order and be ordained.
The four primary categories of ritual activities: pacifying, increasing, enthralling, and subjugating.
A ruler of the Heaven Free from Strife.
Literally meaning the “fruit” of action(s), karmic result denotes rebirth and karmic punishment and reward as a consequence of, and in accordance with the moral character of, one’s actions.
One of the pīlavas.
Lit. “action seal,” a worldly (human) consort. Also rendered here in Sanskrit as “karmamudrā.”
One of the five buddha families, it is presided over by the Tathāgata Amoghasiddhi.
Name of an absorption.

The complex process of the ripening of karma, i.e., the development of the karmic result ({las kyi 'bras bu}) of karmically relevant actions committed with body, speech and mind, by virtue of the power of the action as cause and supporting conditions.
Obstructions due to past actions.
Obscurations or obstructions caused by past deeds.
The persistent physical, mental, or emotional obstacles to spiritual progress.
The emotional and cognitive veils that create impediments in one’s life and prevent one from seeing the nature of reality.
An obscuration consisting of negative actions committed in the past that prevents progress on the path to awakening in the present.
An alternate title for The Detailed Account of the Previous Aspirations of the Thus-Gone Bhaiṣajya guru vaiḍūrya prabha.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A mountain range surrounding the hell of Embers Within.

Read as a variant of the Tib. {bram ze'i las drug}, they are (1) reading ({klog pa}), (2) encouraging others to read ({klog tu 'jug pa}), (3) making sacrificial offerings ({mchod sbyin}), (4) encouraging others to perform sacrificial offerings ({mchod sbyin byed du 'jug pa}), (5) practicing giving/giving alms ({sbyin pa}), and (6) accepting alms/offerings ({len pa}) (Rigzin 285).
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

Literally “maker of sundry things,” Viśvakarma is the architect of the gods. He was an important deity in early Hinduism. In the Ṛg Veda, he is regarded as the personification of ultimate reality, the abstract creative power inherent in deities and in living and nonliving beings in this universe.
A god.

Meaning “action” in its most basic sense, karma is an important concept in Buddhist philosophy as the cumulative force of previous physcial, verbal, and mental acts, which determines present experience and will determine future existences.

A single term is used in Sanskrit and Tibetan to denote both an “action” as a conditioning factor and the “karma” that it conditions. In translation it may be necessary to use one term or the other to clarify the meaning, but the source term is no different.

Generally meaning “work,” or “action,” it is an important concept in Buddhist philosophy as the cumulative force of previous actions, which determines present experience and will determine future existences. In this text, it is left untranslated when this specific conception of moral causation is implied.

Karmic accumulation, positive or negative, that will produce results in the future, unless it is purified. This term is also translated in other instances as “activity” or “rite.” In these latter cases the term refers to a ritual activity (such as pacifying, nourishing, etc.) or a rite meant to accomplish such activity.

A rite that is meant to accomplish an activity (such as pacifying, nourishing, etc.). This term is also translated in other instances as “activity,” “karma,” “karman,” or “karmic accumulation.” In the latter three cases the term refers to karmic accumulation, positive or negative, that will produce results in the future, unless it is purified.

Matters that govern the saṅgha community’s daily life, regular observances (such as the rains retreat and the purification) and special events (like ordination) are ratified by a formal act of the saṅgha. There are one hundred and one such types of formal acts, all of which fall into one of three categories depending on the procedure needed for ratification. An act of motion alone requires only a petition; an act whose second member is a motion require a motion and the statement of the act; while an act whose fourth member is a motion require a motion and three statements of the act.
A physical condition considered an impediment to ordination.
The precise identity of this metal or metal compound is currently unclear. The Tibetan translation of the term means “high-quality metal.”
A type of worm ({srin bu}) that lives in and feeds on the body.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
The three usually are gold, silver and copper.
One of the sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Heat.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Howling Hell.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell. Alternatively referred to as Heap of Live Coals of Iron-dust ({lcags kyi phye ma me ma dag gi ra ba}).
A mountain off Videha.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell. Alternatively referred to as Metallic Fire ({lcags kyi me}).
The name of a karmic wind involved in the formation of an embryo in its thirtieth week.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
A goddess.
It is not clear who Aṅkuśarāja is; this could be a name variant of Amoghāṅkuśa.
Fifth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
One of the sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Heat.
One of the goddesses.
It is not clear who this goddess is. This could be a variant spelling of Saṅkalā.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Howling Hell.
The world of yakṣas ruled over by Kubera.
The name of a city on Mount Sumeru, and the main palace in that city.
The realm of Kubera.
A yakṣiṇī who converted to Buddhism.
A thunderbolt or flash of lightning.

Listed in The Question of Mañjuśrī as the tenth of the thirty-two signs of a great being. In most other sources, the Tibetan is rendered as “very long and slender tongue” ({ljags shin tu ring zhing srab pa}), but the underlying Sanskrit is likely the same or similar at the very least.
One of the bodhisattva great beings.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Tenth of the eighteen sensory elements.
One of the eighteen constituents.
Twelfth of the eighteen sensory elements.
Fourth of the twelve sense fields.

This description is in reference to one of the thirty-two signs of a great being. In some lists of the signs, this one is simply described as having a long and slender tongue, but in others it is explained that the tongue is capable of reaching anywhere on the face up to the hairline.
A south Indian king contemporary with Mahendra.
Attendant of the buddha Rāhucandra.
One of the pratyeka buddhas in the maṇḍala of Mañjuśrī (it is not clear if upāriṣṭa here is a variant spelling of upariṣṭa, i.e. one of the eight chief pratyeka buddhas).
Mythical eight-legged lion.
Speech with undisclosed meaning; speech that is indirect and therefore requires further interpretation.
Speech that is allusive, indirect, or contains undisclosed meaning and therefore requires further interpretation.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

In Buddhist logic, the term “distinguishing counterpart” (vyāvṛtti, {ldog pa}) denotes a given phenomenon that conceptually appears to be the opposite of a phenomenon of a dissimilar class but is not actually existent, such as the idea of a specific form that appears in conceptual thought.
Arsenic ore, used as a yellow pigment.
Carthamus tinctorius.
Lit. “separated from all laziness.” Name of a meditative stabilization.

This name is transcribed from the Chinese 牢度跋提. We have been unable to determine the meaning of this name, or a Sanskrit equivalent. In the Chinese, this figure is described as a “great god” rather than a “great king.”
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.

A distinctive shade of red now known as “rose madder,” common in ancient India and derived from the root of the madder plant (Rubia manjista/Rubia tinctorum). According to the Mahāvyutpatti, the Tibetan should be {btsod}.
Son of the buddha Yaśomati.
Birthplace of the buddha Sūrata.

A buddha realm.
Son of the buddha Vipulabuddhi.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha in the past.
A disciple of the Buddha.
Son of the buddha Ratnayaśas.

A pupil of the Buddha, originally a destitute beggar, who, in particular, accidentally drank alcohol offered by villagers after he had tamed a nāga to end a drought. This resulted in the Buddha’s adding abstention from alcohol as part of the monastic rules.

Svāgata was a pupil of the Buddha, originally a destitute beggar, who, in particular, accidentally drank alcohol offered by villagers after he had tamed a nāga to end a drought. This resulted in the Buddha’s adding abstention from alcohol as part of the monastic rules.
A future buddha realm where Vaiśravaṇa will awaken.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
Father of the buddha Guṇabala.
Mother of the buddha Abhaya.
Birthplace of the buddha Brahmamuni.
The 415th buddha in the first list, 414th in the second list, and 408th in the third list.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Maṇḍita.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Caraṇabhrāja.
Attendant of the buddha Anihatavrata.
The 616th buddha in the first list, 615th in the second list, and 608th in the third list.

(c. a.d. 400). A major Indian philosopher, a master of the Mādhyamika school of Buddhism, who founded a sub-school known as Svātantrika.

A buddha in the past. Note that there appear to be three distinct buddhas with the name Kṣemaṃkara as is listed at https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-5407 . See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-5278 .

Lit. “Auspicious Intellect.” The ninth level of accomplishment pertaining to bodhisattvas. See “ten bodhisattva levels.”

Sudatta was a great lay patron of the Buddha and philanthropist of Śrāvastī, and is more commonly called Anāthapiṇḍada ({mgon med zas sbyin}); he known as “the foremost of donors” (Pāli; aggo dāyakānaṃ).
“Well arisen.” The name of a kalpa in the distant past.

Monarch of Videha during Siṃhahanu’s reign in Kapilavastu, at the time of the Buddha’s birth as Siddhārtha Gautama. His daughters were Mahā māyā (the Buddha’s mother) and Māyā. See “Śākya Suprabuddha.”

A certain lay vow holder in Śrāvastī. Though in the Lalitavistara Sūtra and elsewhere a young woman named Sujātā is among those said to have given food to Gautama prior to his enlightenment, in this text and in the Divyāvadāna that deed is credited to Nandā and Nandabalā.
Father of the buddha Gandheśvara.

The ninth link of dependent arising.
The ninth of the twelve links of dependent origination. See “dependent origination.”
Ninth of the twelve links of dependent arising. For the four appropriations, see https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-057-006.html#UT22084-057-006-398 .

In some texts, four types of appropriation are listed: of desire (rāga), of view (dṛṣṭi), of rules and observances as paramount (śīla vrata parāmarśa), and of belief in a self (ātmavāda). The term {nye bar len pa} also means “grasping” and it was rendered as such when it refers to the ninth of the twelve links of dependent origination, between craving and becoming.

Also means “grasping” or “clinging;” but has a particular meaning as the ninth of the twelve links of dependent arising, between craving (tṛṣṇā, {sred pa}) and becoming or existence (bhava, {srid pa}). In some texts, four types of appropriation are listed: of desire (rāga), of view (dṛṣṭi), of rules and observances as paramount (śīla vrata parāmarśa), and of belief in a self (ātmavāda). Only the first three are mentioned in this sūtra.
cf. Sanskrit text in Matsuda 2013, p. 940 ad Lamotte VIII.40.

A cousin of Buddha Śākyamuni who broke with him and established his own community. His tradition was still continuing during the first millennium ce. He is portrayed as engendering evil schemes against the Buddha and even succeeding in wounding him. He is usually identified with wicked beings in accounts of previous lifetimes.

A wheel-turning king who was the Buddha in a former life. It is also the name of his eldest son and the other eighty-four thousand eldest sons in his line of succession.
In former times, the king of the city of Mithilā. His two chief ministers were Nanda and Upananda.\nIn other contexts, sometimes an epithet of the god Śiva, see “Mahā deva.”

An epithet of the god Śiva. Though not in this text, in other texts this term may also appear as an epithet of the Buddha. Alternatively a certain king of Mithilā who lived before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni, see “Mahā deva (the king).”

Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Bhava tṛṣṇā mala prahīṇa.

The eight classes are gods, nāgas, yakṣas, gandharvas, asuras, garuḍas, kinnaras, and mahoragas.

Father of the buddha Marutskandha.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Padmaśrī.

A class of semidivine beings who are engaged in a mythic war with the gods (deva) for possession of the nectar of immortality. In Buddhist cosmology, they inhabit the realm neighboring that of the gods, from which they observe the gods with intense jealousy.

One of the six classes of sentient beings. The asuras are engendered and dominated by envy, ambition, and hostility and are metaphorically described as being incessantly embroiled in disputes with the gods (deva). They are frequently portrayed in brahmanical mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.

One of the six classes of living beings, sometimes included among the gods and sometimes among the animals. A class of superhuman beings, sometimes misleadingly called demigods, engendered and dominated by envy, ambition, and hostility, who are metaphorically described as being incessantly embroiled in a dispute with the gods over the possession of a magical tree.

One of the six classes of sentient beings according to the Buddhist tradition. The asuras are engendered and dominated by envy, ambition, and hostility, who are metaphorically described as being incessantly embroiled in disputes with the gods (deva). They are frequently portrayed in brahmanical mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.

A class of beings, accounts of which can be traced back to the Vedas. They are often considered inferior, even demonic, deities. In Buddhist contexts, they are generally depicted as being in constant conflict with the gods due to their intense jealousy. They are often considered one of the six realms of rebirth in saṃsāra, although they are sometimes classified together with the gods.

One of the six classes of living beings, asuras are sometimes included among the gods and sometimes among the animals. They are engendered and dominated by envy, ambition, and hostility and are metaphorically described as being incessantly embroiled in disputes with the gods (devas). They are frequently portrayed in brahmanical mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.
The 835th buddha in the first list, 834th in the second list, and 824th in the third list.
Mother of the buddha Ratnābhacandra.

In Tibetan, māra is usually rendered as {bdud}; {lha min} usually translates asura (“demigod”).
A class of divine beings ranking below gods (deva), known for their jealous and warlike disposition.
The traditional adversaries of the devas (gods), who are frequently portrayed in brahmanical mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.

A class of semidivine beings who are engaged in a mythic war with the gods (deva) for possession of the nectar of immortality. In Buddhist cosmology, they inhabit the realm neighboring that of the gods, from which they observe the gods with intense jealousy.

“Glorious Great Goddess.” This is also a widespread name in Hindu contexts; it is, for example, an epithet of Śiva’s consort.

Another name of Umā, one of Śiva’s wives.

Umādevī is also known as Pārvatī. The name is of obscure origin, but can mean “splendor,” “tranquility,” or “light.” She is the consort of Śiva, also known as Maheśvara, and believed to be the rebirth of Sīta, his previous consort.

Popular figures in Indian culture, they are said to be goddesses of the clouds and water. They are also portrayed as the wives of the gandharvas who are the court musicians for Śakra/Indra on top of Mount Meru.

In this sūtra, “apsaras” (or “apsarases” in plural) is synonymous with devī, the female equivalent of deva. In Indian culture, it is also the name for goddesses of the clouds and water, and the wives of the gandharvas.

The “apsarases” are popular figures in Indian culture, they are said to be goddesses of the clouds and water and to be wives of the gandharvas. However, in the Kāraṇḍavyūha, they are presented as the female equivalent of the devas. Therefore the Tibetan has translated them as if the word were devī (“goddess’’).

A xylograph Kangyur printed in 1934. Based mainly on the Narthang ({snar thang}) Kangyur but with some texts following the Degé Kangyur, it is among several Kangyurs of “mixed” lineage, including elements from the Thempangma ({them spangs ma}) in addition to the predominating Tshalpa ({tshal pa}) traditions.

A disciple of the Buddha.

The Śākyan cousin of the Buddha traditionally depicted as eager for gain and jealous of the Buddha’s fame.

The historical Buddha’s cousin, and brother of Ānanda. He became notorious through his schemes to become the Buddha’s successor—to the point of attempting to kill the Buddha—and through the splitting of the Saṅgha.

The Buddha’s cousin and fellow Śākya clan member as well as his brother-in-law; brother of Ānanda and Upadhāna. His hostility toward Buddha Śākyamuni is widely recorded in Buddhist literature, and as a result he often represents the paradigm of improper behavior and attitudes toward the Buddha and the Buddhist saṅgha.

A cousin of the Buddha Śākyamuni who broke with him and established his own community. His tradition was still continuing during the first millennium ᴄᴇ. He is portrayed as engendering evil schemes against the Buddha and even succeeding in wounding him. He is usually identified with wicked beings in accounts of previous lifetimes.

This term, meaning “god,” was often used as an honorific term of address for divine beings and royalty. In such contexts, it has been rendered here with the Sanskrit deva.

One of the five or six classes of living beings, specifically engendered and dominated by exaltation, indulgence, and pride. The gods are said to exist in realms higher than that of the human realm within in the world system of desire (kāma dhātu), and also in the world system of form (rūpa dhātu).

Literally “son of gods” or “divine scion,” the Sanskrit devaputra is often simply used as a synonym for “god” (deva), with -putra indicating that it involves a male member of this category of beings. But the term can have the added connotation of a being of divine origin who, due to a heroic feat, is able to enjoy long-lasting bliss in heaven.
Attendant of the buddha Varabodhigati.

A common epithet of Śatakratu, also known as Indra.

Second of the five eyes. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1117 .

Clairvoyance, i.e., the ability to see all forms whether they are near or far, subtle or gross; also the ability to see the births and deaths of sentient beings. This is the first of the six (or sometimes five) superknowledges (ṣaḍabhijñā).

One of the six “superknowledges” (q.v.) as well as one of the “five eyes,” this is the supernormal ability to see to an unlimited distance, observe events on other worlds, see through mountains, etc. The five eyes consist of five different faculties of vision: the physical eye (māṃsa cakṣu), the divine eye (dīvya cakṣu), the wisdom eye (prajñā cakṣu), the Dharma-eye (dharma cakṣu), and the Buddha-eye (buddha cakṣu).
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Śīlaprabha.

Name of a bodhisattva.
A buddha.
Name of a bodhisattva.

The name of Devadatta when he becomes a buddha in the future.

Third of the six extrasensory powers.
One of the five supernormal knowledges.

Clairaudience, i.e., the sublime ability to understand all languages and listen to them whether they are nearby or far away. This is the second of the six (or sometimes five) superknowledges (ṣaḍabhijñā).
A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Vigataśoka.

Prolific Tibetan translator active during the late eighth- and early ninth-centuries.

Child of the high brahmin Majestic Body, he visited Lord Buddha to inquire about the proper way to perform the sacrifice, and hearing the Dharma that the Buddha taught in reply he attained stream entry.
A strong sense of determination, often associated with altruism.
The attainment of nirvāṇa without any remainder of the physical and mental aggregates.
One of the different types of nirvāṇa, where the aggregates have also been consumed within emptiness. See also “final nirvāṇa.”

The mode of nirvāṇa in which all physical and mental attributes have been relinquished. This mode occurs after death, as some physical and mental attributes remain when an awakened being is still alive.
The cessation of karma and affliction within which no residue of the aggregates remains.
A sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
The second of the two main branches of Buddhist meditation (along with “peaceful meditation”) aiming at developing insight into the nature of reality.
One of the basic forms of Buddhist meditation, aimed at developing insight into the nature of reality. Often presented as part of a pair of meditation techniques, the other being “tranquility.”

An important form of Buddhist meditation focusing on developing insight into the nature of phenomena. Often presented as part of a pair of meditation techniques, the other being “tranquility” (śamatha).

Refers to insight into the nature of reality or the practice of developing such insight. One of the two basic forms of Buddhist meditation, the other being meditative calm (Skt. śamatha; Tib. {zhi gnas}).

Often translated as “insight meditation,” referring to the liberating insight into the nature of reality or the meditative practice of developing insight into the nature of reality. One of the two basic forms of Buddhist meditation, the other being calm abiding (śamatha).

This is paired with “mental quiescence” (see entry). In general “meditation” is too often understood as only the types of practices categorized as “quietistic”—which eschew objects, learning, analysis, discrimination, etc., and lead only to the attainment of temporary peace and one-pointedness. However, in order to reach any high realization, such as the absence of a personal self, the absence of a self in phenomena, or voidness, “transcendental analysis,” with its analytical penetration to the nature of ultimate reality, is indispensable. The analysis is called “transcendental” because it does not accept anything it sees as it appears. Instead, through analytic examination, it penetrates to its deeper reality, going ever deeper in infinite penetration until tolerance is reached. All apparently self-sufficient objects are seen through and their truth-status is rejected—first conceptually and finally perceptually, at buddhahood. Thus “meditation,” to be efficacious, must include both mental quiescence (śamatha), and transcendental analysis (vipaśyana) in integrated combination.
A forest on Flocking Peacocks.

Bṭ1 na, 39a3–b3https://read.84000.co/translation/toh3807.html lists the following: (1–3) faith in the Buddha, Dharma, and Saṅgha (the finest aspiration); (4) for morality (moral aspiration); (5–9) aspiration for the perfections (surpassing aspiration for the other five perfections); (10–13) aspiration for the profound selflessness of persons and dharmas, the ultimate, and the reality of dharmas (aspiration for the real dharmas); (14–15) a single-pointed mind and clairvoyance (inconceivable aspiration); (16) aspiration to establish beings in the wholesome; (17–18) the pure aspiration of the ninth and tenth levels; and (19–20) aspiration for the inconceivable force of a buddha’s clairvoyance, etc.
Selfless concern for the well-being of others.
A strong sense of determination, often associated with altruism.
As defined in the Bodhisattvabhūmi, this is a bodhisattva’s determined, deeply informed enthusiasm for the Buddhist teachings that is grounded in faith and careful study of the Dharma.

This is a stage in the conception or initiation of the spirit‌ of enlightenment‌. It follows upon the positive thought, or aspiration to attain it, wherein the bodhisattva becomes filled with a lofty determination that he himself should attain enlightenment, that it is the only thing to do to solve his own problems as well as those of all living beings. This high resolve reaches its most intense purity when the bodhisattva simultaneously attains the Path of Insight and the first bodhisattva-stage, the Stage of Joy. The translation follows Lamotte’s happy coinage “haute résolution.”
One of the seven types of pride. The pride of thinking oneself equal to superiors and superior to equals.
A particular type of pride associated with the unreasonable opinion that one is superior to those with whom one is in fact equal.

The pride of overestimating one’s accomplishments. It is one of seven types of pride, which include (1) pride (Tib. {nga rgyal;}Skt. māna), (2) excessive pride (Tib. {lhag pa'i nga rgyal;} Skt. adhimāna), (3) outrageous pride (Tib. {nga rgyal las kyang nga rgyal;} Skt. mānātimāna), (4) egoistic pride (Tib. {nga'o snyam pa'i nga rgyal}; Skt. asmimāna), (5) blatant pride (Tib. {mngon pa'i nga rgyal;} Skt. abhimāna), (6) pride of feeling inferior (Tib. {cung zad snyam pa'i nga rgyal}; Skt. ūnamāna), and (7) unfounded pride (Tib. {log pa'i nga rgyal}; Skt. mithyāmāna).
A lay brother living in Nādikā.
A king.
A broad term for any kind of service that one might perform to honor, worship, or otherwise support the Three Jewels, even outside the context of performing a formal offering rite.
A “ruler of the world” who belongs to the class of the māras.
A realm of the ever-infatuated gods.
It is marked by the moment when the wisdom deity (jñānasattva) descends into the maṇḍala.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
One of the two primary forms of meditation in Buddhism, the other being calm abiding.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Niyatabuddhi.
A meditation teacher who was one of the Buddha’s teachers before he attained awakening.
Although the spelling Rudraka is attested in the Sanskrit of this sūtra, in most other texts his name is Udraka, or Udraka Rāmaputra (“Udraka the son of Rāma”).
A junior monk who lives with and under the guidance of a senior monk.

Although referred to as the “fourth” in the fourfold division of the joys, the innate joy does not fit into a sequential order in quite the same way as the other three joys. It is first discerned when the supreme joy gives way to the joy of cessation, and is gradually extended through practice until it becomes ever present.
Yakṣa and other spirits that appear at the same time a person is born in order to protect them.
The fourth joy.
Son of Siddhārtha Gautama’s maternal grandfather King Suprabuddha of Videha.
A city ruled by King Suprabuddha.
Mother of the buddha Vidyutprabha.
Father of the buddha Maruttejas.
Nāga King Sāgara in a previous life as a universal monarch in the world to the east called Pure View.
The Buddha’s jealous, scheming cousin.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Nirbhaya.
Cousin, student, and competitor with the Buddha. He is one of the main characters in the stories from the Buddha’s life.
The name of the Buddha’s cousin and brother-in-law who defected from the Buddha’s saṅgha, causing the very first schism, and went on to compete against and even attempt to kill the Buddha Śākyamuni.

The historical Buddha’s cousin, and brother of Ānanda. He became notorious through his schemes to become the Buddha’s successor—to the point of attempting to kill the Buddha—and through the splitting of the Saṅgha.

A cousin of Śākyamuni, who broke with him and established his own community. His tradition was still continuing during the first millennium ce. He is portrayed as engendering evil schemes against the Buddha and even succeeding in wounding him. He is usually identified with wicked beings in accounts of previous lifetimes, but not in The White Lotus of the Good Dharma, where he is a teacher of the Buddha in a previous lifetime, and the Buddha prophesies his future buddhahood.
Mother of the buddha Gaṇiprabha.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Puṇyaraśmi.
Son of the buddha Kuśalapradīpa.
Attendant of the buddha Ratnaruta.
Birthplace of the buddha Satyadeva.
Mother of the buddha Sthita buddhi rūpa.
Father of the buddha Sthita buddhi rūpa.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Uttama.
One of the Buddha’s foremost hearer disciples. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-048-001-OLD.html#UT22084-048-001-OLD-39 .
Son of the buddha Jñānapriya.

A cousin of the Buddha Śākyamuni who broke with him and established his own community. His tradition was still continuing during the first millennium ᴄᴇ. He is portrayed as engendering evil schemes against the Buddha and even succeeding in wounding him. He is usually identified with wicked beings in accounts of previous lifetimes.
A world system.

One of the five or six classes of sentient beings, specifically influenced by exaltation, frivolousness, and pride. According to Buddhist cosmology, the gods live in many divine realms within the desire realm, the form realm, and the formless realm.. Also rendered here as “devas.”

One of the five or six classes of living beings, specifically engendered and dominated by exaltation, indulgence, and pride. The gods are said to exist in realms higher than that of the human realm within in the world system of desire (kāma dhātu), and also in the world system of form (rūpa dhātu).

One of the five or six classes of sentient beings, specifically engendered and dominated by exaltation, indulgence, and pride. The gods are said to exist in realms higher than that of the human realm within in the world system of desire (kāma dhātu), and also in the world system of form (rūpa dhātu).

One of the five or six classes of sentient beings, specifically engendered and dominated by exaltation, indulgence, and pride. According to Buddhist cosmology, the gods are said to exist in many levels of celestial or divine realms, higher than that of the human realm, within in the desire realm, in the form realm, and in the formless realm.

According to the Buddhist tradition, one of the five or six classes of sentient beings, specifically engendered and dominated by exaltation, indulgence, and pride. The gods are said to exist in many levels of celestial or divine realms, higher than that of the human realm, within in the desire realm (kāma dhātu), and also in the form realm (rūpa dhātu) and the formless realm (ārūpya dhātu).

Cognate with the English term divine. The devas are most generically a class of divine, celestial beings who populate the narratives of Indian mythology. Devas make regular appearances in Buddhist literature at the head of the assemblies of celestial and supernatural beings who attend the teachings, interact with the Buddha, bodhisattvas, and other spiritual figures, and celebrate the delivery of their sermons. In Buddhist cosmology, the devas are subdivided into numerous classes based on the specific devalokas, the “heavens” in which they reside. Traditionally there are between twenty-six and twenty-eight devalokas, divided between the desire realm (kāmadhātu), form or material realm (rūpadhātu), and formless or immaterial realm (arūpyadhātu). The state of deva is reached either through meritorious acts or the cultivation of subtle meditative states, and is therefore considered a higher mode of rebirth in comparison to rebirth among hell beings, pretas, and animals. Nonetheless, all the devalokas are within the three realms of saṃsāra and therefore transitory. Thus while the devas occupy the highest strata within the scheme of the five or six “destinies” (gati), the realms within saṃsāra where beings take rebirth, their state is still one determined by the fetters (saṃyojana) that bind one to the perpetual cycle of rebirth. Also rendered here as “gods.”
One of the two kings of the country of Pañcāla.
A region where the teachings on the perfection of wisdom will spread.
Symptom that may be evidence of an illness considered an impediment to ordination. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1011 .

Early Mahāyāna sūtras identify this as separate from Sumeru, the mountain at the center of the world. This refers to a legendary mountain in such epics as the Mahābhārata, which, while sacred, is not situated in the world’s center. This is presumably identical to the Mount Meru that is the source of one of the two main tributaries of the Ganges and lies within the territory of India.

The kinnara king Druma is a well-known figure in canonical Buddhist literature, where he frequently appears, mostly in minor roles. For example, King Druma appears in https://read.84000.co/translation/toh113.html (Toh 113), where he is one of the four kinnara kings attending the Buddha’s teaching. He is also included in https://read.84000.co/translation/toh127.html (Toh 127), where he arrives with his queens to make an offering of his music to the Buddha. He is also a bodhisattva who teaches and displays a profound understanding of the doctrine of emptiness in https://read.84000.co/translation/toh157.html (Toh 157), where his future awakening is also prophesied by the Buddha.\n(His name has been translated into Tibetan both as “{sdong po}” and “{ljon pa}.”)

“Lord of the world” is a translation of lokeśvara or lokanātha when these are used in their literal meaning (for the technical meaning of the first see the glossary entry for Lokeśvara). The latter of the two terms has an added connotation of the “protector of the world,” however, in most contexts, the meaning of the “lord of the world” predominates. The phrase is capitalized when used as the title without the name.

“Lokeśvara” is the title applied to Avalokiteśvara and his male emanations, including Amoghapāśa; in the later tradition there are 108 lokeśvaras. In contexts where the literal meaning, “lord of the world,” is more relevant than the class name, the term has been translated as such (see corresponding glossary entry for “lord of the world”). It is capitalized when used as the title without the name, such as “the Lokeśvara” or “the Lord of the World.”

The tenth of the ten nonvirtuous actions; also one of five commonly listed kinds of erroneous views, wrong view designates the disbelief in the doctrine of karma, i.e., rebirth and karmic punishment and reward as a consequence of one’s actions (i.e., cause and effect of actions).
