An emanated city on the back of Airāvaṇa.

The capital of the ancient Indian kingdom of Kośala, and the setting for many sūtras, as the Buddha spent most rainy seasons outside the city. It has been identified with the present-day Sāhet Māhet in Uttar Pradesh on the banks of the river Rapti.

The capital of Kośala, a kingdom in what is now Uttar Pradesh, where Buddha Śākyamuni spent most of his life. There are differing explanations for the name, including that it was founded by King Śrāvasta or that it was named after a rishi, Sāvattha, who lived there.

The capital town of the ancient Indian kingdom of Kośala. It has been identified with the present-day Sāhet Māhet in Uttar Pradesh on the banks of the river Rapti (cf. DPPN, s.v. Sāvatthi. The majority of the suttas in the Pāli Canon mention Sāvatthi as the place where the Buddha gave sermons.)

The capital of the ancient Indian kingdom of Kośala, where the Buddha spent many summers and gave numerous teachings. The city was ruled by King Prasenajit, who makes frequent appearances in the sūtras. It is also the site of Prince Jeta’s Grove, which was gifted to the Buddha by his patron Anāthapiṇḍada.

Śrāvastī (Pali: Sāvatthi) was the capital of the kingdom of Kosala in the Ganges plains to the west of Magadha and was incorporated into Magadha in the fourth century bce. The area is now the Awadh or Oudh region of Uttar Pradesh. The Buddha Śākyamuni spent twenty-four monsoon retreats there at Jetavana. Also translated as {mnyan yod}.

The capital of the ancient Indian kingdom of Kośala during the sixth–fifth centuries bce ruled by one of the Buddha’s royal patrons, King Prasenajit. It was the setting for many sūtras as the Buddha spent many rains retreats outside the city, in the Jeta Grove. It has been identified with the present-day Sahet Mahet in Uttar Pradesh on the banks of the river Rapti.
The capital of the ancient Kosala kingdom in India.

The capital of the ancient Indian kingdom of Kośala, and the setting for many sūtras, as the Buddha spent most rainy seasons in a park outside the city called the Jeta Grove. The city has been identified with the present-day Sāhet Māhet in Uttar Pradesh on the banks of the river Rapti.

The capital of the ancient Indian kingdom of Kośala during the sixth and fifth centuries ʙᴄᴇ.The Buddha spent a number of rains retreats outside the city in the Jeta Grove, which therefore became the setting for many sūtras. It has been identified with present-day Sahet Mahet in Uttar Pradesh.

The capital of the ancient Indian kingdom of Kośala, where the Buddha spent many summers and gave numerous teachings. The city was ruled by King Prasenajit, who makes frequent appearances in the sūtras. It is also the site of the Jeta Grove, which was gifted to the Buddha by his patron Anāthapiṇḍada.

The capital city of the kingdom of Kośala which was ruled over by King Prasenajit, one of the Buddha’s devoted patron kings. It is located on the banks of the Rāpti river in northern India, not far west from Kapilavastu and Lumbinī. The Buddha spent many rainy-season retreats there, especially in the later years of his life.

The capital of the ancient Indian kingdom of Kośala during the sixth–fifth centuries bce, which was ruled by one of the Buddha’s royal patrons, King Prasenajit. It was the setting for many sūtras, as the Buddha spent many rains retreats outside the city in the Jeta Grove. It has been identified with present-day Sahet Mahet in Uttar Pradesh on the banks of the river Rapti.

A city of ancient India, in what is now Uttar Pradesh. The name Śrāvastī is explained as being derived from the name of a sage, Śravasta, who used to live in that area (this explanation is found in the commentary Nibandhana, Samtani 1971, p. 77, and is also found in the ṭīkā on Distinctly Ascertaining the Meanings found in the Tengyur, where, however, the name of the sage is transliterated as Śravasti). Pāli sources offer three explanations for the term: one is the one just mentioned, that Sāvatthī is derived from Savattha, just like other city names (Kākandī, Mākandī, Kosambī); alternatively, it is so called because “everything is there” in terms of possible objects of enjoyment for humans; and lastly the name refers to the reply, “there is everything,” that the Buddha offered when asked about what kind of shops were there (sāvatthīti savatthassa isino nivāsaṭṭhānabhūtā nagarī yathā kākandī mākandī kosambīti evaṃ tāva akkharacintakā aṭṭhakathācariyā pana bhaṇanti yaṃkiñci manussānaṃ upabhogaparibhogaṃ sabbamettha atthīti sāvatthī satthasamāyoge ca kiṃ bhaṇḍam atthīti pucchite sabbamatthīti vacanam upādāya sāvatthī Aṭṭhakathā on the Sabbāsava sutta of the Majjhima nikāya, Mūlapaṇṇāsa). The Tibetan translation as {mnyan yod} seems to derive the first part of the name from the root śru (“to hear”) and the second part as “there is” (asti); this derivation seems to be implied in one of the explanations of the Artha viniścaya ṭīkā.https://read.84000.co/translation/toh4365.html

An early stage in a bodhisattva’s career during which they have developed a degree of conviction that is not yet informed by direct experience. The level of devoted engagement is said to comprise the first two of the five paths, those of accumulation and preparation, which lead up to the path of seeing. This level is also presented as the second of seven spiritual levels in the Bodhisattvabhūmi,https://read.84000.co/translation/toh4037.html which follows the initial level of the spiritual potential (gotrabhūmi).

A buddha in the distant past. The name as given in verse. In prose he is called Vipula dharmādhimukti saṃbhava tejas.
A bodhisattva monk; a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
A type of worm ({srin bu}) that lives in and feeds on the body.
One of the great śrāvakas present in Śrāvastī. Also called Vasunandi. In other sūtras translated as {dga' byed}.

In a general sense, the mental inclination or focus toward a virtuous object. The term is also classified as a mental factor (caitta), being categorized variably according to different Buddhist schools but generally indicating the mental ability to focus on one object without straying to another. The term is also commonly translated as “determination,” “interest,” or “zeal.”

The level of devoted conduct is said to comprise the first two of the five paths, those of accumulation and preparation, which lead up to the path of seeing. This level is also presented as the second of seven spiritual levels in the Bodhisattva bhūmi,https://read.84000.co/translation/toh4035.html which follows the initial level of the spiritual potential (gotrabhūmi).

The two views of (1) eternalism (nityānta), the belief in a permanent, causeless creator and/or the belief in an independent, permanent, singular self; and (2) nihilism (ucchedānta), the belief that things ultimately do not exist and/or the denial of the law of cause and effect or of past and future lives.

Nine states of concentration that one may attain during a human life, corresponding to the four concentrations found in the form realm, the four concentrations found in the formless realm, and the attainment of the state of cessation.

An alternate name for Viṣṇu. The Sanskrit is variously interpreted, including as “dwelling in water,” but is most obviously “the path of human beings.”

An alternate name for Viṣṇu ({khyab 'jug}), which is also used for Brahmā and for Kṛṣṇa. The Sanskrit is variously interpreted as “the path of human beings” and “the son of man.” In Buddhist texts it is used for powerful beings such as Śakra. The usual Tibetan translation is {sred med kyi bu}, meaning “the son of Nāra,” with Nāra translated as “one without craving.” However, here it appears to be translated as {mthu bo che} (“great power”).
One of the bodhisattva great beings.

Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Vajradhvaja.

Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Yangarvatī.
One of the lokeśvara emanations of Avalokiteśvara; also, one of the ancient bodhisattvas, possibly the same as Mahāsthānaprāpta.
The name of an important bodhisattva in the Mahāyāna pantheon.
Dharma-preaching monk living at the time of the buddha King of All Qualities’ Light Rays.
One of the lokeśvara emanations of Avalokiteśvara; also, one of the ancient bodhisattvas, possibly the same as Mahāsthānaprāpta.

A bodhisattva who serves alongside Avalokiteśvara as Amitābha’s attendant in the buddhafield of Sukhāvatī. As his name suggests, he is renowned for possessing great strength (Skt. prāpta; Tib. {thob pa}) and power (Skt. mahāsthāma; Tib. {mthu chen}).
Bodhisattva great being who represents the power of wisdom.
Along with Avalokiteśvara, he is one of the two main bodhisattvas in the realm of Sukhāvatī.
An alternate name for Vajrapāṇi, the bodhisattva of power; one of the bodhisattvas in the retinue of the Buddha.
One of the lokeśvara emanations of Avalokiteśvara; also, one of the ancient bodhisattvas, possibly the same as Mahāsthānaprāpta.
A bodhisattva great being present in the audience of this sūtra. Along with Avalokiteśvara, he is one of the two main bodhisattvas in the realm of Sukhāvatī.
One of the two principal bodhisattvas in Sukhāvatī, and prominent in Chinese Buddhism. In Tibetan Buddhism, he is identified with Vajrapāṇī, though they are separate bodhisattvas in the sūtras.
A group of goddesses connected to Vajrapāṇi; also, a group of mātṛs attending upon Skanda.
The 372nd buddha in the first list, 371st in the second list, and 366th in the third list.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Maitreya (5) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.

A gathering of all the monks present within a monastery’s boundaries for an official function (such as an ordination ceremony); with consent from any absentee monks. Also rendered here as “in concord.”\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-881 .

Acts for which one will be reborn in hell immediately after death, without any intervening stages; they are killing a worthy one, killing one’s father, killing one’s mother, causing a schism in the saṅgha, and maliciously drawing blood from a tathāgata.

The five heinous deeds or acts that bring immediate retribution: (1) killing one’s father, (2) killing one’s mother, (3) killing an arhat, (4) drawing blood from the body of a tathāgata with malicious intent, and (5) causing schism in the saṅgha.

Matricide, parricide, killing an arhat, causing a schism in the monastic order, and drawing a buddha’s blood with malicious intention. These actions are said to result in immediate birth in the hells.
These are killing one’s mother, father, or an arhat; drawing blood from a thus-gone one; or causing a schism in the sangha.

Lit. “sins of immediate retribution [after death].” These five, all of which cause immediate rebirth in hell, are killing one’s father, killing one’s mother, killing an arhat, breaking up the saṅgha, and causing, with evil intent, the Tathāgata to bleed.

The five inexpiable acts are 1) killing one’s father, 2) killing one’s mother, 3) killing a worthy one (Skt. arhat), 4) shedding the blood of a buddha with ill intent, and 5) sowing discord in the saṅgha. These acts are said to lead to unavoidable rebirth in the hell realms.

The five extremely negative actions which, once those who have committed them die, result in their going immediately to the hells without experiencing the intermediate state. They are killing an arhat, killing one’s mother, killing one’s father, creating schism in the Saṅgha, and maliciously drawing blood from a tathāgata’s body.

The “five inexpiable crimes,” or “crimes with immediate retribution” because they result in immediate rebirth in the hells without any intermediate state, are regarded as the most severe and consequently the most difficult negative actions to overcome by reparation. They are matricide ({ma gsod pa}), killing an arhat ({dgra bcom pa gsod pa}), patricide ({pha gsod pa}), creating a schism in the monastic community ({dge 'dun gyi dbyen byas pa}), and intentionally wounding a buddha ({de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku la ngan sems kyis khrag 'byin pa}).

Acts for which one will be reborn in hell immediately after death, without any intervening stages; they are (1) killing one’s master or father, (2) killing one’s mother, (3) killing an arhat, (4) maliciously drawing blood from a buddha, and (5) causing a schism in the saṅgha.

Acts for which one will be reborn in hell immediately after death, without any intervening stages; they are killing a worthy one, killing one’s father, killing one’s mother, causing a schism in the saṅgha, and maliciously drawing blood from a tathāgata.

A subsidiary set of actions that bring immediate and severe consequences at death, such that the person who commits them will take rebirth in the lower realms directly after they die. These five are damaging a caitya, killing a bodhisattva, violating a woman who has exhausted her afflictions, killing a novice student, and stealing from the saṅgha.

Five actions that bring immediate and severe consequences at death, such that the person who commits them will take rebirth in the lower realms directly after they die. The five are patricide, matricide, killing an arhat, intentionally injuring a buddha, and causing a schism within the saṅgha.

These five are killing one’s father, killing one’s mother, killing an arhat, wounding a buddha, and splitting a buddha’s saṅgha. They are literally called “without an interval” because they result in instantaneous rebirth in hell at the moment of death without passing through an intermediate state.

Acts for which one will be reborn in hell immediately after death, without any intervening stages; they include killing one’s mother, father, or an arhat, causing a dissention in the saṅgha, and causing the blood of a tathāgata to flow. The term is also written in this translation as the “five karmas of immediate retribution.”

Five actions that bring immediate and severe consequences at death. The person who engages in them will experience a rebirth in the lower realms directly after death. The five are (1) killing one’s father, (2) killing one’s mother, (3) killing an arhat, (4) causing a schism in the saṅgha, and (5) with evil intention making a buddha bleed.

The five extremely negative actions which, once those who have committed them die, result in the perpetrators going immediately to the hells without experiencing the intermediate state. They are killing an arhat, killing one’s mother, killing one’s father, creating schism in the saṅgha, and maliciously drawing blood from a tathāgata’s body.

Describing the result of committing one of five particularly heinous crimes: (1) killing one’s father, (2) killing one’s mother, (3) killing an arhat, (4) maliciously drawing blood from a buddha, and (5) causing a schism in the sangha. In this sūtra, Mañjuśrī describes a corresponding set of five acts with immediate consequences that bodhisattvas should, in fact, perform.
The five actions that lead to going instantly to hell on death are killing one’s father, killing one’s mother, killing an arhat, splitting the saṅgha, and wounding a buddha so that he bleeds.

The five extremely negative actions that, once those who have committed them die, result in immediate rebirth in the hells without the experience of the intermediate state. They are killing an arhat, killing one’s mother, killing one’s father, creating a schism in the Saṅgha, and maliciously drawing blood from a tathāgata’s body.

Sanskrit ānantarya is a short for pañcā nantaryāṇi karmāṇi. These are five grave sins which, when committed, lead one to fall immediately, i.e., with no intermediate period, into the Avīci hell after death due to their severity. Usually five are enumerated: killing one’s mother, father, or an arhat; causing dissension in the order of monks (the saṅgha); and deliberately causing a tathāgata’s blood to flow. But the exact number of items varies in different lists from two or three to five (cf. BHSD, s.v. ānantarya).

Five actions considered so heinous that they result in immediate rebirth in the hell realms. They include killing one’s mother, killing one’s father, killing an arhat, harming a buddha, and creating a schism in the saṅgha.

Describing the result of commiting one of five particularly heinous crimes: (1) killing one’s father, (2) killing one’s mother, (3) killing an arhat, (4) maliciously drawing blood from a buddha, and (5) causing a schism in the sangha.

Five particularly heinous crimes that result in immediate and severe consequences: (1) killing one’s father, (2) killing one’s mother, (3) killing a worthy one, (4) maliciously drawing blood from a buddha, and (5) causing a schism in the saṅgha.

The most severe among the eight hot hell realms. It is characterized as endless not only in terms of the torment undergone there, but also because of the ceaseless chain of actions and effects experienced, the long lifespan of its denizens, and their being so intensely crowded together that there is no physical space between them.

The five heinous deeds or acts that bring immediate retribution: (1) killing one’s father, (2) killing one’s mother, (3) killing an arhat, (4) drawing blood from the body of a tathāgata with malicious intent, and (5) causing schism in the saṅgha.

The most severe among the eight hot hell realms. It is characterized as endless not only in terms of the torment undergone there, but also because of the ceaseless chain of actions and effects experienced, the long lifespan of its denizens, and their being so intensely crowded together that there is no physical space between them.
The name of a god.

An area demarcated by the saṅgha which then functions as the community’s borders. Such boundaries may be set to define the area monks are confined to during the rains retreat. A gathering of all the monks within these boundaries constitutes a “consensus,” during which formal acts of saṅgha may be performed.
Son of the buddha Guṇaratna.
Attendant of the buddha Sthita buddhi rūpa.
A god.
Name of a god.
Son of the buddha Viniścitamati.
The thirty-two signs and the eighty marks of a superior being.
The thirty-two major and the eighty minor distinctive physical attributes of a buddha or a superior being.
The thirty-two primary and eighty secondary physical characteristics of a “great being,” a mahāpuruṣa, which every buddha has.
Seventy-eighth of the eighty minor marks.
A tathāgata mentioned here as one of the thirty-five buddhas of confession.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Jagattoṣaṇa (819 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A buddha realm in the upward direction.
A buddha in the distant past.
A buddha.
Attendant of the buddha Mānajaha.
A buddha realm.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Añjana.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Mārakṣayaṃkara (887 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.

Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Arciskandha (449 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
A bodhisattva from King of All Śāla Trees’ buddha realm.
Birthplace of the buddha Ajitagaṇa.
Son of the buddha Jñānarāja.
Son of the buddha Brahmagāmin.
Birthplace of the buddha Tiṣya.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha in the distant past. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-037-007.html#UT22084-037-007-3101 .
A buddha realm.
Mother of the buddha Vibhakta jñā svara.
The thus-gone one residing in the buddhafield Unconquered.
The absence of the conceptual identification of perceptions. Knowing that the true nature has no attributes, such as color, shape, etc. One of the three doorways to liberation.
A bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Name of a dhāraṇī.
The ultimate absence of marks and signs in perceived objects. One of the three gateways to liberation; the other two are emptiness and wishlessness.
The second of the three doorways to liberation. The other two are emptiness (śūnyatā; {stong pa nyid}) and wishlessness (apraṇihita; {smon pa med pa}).
Meditative concentration which views the five aggregates, the basis for the conception of a self, as faulty; the second of the three doors of liberation.
The absence of the conceptual identification of perceptions. Knowing that the true nature has no attributes, such as color, shape, etc. One of the three doorways to liberation.

Emptiness ({stong pa nyid}), signlessness ({mtshan ma med pa}), and wishlessness ({smon pa med pa}) are known as the “three doors to deliverance” (triṇi vimokṣa mukhāni) or the “three concentrations” (trayaḥ samādhyaḥ) and as a set appear in both mainstream Buddhist sūtras and Mahāyāna sūtras. See Conze 1962, pp. 59–69; Lamotte 1944, pp. 1213–15; and Deleanu 2000, pp. 74–78.

In ultimate reality, there is no sign, as a sign signals or signifies something to someone and hence is inextricably involved with the relative world. We are so conditioned by signs that they seem to speak to us as if they had a voice of their own. The letter “A” seems to pronounce itself to us as we see it, and the stop-sign fairly shouts at us. However, the configuration of two slanted lines with a crossbar has in itself nothing whatsoever to do with the phenomenon made with the mouth and throat in the open position, when expulsion of breath makes the vocal cords resonate “ah.” By extending such analysis to all signs, we may get an inkling of what is meant by “signlessness,” which is essentially equivalent to voidness, and to “wishlessness” (see entry). Voidness, signlessness, and wishlessness form the “Three Doors of Liberation.”
This refers to the conceptual designation of things using linguistic signs.
Can refer both to a physical mark or trait as well as to the data of perception.
Conceptual characteristics or reifications that lead to distraction and a false understanding of reality.
Any imagined mark or feature of an object, the misperception of which serves as the basis of perception and the arising of coarse conceptuality. Also translated here as “mark.”

A causal sign is the projected reality that functions as the objective support of a cognitive state. It cannot be separated out from the cognitive state and to that extent may enjoy a modicum of conventional reality. To “practice with a causal sign” means to look at an apparent phenomenon within accepting that it has more reality than it actually does.

A sign or characteristic, which refers to the generic appearance of an object, in distinction to its secondary characteristics or anuvyañjana. Advertence toward the generic sign and secondary characteristics of an object furnishes the conception or nominal designation (Skt. saṃjñā) of that object, which may in turn generate clinging or rejection and ultimately lead to suffering.

A polyvalent term, it generally refers to the characteristic features of an object or image. Nimitta can refer to features of an object that attract the mind’s attention, engage with it more deeply, and develop emotional responses to it. Such marks or features are often considered to be ultimately false and deceptive. In a more positive sense nimitta can refer to the focus of meditation practice. The term applies to both external objects and visualized images that are used to deepen meditative concentration and absorption. Also translated here as “mark” and “feature.”
These are thirty-two physical characteristics of a “great person.”
A buddha.
Birthplace of the buddha Guṇavisṛta.
The goddess of the night.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
Mahāvyutpatti 353.
A buddha realm.
Second of the three gates to liberation, the first being emptiness and the third wishlessness.
A buddha in the distant past.
Name of the ninetieth meditative stability.
Lit. “purification of marks.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Can refer both to a physical mark or trait as well as to the data of perception.
The defining quality of a thing, such as the wetness of water and the heat of fire.
Symptom that may be evidence of an illness considered an impediment to ordination.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1011 .
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
A series of identifying physical features characteristic of a great being (Skt. mahāpuruṣa), exemplified by a buddha or cakravartin king.
The thirty-two major signs of a buddha that manifest as specific physical attributes to indicate the perfection of the awakened state of buddhahood.

The distinctive physical attributes of the Buddha. These are the “signs of a great man” (Skt. mahā puruṣa lakṣaṇa, Tib. {skye bu chen po'i mtshan bzang}) that following Indian tradition characterize cakravartin kings (world sovereigns) as well as buddhas. For a descriptive list, see Dharmachakra (2013), https://read.84000.co/translation/toh95.html#UT22084-046-001-2206-https://read.84000.co/translation/toh95.html#UT22084-046-001-2234.

These are the major physical marks that identify the buddha body of emanation and which, in some sources and traditions, portend the advent of a universal monarch. As well as being listed in this and other Prajñā pāramitā sūtras (see The Transcendent Perfection of Wisdom in Ten Thousand Lines [Toh 11], https://read.84000.co/translation/toh11.html#UT22084-031-002-271 and https://read.84000.co/translation/toh11.html#UT22084-031-002-2379), they are to be found detailed in the Lalita vistara (see The Play in Full (Toh 95), https://read.84000.co/translation/toh95.html#UT22084-046-001-475 and https://read.84000.co/translation/toh95.html#UT22084-046-001-2206–https://read.84000.co/translation/toh95.html#UT22084-046-001-2234), Mahā yānopadeśa (Toh 169)https://read.84000.co/translation/toh169.html, Ratna gotra vibhāgottara tantra śāstra (Toh 4024, 3.17–25)https://read.84000.co/translation/toh4024.html, Mahā vastu, and in the Pali Lakkhaṇa sutta.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
A great bodhisattva.
Listed as thirty-two marks on the body of a buddha.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The thirty-two major and eighty minor marks of a buddha.
For their enumeration in this text, see https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-029-001.html#UT22084-029-001-5641 .
The thirty-two characteristics of a great being (mahāpuruṣa; {skyes bu chen po}), including the uṣṇīṣa, or head mound, and the long tongue.

The thirty-two primary physical characteristics of a “great being,” mahāpuruṣa, which every buddha and cakravartin possesses. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-037-007.html#UT22084-037-007-4379 for a complete list according to this sūtra.
The principal deity in the Yāma paradise, the third of the six paradises in the desire realm.
The third of the six heavens of the desire realm. Also known as the Heaven Free from Strife (Tib. {'thab bral}).

The third (counting from the lowest) of the six paradises in the desire realm. The usual translation is {'thab bral} from “Yāma.” Here, the Tibetan translation appears to be from Yama, the name for the lord of death.

Another name for the Heaven Free from Strife, this is the third of the six heavens of the desire realm. The Tibetan literally means “twins.” The Sanskrit for this heaven is Yāma or Suyāma, the precise meaning of which is uncertain.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
A part of Mountainous Garland.
A buddha realm.
Name of a lake.
A lake north of the Himālayas believed to be the source of the river Sutlej and identified with Rakshastal.
Attendant of the buddha Sārthavāha.

The Mandākinī river, which translates as “the slow-flowing” river, is the name of a specific tributary of the Ganges that flows through the Kedāranātha valley in the Himālayas, as well as a name that might be used for other rivers (Monier-Williams 788.2). The term is assumed to refer to a lake in this case (and not a river) because the Tibetan uses the term {mtsho}.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
A nāga king.
A river. Lit. “has a lake.” Possibly the Sarasvatī river, or one of the rivers connected to Lake Manasarovar, perhaps the Brahmaputra.
A certain lake on the banks of which the mendicant Subhadra often spent his days.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
One of the great piśācīs.
Mother of the buddha Nārāyaṇa.
Attendant of the buddha Sudatta.
Father of the buddha Guṇaskandha.
Son of the buddha Anantavikrāmin.
Birthplace of the buddha Marutskandha.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Subhadra.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Indra.
Name of a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
A buddha.

This denotes the five aspects of concomitance between mind and its mental states, which may concern (1) location or support ({gnas sam rten}), (2) objective referent ({dmigs pa}), (3) sensum ({rnam pa}), (4) time ({dus}), or (5) substance ({rdzas}).\n(See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1972 ).
A bodhisattva.
Mother of the buddha Siṃhagātra.

An Indian preceptor who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.

Musāragalva is fossilized coral that has undergone transformation under millions of years of underwater pressure. It appears in one version of the list of seven precious materials. The Tibetan tradition describes it as being formed from ice over a long period of time. It can also refer to tridacna (Tridacnidae) shell, which is also presently referred to by the name musaragalva. Attempts to identify musāragalva have included sapphire, cat’s eye, red coral, conch, and amber.

In other translations, this is translated into Tibetan as {spug}. White coral is fossilized coral that has undergone transformation under millions of years of underwater pressure. Tibetan tradition describes it being formed from ice over a long period of time. It can also refer to tridacna (Tridacnidae) shell, which is also presently referred to by the name musaragalva. Attempts to identify musalagalva have included sapphire, cat’s eye, red coral, conch, and amber. It appears in one version of the list of seven jewels or treasures.
A river on Saṅkāśa.

Musāragalva is fossilized coral that has undergone transformation under millions of years of underwater pressure. It appears in one version of the list of seven precious materials. The Tibetan tradition describes it as being formed from ice over a long period of time. It can also refer to tridacna (Tridacnidae) shell, which is also presently referred to by the name musaragalva. Attempts to identify musāragalva have included sapphire, cat’s eye, red coral, conch, and amber.
Son of the buddha Atyuccagāmin.
Father of the buddha Lokāntara.
A person, who though once a Buddhist later converts, barred from joining the renunciate order.
A follower of one of the non-Buddhist religious systems in India, who from a Buddhist perspective promote extreme views on the nature of reality.
A member of a religion, sect, or philosophical tradition that was a rival of or antagonistic to the Buddhist community in India. The term has its origins among the Jains.
Religious or philosophical orders that were contemporary with the early Buddhist order. Initially, the term tīrthika or tīrthya may have referred to non-brahmanic ascetic orders.”

The non-Buddhist spiritual traditions of ancient India, which according to the Buddhist view are generally said to fall into one of two categories of erroneous views: the view of eternalism or the view of nihilism.

Holders of philosophical views diverging from the Buddhist philosophy of the Middle Way into one of the two “extremes” of nihilism or eternalism. In the Buddha’s day they were typified by the non-Buddhist teachers Pūraṇa Kāśyapa, Parivrājaka Gośālīputra, Saṃjayin Vairaṭīputra, Ajita Keśakambala, Kakuda Kātyāyana, and Nirgrantha Jñātiputra.

Religious or philosophical orders that were contemporary with the early Buddhist order, including Jains, Jaṭilas, Ājīvikas, and Cārvākas. Initially, the term tīrthika or tīrthya may have referred to non-brahmanic ascetic orders.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-48 and https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-49 .
A member of a religion, sect, or philosophical tradition that was a rival of or antagonistic to the Buddhist community in India. The term has its origins among the Jains.
A follower of one of the non-Buddhist religious systems in India.
An ascetic or mendicant follower of a non-Buddhist religious system or philosophy.
Any non-Buddhist tradition in pre-Muslim India, both those Veda-based and not. The term has its origins among the Jains.
A member of a religion, sect, or philosophical tradition that was a rival of or antagonistic to the Buddhist community in India.
A person belonging to any non-Buddhist tradition in pre-Muslim India, both those Veda-based and not. The term has its origins among the Jains.

Those of religious or philosophical orders that were contemporary with the early Buddhist order, including Jains, Jaṭilas, Ājīvikas, and Cārvākas. Initially, the term tīrthika or tīrthya may have referred to non-brahmanic ascetic orders. Tīrthika (“forder”) literally translates as “one belonging to or associated with (possessive suffix –ika) stairs for landing or for descent into a river,” or “a bathing place,” or “a place of pilgrimage on the banks of sacred streams” (Monier-Williams). The term may have originally referred to temple priests at river crossings or fords where travelers propitiated a deity before crossing. The Sanskrit term seems to have undergone metonymic transfer in referring to those able to ford the turbulent river of saṃsāra (as in the Jain tīrthaṅkaras, “ford makers”), and it came to be used in Buddhist sources to refer to teachers of rival religious traditions. The Sanskrit term is closely rendered by the Tibetan {mu stegs pa}: “those on the steps ({stegs pa}) at the edge ({mu}).”
An unidentified city in Gauḍa.
Attendant of the buddha Vibhaktagātra.
A follower of one of the non-Buddhist religious systems in India.
A member of a religion, sect, or philosophical tradition that was a rival of or antagonistic to the Buddhist community in India. The term has its origins among the Jains.

Literally meaning a “ford,” “crossing place,” or “confluence,” the term is used to refer to the geographical holy places and pilgrimage sites (whether associated with rivers or not) of both Hinduism and Jainism, and by extension to the spiritual practices of pilgrimage in general.
King of the gods in the Heaven Free from Strife.

Son of King Lion Glory, who, together with his brother Aśoka, became a monk and a bodhisattva of the thus-gone King of Bliss. Finally, he became the buddha known as Supreme Accumulations.

This is likely a pre-reform expression. We were unable to determine the exact meaning of this Tibetan expression, and we did not find it used elsewhere in either the Kangyur or the Tengyur. In the Dictionary of Old Tibetan Orthography (Tib. bod yig brda rnying tshig mdzod) by rnam rgyal tshe ring (2001), we find the entry {nyon mongs bzod}; one who endures hardship or suffering, as an older Tibetan expression for a monk or nun (Tib. {dge slong gi ming}). Thus, one literal translation that we are proposing for this expression is “one who sustains (or endures) suffering (or hardship).” Comparison with similar contexts in related texts (https://read.84000.co/translation/toh338.html, F.278.a) and passim, i.e., where we find {rab tu byung ba tshul dang ldan pa rnams} etc. instead, suggests that the expression may be a collective term for those who have entered the path to liberation (Skt. āryapudgala; Pāli ariyapuggala) or for the Buddhist saṅgha generally. See also “those who have entered the path of liberation.”
Father of the buddha Balatejojñāna.
A buddha.
Birthplace of the buddha Aśoka.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Branch Guru. Alternative name for the world system Liberation from All Sorrow and Harm.
A buddha realm.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Branch Guru. Alternate name for the world system Beyond All Sorrow and Harm.
A buddha realm.

A bodhisattva.
The name of a bodhisattva. “Intelligence Dispelling All Darkness of Sorrow.”
“Complete nirvāṇa.” It can specifically refer to entering nirvāṇa at death.

Final liberation from suffering. The Sanskrit literally means “extinguishment” and the Tibetan “the transcendence of suffering.”
The Sanskrit means “extinguishment,” for the causes for saṃsāra are “extinguished.” The Tibetan means “the transcendence of suffering.”
The state of “extinction,” said to be blissful and inviolable, where the afflictions are extinguished and one is not subject to ever be born again.

Literally meaning “extinction,” it is the state beyond sorrow, referring to the ultimate attainment of buddhahood, the permanent cessation of all suffering and of the afflicted mental states that lead to suffering.

Final liberation from suffering. In the Hinayāna it is believed attainable by turning away from the world of living beings and transcending all afflictions and selfishnesses through meditative trances. In the Mahāyāna, it is believed attainable only by the attainment of buddhahood, the nondual realization of the indivisibility of life and liberation, and the all-powerful compassion that establishes all living beings simultaneously in their own liberations.

Literally “extinction,” the state beyond sorrow, it refers to the ultimate attainment of buddhahood, the permanent cessation of all suffering and of the afflicted mental states that lead to suffering. Three types of nirvāṇa are identified: (1) the residual nirvāṇa where the person is still dependent on conditioned psycho-physical aggregates, (2) the non-residual nirvāṇa where the aggregates have also been consumed within emptiness, and (3) the non-abiding nirvāṇa transcending the extremes of phenomenal existence and quiescence. See also “parinirvāṇa.”
Extinction of suffering.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Prabhūta.
“Without misery, free of dust.” The name of a kalpa in the distant past.

(1) Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Created with Joy. (2) Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Leader of Heroes.
“Free from Sorrow.” A bodhisattva from a world system called Sarva śokāpagata, in the southern direction, who comes to pay homage and listen to the Buddha.

Son of King Lion Glory, who, together with his brother Vigataśoka, became a monk and a bodhisattva of the thus-gone King of Bliss. Finally, he became the buddha known as Array of the Perfect Assembly.

A future buddha.\nNot to be confused with the young brahmin Aśoka who was Buddha Kāśyapa’s best friend prior to his enlightenment, nor with King Aśoka who does not appear in this text.

The historical Indian king of the Maurya dynasty who ruled over most of India c. 268–232 bce. In this text he appears to be briefly referenced as the biological father of the prince Suckler of the Earth Breast, adopted as the Chinese prince who, according to this text, is said to have been the first person to settle in Khotan.

Young brahmin who was Buddha Kāśyapa’s best friend prior to his enlightenment. The Hundred Deeds is not clear on this point, but Edgerton notes that Aśoka is understood as the nephew and disciple of Buddha Kāśyapa (Edgerton 80.2).\nNot to be confused with the future buddha Aśoka, nor with the historical King Aśoka who does not appear in this text.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Priyaṅgama (929 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
The 936th buddha in the first list, 935th in the second list, and 926th in the third list.

Literally “Blue Throat,” he is associated with the legend of the churning of the great ocean. In the Buddhist context he is Vajrapāṇi, and in the Hindu context, Śiva. In the AP the name may refer to one of the lokeśvara emanations of Avalokiteśvara.
Jasminum arborescens. A species of jasmine that is a shrub and does not twine or climb. Its other common name is navamallika.
A female buddha of the lotus family.
The undergarment covering the lower body. One of the three Dharma robes (tricīvara, {chos gos gsum}).
A legendary king before the time of the Buddha.
Śāriputra’s birthplace in Magadha. King Bimbisāra granted Śāriputra’s grandfather Māṭhara and father Tiṣya rights to this village as a victor’s spoils after debates held in his presence.

Identified as Nardostachys jatamansi, or Indian spikenard, a plant recognized for its medicinal properties in the Atharvaveda and Suśrutasaṃhitā. The Sanskrit epic poem called Naiṣadhacarita identifies this plant as the root of Andropogon muricatus. A number of classical Sanskrit lexicographers identify this plant as the blossom of Hibiscus rosa sinensis.
A town in ancient India where this sūtra is taught.
A village in Magadha.
Name of a bodhisattva.
The name of an island.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
Jasminum arborescens. A species of jasmine that is a shrub and does not twine or climb. Its other common name is navamallika.

Indian scholar and practitioner (956 - 1041), a major figure in the transmission of tantric Buddhism to Tibet; earlier in his life he was an important paṇḍita of Nālandā, but left to become a yogi and siddha, the student of Tilopā, and later the teacher of Kukkuripa, Marpa, and others.
Father of the buddha Oṣadhi.
Attendant of the buddha Siṃhadaṃṣṭra.
Father of the buddha Girikūṭaketu.
The 305th buddha in the first list, 304th in the second list, and 299th in the third list.
Son of the buddha Candra.

A nāga. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2562 .
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Beta Geminorum in the occidental tradition.
One of the notorious “group of six’ monks whose antics and heavy-handed interference prompted a great many of the Buddha’s injunctions on conduct. Also known as Punarvasuka.

One of the sixteen great bodhisattvas. The content of the list varies from text to text.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
A great bodhisattva.
Disease; also a spirit causing disease.
Disease or sickness; also a class of mischievous spirits.

Kālidāsa (c. fourth–fifth century ce) was one of India’s greatest poets. He is the author of Cloud Messenger (Skt. Meghadūta, Tib. sprin gyi pho nya), a work that exerted a major influence on Tibet’s poetic tradition, and a praise to Sarasvatī called https://read.84000.co/translation/toh3704.html (Toh 3704).
A goddess; a rākṣasī in the Mahā māyūrī vidyārājñī (Toh 559); https://read.84000.co/translation/toh559.html one of Durgā’s attendants.

Iron sulfate or ferrous sulphate, also known in the past as copperas. A blue-green powder that has had many uses including being used in the process of refining gold through solutions of gold and green vitriol.
In Rājagṛha, the son of King Bimbisāra’s elephant trainer Elephant Heart. He is tricked into giving back his precepts, then becomes ordained once again.
The name of a nakṣatra.
Citra Mounted on an Elephant’s name in a former life.
The twelfth (sometimes the fourteenth) lunar asterism.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Spica (alpha Virginis) in the occidental tradition.
A river to the south of Jambudvīpa.
The wrathful form of Śiva; also a wrathful Buddhist deity.
A Buddhist protector deity; also the name of one of the attendants on Śiva.
‟Great Death.” Most often considered a wrathful form of Avalokiteśvara, in the Bhūta ḍāmara Tantra he is one of the wrathful forms of Śiva.

Mahākāla (“the great black one”) is both a name for one of the god Śiva’s wrathful manifestations and an important Buddhist protector deity. The Mahābhārata and Harivaṁśa list Mahākāla as one of Śiva's attendants.

Not to be confused with the protectors in the later higher tantras in this sūtra, or with Śiva who also has this name (though then it has the alternative meaning of “Great Time”), in the Kāraṇḍavyūha these are dangerous spirits. Elsewhere they are also said to be servants of Śiva, which may be the meaning here as they are grouped with the mātṛ goddesses.
(1) An area in Kuru ({nag po gsus pa}). 2. One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment. ({lto gnag}), also called Raven’s Belly.
An 11th or 12th century Buddhist commentator. Wrote Recollection: a commentary on the Mahāmāyā Tantra.
One of the deities invited to partake in the oblation offering.
An elephant.
Grove offered to the Buddha by Kālaka, a wealthy man of Sāketa.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
The army, divisions, or factions of Māra, the deity who personifies spiritual death; from Māra’s point of view, this is the “white faction.” Also refers to the dark fortnight of the lunar month.
The son of Anāthapiṇḍada (Pali: Anāthapindika), the merchant who donated to the Buddha the land for the Jetavana Monastery.
Kāla was the son of Anāthapiṇḍada (Pali: Anāthapindika), the merchant who donated to the Buddha the land for the Jetavana Monastery.
A certain nāga king who praised Gautama prior to his enlightenment.\nNot to be confused with Black ({nag po}), the yakṣa; nor with Black ({nag po}), the brahmin.
A certain yakṣa tamed by the Buddha and subsequently sworn to protect the people of Rājagṛha.\nNot to be confused with Black the brahmin who also appears in his story, nor with Kāla the nāga king.

A certain dark-complected brahmin youth who became a sage, then heard the Dharma from the Buddha, became ordained, and manifested arhatship.\nNot to be confused with Black the yakṣa who also appears in his story, nor with Kāla the nāga king (whose name in Tib. is the same {nag po}).

The Kāla Mountains of Bhāratvarṣa (i.e., India) are listed in the Mahābhārata as the mountain ranges Vindhya (separating the Deccan from north India), Mahendra (the eastern Ghats), Malaya (southern half of the Western Ghats), Sahya (the northern half of the Western Ghats), Rakṣavat (northeast extension of the Vindhya), Pāripātra, and the Sūktimat (or Śuktimat), which is presumably another name for the one remaining significant mountain range, the Arbuda in the northwest.
1011–1064. His personal name was Tsultrim Gyalwa ({tshul khrims rgyal ba}). A translator who brought Atiśa to Tibet and wrote an important record of his travels to India.
A forest in Moving in Mixed Environments.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Jyeṣṭhavādin (676 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A mountain on Videha.
One of the māras.
A yakṣa.
A city in Videha.
A river on Great Slope.
A monk disciple of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife.
A class of spirit being.
One of the sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Heat.
A queen of Rāhu, king of asuras.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
A region in South India.
A buddha realm.
The country where Śākyamuni descended to the earth after preaching to his deceased mother in Indra’s heaven.
A river that passes Bodhgaya.
A śrāvaka, the youngest brother of Śāriputra. Also known as Khadiravanīya. Elsewhere translated as {nam gru}.
An nickname of Revata, a disciple of the Buddha.
A great śrāvaka.
A disciple of the Buddha.
The youngest brother of Śāriputra.
A follower of Śāriputra (Malalasekera).
The name of a nakṣatra; also a yakṣiṇī invoked in magical rites.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Zeta Pisicum in the occidental tradition.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
Lit. “sky-like.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Mother of the buddha Rāhu sūrya garbha.
Name of the twenty-second meditative stability.
Lit. “pervading space.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A class of asuras.
A buddha in the southern direction.
A class of vidyādharas.

A class of nonhuman beings described as eagle-type birds with a gigantic wingspan. They were traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they were thought to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.

A class of supernatural being described as an eagle-type bird with a gigantic wingspan. They are traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they are thought to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.

A class of nonhuman beings who have the form of eagle-type birds with gigantic wingspans. They are traditionally considered enemies of the nāgas. Garuḍa can also be used as a proper name for a king of such creatures.

Lower class of divine being, described as an eagle-like bird with a gigantic wing span. They were traditionally enemies of the nāgas . In the Vedas, they were thought to have brought ambrosia from the heavens to Earth.

In Indian religious mythology, the garuḍa is a eagle-like sun bird with an enormous wingspan that is regarded as the king of all birds. They are traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they are said to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.

A class of nonhuman being described as eagle-type birds with a gigantic wingspan. They are the traditional enemies of the nāgas. Literally “sky-soarer” in Tibetan, they are one of the aṣṭasenā, eight groups of nonhuman beings said to have been present when the Buddha preached the Mahāyāna sūtras.
One among a list of eight uṣṇīṣa buddhas mentioned in this text that do not appear elsewhere in the canon.
Name of the 111th meditative stability.
Lit. “unattached, liberated, and uncovered like space.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A buddha in the distant past.
A bodhisattva.
An absorption.
One of the bodhisattvas attending this teaching.

In the Kāraṇḍavyūha it is the name of both a bodhisattva and a samādhi. In this sūtra the bodhisattva is a pupil of Buddha Viśvabhū, but he is also portrayed in other sūtras receiving teaching from Śākyamuni, and is one of the sixteen bodhisattvas in the Vairocana maṇḍala.

The first of the four states of imperturbability. In the formless realm (Skt. ārūpyadhātu), no bodies or materiality of any kind exist, only mind; rebirth there is the result of accomplishing four formless meditative absorptions (Skt. ārūpya samāpatti; five absorptions, i.e., if one includes the stage of Skt. saṃjñā-vedayita-nirodha or nirodhasamāpatti).
Fourth of the eight aspects of liberation. Also the fifth of the nine serial steps of meditative absorption.
First of the four meditative absorptions.
Seventh of the eight sense fields of mastery. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-209 .
A formless state, either a meditative state or its resultant realm of existence, i.e., a class of deities of the formless realm.
First of the four heavens of the formless realm. Rebirth there is the karmic result of accomplishing one of the formless meditative absorptions.
Alt. “the activity field infinite as boundless space” (Rangjung Yeshe Dictionary). Here the Blessed One begins an enumeration of the four formless realm states.
Name of the first of the four formless realms and of the first formless meditative absorption, so termed because in its preparatory phase limitless space is the object of meditation.

First of the four formless realms. The term also refers to the class of gods that dwell there and the name of the first of the four formless absorptions. The other three realms are the station of endless consciousness, the station of nothing-at-all, and the station of neither perception nor nonperception.

The first of the four states of imperturbability. In the formless realm (Skt. ārūpyadhātu), no bodies or materiality of any kind exist, only mind; rebirth there is the result of accomplishing four formless meditative absorptions (Skt. ārūpya samāpatti; five absorptions, i.e., if one includes the stage of Skt. saṃjñā-vedayita-nirodha or nirodhasamāpatti).
One of the gods’ realms; also used as the name of the gods living there.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Nāgaruta (948 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Lit. “limitless sky.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
An area in Eyes Beyond the World.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
Lit. “inconceivable sky.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Religious Practice.
One of the eight main bodhisattvas, the heart sons of the Buddha.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Lamp of the Sky of Dharma. Likely the same as the world system Palmyra Trees Reaching the Sky.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A nobleman in the retinue of the Buddha.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Ratnaketu.
A bodhisattva present with the Buddha at Śrāvastī, and also the name of a buddha in the distant past.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Akṣobhya (776 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A god.
Name of a nāga king. Also known as Gaganasvara.
The 968th buddha in the first list, 967th in the second list, and 958th in the third list.
The eighth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past, and also the name of the sixty-second buddha in another kalpa. The Tibetan has {dbyings} in error for {dbyangs} for the sixty-second buddha.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
The tathāgata of the northeastern buddhafield Pure Immaculate Dwelling.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A town in Videha.
Lit. “abiding in space.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
The eleventh buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
Lit. “limitless space element.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Female garuḍa.
The name of a garuḍa.
A class of nonhuman beings, half-human and half-bird.
“Sky mother”; a class of female spirits.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
A bodhisattva.
Father of the buddha Vimuktilābhin.
One of the sixteen great bodhisattvas. The content of the list varies from text to text.
Metaphorical expression for something unreal, illusionary.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A buddha.

An epithet, given to the seer Vyāsa, that alludes to the association of the Vedic ṛṣis with a range of astronomical phenomena. Like the figure of the siddha, the great seers can also be understood as beings who dwell “in the vault of the heavens,” which symbolizes their ascension to a semidivine status through the practice of intense asceticism.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
The sixty-sixth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
A buddha in the distant past.
Name of a mercenary demon.
The name of a bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A bodhisattva residing in a buddha realm in the northern direction during the time of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
An important bodhisattva, his name means “essence of space.” He is one of the “eight great close sons” (aṣṭa mahopa putra, {nye ba'i sras chen brgyad}).
The forty-third buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Gagana megha śirī.
A class of vidyādharas.
A buddha in the distant past.
A buddha.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha in the distant past.
Eighth-century Tibetan editor of Toh 21.
A king in King of Thunderous Voice’s buddha realm.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Epithet of Ākāśagarbha, one of the eight great bodhisattvas.
The 766th buddha in the first list, 765th in the second list, and 755th in the third list.

The Sanskrit text has “gaganaṃ,” signifying this epithet of Ākāśagarbha, one of the eight great bodhisattvas, while the Tibetan uses an abbreviated form of the Tibetan translation of Ākāśagarbha, {nam mkha'i snying po}.
A bodhisattva.
This seems to be another name of Nandi, Śiva’s bull.
A householder, the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 29.

A formal act of the saṅgha requiring a act whose fourth member is a motion, meted out to a wayward monk or monks. There are five types: acts of censure, chastening, expulsion, reconciliation, and suspension.
Various inner bodily parts and outer material things that may be requested from bodhisattvas.

One of a number of lifestyles that Buddhist monks might adopt, it is particularly conducive to practicing meditation and is thus associated with monks who valued meditation as an integral part of their lives as ascetics. The Tibetan {nang du yang dag 'jog pa} can correspond to the Sanskrit pratisaṃlāyana or pratisaṁlīna.
This term can mean both physical seclusion and a meditative state of withdrawal.
This term can mean both physical seclusion and a meditative state of withdrawal. It often refers specifically to the practice of calm abiding (śamatha) and special insight (vipaśyanā).
Appearing in the Mahā vyutpatti as a type of dhyāna, this term is used in The Hundred Deeds to signify a period of secluded meditation retreat.
This term can mean both physical seclusion and a meditative state of withdrawal. It often refers specifically to the practice of calm abiding (śamatha) and special insight (vipaśyanā).
A river.

The six inner sense fields, as listed in https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-148 , comprise (1) the sense field of the eyes, (2) the sense field of the ears, (3) the sense field of the nose, (4) the sense field of the tongue, (5) the sense field of the body, and (6) the sense field of the mental faculty. These are part of the twelve sense fields.
Second of the eight aspects of liberation.
A realm that neighbors the Hell of Intense Heat.
The name of a karmic wind involved in the formation of an embryo in its fourth week.
One among a list of sixteen uṣṇīṣa buddhas named after the sixteen emptinesses.
First of the eighteen aspects of emptiness.
One of the fourteen emptinesses and eighteen emptinesses.
A lake in Supreme Strength.
A river to the south of Jambudvīpa.
A river in the Deccan (the modern Nerbudda).
Literally “The Barley Islands,” this refers to the land of the Greeks, whose empire at one time extended along the northern coasts of the Persian gulf as far as India.
Twenty-third of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.

(1) A king of the Pāla dynasty who ruled from 1077–1120 ce ({rA ma phA la}). (2) The alternate spelling, {ne bai pA la}, is tentatively identified to be the very same king of the Pāla dynasty. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-068-021.html#UT22084-068-021-8447 .

Butea monosperma, Butea frondosa, and Erythrina monosperma. A tree that grows up to 15 meters tall and has bright red flowers. Other names include parrot tree, bastard teak, dhak (Hindi), palas (Hindi), porasum (Tamil); and khakda (Gujarati).
Twentieth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
A 13th century Tibetan historian. Personal name: Drakpa Mönlam Lodrö ({grags pa smon lam blo gros}).
Lit. “that cuts off doubt.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Name of the eightieth meditative stability.
Lit. “eliminator of doubts.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A legendary king before the time of the Buddha.
A wheel-turning king who was the Buddha in a former life.
(1) A powerful king whose good deeds lent splendor to the Pleasure Grove Park. (2) A universal monarch.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Ratna svara ghoṣa.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
Son of the buddha Puṇyahastin.
Mother of the buddha Brahmagāmin.
One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife.
Mother of the buddha Puṃgava.
A bodhisattva.
One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife.
The 896th buddha in the first list, 895th in the second list, and 886th in the third list.
Literally, “I king.” Arrogance or egocentrism.
Fourth of the five fetters associated with the higher realms.

The Abhidharmakośa (Toh 4089, 5.10)https://read.84000.co/translation/toh4089.html lists seven types of pride: (1) pride (Tib. {nga rgyal}; Skt. māna), (2) exaggerating pride (Tib. {lhag pa'i nga rgyal}; Skt. adhimāna), (3) outrageous pride (Tib. {nga rgyal las kyang nga rgyal}; Skt. mānātimāna), (4) egoistic pride (Tib. {nga'o snyam pa'i nga rgyal}; Skt. asmimāna), (5) arrogating pride (Tib. {mngon pa'i nga rgyal}; Skt. abhimāna), (6) pride of feeling inferior (Tib. {cung zad snyam pa'i nga rgyal}; Skt. ūnamāna), and (7) unfounded pride (Tib. {log pa'i nga rgyal}; Skt. mithyāmāna).
A great bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Dṛḍhavikrama.
Son of the buddha Varabodhigati.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
Attendant of the buddha Ratnaketu.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Mahendra.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Nāgadatta (550 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
The 723rd buddha in the first list, 722nd in the second list, and 712th in the third list.
A great bodhisattva.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Siṃhadhvaja (66 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Father of the buddha Viśiṣṭa svarāṅga.
A great bodhisattva.
Mother of the buddha Amṛta.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Kusumaprabha (831 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Puṇya (978 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Mother of the buddha Priyābha.
Mother of the buddha Daśavaśa.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Pratimaṇḍita.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Siṃha (6) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Mahendra.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Siṃha.
Mother of the buddha Dṛḍhavrata.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Gaṇiprabha.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Siṃhagati.
First of the Buddha’s four assurances.
Second of the Buddha’s four assurances.
Mother of the buddha Saṃtoṣaṇa.
Seventh of ten non-virtuous actions.
A disciple of the Buddha.
Goddess of learning; in the SEV she is associated with Tārā; she is also one the four retinue goddesses of Siddhaikavīra.
Fourteenth of the eighteen distinct qualities of the buddhas.

The four sinful or nonvirtuous verbal actions, namely telling lies, using abusive language, slandering others, and indulging in irrelevant talk. Their counterparts are the four wholesome or virtuous actions of speech, namely, not telling falsehoods, not using abusive language, not slandering others, and not indulging in irrelevant talk.
Name of the 110th meditative stability.
Lit. “destroying verbal flaws, it is like space.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
The fourth among the four misdeeds of speech.
Symptom that may be evidence of an illness considered an impediment to ordination.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1011 .

As one of the Four Mahārājas, he is the lord of the northern region of the world and the northern continent, though in early Buddhism he is the lord of the far north of India and beyond. He is also the lord of the yakṣas and a lord of wealth. Translated in other sūtras as {rnam thos kyi bu} and {mchog gi gzugs}.
The name of a country once located in the Punjab region, frequently mentioned in epic and purāṇic literature.
The animal, preta, and hell realms.
The realms of hell beings, pretas and animals.
A bodhisattva.
Lower rebirths within cyclic existence.
The realms of hell beings, pretas, and animals.
A collective name for the realms of animals, hungry ghosts, and denizens of the hells.
The three lower realms of animals, pretas, and hell beings. Also translated as “sad destinies” and “miserable destinies.”
Rebirth in one of the three lower states of existence, namely, the hell realm, the realm of hungry ghosts, or the animal realm.
A collective name for the realms of animals, pretas, and hell beings. The term is also referred to in this translation as “evil state.”
The so-called lower realms of rebirth (see “unfortunate rebirth destinies”).

Lacking knowledge of or being ignorant [of the Dharma]. J. S. Negi (Negi 935, s.v. {ngan pa}) cites a few instances where Tibetan {ngan pa} represents the Sanskrit semantic field “lack of understanding,” e.g., Bodhi caryāvatāra (Tib. {ngan pa}; Skt. ajñaḥ “not knowing,” “devoid of knowledge,” “stupid,” “foolish,” etc.); Jātakamālā (Tib. {ngan pa}; Skt. jaḍā matiḥ “dull,” “stupid,” “irrational”); Avadāna kalpalatā (Tib. {ngan pa}; Skt. mūrkhāḥ “stupid, dull-headed; a fool”). Context suggests that this is one sense of {ngan pa} in Exposition of Karma when it talks about the Dharma and knowledge thereof. Also translated here as “bad deed.”\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-039.html#UT22084-072-039-88 .
The animal, preta, and hell realms.
A collective name for the realms of animals, anguished spirits, and denizens of the hells.
Son of the buddha Devarāja.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
One of the sixteen great bodhisattvas. The content of the list varies from text to text.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Vigataśoka (880 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
The name of a bodhisattva.
Son of the buddha Pradīparāja.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Sārodgata.
Negi gives the Skt. apāyajaha for {ngan song spong 'joms pa}, where it refers to the name of a bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
The realms of animals, hungry ghosts, and hell beings.
The states of hell beings, hungry ghosts (pretas), and animals.
The lower realms of hell beings, hungry ghosts (pretas), and animals.
A collective name for the realms of animals, hungry ghosts, and denizens of the hells.

Usually Tibetan {ngan song} [{gsum}] is an expression for the three lower realms of rebirth according to Buddhist cosmology: animals, ghosts, and hell beings. Here, however, the asuras are counted among lower rebirths too.

The three bad migrations are those of (1) denizens of hells, (2) inhabitants of the “limbo” of the pretaloka, where one wanders as an insatiably hungry and thirsty wretch, and (3) animals, who are trapped in the pattern of mutual devouring (Tib. {gcig la gcig za}).
Name of a sage.
A ṛṣi in the past.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
One of the seven great rishis of ancient India. The founder of Indian astrology.
A brahmin. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-4502 .

A precious gem that, when cut, shows a luminous star shape. This includes such gems as star sapphires, star rubies, and star topazes. In some Kangyurs written incorrectly as {sgra snang ba} and with a wide variety of other spelling renditions. Jyotīrasa is translated as {skar ma mdog} in https://read.84000.co/translation/toh113.html (Toh 113, Saddharma puṇḍarīka).
A river on Saṅkāśa.
(1) A forest on Encircled by White Clouds ({ngang ngur rnams kyis rjes su bsgrags par byed pa}). (2) A river on Saṅkāśa ({ngang pa kun sgra 'byin pa}).
A lake on Equal Peaks.
One of four parks that surround the city of Radiant.
(1) A forest in Endowed with Migration. (2) A lake to the north of Jambudvīpa.
A lotus grove in Part of the Assembly.
A queen of King Sarvārthasiddha.
A class of vidyādharas.
An epithet of Brahmā, who rides a swan.
Forty-fourth of the eighty minor marks.
A pond on Equal Peaks.
A kind of bird, which is identified with the swan or goose.
Twenty-first of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.

One of the four mahārājas, he is the guardian deity for the east and traditionally lord of the gandharvas, though in this sūtra he appears to be king of the nāgas. It is also the name of a goose king that was one of the Buddha’s previous lives, and in that instance it is translated into Tibetan as {ngang skya}.
A head merchant’s son in Dhanyākara.
Birthplace of the buddha Deva.
One of the kings of Nepal, possibly Jiṣṇugupta of the seventh century.
The king identified with Śīlāditya Dharmāditya I of the Maitraka dynasty.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Puṣpaprabha (904 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Third of the Buddha’s four assurances.
A god from the Sphere of neither Perception nor Nonperception who later becomes the Buddha Supreme Precious One.
Fourth of the Buddha’s four assurances.
A great bodhisattva.
This term is also translated as ‘renunciation’ and denotes the practitioner’s mind turning away from the bonds of saṃsāra and towards liberation.
A buddha realm.
A great bodhisattva.
Along with the Yajurveda, Sāmaveda, and Atharvaveda, one of the four Vedas, the most ancient Sanskrit religious literature of India. Generally considered the “first” of the four Vedas.
Mother of the buddha Vajrasena.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Sārathi.
Mother of the buddha Kṛtavarman.
Attendant of the buddha Vigatabhaya.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Vigatamala (193 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.

This refers to those teachings of the Buddha that are in terms of ultimate reality; it is opposed to those teachings given in terms of relative reality, termed “interpretable meaning,” because they require further interpretation before being relied on to indicate the ultimate. Hence definitive meaning relates to voidness, etc., and no statement concerning the relative world, even by the Buddha, can be taken as definitive. This is especially important in the context of the Mādhyamika doctrine, hence in the context of Vimalakīrti’s teachings, because he is constantly correcting the disciples and bodhisattvas who accept interpretable expressions of the Tathāgata as if they were definitive, thereby attaching themselves to them and adopting a one-sided approach.
Attendant of the buddha Mahāraśmi.
Son of the buddha Vigatabhaya.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Gandhahastin.

This is the stage attained by followers of the Hinayāna wherein they become determined for the attainment of liberation (nirvāṇa, i.e., the ultimate for them) in such a way as never to regress from their goals, and by bodhisattvas when they attain the holy path of insight.
The 177th buddha in the first list, 176th in the second list, and 176th in the third list.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Vijitāvin (86 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
One of the four reliances.
Birthplace of the buddha Siṃhahasta.
The ultimate meaning of a given Dharma teaching.
The final meaning of the truth; the real intent of the Buddha’s teachings.
A statement of clear and explicit meaning that has no ulterior motive and thus does not require further explanation.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Jyotiṣka (564 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Birthplace of the buddha Sumati.
Name of the ninth meditative stability.
Lit. “crest of the victory banner of certainty.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Mother of the buddha Prajñāna vihāsa svara.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Vigatakāṅkṣa.
Lit. “entry into the exposition of etymologies.” Name of a meditative stabilization. (Ghoṣa has niruktāniyata praveśa.)
Name of the sixteenth meditative stability.
Lit. “entry into certainty about the etymologies.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
One of the four kinds of knowledge.
Third of the four kinds of exact knowledge. See also “lexical explanations.”

Lexical explanations here implies the exact knowledge of the primary and derivative definitions and explanations of names and words. It is also the third of the four kinds of exact knowledge, see “exact knowledge of language and lexical explanations.”

“These are the four stages on the path of application (prayogamārga). They are heat (uṣmagata), tolerance (kṣānti), summit (mūrdha), and highest worldly dharma (laukikāgradharma).” Rotman (2005) p. 452.\nTranslated here as “heat,” “peak” (given as the second stage in this text), “patience in accord with the truths” (given as the third stage in this text), and “highest worldly dharma.”
Deliverance from cyclic existence.
Definite emergence or release from saṃsāra; also a term for renunciation.
Having left one’s home to become a wandering mendicant. Also translated here as emancipation and as pathway.
This term is also translated as ‘renunciation’ and denotes the practitioner’s mind turning away from the bonds of saṃsāra and towards liberation.
Deliverance or emancipation from cyclic existence. When used as a transitive verb, it has the sense of leaving behind or escaping cyclic existence.

Setting forth, issue, exit, departure, escape, a road out of town. Also translated here as “emancipated” and “gone forth.”\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-049-001.html#UT22084-049-001-177 .
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
The name of an extensive teaching that the Buddha is said to have taught directly preceding the Lotus Sūtra.
Mother of the buddha Sthāmaprāpta.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Padmaskandha.
Mother of the buddha Samṛddha.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Baladatta.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ūrṇāvat.
The name of an asura.
Mother of the buddha Ratnaprabhāsa.
A park in Blazing Splendor.
Name of the forty-fourth meditative stability.
Mahāvyutpatti 7450.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Jñānakīrti (501 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Mvy
Mahāvyutpatti 7450.
Analytic concentration that gains insight into the nature of reality, synonymous with “transcendental analysis,” vipaśyana (q.v.).
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Manujacandra (146) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A world system.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Siṃhahasta.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Suyajña.
Son of the buddha Suceṣṭa.
Lit. “Certain.” Name of four lotus ponds, each located in one of the four gardens of the residence of the bodhisattva great being Dharmodgata, in the city of Gandhavatī.

These comprise the imaginary, dependent, and consummate essenceless natures, which are elaborated particularly in the discourses associated with the third turning of the doctrinal wheel.\n(See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-4 ).
The three kinds of essencelessness are essencelessness regarding defining characteristics, essencelessness regarding arising, and essencelessness regarding the ultimate.
This indicates either an active or a passive distinction in the buddha body of reality, or the underlying indivisible essence of the three buddha bodies.
One of the eighteen emptinesses.
Seventeenth of the eighteen aspects of emptiness.

This term denotes the ontological status of phenomena, according to which they are said to possess existence in their own right—inherently, in and of themselves, objectively, and independent of any other phenomena such as our conception and labelling. The absence of such an ontological reality is defined as the true nature of reality, emptiness. Also rendered here as “basic nature.”
A body goddess.
Father of the buddha Puṣpaketu.
Attendant of the buddha Dharmaprabhāsa.
A sense of shame that prevents one from carrying out immoral actions.

One of the eleven virtuous mental factors (Tib. {sems byung dge ba}; Skt. kuśalacaitta), a subgroup of the mental states or factors associated with the mind (Skt. caitasika; caitta), according to the Abhidharma. According to Vasubandhu (in his Pañcaskandhaka), {ngo tsha} (“scruples,” “conscience”) is different from {khrel} (“embarrassment” or “shame”) in that it is independent from others’ judgment of one’s behavior, and solely internal, in that it contradicts one’s internalized values and one’s inner moral compass. See “embarrassment.”
A country in India corresponding to modern Tirhut.
A river in Dwelling on Summits.
Attendant of the buddha Vratatapas.
A pond in Continuous Movement.
(1497−1557). The tenth abbot of Ngor Monastery and a prominent master of the Sakya tradition who wrote a history of Buddhism.
A great Sakya scholar and prolific author (1382–1456), founder of the Ngor tradition and the monastery of Ngor Ewam Chöden.

Dhanada (“Wealth Giver”) is another name of Vaiśravaṇa ({rnam thos sras}, “Prince of the Distinctly Hearing One”), one of the Four Great Kings ({rgyal po chen po bzhi}) ruling the four directions of the desire realm. Vaiśravaṇa rules the northern direction and the yakṣas (gnod sbyin) that reside there. In The Question of Mañjuśrī his image is the fifty-third of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.

This is a reference to saṃsāra, which is called an “ocean of milk” since the beings therein are sustained by their mother’s milk which, if accumulated over countless rebirths, would be enough to fill an ocean.
The western continent according to Buddhist cosmology. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-68 .

An epithet attributed to the great seer Vyāsa. The Tibetan {nus can bu}/{nus pa can bu}, which would back-translate to the Sanskrit *samarthika, is in this case either a mistranslation or the result of a corruption in the original source, which would likely have read *smārtikaśāstra, a reference to the “treatises” of those who follow the smṛti tradition (smartikas).

A term denoting the primary disciples of a buddha.
