A king of Tibet who reigned from 815 to 838.
King of Tibet, who reigned 815–838 ce. Also known as Tritsuk Detsen ({khri gtug lde btsan}).
A king of Tibet, born circa 806, who reigned from 815 to 838. His formal name was Tritsuk Detsen ({khri gtsug lde btsan}).
A religious sect of men distinguished by their long, clotted hair, to which the Buddha’s disciple Venerable Uruvilvā Kāśyapa had belonged. The Buddha ordained a thousand of them in Uruvilvā.

The Brahmā of the universe Aśoka, who is personally called Śikhin to distinguish him from Brahmās of other universes (see Brahmā). The second of the “seven buddhas of the past” is also called Śikhin but his name is rendered in Tibetan as {gtsug gtor can}.
A goddess.
One of the deities in the maṇḍala of Avalokiteśvara-Amoghapāśa and in some of the maṇḍalas of Avalokiteśvara.
A young brahmin from Suvarṇadvīpa who brings news to Śāriputra and Maudgalyāyana that confirms their teacher Sañjayin’s prophecy and sparks their search for the Buddha.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Indigofera tinctoria.
(1284–1339). An important master in the Karma Kagyu lineage of Tibetan Buddhism ({karma bka' brgyud}). He is considered the third master in the lineage to have the title of Karmapa.

Someone who has attained liberation entirely through their own contemplation as a result of progress in previous lives but, unlike a buddha, does not have the accumulated merit and motivation to teach others.
This is a consecration of oneself (in the Sanskrit compound, the word "self" is in a genitive case relationship with "consecration").
The Buddha’s ordination as a monk was a self-ordination, not presided over by a preceptor or following one of the ritual procedures that were later adopted by the tradition.
An epithet for Buddha Śākyamuni, or for any fully awakened buddha.
One of the pratyeka buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
An epithet frequently applied to buddhas to denote their quality of being self-manifest, i.e., not born through causes and conditions.
The Buddha’s ordination as a monk was a self-ordination, not presided over by a preceptor or following one of the ritual procedures that were later adopted by the tradition.
A bodhisattva.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
An adjective applied to a monk who observes his vows and hence is “in good standing” or to a person who is sound of mind.

Schmithausen understands this term as meaning “normal”: “should we [indeed] say that even the normal ({rang bzhin du gnas pa}, *prakṛtisthita?) images . . .” (Schmithausen 2014, p. 392, n. 1733). I understand the use of {rang bzhin du gnas pa} as implying a context where the object of the cognition is not an object of concentration corresponding to visualization practices as in the case of the kasiṇa. In the Pāli tradition, kasiṇa designates a visualization object used as a support for the totality of the meditator’s attention. In this paragraph, {sems can} has the connotation of beings who do not practice the yoga taught in this chapter, that is, ordinary beings.
The central figure of the maṇḍala surrounded by a group of among a list of eight uṣṇīṣa buddhas mentioned in this text that do not appear elsewhere in the canon.
One of the fourteen emptinesses and eighteen emptinesses.
The hundred-and-tenth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS in verse: Prakṛtīśarīra śiri bhadra.
Lit. “has seen the basic nature.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
One among a list of sixteen uṣṇīṣa buddhas named after the sixteen emptinesses.
Twelfth of the eighteen aspects of emptiness.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The inherent nature of a phenomenon; in the present text, this is possibly a reference to the buddha-nature, or tathāgatagarbha.
“According to Sāṁkhya, the prime substance, from which the material universe evolves, as opposed to puruṣa, pure consciousness.” (Reat, 39 n5).

This term denotes the ontological status of phenomena, according to which they are said to possess existence in their own right—inherently, in and of themselves, objectively, and independent of any other phenomena such as our conception and labelling. The absence of such an ontological reality is defined as the true nature of reality, emptiness. Also rendered here as “basic nature.”

Svabhāva is usually rendered as “self-nature,” sometimes as “own-being,” both of which have a certain literal validity. However, neither artificial term has any evocative power for the reader who has no familiarity with the original, and a term must be found that the reader can immediately relate to his own world to fulfill the function the original word had in its world. In our world of identities (national, racial, religious, personal, sexual, etc.), “identity” is a part of our makeup; thus, when we are taught the ultimate absence of identity of all persons and things, it is easy to “identify” what is supposedly absent and hence to try to understand what that entails.
A sambhogakāya deity to which the practitioner has a samaya commitment, commonly known by the students of Tibetan Buddhism as yidam.
The forty-sixth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
One among a list of sixteen uṣṇīṣa buddhas named after the sixteen emptinesses.
One of the fourteen emptinesses and eighteen emptinesses.
Thirteenth of the eighteen aspects of emptiness.
One among a list of sixteen uṣṇīṣa buddhas named after the sixteen emptinesses.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Mayūra.
One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife.
One of the goddesses associated with Amoghapāśa.
One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife.

The vehicle comprising the teaching of the pratyekabuddhas, literally “solitary enlightened ones” or “buddhas on their own.” The pratyekabuddhas are typically defined as those who have attained liberation but do not teach the path to liberation to others. Pratyekabuddhas are said to appear in universes and times in which there is no fully enlightened buddha who has rediscovered the path and taught it to others.
Synonymous with pratyeka buddha.
Those who, in times when there is no buddha, reach enlightenment on their own, but do not teach the Dharma to others.
A person who in his final life achieves realization through contemplating the twelve links of dependent origination without following an external teacher.

A hermit buddha who attains individual enlightenment, either in solitude or in small groups, without relying on a teacher.\n(See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-8 ).

Someone who has attained liberation entirely through their own contemplation as a result of progress in previous lives but, unlike a buddha, does not have the accumulated merit and motivation to teach others. They are named as “rhinoceros-like” (khaḍgaviṣāṇakalpa) for their preference for staying in solitude or as “congregators” (vargacārin) when their preference is to stay among peers.

“Solitary buddha.” Someone who has attained liberation entirely through their own contemplation, hence their alternate epithet, pratyayajina, which means one who has become a jina, or buddha, through dependence [on external factors that were contemplated upon]. This is the result of progress in previous lives but, unlike a buddha, they do not have the necessary accumulated merit nor the motivation to teach others.
The nonconceptual wakefulness that is both the basis for and the result of tantric sādhana practice.
Name of the eighth level attainable by bodhisattvas. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1282 .
The path of the pratyekabuddhas.
The way or vehicle of the pratyeka buddhas.
The vehicle comprising the teaching of the pratyekabuddhas.
The way of the pratyekabuddha, particularly characterized by contemplation on the twelve phases of dependent origination.
The eighth of the ten levels traversed by all practitioners, from the level of an ordinary person until reaching buddhahood. See “ten levels” and “pratyekabuddha.”

A “solitary enlightened one,” or “buddha on one’s own,” this refers to one who has attained liberation but does not teach the path to liberation to others. Pratyekabuddhas are said to appear in universes and at times in which there is no fully enlightened buddha who has rediscovered the path and taught it to others.

Someone who has attained liberation without relying on a teacher in their final lifetime and as a result of progress in previous lives but, unlike a buddha, does not have the accumulated merit and motivation to teach others. Like śrāvaka (“hearer”), this term is also used to denote Buddhists who do not follow the Mahāyāna.

Someone who has attained liberation entirely through their own contemplation as a result of progress in previous lives but, unlike a buddha, does not have the accumulated merit and motivation to teach others. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-051-001.html#UT22084-051-001-731 and https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-051-001.html#UT22084-051-001-734 .

Someone who has attained liberation entirely through their own contemplation as a result of progress in previous lives but, unlike a buddha, does not have the accumulated merit and motivation to teach others. They are named as “rhinoceros-like” (khaḍgaviṣāṇakalpa) for their preference for staying in solitude or as “congregators” (vargacārin) when their preference is to stay among peers.

“Solitary buddha.” Someone who has attained liberation entirely through their own contemplation, hence their alternate epithet, pratyayajina, which means one who has become a jina, or buddha, through dependence [on external factors that were contemplated upon]. This is the result of progress in previous lives but, unlike a buddha, they do not have the necessary accumulated merit nor the motivation to teach others.

Literally, “buddha for himself,” or “solitary realizer.” Those who attain buddhahood in a time when the Buddha’s doctrine is no longer available in the world, and who remain either in solitude or among peers, without teaching the path to liberation to others. Their attainment is the result of progress in previous lives but, unlike a buddha, they do not have the necessary accumulated merit nor the motivation to teach others.
The name for a number of plants and substances such as a fermented rice gruel, a medicinal plant, an edible legume, or a kind of creeping plant.
A teacher with whom Siddhārtha studied meditation.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
Where Buddha converted a noble band of sixty youths.

karpāsa (rendered here “shrub cotton”) and Tūla (rendered here as “tree cotton”) are both kinds of cotton, perhaps overlapping as is translated into Tibetan as {ras bal} in some texts. Our rendering is based on the Tibetans’ choice of the term {shing bal} and the existence of a number of species of Gossypium, among which are the diploid, Asian G. arboreum and G. herbaceum (cf Monier Williams); Negi’s Tibetan-Sanskrit dictionary also mentions five kinds of tūla, at least some of which are trees. Other possible distinctions might be between annual and perennial plants, or varieties grown in different regions.\nSee https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-274 .

(1083–1161). A close disciple of Milarepa, who traveled to India and brought back some of the teaching cycles that Marpa had not transmitted, as well as the Amitāyus tradition he received from the yoginī Siddharājñī.
An acceptable form of cloth for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
“Large” meaning twelve cubits. An acceptable form of cloth for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
Twenty-eighth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
A river on Upward Ocean.
Bitumen, benzoin, or lichen (McHugh, 2008, p 180 n25).

A famous Tibetan scholar (1865–1926) of the Ancient ({rnying ma}) tradition who composed an explication of the dhāraṇī genre entitled An Ornamental Explanation of the Bodhisattva Dhāraṇī: A Garland of Eloquent Explanation that Adorns the Auspicious Body of the Victorious Mother (byang chub sems dpa’i gzungs kyi rgyan rnam par bshad pa rgyal yum lus bzang mdzes byed legs bshad phreng ba).
A country.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Howling Hell.
A buddha realm.
An epithet of Vajrapāṇi.
In the context of this text, Vajradhara is another name for Vajrapāṇi.
In tantra traditions, the name of a primordial buddha, but here perhaps an alternative name for Vajrapāṇi.
‟Vajra holder”; in the Bhūta ḍāmara Tantra this appears to be an epithet of Vajrapāṇi, the deity who teaches this tantra.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
In the context of the AP, Vajradhara is another name for Vajrapāṇi.
One of the tathāgatas.
An epithet of Vajrapāṇi.
Father of the buddha Puruṣadatta.
An epithet of the bodhisattva Vajrapāṇi.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
The Buddhist counterpart of Śiva.
A bodhisattva.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha.
A bodhisattva great being present in the audience of this sūtra.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
Son of the buddha Vajrasena.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Pradyota.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
A buddha.
A mountain.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
“Possessor of vajra”; an epithet of male sambhogakāya deities embodying the adamantine non-duality; a follower of the Vajrayāna; an epithet for anyone abiding in non-duality.
One of the deities in the maṇḍala of Avalokiteśvara-Amoghapāśa.
A type of worm ({srin bu}) that lives in and feeds on the body.
Urine; it is referred to as “vajra water” when used in rituals.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
The most sensitive spot of the woman’s genitals.
Consort of Caṇḍa mahā roṣaṇa. See also “Vajra realm.”
A bodhisattva in the Buddha Akṣobhya’s retinue in this tantra.
The experiential sphere of nonduality.
Intrinsically pure reality experienced through non-dual cognition.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha Akṣobhya’s retinue in this tantra.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the goddesses in the maṇḍala of Vajrasattva.
Bell with a handle in the shape of a vajra scepter.

This is Amoghavajra, Vajrāsana the younger (eleventh century), who was the successor of Vajrāsana the elder. They were both the abbots of the Vajrāsana Monastery in what is now Bodhgaya. His teachings are important in the Sakya tradition.
Another name of Bodhgaya.
Another name for the “seat of awakening.”
A bodhisattva in the Buddha Akṣobhya’s retinue in this tantra.
One of the goddesses in the maṇḍala of Vajrasattva.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A great bodhisattva.
Name of a buddha realm in the east where the buddha Glory of Being Renowned for Superior Skill That Brings Satisfaction resides.
Lit. “Fierce Vajra.”
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the goddesses in the maṇḍala of Vajrasattva.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
An epithet of Cakrasaṃvara.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the goddesses associated with Amoghapāśa.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha Akṣobhya’s retinue in this tantra.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the goddesses in the maṇḍala of Vajrasattva.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
One of the eight goddesses visualized on the petals of a lotus in a ritual associated with the vajra scepter.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the goddesses in the maṇḍala of Vajrasattva.
One of the goddesses associated with Amoghapāśa, probably the same as Vajraśṛṅkhalā (“Vajra Chain”).
One of the goddesses associated with Amoghapāśa, probably the same as Vajraśṛṅkhalā (“Vajra Chain”).
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
A very high level of samādhi obtained during the last stages of the Buddhist path.
The name of a bodhisattva in the Buddha’s audience.
An absorption.
Name of the tenth meditative stability.
Lit. “diamond-like.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Applied to a particular meditative absorption that destroys all fetters and leads to the fifth path, that of no further training, in Sarvāstivāda and Mahāyāna systems.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
An absorption.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
One of the goddesses associated with Amoghapāśa, probably the same as Vajraśṛṅkhalā (“Vajra Chain”).
One of the goddesses associated with Amoghapāśa, probably the same as Vajraśṛṅkhalā (“Vajra Chain”).
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the goddesses associated with Amoghapāśa.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha Akṣobhya’s retinue in this tantra.
One of the goddesses in the maṇḍala of Vajrasattva; one of the five ḍākinīs visualized on the five prongs of the vajra scepter.
A wrathful deity.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
The 749th buddha in the first list, 748th in the second list, and 738th in the third list.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A buddha in the distant past.
One of the four retinue goddesses of Mahāsukhavajra.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
The 282nd buddha in the first list, 281st in the second list, and 281st in the third list.
A sambhogakāya buddha personifying the true nature of the aggregate of sensation.
A buddha in an analogy given by the bodhisattva Vajra garbha.
A Buddhist goddess related to Vajrayoginī.
One of the “messenger” goddesses.
A goddess.
The name could suggest a Buddhist counterpart of the Śaiva deity Piṅgala, an attendant of Śiva.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
This seems to be the Buddhist (Vajrayāna) name of the male deity, Aralli, in the centre of the dharmodaya.
A buddha in a northern realm.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha Akṣobhya’s retinue in this tantra.

Vajrapramardin (Vajra Vanquisher) is a buddha who inhabits a buddhafield. This buddhafield is specifically said to be Kaṣāyadhvajā in http://read.84000.co/translation/toh44-37.html#UT22084-036-008-63 and http://read.84000.co/translation/toh104.html#UT22084-048-004-76. In Toh 104 he is named Vajrasārapramardin (Vajra Essence Vanquisher).
A buddha realm in the southern direction.
A pore on Avalokiteśvara’s body.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A sambhogakāya buddha personifying the true nature of the aggregate of mental formations.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
“The Magnificence of a Mountain of Precious Diamonds.” The precious elephant of a cakravartin in the past.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Lit. “vajra jewel.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
A Buddhist goddess.
This seems to be a class of enlightened beings.
A Buddhist deity, the embodiment of the eponymous dhāraṇī revealed in The Dhāraṇī “Vajra Conqueror” and a form of the bodhisattva Vajrapāṇi.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A deity.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A wrathful deity.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the goddesses in the maṇḍala of Vajrasattva.
Son of the buddha Vaidyarāja.
One of the goddesses from Vajrapāṇī’s retinue in the maṇḍala of Mañjuśrī.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Sūryagarbha.
One of the four retinue goddesses of Mahāsukhavajra.
The deity delivering the CMT.
The sambhogakāya buddha who delivers the Sampuṭodbhava; he also represents the aggregate of consciousness.

Used as a proper name, Vajrasattva is one of the principle deities of the esoteric Buddhist pantheon, regarded as both a source of the Buddhist tantras and the exemplar of the awakened state. As an adjective, the term vajrasattva, literally “vajra being,” can also be applied to other esoteric Buddhist deities, particularly Vajrapāṇi.
A form of Tārā, the Buddhist goddess of compassion, commonly depicted as golden yellow in color, with four faces and eight arms.
One of the four retinue goddesses of Mahāsukhavajra.
A buddha.
Vajra sārapramardin (Vajra Essence Vanquisher) is a buddha who inhabits the buddhafield Kaṣāyadhvajā.
A buddha realm.
A bodhisattva; in some parts of the Sampuṭa Tantra, he is the interlocutor of the Blessed One.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
The Buddhist counterpart of Viṣṇu.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
A yakṣa bodhisattva and Buddhist deity, also called the “general of yakṣas.”
A buddha realm.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
One of the goddesses in the maṇḍala of Vajrasattva.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the goddesses in the maṇḍala of Vajrasattva.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Vegajaha.
A bodhisattva.
Mother of the buddha Arciṣmat.
Not in Negi. {rdo rje 'od ma} appears in Negi as Skt. Vajrābha.
The fifty-fourth buddha in the distant past. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-037-007.html#UT22084-037-007-3366 .
Mother of the buddha Vajrasena.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Asaṅga.
An absorption.
Name of the twenty-third meditative stability.
Lit. “vajra circle.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
The name of countless realms in the ten directions, in each of which is a buddha named Vajradhvaja.
Another name for the “seat of awakening.”
The site of the Buddha’s ultimate awakening.
The site of a buddha’s awakening, referring to the vajra seat of any buddha realm.
The seat upon which a full realization of a buddha is attained. This attainment is one of the twelve great deeds of a tathāgata.
This seems to be the name of the realm/abode of Vajrapāṇi.
A bodhisattva in a northern realm.
A town in the Draviḍa region in South India.
The name of a monastery
The names of two buddhas in the past: one not long before Dīpaṅkara and another in the far distant past. BHS verse: Vajiranābhi.

The body of the Buddha is like an indestructible vajra. While the term vajrakāya has specialized meaning in a tantric context, it is unlikely that such meaning is applicable here. In the Chinese, the term is translated as a “vajra-like, indestructible solid body” (jin gang bu huai jian gu zhi shen 金剛不壞堅固之身).
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
A bodhisattva.
A cave inhabited by the asuras.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A realm in the distant past.
An absorption.
The name of a past bodhisattva.
The 109th buddha in the first list, 109th in the second list, and 110th in the third list.
The name of countless buddhas, each in a realm named Vajraśrī, from which countless bodhisattvas come at the conclusion of the sūtra.
The family associated with Vajrapāṇi.
One of the five buddha families, it is presided over by the Tathāgata Akṣobhya.
In this context‌, the term vajrakula denotes the retinue of the wrathful bodhisattva Vajrapāṇi.
Name of a bodhisattva.

(1) The four vajrayogas are the vajrayogas of purity (Skt. viśuddha), dharma, mantra, and form (Skt. saṃsthāna).\n(2) In this text, Vajrayoga is also the name of one of the six self-arisen supramundane beings, see https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-077-002.html#UT22084-077-002-92 .
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi. The attested Tibetan appears to in error, and should read {rdo rje'i smin ma}.
Son of the buddha Guṇadhvaja.
Father of the buddha Sarvārtha darśin.
The 246th buddha in the first list, 245th in the second list, and 245th in the third list.
A pore on Avalokiteśvara’s body.
He is described in the text as a nāga king.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one All-Conquering Vajra.
A tathāgata mentioned here as one of the thirty-five buddhas of confession.
A great bodhisattva.

The bodhisattva who gives all the teachings of The Ten Bhūmis while in the Para nirmita vaśa vartin paradise in the presence of a silent emanation of the Buddha Śākyamuni who has just attained buddhahood in Jambudvīpa. A bodhisattva of that name appears in passing in a few other sūtras and is the name of the principal interlocutor for the Hevajra Tantra, and the commentary to that tantra is also attributed to him.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
A bodhisattva.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
One of ten different kinds of verbal phrase or statement (Skt. pada) mentioned in this text.
One of the deities in the maṇḍala of Avalokiteśvara-Amoghapāśa.
Father of the buddha Anindita.
Vajrapramardin (Vajra Vanquisher) is a buddha who inhabits the buddhafield Kaṣāyadhvajā.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with the Essence of Vajra.
A ritual sceptre; thunderbot; a diamond; a general term denoting an indestructible non-dual state.
An impenetrable substance, used both as a reference to diamond and in particular to the thunderbolt held by the god Indra; also denotes indestructibility.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya guru vaiḍūrya prabha rāja sūtra.

The term stands for indestructibility and perfect stability. According to Indian mythology, the vajra is the all-powerful god Indra’s weapon, likened to a thunderbolt, which made him invincible. It also relates to a substance called vajra, which is the hardest physical material.

The word vajra refers to the “thunderbolt,” the indestructible and irresistible weapon that first appears in Indian literature in the hand of the Vedic deity Indra. As a symbol of indestructibility and great power it is used in the Kāraṇḍavyūha to describe the qualities of the maṇi mantra.

The term stands for indestructibility and perfect stability. According to Indian mythology, the vajra is the god Indra’s weapon, which made him invincible. According to the Purāṇas, the vajra was made of the bones of the sage Dadhichi, who gave up his life, so that the gods could defeat the asuras.
Name of a location in Khaṣa.
A river on Uttara Mountain.

The Gaṇḍa vyūha uses the same terminology as the Jain text Tandulaveyāliyua and differs from other sūtras. Other texts have {nar nar}. In the Nanda garbhāvakranti nirdeśa sūtra https://read.84000.co/translation/toh57.html peśi is translated as {ltar ltar}.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha Akṣobhya’s retinue in this tantra.
Birthplace of the buddha Pratibhānakūṭa.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
A nāga king.
A buddha realm.
One of the power places.
Mother of the buddha Jñānin.
Attendant of the buddha Tiṣya.
The 776th buddha in the first list, 775th in the second list, and 765th in the third list.
Birthplace of the buddha Arciṣmat.
Lit. “piled up as one sweats and reeks.” Akin to Pali sedāvakkhitta.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A buddha realm.
“Domain Free of Dust.” The name of a kalpa in the distant past.
“The Essence of the Splendor That Is Free of Dust.” The name of a ray of light.
A bodhisattva.
A four-continent world realm.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Lit. “dust free.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Virajā (Dustless) is a buddhafield inhabited by the Buddha Dharmadhvaja.
A buddha.
A mountain in Godānīya.
Lit. “Free of Dust Collections.” A world system in the intermediate southwest direction, where the buddha Sūrya maṇḍala prabhāsottara śrī now dwells.
The name of an ancient city ruled by King Diśāṃpati. Śāriputra and Maudgalyāyana are said to have lived on the outskirts of this city during their former lifetimes as ascetics.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha.
Name of the 105th meditative stability.
Lit. “endowed with a dustless mode free from dust.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A buddha.
Realm of a tathāgata.
The realm of Buddha Padmaprabha.
Lit. “dustless.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
The buddha realm of the buddha Displaying Leonine Power.
Virajā (Dustless) is a buddhafield inhabited by the Buddha Dharmadhvaja.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva.
The name of the buddha that the sage Jyotīrasa will become, according to a prophecy by the Buddha.
A buddha realm.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Ambrosia Melody.
One of the pratyeka buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The 866th buddha in the first list, 865th in the second list, and 855th in the third list.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
One of the seven kings mentioned in the story of Govinda.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A maṇḍala created with colored powders.
A particular part of the maṇḍala (?); the Tibetan reads “sand-colored ground”.

This appears to be another name for the cloak called saṃkakṣikā. It is listed as one of the extra two robes for a bhikṣuni, which covers the body, but in the Sarvāstivādavinaya, it is mentioned only twice, and both times in relation to bhikṣus. The Buddha says bhikṣus should cover their bodies with this cloak so their chest is not visible when they go on alms rounds in villages. The two Tibetan spelling variants mean either “sweat robe” or “dust robe.”
A buddha realm.
One of the rāśis.
One of the pratyeka buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the three principles or forces of nature, as known in the Sāṃkhya philosophy, characterized by energy and movement.

A son of King Diśāṃpati of Pāṁśula who lived before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni. He became king after the death of his father. In The Hundred Deeds, he is said to have been a previous incarnation of King Bimbisāra.
Great lay follower of Buddha Kāśyapa.

A kettledrum with ends played horizontally. Unlike the mṛdaṅga, one half of the drum is wider than the other. Another description says that the heads of the drum are smaller than those of the mṛdaṅga.
One of the goddesses in the maṇḍala of Vajrasattva.
A two-headed hand drum that is played horizontally, wider in the middle with one drum head smaller than the other. Seventy-second of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.

A kettledrum played horizontally, wider in the middle, with the skin at both ends played with the hands. One drumhead is smaller than the other. It is a South Indian drum, and maintains the rhythm in Karnataka music.
Things that are merely labelled through concepts or ideas.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Things that are not merely labelled through concepts or ideas but are actually capable of performing a function, e.g., form.
One of the vidyārājñīs attending the delivery of the MMK.
A lotus pond where the nāga king Supratiṣṭhita lives.
One of the auxiliary charnel grounds.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
One of the groves in the realm of Thirty-Three.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
One of the eight bhūta kings.
An abbreviation of Pūraṇa Kāśyapa.
Extremist teacher at the time of the Buddha
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya guru vaiḍūrya prabha rāja sūtra.

A certain brahmin, child of wealthy householders in Śrāvastī, who became an attendant of Venerable Aniruddha before returning home at his parents’ request and manifesting arhatship. Appears in the Story of Pūraṇa.
One of the four garuḍa kings, present at the teaching of the sūtra.

The first of the four ages of human life in Jambudvīpa. Humans in this age enjoy good qualities such as long lifespans free from disease (see https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-068-021.html#UT22084-068-021-8228 ). Over the course of the four ages humans will lose a quarter of these qualities between each age.
Birthplace of the buddha Anuddhata.
Attendant of the buddha Mahāpraṇāda.
The most auspicious in the cycle of four eons.
(1) A disciple of the Buddha from Sūrpāraka ({gang po}). (2) A disciple of the Buddha from Kuṇḍopadhāna ({gang po}). (3) A haṃsa ({gang ba}). (4) A buddha in the past ({rdzogs ldan}).
The 275th buddha in the first list, 274th in the second list, and 274th in the third list. The Tibetan-Sanskrit correspondence is tentative; see Skilling and Saerji 2016: p. 153 n. 56.

In chapter 29 it is the name of the sixth buddha in a list that begins with Kanaka muni. In chapter 44 it is the name of a future buddha in this kalpa. Mahāvyutpatti and other sūtras translate puṣya as {rgyal}.

The second of the two stages of tantric sādhana practiced. Its practices are specific to individual tantric systems but typically include sexual yogas, the consumption of illicit substances, manipulation of the subtle energetic anatomy or resting in an uncontrived state.
Someone fully ordained.

The 684th buddha in the first list, 683rd in the second list, and 675th in the third list. In regard to the correspondence between the Tibetan {rdzogs} and the Sanskrit anupama see Skilling and Saerji 2017: p. 325 n. 193.
Mother of the buddha Ratnaketu.
Mother of the buddha Guṇarāśi.
Mother of the buddha Rāhugupta.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Brahmasvara (322 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Attendant of the buddha Abhijñāketu.
Son of the buddha Puṇyapradīpa.
Attendant of the buddha Surāṣṭra.
One of the kinnara kings.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Vigatakāṅkṣa.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Prasannabuddhi.
Four types of absorption related to intention, diligence, attention, and analysis as they manifest on the greater path of accumulation.
These are (1) single-pointed intention, (2) single-pointed thoughts, (3) single-pointed diligence, and (4) single-pointed investigation.
The four foundations or bases of miraculous power are: determination, discernment, diligence, and absorption. These are among the thirty-seven factors of awakening.
Extraordinary abilities that arise due to success in meditation. They are the footings of success based on isolation, based on nonattraction, based on cessation, and matured by relinquishment.

The first basis of magical power consists of the energy from the conscious cultivation of concentration of will (chanda samādhi prahāṇa saṃskāra samanvāgataḥ). The second consists of the energy from the conscious cultivation of concentration of mind (citta‑). The third consists of concentration of effort (vīrya‑). The fourth consists of concentration of analysis (mīmāṃsa‑). These four form a part of the thirty-seven aids to enlightenment.

The four supports for miraculous ability, as enumerated in https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-161 , comprise (1) the support for miraculous ability combining the meditative stability of resolution with the formative force of exertion, (2) the support for miraculous ability combining the meditative stability of perseverance with the formative force of exertion, (3) the support for miraculous ability combining the meditative stability of mind with the formative force of exertion, and (4) the support for miraculous ability combining the meditative stability of scrutiny with the formative force of exertion.
Intention, diligence, attention, and discernment.
Extraordinary abilities that arise due to success in meditation. They are the footings of success based on isolation, based on nonattraction, based on cessation, and matured by relinquishment.
Four qualities that eliminate negative factors: zeal, vigor, attention (Tib. {sems pa}, Skt. citta), and investigation (Tib. {dpyod pa}, Skt. mīmāṃsā).
Four qualities belonging to the thirty-seven aids to awakening, these are concentration based on (1) intention, (2) diligence, (3) attention, and (4) analysis.
Refers here to the four bases of miraculous power that belong to the thirty-seven factors conducive to awakening; they are determination, discernment, diligence, and contemplation.
Four types of absorption related to intention, diligence, attention, and analysis respectively. Among the https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-047-001.html#UT22084-047-001-1953 (q.v.).

The four bases of magical power (Skt. ṛddhipāda, Tib. {rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa bzhi}) are: (1) concentration through will (Skt. chanda, Tib. {'dun pa}); (2) concentration through vigor (Skt. vīrya, Tib. {brtson 'grus}); (3) concentration through the mind (Skt. citta, Tib. {bsam pa}); (4) concentration through investigation (Skt. mīmāṃsā, Tib. {dpyod pa}).

Four (supernatural) qualities or powers of the mind that help to gain the fruit of the path: aspiration, effort, concentration, and analysis. In contrast to what the name suggests, the actual supernatural power––like the ability to walk on water, dive into the earth, pass through solid objects, flying, etc.–– are usually considered byproducts and even distractions from attaining the fruit of the path: liberation.
These are (1) single-pointed intention, (2) single-pointed thoughts, (3) single-pointed diligence, and (4) single-pointed investigation.
Birthplace of the buddha Acyuta.
Father of the buddha Maticintin.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Āśādatta (464 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Determination, discernment, diligence, and concentration.
Four qualities that eliminate negative factors: zeal, vigor, attention (Tib. {sems pa}, Skt. citta), and investigation (Tib. {dpyod pa}, Skt. mīmāṃsā).
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Vighuṣṭarāja.
Birthplace of the buddha Gaganasvara.
Birthplace of the buddha Sarva vara guṇa prabha.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ketumat.
The 909th buddha in the first list, 908th in the second list, and 899th in the third list.
Son of the buddha Nāgaruta.
One of the five supernormal knowledges.
The ability to make manifest miraculous displays evident to ordinary beings.

The supernatural powers of a śrāvaka correspond to the first abhijnā: “Being one he becomes many, being many he becomes one; he becomes visible, invisible; goes through walls, ramparts and mountains without being impeded, just as through air; he immerses himself in the earth and emerges from it as if in water; he goes on water without breaking through it, as if on [solid] earth; he travels through the air crosslegged like a winged bird; he takes in his hands and touches the moon and the sun, those two wonderful, mighty beings, and with his body he extends his power as far as the Brahma world” (Lamotte 2003: 20). The great supernatural powers (mahāṛddhi) of bodhisattvas are: “causing trembling, blazing, illuminating, rendering invisible, transforming, coming and going across obstacles, reducing or enlarging worlds, inserting any matter into one’s own body, assuming the aspects of those one frequents, appearing and disappearing, submitting everyone to one’s will, dominating the supernormal power of others, giving intellectual clarity to those who lack it, giving mindfulness, bestowing happiness, and finally, emitting beneficial rays.” (Lamotte 2003: 30).
A deprecatory term meaning “old” or “out-of-date.”
Fourth of the ten non-virtuous actions.
The first among the four verbal misdeeds.
Fourth of the four modes of birth.

Regarded as the most superior of the four modes of birth, the three other modes being birth from an egg, birth from a womb, or birth from warmth and moisture. Those who take a miraculous birth are spontaneously born fully mature at the time of their birth.
One of the fourfold classification of ways in which beings are born.

One of the four modes of birth (caturyoni; {skes gnas bzhi}). Those who take miraculous birth are spontaneously born fully mature at the time of their birth. There are many categories of beings that can be born under these circumstances including gods, hungry ghosts, beings born in hell, beings born in the intermediate state (antarābhava; {bar ma do}), and even humans in special circumstances or in the pure realms.
Exhalation (one of the four stages during a single breath).
A village or town. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2482 .
Fourteenth of the eighteen sensory elements.
Eleventh of the twelve sense fields.
A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
Sustenance obtained through consciousness being in contact with an object; one of the four kinds of food.
This refers to the six “internal entrances,” i.e., the five sense faculties plus thought.
Second of the four nourishments.
Sustenance obtained through consciousness being in contact with an object; one of the four kinds of food.
The sixth link of dependent arising.
Sixth of the twelve links of dependent origination.
The sixth of the twelve links of dependent origination. See “dependent origination.”
The contact of the sense organs with the sense objects. Also translated here as “sensory contact.”

This can mean either, more literally, “touch,” or coming into contact; in the context of the twelve parts of dependent arising, “contact” refers more specifically to the coming together of the object, faculty, and consciousness. According to some abhidharma masters, this coming together gives rise to a specific entity called “contact,” while others consider “contact” to simply describe a specific state of those three entities, i.e., when object, faculty, and consciousness are “together” and thus able to give rise to notion. It is also worth noticing that the root spṛś is used far more often in Sanskrit than either “to touch” or “to come in contact with” is used in English, and can often mean something like “to obtain” etc.
The period after exhalation and before the next inhalation (one of the four stages during a single breath).
A spirit that causes paralysis.
It is not clear what location or entity this name refers to; the Sanskrit dictionary identifies it as the name of a river.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A buddha.
Twelfth of the twelve links of dependent origination.
Father of the buddha Guṇagaṇa.
Attendant of the buddha Ratna svara ghoṣa.
One of the great mātṛs.
‟One with an Aged Face,” one of the eight demonesses who inhabit the eight great charnel grounds.
‟Pleasure,” one of the eight great bhūtinīs; one of the eight great yakṣiṇīs; the wife of Kāmadeva.
Someone who is ordained late in their life.

This term refers to those who renounce the world late in life, generally after having had and raised children of their own. It is somewhat pejorative; it is telling, for instance, that such monastics are directly addressed as “old-timers” rather than as “venerable,” the customary address for ordained monks.
‟Laughing One,” one of the eight great bhūtinīs.
One of the grahas.

Also known as “Vulture Peak,” a hill located in modern-day Bihar, India, and in the vicinity of the ancient city of Rājagṛha. A location where many sūtras were taught and which continues to be a sacred pilgrimage site for Buddhists to this day.
A mountain by Rajghir in Bihar, which is the setting for many sutras. Also rendered here as “Gṛdhrakūṭa.”
One of the grahas.
One of the emanations of Śiva.
“Mare’s fire,” a subterranean mythical fire.
One of the five obscurations.
Fifth of the five fetters associated with the higher realms.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Śrī.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Jñānakrama.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Sumati.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Gaṇimukha.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Saṃjaya.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Merudhvaja.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Śrotriya.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ratnaskandha.
A prize awarded by a king to the winner of a debate. In the Vinayavastu, the prize was title to a village and its taxes.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Śāntagati.
Attendant of the buddha Abhaya.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
A realm of the ever-infatuated gods.
Mother of the buddha Apagatakleśa.
The forty-first buddha in a kalpa in the distant past, and also the eighty-eighth buddha in another kalpa in the distant past.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Kāśyapa (471 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.

The name of one of the bodhisattvas in the Buddha Śākyamuni’s presence in Śrāvastī in chapter 1 (where it is translated as {rgya chen po'i 'od}), and the name of the king, one of Sudhana’s kalyāṇamitras, in chapter 22 (where it is translated as {'od chen po}).
One of the twenty-seven realms of the Heaven Free from Strife, presumably the same as Moving in Mixed Environments.
The 601st buddha in the first list, 600th in the second list, and 594th in the third list.
Father of the buddha Nāgaruta.
A holy site blessed by the presence of sages.
A merchant’s son.
A bodhisattva.
An unidentified river in India.
“Ten Lakes,” the country southeast of Madhyadeśa.
A short form of Sāgara vara dhara buddhi vikrīḍitābhijña, the name that Ānanda will have when he is a buddha.
A town in South India.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Sadgaṇin.
Four oceans believed to surround the central mountain, Mt. Meru, in Indian cosmology.
In Buddhist cosmology, the four oceans in between the four continents that are at the cardinal points of the flat disc of the world, with the gigantic Mount Sumeru in its center.
Attendant of the buddha Janendrarāja.
A buddha in the distant past.
A mountain on Videha.
The name of Ānanda when he becomes a buddha in the future.
Birthplace of the buddha Samudradatta.
Lit. “limitless ocean.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A buddha in the distant past. BHS verse: Sāgara śiri.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one He Who Overwhelms the Seat of Awakening with His Brilliance.
An area in the south of India.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A province in South India.
One of the charnel grounds.
Mother of the buddha Janendrarāja.
Father of the buddha Ratnaketu.
A bhikṣu who was a pupil of Śāriputra.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Samudradatta.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Vibhrājacchattra (157 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha who lived in the distant past.
One of the emanations of Śiva.
The son of King Glacier Lake Deity, a past monarch of the city of Campā.
Name of a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A buddha that resides in a world system below our world called Adorned with Immaculate and Countless Precious Qualities.
Attendant of the buddha Sārathi.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Sucintitārtha.
An area in the Laṅka region of South India.
An absorption.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the twelve retentions of the bodhisattvas.
The name of an absorption and the name of a dhāraṇī.
A bhikṣu, the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 9.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
An area in the south of India.
Mother of the buddha Akṣaya.
A buddha in the distant past.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Shining with Immeasurable Incense.
A bhikṣu, the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 5.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Hutārci.
A nāga king.
One of four cronies of Devadatta.
Mother of the buddha Sarvārtha darśin.
The 503rd buddha in the first list, 503rd in the second list, and 496th in the third list.
One of the members of a group of four monks described in the Vinaya as followers of Devadatta that attempted to create a schism in the Buddhist saṅgha.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Janendrakalpa.
The 387th buddha in the first list, 386th in the second list, and 380th in the third list.
Literally meaning “ocean,” he is a king of the nāgas, a class of semidivine snake creatures.
The ocean personified; the Gupta emperor Samudragupta who ruled Gauḍa and Magadha in the third quarter of the fourth century.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Sahitaraśmi (358 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
The principal nāga king. In the Samādhi rāja Sūtra (http://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-055-001.html) this is said to be another name for Vaṛuna, the deity of the water.
A land to the north of Jambudvīpa.
A divine being who rules the Heaven of the Thirty-Three
Another name of Bhavatrāta, a half brother of Pūrṇa from Sūrpāraka.
A dye made from the insect Laccifer lacca.
Indian valerian or Valeriana jatamansi.
Valeriana wallichii. Specifically Indian valerian, also known as tagara and tagar.
The shrub Tabernaemontana coronaria from which a fragrant powder or perfume is obtained.
Either Tabernaemontana coronaria, Ervatamia divaricata, Valeriana hardwickii, or Valeriana wallichi (McHugh 2008, p 129 n34).
A river on Saṅkāśa.
Mother of the buddha Jaya.
One of four parks that surround the city of Radiant.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Vijita.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Bhasmakrodha.
The wife of Prince Viśvantara.
Name of a brahmin, a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
Indian paṇḍita of the ninth century.
Birthplace of the buddha Merudhvaja.
A holy site blessed by the presence of sages.
A head merchant who is the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 26.
A buddha.
Attendant of the buddha Prasannabuddhi.
A mansion upon the mountain Playful in the forest Joyous Wisdom.
Lit. “Victorious.” King of the city of Undefeated Victory before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
The ruler of the world Flower Origin.
Lit. “gained the victory.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Prāṇītajñāna (612 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
King Śrīsena’s wife.
Birthplace of the buddha Janendrakalpa.

Presumably a member of the royal dynasty in Kaliṅgavana. He is said to have donated the parkland that Bhikṣuṇī Siṃha vijṛmbhitā dwells in. Also the name of a king in another world realm in the distant past.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue; also one of Māra’s sons.
The name of a dhāraṇi taught in the King of the Array of all Dharma Qualities.
A bodhisattva and monastic teacher of a past eon; the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī in a former life.
A great bodhisattva.
Son of the buddha Prabhūta.
Co-translator and editor of the Tibetan text of the Uṣṇīṣavijayā Dhāraṇī. His name means “Spiritual Guide (mitra) of the Conquerors (jina).”
A buddha of the north.
Father of the buddha Janendrakalpa.
Lit. “Victorious Indra.” A buddha in a world system called Jayā, in the northern direction.
Son of the buddha Prahāṇakhila.
A thus-gone one from whom the buddha Śakyāmuni received a dhāraṇī called jayamatī in one of his previous lifes.
A brahmin, the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 12.
One of the eight uṣṇīṣa kings.
Name of a yakṣa general; a son of Kubera.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Rāhu sūrya garbha.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Vratanidhi (924 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A forest on the northern border of the Middle Country earlier in the current eon, during the time of the Buddha Kāśyapa.
A bodhisattva. The Tibetan rendering could be derived from Jayaskandha, Jinaskandha, or Jinarāśi.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Balasena.
A king; the context suggests that he is a king of the nāgas or the asuras.
Son of the buddha Kanakamuni.
Name of a past king, a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Subhaga (634 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
An epithet for a bodhisattva meaning “child of the jinas.”
“Son of the Jina,” a synonym for {bodhisattva}.
“Son of the Jina.” While it is a synonym for bodhisattva, jinaputra is used more frequently in this sūtra.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Son of the buddha Amitalocana.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Maṇicaraṇa (416 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
The fifth bodhisattva bhūmi.
Birthplace of the buddha Mahāsthāman.
The 211th buddha in the first list, 210th in the second list, and 210th in the third list.
The name of a kalpa in the distant past.
Father of the buddha Nāgadatta.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Yaśomati.
A bodhisattva of the north.
Mother of the buddha Mahāprabha.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Arthadarśin.
Lit. “Victory Given.” A bodhisattva from a world system called Jayā, in the northern direction, who comes to pay homage and listen to the Buddha.
The bodhisattva to whom this sūtra is spoken.
The 348th buddha in the first list, 347th in the second list, and 342nd in the third list.
One of the many standard titles or epithets of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
The 66th buddha in the first list, 66th in the second list, and 67th in the third list.
Lit. “Victorious.” A world system in the north direction, where the buddha Jayendra dwells.
A common epithet of the buddhas also used among the Jains, whose name is derived from the term jina.
One of the synonyms for a buddha. It literally means “victor” but is only used for founders of religious traditions.
The most common epithet of the buddhas, and also common among the Jains, hence their name. It means “the victorious one.”
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, lowest of the six heavens of the desire realm. It is located on the slopes of Mount Meru and ruled by the Four Great Kings.

A park outside Śrāvastī. It was donated to the Buddha by Anāthapiṇḍada, who purchased it at great cost from Prince Jeta, and built there the monastery where the Buddha spent most rainy seasons and is therefore the setting for many sūtras.

A grove that was bought by the Buddha’s wealthy follower and supporter Anāthapiṇḍada from a prince named Jeta and donated to the Buddha and his saṅgha (the story of the purchase and the events leading to it is told in the Cullavagga of the Pāli Vinaya (Vin II 158f.)).

A park in Śrāvastī, the capital of Kośala in northern India. It was owned by Prince Jeta, from whom Anāthapiṇḍada bought it in order to offer it to the Buddha. It was a place where the Buddha and his community of monks stayed during the monsoon season, and therefore eventually became the first Buddhist monastery. It is the setting for many of the Buddha’s discourses.

“Jeta’s Grove.” A grove to the south of the city of Śrāvastī. It was gifted to the Buddha and the monastic community by the merchant Anāthapiṇḍada after he purchased it from Prince Jeta by covering almost the entire grove with gold coins. The part that he could not cover was donated by Prince Jeta, who was impressed by Anāthapiṇḍada’s devotion and had a grand entrance built there with the sum of Anāthapiṇḍada’s gold coins.

A park in Śrāvastī, the capital of the ancient kingdom of Kośala in northern India. It was owned by Prince Jeta, and the wealthy merchant Anāthapiṇḍada, wishing to offer it to the Buddha, bought it from him by covering the entire property with gold coins. It was to become the place where the monks could be housed during the monsoon season, thus creating the first Buddhist monastery. It is therefore the setting for many of the Buddha’s discourses.

One of the first Buddhist monasteries, it is located outside of Śrāvastī and is also known as Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park. Anāthapiṇḍada, a merchant and benefactor of the Buddha, bought the land from Prince Jeta and donated it to the saṅgha. It is said that both names are mentioned to acknowledge their mutual efforts in building the monastery. It was there that the Buddha spent several rainy seasons and gave discourses that were later recorded as sūtras.
Prince who sold the so-called garden of Prince Jeta in Śrāvastī to the householder Anāthapiṇḍada, who built a monastery there and offered it to the Buddha.
The grove of Prince Jeta in Śrāvastī purchased by Anāthapiṇḍada; the Buddha taught many of his discourses there, especially during the rainy season retreat.
Son of the buddha Suvarṇacūḍa.
Prince Jeta’s Grove.

One of the first Buddhist monasteries, it is located outside of Śrāvastī and is also known as Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park. Anāthapiṇḍada, a merchant and benefactor of the Buddha, bought the land from Prince Jeta and donated it to the saṅgha. It is said that both names are mentioned to acknowledge their mutual efforts in building the monastery. It was there that the Buddha spent several rainy seasons and gave discourses that were later recorded as sūtras.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
One of the vidyās attending upon Mañjuśrī; one of the “four sisters” invoked in a mantra.
Attendant of the buddha Lokaprabha.
Prince who sold a piece of land in Śrāvastī to the householder Anāthapiṇḍada, who built a monastery there and offered it to the Buddha.
A rishi of ancient India, who was said to have swallowed the Ganges when it first appeared, and then on being supplicated allowed it to come out of his ear.
Attendant of the buddha Prasanna.
Son of the buddha Pratibhāna kīrti.
Son of the buddha Ratna svara ghoṣa.
A bodhisattva.
First of six levels of gods in the desire realm.
A class of gods who inhabit the lowest among the six heavens of the desire realm, the dwelling place of the Four Great Kings.
The lowest of the six heavens of the desire realm, it is ruled over by the Four Great Kings, who each guard one of the cardinal directions.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, lowest of the six heavens of the desire realm. It is located on the slopes of Mount Meru and ruled by the Four Great Kings.

The four respective realms of the Four Great Kings—Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and Vaiśravaṇa. They are the lowest of the god realms and found on the slopes of Mount Meru, one in each of the four directions.

One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, lowest among the six heavens of the desire realm. Dwelling place of the four great kings, traditionally located on a terrace of Sumeru, just below the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.

The realm of the Four Great Kings and their retinue constitutes the first and lowest heaven of the form realm on the slopes of Mount Meru. The Four Great Kings are Dhṛtarāṣṭra in the east, Virūḍhaka in the south, Virūpākṣa in the west, and Vaiśravaṇa in the north.

For consistency {rgyal chen bzhi'i ris} is rendered cāturmahā rājika (“[gods] belonging to the group of the Four Great Kings”), even though there are a number of Skt. forms (Edg says the forms are cāturmahā rāja kāyika and less often caturmahā rāja kāyika, and cāturmahā rājika and less often caturmahā rājika) and slight differences are encountered in the Tib. translation. “Gods” is sometimes rendered explicitly and is sometimes implicit in the Tib.
Gods of the four directions and the first heaven in the desire realm.
The divine kings who rule the four directions: Vaiśravaṇa (who in this text appears under his alternative name Kubera), Virūḍhaka, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and Virūpākṣa.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Son of the buddha Samṛddha.
Attendant of the buddha Rājan.
Attendant of the buddha Amṛtadhārin.
A mountain in Uttarakuru.
A great bodhisattva.
Attendant of the buddha Madhura svara rāja.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Mahāmeru.
Mother of the buddha Janendra.
Attendant of the buddha Puṣpaprabha.
A past king.
A brahmin; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Mother of the buddha Ugraprabha.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha field in the future where the bodhisattva Earth Holder attains buddhahood as the tathāgata Lord of Wisdom.
One of the goddesses invited to partake in the oblation offering.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi; one of the great yakṣiṇīs.
Father of the buddha Prabhūta.
Son of the buddha Puṣpaprabha.
Birthplace of the buddha Asthita.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Campaka.
Name of a tathāgata.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Vaidya (34) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Father of the buddha Indra.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.

In chapter 1 it is the name of one of the bodhisattvas in the presence of the Buddha at Śrāvastī (translated as {dri myed rgyal mtshan}). In chapter 44 it is the name of a bodhisattva in another world in the distant past (translated as {rgyal mtshan dri ma med pa}).
A royal city in the distant past.
Son of the buddha Abhedyabuddhi.
Lit. “trophy atop the victory banner.” Name of a meditative stabilization. ({dpung rgyan} renders keyūra. Khri pa has {thog}, perhaps for ketu.
Name of the twenty-fourth meditative stability.
One of the bodhisattvas.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha realm below this world.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Atula pratibhāna rāja.
A great bodhisattva.

The abbreviated name that the bodhisattva Incomparable/Stainless is prophesied to adopt when he takes his place as the tathāgata presiding over the buddhafield Full of Pearls after the tathāgata King of Jewels passes into parinirvāṇa. The full name of this tathagata in this work is Victory Banner King Whose Light Rays Illuminate All the World Realms in the Ten-Directional Unimpeded Circular Maṇḍala, Adorned with Completely Illuminating Sunlight, Endowed with a Space-Like Body Resembling Youthful Varuna, the Light of the Sun, a Moon Flower, and a Beautiful Golden Lotus.
A buddha realm.

An aerial palace in Samanta vyūha Park, also a forest of ashoka trees on the eastern edge of the town of Nandihāra, also a capital city in the distant past, as well as a four-continent world in the distant past.
Name of a rākṣasī and Dharma protector; in this text a guardian of the eastern direction.
Second of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
One of the eight auspicious symbols, often in the form of a roof-top ornament, representing the Buddha’s victory over malign forces.
A god.

The powerful nonhuman guardian kings of the four quarters‍—Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and Vaiśravaṇa‍—who rule, respectively, over kumbhāṇḍas in the south, nāgas in the west, gandharvas in the east, and yakṣas in the north.
A deity in the paradises of the Four Mahārājas.
The paradise of the Four Mahā rājas situated around the base of Sumeru.
One of the gods’ realms; also used as the name of the gods living there.
Four deities on the base of Mount Meru, each one the guardian of his direction: Vaiśravaṇa in the north, Dhṛtarāṣṭra in the east; Virūpākṣa in the west; and Virūḍhaka in the south.
The four divine kings who preside over the lowest of the god realms, on the slopes of Mount Meru: Dhṛtarāṣṭra in the east, Virūḍhaka in the south, Virūpākṣa in the west, and Vaiśravaṇa in the north.

Four gods who live on the lower slopes (fourth level) of Mount Meru in the Heaven of the Four Great Kings and guard the four cardinal directions. Each is the leader of a semidivine class of beings living in his realm. They are Dhṛtarāṣṭra, Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, and Vaiśravaṇa.

The powerful non-human guardian kings of the four quarters of this universe—Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and Vaiśravaṇa or Kubera, as he is called in this text—who rule, respectively, over kumbhāṇḍas in the south, nāgas in the west, gandharvas in the east, and yakṣas in the north.

The Four Great Kings—Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and Vaiśravaṇa. They are gods of the first god realm of the desire realm and known as powerful guardians of the four quarters who rule, respectively, over kumbhāṇḍas in the south, nāgas in the west, gandharvas in the east, and yakṣas in the north.

The Four Great Kings, or mahārājas, also known as the “Protectors of the World” ({'jig rten mgon po}; lokapāla), are the protectors of the four directions: (1) Dhṛtarāṣṭra ({yul 'khor srung}) in the east, (2) Virūḍhaka ({'phags skyes po}) in the south, (3) Virūpākṣa ({spyan mi bzang}) in the west, and (4) Vaiśravaṇa ({rnam thos sras}) in the north.
The five great deities of the Heaven of Joy. In the Tibetan translation, they are specified as kings.
A guardian of one of the four cardinal directions.
Four deities on the base of Mount Meru, each one the guardian of his direction: Vaiśravaṇa in the north, Dhṛtarāṣṭra in the east, Virūpākṣa in the west, and Virūḍhaka in the south.

A king ruling over a particularly large territory, often including the territories of other petty rulers; a class of divine beings assigned to the cardinal directions who guard the earth, Buddhist practitioners, and Buddhist institutions against demonic forces.

Literally means “great king.” In addition to referring to human kings, this is also the epithet for the four deities on the base of Mount Meru, each one the guardian of his direction: Vaiśravaṇa in the north, Dhṛtarāṣṭra in the east, Virūpākṣa in the west, and Virūḍhaka in the south.
A goddess.
Literally “king of rites,” the term can refer to an actual ritual or a ritual text, such as the AP.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Rājan.
The last emperor of the Sātavāhana dynasty.
A king during the life of the previous Buddha Vipaśyin.
One of the classes of people barred from joining the renunciate order.

A stylized way to say that a person or group may govern itself and is not subject to the “law of the land.” The Buddhist saṅgha enjoyed such autonomy. The analogy means the king granted sovereignty to the saṅgha, which was then allowed to govern itself and was not subject to the law of the land. The legal exemption members of the saṅgha enjoyed made it an attractive sanctuary for those on the run from their masters, debt collectors, and the law, who would join the saṅgha for legal rather than spiritual reasons. “From ancient times the legal tradition recognized the right of properly constituted groups to formulate their own laws” (Olivelle, 1993, 209).

In addition to the Five Royal Sūtras: (6) Aparimitāyur jñāna (tshe dang ye shes dpag tu med pa’i mdo, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh674.html); for extending longevity ({tshe bsring}). (7) gos sngon can gyi gzungs, perhaps Bhagavān nīlāmbara dhara vajrapāṇi tantra (https://read.84000.co/translation/toh498.html) but possibly another of the several texts on this form of Vajrapāṇi; for protection ({srung ba}). (8) Uṣṇīṣa sitāta patrā (gtsug tor gdugs dkar, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh590.html, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh591.html, and https://read.84000.co/translation/toh592.html); for averting ({zlog pa}). (9) Vasu dhāra (nor rgyun ma, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh663.html and https://read.84000.co/translation/toh664.html); for increasing resources ({longs spyod spel ba}). (10) Ekākṣarīmātā prajñā pāramitā (sher phyin yi ge gcig ma, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh23.html); for the essence ({snying po}).

This set of sūtras is so called either because they represent distillations of the most profound scriptures, or because according to traditional histories they were recommended to King Trisong Detsen for his daily practice by Guru Padmasambhava. These are: (1) Bhadra caryā praṇidhāna (bzang spyod smon lam, (https://read.84000.co/translation/toh44-45a.html) in chapter 45 of the Avataṃsaka); for aspiration ({smon lam}), and described as vast ({rgya chen}). (2) Vajra vidāraṇā dhāraṇī (rdo rje rnam ’joms, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh750.html); for ablution ({khrus}). (3) Prajñā pāramitā hṛdaya (shes rab snying po, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh21.html and https://read.84000.co/translation/toh531.html); for the view ({lta ba}), and described as profound ({zab mo}). (4) Atyaya jñāna (’da’ ka ye shes, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh122.html); for cultivation ({sgom pa}) and described as of definitive meaning (nges don). (5) bya ba ltung bshags (part of Vinaya viniścayopāli paripṛcchā, Toh 68: see UCSB Buddhist Studies Translation Group, trans. https://read.84000.co/translation/toh68.html#UT22084-043-005-94 , forthcoming); for purification of karmic obscurations ({las sgrib dag pa}). : (6) Aparimitāyur jñāna (tshe dang ye shes dpag tu med pa’i mdo, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh674.html); for extending longevity ({tshe bsring}). (7) gos sngon can gyi gzungs, perhaps Bhagavān nīlāmbara dhara vajrapāṇi tantra (https://read.84000.co/translation/toh498.html) but possibly another of the several texts on this form of Vajrapāṇi; for protection ({srung ba}). (8) Uṣṇīṣa sitāta patrā (gtsug tor gdugs dkar, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh590.html, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh591.html, and https://read.84000.co/translation/toh592.html); for averting ({zlog pa}). (9) Vasu dhāra (nor rgyun ma, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh663.html and https://read.84000.co/translation/toh664.html); for increasing resources ({longs spyod spel ba}). (10) Ekākṣarīmātā prajñā pāramitā (sher phyin yi ge gcig ma, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh68.html#UT22084-043-005-94); for the essence ({snying po}).

(1) Bhadra caryā praṇidhāna (bzang spyod smon lam, (https://read.84000.co/translation/toh44-45a.html) in chapter 45 of the Avataṃsaka); for aspiration ({smon lam}), and described as vast ({rgya chen}). (2) Vajra vidāraṇā dhāraṇī (rdo rje rnam ’joms, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh750.html); for ablution ({khrus}). (3) Prajñā pāramitā hṛdaya (shes rab snying po, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh21.html and https://read.84000.co/translation/toh531.html); for the view ({lta ba}), and described as profound ({zab mo}). (4) Atyaya jñāna (’da’ ka ye shes, Toh 122); for cultivation ({sgom pa}) and described as of definitive meaning (nges don). (5) bya ba ltung bshags (part of Vinaya viniścayopāli paripṛcchā, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh68.html#UT22084-043-005-94); for purification of karmic obscurations ({las sgrib dag pa}).
“Illuminating,” the name Prince Puṇyabala receives when he is coronated as a king.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A king in Khotan. Identified by Thomas (1935, p. 25) as Yehu-la.
The father of the Buddha.
Mother of the buddha Rājan.
An important city in ancient India in the state of present day Bihar.
Literally “king of rites,” the term can refer to an actual ritual or a ritual text, such as the AP.
Birthplace of the buddha Kṣatriya.
Now known as Rajgir and located in the modern Indian state of Bihar, Rājagṛha was the capital of the kingdom of Magadha during the Buddha’s lifetime.
Literally “King’s House,” this was the capital city of Magadha ruled by King Bimbisāra. It is currently the modern-day city of Rajgir in Bihar, North India.
Capital of the ancient country of Magadha, in the Buddha’s time it was ruled by King Bimbisāra, and it was the site for the teaching of many important sūtras.
The capital city of the ancient kingdom of Magadha from where King Bimbisāra and then his son Ajātaśatru ruled. It was located within the bowl of seven hills at present-day Rajgir in Bihar.

Modern Rajgir. Nearby is Vulture Peak mountain (Gṛdhrakūṭaparvata), where the Buddha is said to have taught the Prajñāpāramitā and other teachings, and the Bamboo Grove (Veṇuvana) where the Buddha regularly gave teachings.

The ancient capital of Magadha prior to its relocation to Pāṭaliputra during the Mauryan dynasty, Rājagṛha is one of the most important locations in Buddhist history. The literature tells us that the Buddha and his saṅgha spent a considerable amount of time in residence in and around Rājagṛha enjoying the patronage of King Bimbisāra and then of his son King Ajātaśatru. Rājagṛha is also remembered as the location where the first Buddhist monastic council was held after the Buddha Śākyamuni passed into parinirvāṇa. Now known as Rajgir and located in the modern Indian state of Bihar.
A certain nunnery, residence of Bhikṣuṇī Sthūlanandā.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Vigatabhaya (135) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
An image of the Buddha.
Birthplace of the buddha Krakucchanda.
Name of the thirteenth meditative stability.
Lit. “Seal of the king.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A member of the warrior caste.
The royal, noble, or warrior caste; one of the four social classes in Indic culture.
Such as a courtier. One of the classes of people barred from joining the renunciate order.
Son of the buddha Pramodyakīrti.
The 595th buddha in the first list, 594th in the second list, and 588th in the third list.
The ruling caste in the brahminical varṇāśrama dharma system, associated with warriors and kings.
One of the four castes of the Indian caste system. It traditionally consisted of rulers and administrators.
One of the four classes (Skt. varṇas) of ancient Indian society, responsible for political and military affairs.
One of the four classes of the Indian caste system. Traditionally rulers and administrators belonged to this caste.
The second highest of the four classes in the Indian caste system, it is associated with warriors, the aristocracy, and kings.
The ruling caste in the traditional four-caste hierarchy of India, it is associated with warriors, the aristocracy, and kings.
The 119th buddha in the first list, 119th in the second list, and 120th in the third list.
A great bodhisattva.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Arciṣmati (314 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.

The 236th buddha in the first list, 235th in the second list, and 235th in the third list.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Delta Cancri in the occidental tradition.
A certain brahmin, father of Śāriputra Upatiṣya. Not to be confused with Devadatta’s crony Katamoraka Tiṣya.
A buddha in the past. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-5367 .
One of the pratyeka buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
In chapter 29 the name of the sixth buddha in a list that begins with Kanaka muni. In chapter 44 it is the name of one of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya guru vaiḍūrya prabha rāja sūtra.
A bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Bahudevaghuṣṭa.

The name of an apsaras.
‟Adorned One,” one of the eight great bhūtinīs.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Light of Incense.
A great park in South India.
A buddha in the distant past.
Vyūhā (Ornamented) is a buddhafield inhabited by the Buddha Light of All Supernatural Abilities.
Name of a tathāgata.
A buddhafield at the zenith, where the Tathāgata Sovereign of Supreme Reverberating Sound resides.
‟Adorned One,” one of the eight great bhūtinīs.
“Winner at Dice,” a previous life of Prince Puṇyabala and the Buddha himself. Also called King Jaya.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
A nāga king.
A four-continent world in the distant past.
The name of an absorption.
One of the bodhisattvas attending this teaching.
A distance equivalent to five hundred arm spans.
A measure of distance corresponding to one calling-distance. Four krośa equal one yojana.
A measure of distance, one quarter of a yojana; supposedly the distance within which a cry can be heard.
A quarter of a yojana, sometimes called an “Indian league.” It is said to be about two miles. The Tibetan means “an earshot.”
An ancient unit of measuring distance. Approximately 2.25 English miles, although it is calculated differently in various systems.
A quarter of a yojana, a distance that could be between one and over two miles. The milestones or kos-stones along the Indian trunk road were just over two miles apart. The Tibetan means “earshot.”
Attendant of the buddha Sucīrṇabuddhi.
A commentary on the Mūlatantra.
Having a particular deity at the top of one’s head.
The name of an eon in which the Buddha Array of Immense Precious Qualities Like the King of Splendor resides.
A town in South India.

There are ten of these meditative states in the Śrāvakayāna: through meditating individually on the four elements of earth, water, fire, and air, on the four colors blue, yellow, red, and white, on space, and on consciousness, one meditates that everything that exists becomes that element, or that color, or space, or consciousness. Elsewhere, including the Mahāvyutpatti, this is translated as {zad par gyi skye mched}. The Sanskrit kṛtsna means “totality,” while {rgyas pa} means “spread,” or “pervade,” and {zad par} means cessation, in that everything ceases within that element, color, etc.
A place at the southernmost tip of India.
One of the four main types of enlightened activity.
One of the sages (ṛṣi), who is their leader or king.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the four primary categories of ritual activities.
One of the ancient sages, regarded as the compiler of the Vedas.
The rishi who is said to have divided the Vedas into four and to have compiled the Mahābhārata epic.
A stamp, signet, or seal.

The Bharatas of southern Punjab were one of the prominent peoples mentioned in the Ṛgveda. Here, we believe the term Bharatas denotes the Aryan people, in contrast to the Drāviḍians who are mentioned below.
One of sixteen (or seventeen) realms that surround the Crushing Hell.
