Meaning “method” in general, in Buddhism it refers to an important body of literature dealing with a great variety of techniques of advanced meditations, incorporating rituals, incantations, and visualisations, that are stamped as esoteric until a practitioner has already attained a certain stage of ethical and philosophical development.
One of the five yakṣa generals.
First of the four fruits attainable by śrāvakas, that of the first stage in progressing toward nirvāṇa.
One who has achieved the first of the four levels of attainment on the śrāvaka path, and who is from then onwards continuously approaching nirvāṇa.
The first of the four spiritual achievements, which is considered to be entering “the stream” of the noble ones that flows inexorably toward awakening.
Described as four attributes of śrāvakas: they are well disposed toward the Buddha, Dharma, and Saṅgha, and they are endowed with the types of discipline that are highly valued by the noble ones.
The state of one who has attained the . . . path of seeing (Rigzin 74), and will be carried to enlightenment as surely as a leaf floats downstream.
One who has achieved the first level of attainment on the path of the śrāvakas, and who has entered the “stream” of practice that leads to nirvāṇa.
One who has achieved the first of the four levels of attainment on the śrāvaka path, and who is from then onward continuously approaching liberation.

The first level of realization that transforms an ordinary person into a “noble one,” someone who has directly seen the nature of reality and has a sufficiently stable level of realization to be already bound toward liberation from saṃsāra.

The first stage of superior development in becoming a noble being on the path to awakening. Such an individual has not yet eliminated the afflictions but has entered a stream of forceful merit where a limit of seven lifetimes in the higher realms precede a final birth in which liberation is achieved.

There are four kinds of noble persons (Skt. āryapudgala) according to the Śrāvakayāna path, characterized by a gradual abandonment of ten kinds of fetters (Skt. saṃyojana) that bind one to saṃsāra. This is the first of the four (or eight) stages of the realization of the supermundane path (and fruit) leading to awakening or liberation.
One of the twenty-seven realms of the Heaven Free from Strife.
A forest in Draped with Jewels.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

A disciple of the Buddha.

Another name for Viśākhā Mṛgāramātā, a lay follower of the Buddha.

This is the nickname of an upāsikā (female lay practitioner), actually called Viśākhā, who is sometimes considered the most prominent among female lay followers of the Buddha. She had married the son of a man called Mṛgāra, who was originally a Jaina but went to meet the Buddha and even become a stream enterer thanks to her. Feeling indebted to her, he said that she was like his mother, which is the origin of the nickname.
The name of a rich man.
Father of the buddha Siṃhaketu.
One of King Prasenajit’s two chief ministers in Śrāvastī.
Father of the buddha Nāganandin.
Another name of Kāla Mṛgāraputra, a disciple of the Buddha.
Śarabha Aiṇeya, the king of ungulates, is a mythical creature, alternatively represented as a spotted antelope (kṛṣṇa sāra) or as an eight-footed antelope ({bse kha sgo}).
A town in South India.
A class of vidyādharas.
A group of ascetics who took vows to live as deer, draping themselves in deerskin, carrying about horns, and residing in close proximity to deer.

The 186th buddha in the first list, 185th in the second list, and 185th in the third list.
Father of the buddha Vikrāntagāmin.
The 714th buddha in the first list, 713th in the second list, and 703rd in the third list.
Father of the buddha Siṃhagati.
A mountain on the northern border of the Middle Country in a past eon.
Most likely refers to the blackbuck (Antilope cervicapra), also known as the Indian antelope. Thirty-second of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
The forest, located outside of Vārāṇasī where the Buddha first taught the Dharma.
The hill in Khotan from which the Buddha deliveres his prophecy. Gośṛṅga means “cow horn” in Sanskrit and the hill is said to have received this name due to having two pointed peaks.
A verse text possibly included in the Kṣudraka piṭaka of the Mūla sarvāstivādins and preserved in the Bhaiṣajyavastu of the Mūla sarvāstivāda Vinaya.
A mountain in Pleasant Sound.
A mountain located near Mount Sumeru.
(1) A mountain in the sea west of Jambudvīpa ({tsakra bA Do}). (2) Eight consecutive rings of mountains that surround the world ocean ({ri khor yug}).
A piśācī renowned for her ability to cure disease, avert epidemics, and pacify obstacles She is often, but not exclusively, considered a form of Tārā.
A piśācī renowned for her ability to cure disease, avert epidemics, and pacify obstacles. She is often considered a form of Tārā.
One of the chief vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode; one of the goddesses in one of the paintings of Mañjuśrī.
One of the goddesses in the retinue of Heruka.
One of the female deities in the retinue of Hevajra.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Ratnāgni.
A mountain range in Jambudvīpa.
Son of the buddha Ratnakīrti.
Attendant of the buddha Bhadrapāla.
A part of Mountainous Garland.
A mountain in Pleasant Sound.

Eighty images found on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-060-001.html#UT22084-060-001-10 and https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-060-001.html#UT22084-060-001-62 .
A mountain.

The Nine Black Mountains found on the northern edge of the continent of Jambudvīpa. There are three sets of three of these peaks, and behind them lies the great snow mountain that is the source of the Ganges River. A description of this cosmology can be found in chapter three of the Abhidharmakośabhāṣya of Vasubandhu.
A piśācinī renowned in Buddhist lore for her power to cure disease, avert epidemics, and pacify obstacles. She is often considered a form of Tārā.
An acceptable form of shelter for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
Lit. “axial mountain–like.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with Light.
A buddha.
The name of a bodhisattva in the Buddha’s audience.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
An mountain of immense size, or a synonym for Mount Meru.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
A buddha in the past.
The sixteenth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Sumeruśirī.
A buddha from the past.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Mind without Torment.
A buddha.

Likely refers to the Heaven of the Thirty-Three (Trāyastriṃśa, {sum cu rtsa gsum}), the second heaven of the desire realm situated on the summit of Mount Meru and presided over by thirty-three gods, of whom Śakra is the chief.
A mountain to the north of Jambudvīpa.
A class of vidyādharas.
The highest mountain at the center of our world according to traditional Buddhist cosmology.
A great bodhisattva.
Name of a tathāgata.
A buddha of a past eon.
A buddha in a western realm.
A bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Beautiful Golden Form.
A buddha.
The fifty-eighth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Merudhvajaśiri.
A buddha in the past.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Sublime Elephant Out of Rut.
A royal city in the distant past.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Smooth as Kācilindika Fabric.
Name of a bodhisattva.
Lit. “variegated axial mountain.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A land in Godānīya.
A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
According to the ancient Indian cosmological system, Mount Meru is a mountain which forms the centre of the universe.
The central mountain of the universe, by the reckoning of Buddhist cosmology, identified with Mount Kailas in western Tibet.
The gigantic mountain in the center of the world, portrayed as a flat disk with the four continents around it. Also known as Sumeru.
(1) The highest mountain at the center of our world according to traditional Buddhist cosmology. (2) Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with the Light of Ethical Conduct.

The great mountain at the center of the universe according to ancient Indian cosmology. At its summit lies Sudarśana city, home of Śakra (Indra) and his thirty-two gods. The mountain is also referred to as Mount Meru.

According to ancient Indian cosmology, Meru is the great mountain forming the axis of the universe. At its summit lies Sudarśana, home of Śakra and his thirty-two gods, and on its flanks live the asuras. Meru has four sides facing the cardinal directions, each of which is made of a different precious stone. Surrounding it are several mountain ranges and the great ocean where the four great island continents lie: in the south, Jambudvīpa (our world); in the west, Godānīya; in the north, Uttarakuru; in the east, Pūrvavideha. Above it are the abodes of the gods of the realm of desire.
The great mountain at the center of the universe, according to ancient Indian cosmology. At its summit lies Sudarśana city, home of Śakra (Indra) and his thirty-two gods.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Sañjayin.
A class of vidyādharas.
(1) A mountain in the forest of Joyous Women. (2) A mountain in High Conduct.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
“The Power of a Blue Mountain of Wind,” the name of a precious horse of a cakravartin in the distant past.
One of ten “kings of mountains” according to Abhidharma cosomology.
A mountain.
One of the pratyeka buddhas in the maṇḍala of Mañjuśrī.
A mountain in Pleasant Sound.
Birthplace of the buddha Kusumaparvata.

A mountain range.\n(We have been unable to identify this mountain, or mountain range. However, since yongs ’du is a translation of “pārijāta tree,” we have opted for this translation. Perhaps it refers to the mountains where the pārijāta tree grows?)
A peak on Sumeru.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A bird in the Heaven Free from Strife.
A mountain in Total Pleasure.
An area in Kuru.
A class of spirit being.
A part of Mountainous Garland.
A mountain in Controlled Movement.
Bodhisattva great being, interlocutor of the Buddha in The Perfection of Generosity.
The mountain in the center of the universe in Buddhist cosmology.
The king of mountains; the axial mountain of the flat world in the exoteric cosmology.
The sacred mountain considered to be at the center of the physical, metaphysical, and spiritual universe.

The great mountain at the center of the universe according to ancient Indian cosmology. At its summit lies Sudarśana city, home of Śakra (Indra) and his thirty-two gods. The mountain is also referred to as Mount Meru.
A buddha.
A thus-gone one of the past.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife.
A scriptural exegete from the south during the Buddha’s time, who Princess She Who Gathers of Takṣaśīla let defeat her in debate, in order to marry him. Their child was Kātyāyana.
A female vidyādhara (a class of semidivine beings).
A class of semidivine beings possessed of magical powers (vidyā); also any person or being possessed of such powers, usually derived from the mastery of a mantra (vidyā) of a female deity (vidyā).

The term literally means “possessor of vidyā” and refers to practitioners of mantra. When the term is used in the sense of “vidyādhara” (a class of semidivine beings), it has been rendered in its Sanskrit form.

Popular in Indian literature as a race of superhuman beings with magical powers who lived high in the mountains, such as in the Malaya range of southwest India. The term vidyā could be interpreted as both “knowledge” and “mantra.”

One possessed of vidyā ; this could refer to any being who is an adept of magical lore, but in particular to the class of semidivine, nonhuman beings of the same name. The term is rendered elsewhere in this translation as “knowledge holder” or “adept of vidyās.”

A class of semidivine beings who are famous for wielding (dhara) spells (vidyā). Loosely understood as “sorcerers,” these magical beings are frequently petitioned through dhāraṇī and Kriyātantra ritual to grant magical powers to the supplicant. The later Buddhist tradition, playing on the dual valences of vidyā as “spell” and “knowledge,” began to apply this term to realized figures in the Buddhist pantheon.

A class of semi-divine being that is famous for wielding (dhara) spells (vidyā). Loosely understood as “sorcerers,” these magical beings are frequently petitioned through dhāraṇī and kriyātantra ritual to grant magical powers to the supplicant. The later Buddhist tradition, playing on the dual valences of vidyā as “spell” and “knowledge,” began to apply this term to realized figures in the Buddhist pantheon.
The textual base for Brahmanism in India is the Vedas: 1) Ṛgveda, 2) Yajurveda, 3) Sāmaveda, and 4) Atharvaveda.

The name of a group of auxiliary works that supplement the Vedas, usually numerated as six different works on the six subjects of 1. śikṣa (pronunciation and phonetics); 2. chandas (meter); 3. vyākaraṇa (grammar and linguistic analysis); 4. nirukta (explanation of difficult terms); 5. jyotiṣa (astronomy); and 6. kalpa (ceremony) (Monier-Williams 1016.3).
An epithet attributed to the great seer Vyāsa.
A sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Name of the ancient sacred scriptures of Hinduism, the most famous of which is the Ṛg Veda.
One of the vidyās attending upon Mañjuśrī.
Son of the buddha Ratnārci.

The eighteen great fields of knowledge are listed in the Mahāvyutpatti as (1) music ( gandharva , {rol mo}), (2) love-making (vaiśika, {'khrig thabs}), (3) sustenance (vārtā, {'tsho tshis}), (4) arithmetic (sāṃkhyā, {grangs can}), (5) grammar (śabda, {sgra}), (6) medicine (cikitsita, {gso dpyad}), (7) behavior (nīti, {chos lugs}), (8) fine arts (śilpa, {bzo}), (9) archery (dhanurveda, {'phongs}), (10) logic (hetu, {gtan tshigs}), (11) yoga ({rnal 'byor}), (12) study (śruti, {thos pa}), (13) recollection (sṃṛti, {dran pa}), (14) astronomy (jyotitiṣa, {skar ma'i dpyad}), (15) astrology (gaṇita, {rtsis}), (16) optical aberrations (māyā, {mig 'phrul 'khor}), (17) antiquity (purāṇa, {sngon gyi rabs}), and (18) history (itihāsaka, {sngon byung ba}).\nOn all these and related matters, see Jamgon Kongtrul TOK Book 6, Pt.1: 311–315.
Attendant of the buddha Yaśoratna.
The pair of the deity or practitioner in sexual yoga. See “consort (female)” and “consort (male).”
[The pair of the deity or practitioner in sexual yoga. See “consort (female)” and “consort (male).”]
Knowledge; the power of mantra (of a female deity); female mantra deity; female consort in sexual yoga.

An epithet of the female deity of the maṇḍala (most frequently as the consort of the main deity) who represents knowledge; the tantric consort; knowledge; frequently used in the sense of magical incantations and magical power. Also rendered here as “knowledge.”

[The female element of the coupling pair in sexual yoga. Here, the term “consort” has been used to render slighty different concepts or views of the female consort, most important of them are: mudrā, vidyā, and prajñā.\nMudrā emphasizes the symbolic form of the female consort, while vidyā and prajñā emphasize the wisdom, or insight, aspect that the female principle embodies, (also rendered here as “wisdom consort.”]

The female element of the coupling pair in sexual yoga. In this translation the term “consort” has been used to render different terms with slighty different concepts of the female consort, the most important being mudrā, vidyā, and prajñā. Mudrā emphasizes the symbolic form of the female consort, while vidyā and prajñā emphasize the wisdom, or insight, aspect that the female principle embodies (see also “wisdom consort”).
A lake on Equal Peaks.
A stream on Saṅkāśa.
One of the rāśis.
“Knowledge holder”; one possessed of magical powers; a class of semi-divine beings.

The term literally means “possessor of vidyā” and refers to practitioners of mantra. When the term is used in the sense of “vidyādhara” (a class of semidivine beings), it has been rendered in its Sanskrit form.

A type of semi-divine being whose identiy has shifted over time and genre. In their most popular form they are spell (vidyā) wielding (dhara) beings capable of granting magical abilities to those they favor. The Buddhist tradition associated them more closely with soteriological aims, identifying them as realized beings who possess (dhara) knowledge or awareness (vidyā).

A class of semi-divine beings that are famous for wielding (dhara) spells (vidyā). Loosely understood as “sorcerers,” these magical beings are frequently petitioned through dhāraṇī and kriyātantra ritual to grant magical powers to the supplicant. The later Buddhist tradition, playing on the dual valences of vidyā as “spell” and “knowledge,” began to apply this term to realized figures in the Buddhist pantheon.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
Vidyā is synonymous with mantra. Although grammatically it is a female word, the Tibetan has it translated as a male noun.
A bodhisattva; a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.

A common description of buddhas. According to some explanations, “wisdom” refers to awakening, and “conduct” to the three trainings ({bslab pa gsum}) by means of which a buddha attains that awakening; according to others, “wisdom” refers to right view, and “conduct” to the other seven elements of the eightfold path.

The Nibandhana explains this as a metaphor of the eye and the feet, which, operating together, allow one to move; knowledge, interpreted as either “right view” or as “the training in wisdom,” is like the eye, while the other seven parts of the noble eightfold path, or the two other trainings in discipline and samādhi, function as the “feet.” This explanation is also found in the sgra sbyor bam po gnyis pa commentary on the Mahāvyutpatti, which further clarifies that {zhabs} is here simply the honorific term for “foot” ({carana ni rkang pa}). Thus, although it is not uncommon to translate caraṇa here with “conduct,” this loses the significance of the metaphor.
The two modes of awareness are intrinsic and extraneous. In this context‌, the former may indicate the awareness of one’s own mind and the latter the awareness of the minds of others.
Three supernormal knowledges: the knowledge of divine sight, the knowledge of former lives, and the knowledge of the extinction of impurity.
The three knowledges are a worthy one’s three clairvoyant knowledges of past lives, of where and when all die and where they will take birth, and of the extinction of outflows.

Knowledge through the divine eye ({lha'i mig gi shes pa}), knowledge through remembering past lives ({sngon gyi gnas rjes su dran pa'i rig pa}), and the knowledge that defilements have ceased ({zag pa zad pa'i rig pa}).

The three kinds of knowledge obtained by the Buddha on the night of his enlightenment. These comprise the knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings, the knowledge of past lives, and the knowledge of the cessation of defilements. These are the last three of the six superknowledges or of the ten powers of the tathāgatas.

As indicated in the https://read.84000.co/translation/toh238.html (Toh. 238, mdo sde, dza, 42a), these comprise the awareness of clairvoyance ({lha'i mig gi rig pa}), the awareness that recollects past abodes ({sngon gyi gnas rjes su dran pa'i rig pa}), and the awareness of the cessation of contaminants ({zag pa zad pa'i rig pa}). See Nordrang Orgyan (2008): 428.

The three kinds of supernormal cognition among the six supernormal powers (六神通). Applied to buddhas they are called 三達, and applied to worthy ones they are called 三明. They are the power of divine vision (天眼通), whereby they can observe the full course of passage by sentient beings through the six destinies; the power of the knowledge of previous lifetimes (宿命通), (宿住通), whereby they know the events of countless kalpas of previous lifetimes experienced by themselves, as well as by all the beings in the six destinies; and the power of the extinction of contamination (漏盡通), whereby they completely extinguish all the afflictions of the three realms and thus are no longer subject to rebirth in the three realms. In the Abhidharmakośabhāṣya (倶舍論) 27, the three are termed 住智識證明, 死生識證明, and 漏盡識證明 (Skt. tri-vidya, tisrovidyāḥ, traividya; Pāli ti-vijjā; Tib. {rig pa gsum}).
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A bodhisattva.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
Literally “knowledge holder”—this term refers either to someone who has mastered the vidyā, i.e. the power of the mantra, or to a class of semidivine beings.
A traditional list that includes the great philosophical systems of India (Sāṅkhya, Yoga, etc.) as well as ordinary sciences and arts such as arithmetic, medicine, astrology, music, and archery.

(1) Music ( gandharva , {rol mo}), (2) amorous skills (vāiśakam, {'khrig 'thab}), (3) housekeeping (vārttā, {'tsho chos}/{so tshis}), (4) mathematics (sāṃkhyā, {grang can}), (5) grammar (śabdha, {sgra}), (6) medicine (cikitsa, {gso ba}), (7) religious tradition (dharmanītī, {chos lugs}), (8) painting and handicrafts (śilpa, {bzo ba}), (9) archery (dhanurveda, {'phong spyod}), (10) logic (hetu, {gtan tshig}), (11) pharmacology (cikitsayoga, {sman spyor}), (12) self-discipline (svaśīla, {rang gi bcas pa}), (13) reflection on study (śrutismṛiti, {thos pa dran pa}), (14) astronomy (jyotiṣa, {skar ma'i dpyad}), (15) astrology (gaṇita, {rtsis}), (16) magic ( māyā , {mig 'phrul}), (17) history (purāṇam, {sngon rabs}), and (18) storytelling (itihāsakathā, {sngon byung brjod pa}) (Rigzin 395–6).

(1) Music ( gandharva , {rol mo}), (2) amorous skills (vāiśakam, {'khrig 'thab}), (3) housekeeping (vārttā, {'tsho chos}/{so tshis}), (4) mathematics (sāṃkhyā, {grang can}), (5) grammar (śabdha, {sgra}), (6) medicine (cikitsa, {gso ba}), (7) religious tradition (dharmanītī, {chos lugs}), (8) painting and handicrafts (śilpa, {bzo ba}), (9) archery (dhanurveda, {'phong spyod}), (10) logic (hetu, {gtan tshig}), (11) pharmacology (cikitsayoga, {sman spyor}), (12) self-discipline (svaśīla, {rang gi bcas pa}), (13) reflection on study (śrutismṛiti, {thos pa dran pa}), (14) astronomy (jyotiṣa, {skar ma'i dpyad}), (15) astrology (gaṇita, {rtsis}), (16) magic ( māyā , {mig 'phrul}), (17) history (purāṇam, {sngon rabs}), and (18) storytelling (itihāsakathā, {sngon byung brjod pa}) (Rigzin 395–6).

The eighteen great fields of knowledge are listed in the Mahāvyutpatti as (1) music ( gandharva , {rol mo}), (2) love-making (vaiśika, {'khrig thabs}), (3) sustenance (vārtā, {'tsho tshis}), (4) arithmetic (sāṃkhyā, {grangs can}), (5) grammar (śabda, {sgra}), (6) medicine (cikitsita, {gso dpyad}), (7) behavior (nīti, {chos lugs}), (8) fine arts (śilpa, {bzo}), (9) archery (dhanurveda, {'phongs}), (10) logic (hetu, {gtan tshigs}), (11) yoga ({rnal 'byor}), (12) study (śruti, {thos pa}), (13) recollection (sṃṛti, {dran pa}), (14) astronomy (jyotitiṣa, {skar ma'i dpyad}), (15) astrology (gaṇita, {rtsis}), (16) optical aberrations (māyā, {mig 'phrul 'khor}), (17) antiquity (purāṇa, {sngon gyi rabs}), and (18) history (itihāsaka, {sngon byung ba}).\nOn all these and related matters, see Jamgon Kongtrul TOK Book 6, Pt.1: 311–315.

Traditionally, there are eighteen branches of knowledge; they include the great philosophical systems of India (Sāṅkhya, Yoga, etc.) as well as ordinary sciences and arts, such as arithmetic, medicine, astrology, music, archery, etc.
Son of the buddha Kāśyapa.
“vidyā queen,” a female vidyārāja.
A deity invoked in the rite of vanquishing enemies and accomplishing all actions.
“Vidyā king,” a class of mantras and mantra deities; an epithet of Vajrapāṇi; an epithet of any powerful vidyā or mantra.
This seems to be the name of some of the amogha emanations of Avalokiteśvara, although the distinction between Vidyārāja (proper name) and “king of vidyās” (literal translation) is often blurred.

This epithet can refer to individual mantras (vidyā) as well as deities—typically those attending upon Vajrapāṇi; most of the time the mantra and the deity are one and the same, but, in some contexts, the focus may be on either one or the other. If the focus is on the mantra or its corresponding deity, the term has been translated as king of vidyās, and if it is on the class of deities and is used in the plural, it has been translated as vidyārāja . Vidyārāja can also be a deity name.
A term that at once refers to a type of spell or incantation and to the goddess it invokes, thereby reflecting their inseparability.
A type of incantation or spell used to accomplish a ritual goal. This can be associated with either ordinary attainments or those whose goal is awakening.

A mantra-like formula for invoking specific deities, often to bring about more mundane accomplishments in Buddhist ritual practices. A vidyā is at once considered the incantation and the deity it invokes.

The three types of knowledge are the knowledge of previous lives, the knowledge of divine sight or of the deaths and rebirths of beings, and the knowledge of the exhaustion of contamination (āsrava; {zag pa}).

Vidyāmantras are incantations that, by extension of the literal meaning of the Sanskrit word, are believed to encapsulate and invoke hidden or spiritual knowledge in their syllables, which themselves are considered magically potent. In tantric texts, vidyās and vidyāmantras take the form of or can appear as female deities.

This term may generally by synonymous with intelligence or mental aptitude, but it also conveys the meaning of science or branches of knowledge, and of pure awareness. In this last sense, it denotes the fundamental innate mind in its natural state of spontaneity and purity, beyond alternating states of motion and rest and the subject-object dichotomy.
A female vidyādhara.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Yaśoratna.
“Knowledge holder” is a class of semidivine beings renowned for their magical power (vidyā). When referring to the practitioner, the term has been translated as “vidyā holder.”

The term literally means “possessor of vidyā” and refers to practitioners of mantra. When the term is used in the sense of “vidyādhara” (a class of semidivine beings), it has been rendered in its Sanskrit form.

A race of superhuman beings with magical powers who lived high in mountains, such as the Malaya range of southwest India. The term is also used for humans who have gained powers through their mantras and aptitude for spells.\nIn this text, it is unclear to which it refers.
A female vidyārāja—a powerful female mantra deity of the vidyārāja class.
This seems to be the name of some of the amogha emanations of Avalokiteśvara, although the distinction between Vidyārāja (proper name) and “king of vidyās” (literal translation) is often blurred.

This epithet can refer to individual mantras (vidyā) as well as deities—typically those attending upon Vajrapāṇi; most of the time the mantra and the deity are one and the same, but, in some contexts, the focus may be on either one or the other. If the focus is on the mantra or its corresponding deity, the term has been translated as king of vidyās, and if it is on the class of deities and is used in the plural, it has been translated as vidyārāja . Vidyārāja can also be a deity name.
This seems to be the name of some of the amogha emanations of Avalokiteśvara, although the distinction between Vidyārāja (proper name) and “king of vidyās” (literal translation) is often blurred.

This epithet can refer to individual mantras (vidyā) as well as deities—typically those attending upon Vajrapāṇi; most of the time the mantra and the deity are one and the same, but, in some contexts, the focus may be on either one or the other. If the focus is on the mantra or its corresponding deity, the term has been translated as king of vidyās, and if it is on the class of deities and is used in the plural, it has been translated as vidyārāja . Vidyārāja can also be a deity name.
Knowledge or awareness mantra.
The formula associated with and identical to the goddess it invokes.
A sacred utterance or spell made for the purpose of attaining either worldly or transcendent benefits.
A spell. Although a technical term in its own right, it is also used interchangeably at times with the terms dhāraṇī and dhāraṇīmantra, guhyamantra, etc.

Knowledge, especially the secret knowledge of mantras, mudrās, and so forth, and also the magical power that this knowledge entails; a magical spell or the power of a magical spell; a nonhuman female being or deity possessing such power.

Vidyāmantras are incantations that, by extension of the literal meaning of the Sanskrit word, are believed to encapsulate and invoke hidden or spiritual knowledge in their syllables, which themselves are considered magically potent. In tantric texts, vidyās and vidyāmantras take the form of or can appear as female deities.
A great bodhisattva.
The four social classes of traditional Hindu society: brahmin, kṣatriya, vaiśya, and śūdra.
Seemingly the four families cited in this section; namely the lotus, tathāgata, jewel, and karma families.
A term of endearment, used by a teacher when adressing a female follower of the bodhisattva path.
Indian term of address used toward a female student of the bodhisattva path. See “son of noble family.”
A term of endearment, used by a teacher when addressing a male follower of the bodhisattva path.

Indian term of address used toward a male student of the bodhisattva path. While this is usually a characteristic pertaining to Brahmins (i.e., born in the Brahmin caste to seven-generation Brahmin parents), the Buddha redefined noble birth as determined by an individual’s ethical conduct and integrity. Thus, someone who enters the Buddha’s Saṅgha is called a “son or daughter of noble family” and is in this sense “good” or “noble” and considered born again (dvija, or “twice born”).
First level of realization on the path of the hearers.
Lit. “Lineage level.” The second of the ten levels traversed by all practitioners, from the level of an ordinary person until reaching buddhahood. See “ten levels.”
Name of the second level attainable by bodhisattvas. See https://read.84000.co/translation/toh11.html#UT22084-031-002-1281 (Toh 11), https://read.84000.co/translation/toh11.html#UT22084-031-002-1281.
One of the kings of the nāgas.

The vajra family, lotus family, tathāgata family, jewel family, and karma family.
Name of a sage in a story the Buddha tells.
One of the goddesses associated with Amoghapāśa; also a tantric goddess prominent in the Śrīvidyā tradition.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
A great bodhisattva.

The three knowledges are the superior knowledge that is the realization of the recollection of former states (pūrvanivāsanānusmṛtisākṣātkārābhijñā ), the superior knowledge that is the realization of death and rebirth (cyutyupapādasākṣātkārābhijñā), and the superior knowledge that is the realization of the cessation of outflows (āsravakṣayasākṣātkārābhijñā). See Powers 1995, p. 316, n. 17.
The five sciences are grammar, logic, philosophy, medicine, and crafts.
Mother of the buddha Tejorāja.
One of King Udayin of Vatsa’s royal ministers.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Gaṇiprabha.
The Nibandhana explains nyāya as follows: “Nyāya refers to the dharma of nirvāṇa, for it has been said that āya means a path, and that an “eternal path” (nityam āyaḥ) is called nyāya.”

The four principles of reason (yukti) are : (1) the principle of reason based on dependence (apekṣāyukti), (2) the principle of reason based on cause and effect (kārya kāraṇayukti), (3) the principle of reason based on logical proof (upa pattisādhana yukti), and (4) the principle of reason based on the nature of phenomena itself (dharmatāyukti).\nOn “principle of reason” as a translation for yukti, see Kapstein 1988, p. 152ff. See also Lin 2010 for an overview of yukti in Saṃdh.
A class of vidyādharas.
‟Lord of the Family,” one of the eight bhūta kings.
Generally a reference to a person’s spiritual disposition.
The four social classes of traditional Hindu society: brahmin, kṣatriya, vaiśya, and śūdra.

Apart from its ordinary meaning as “family,” the term often refers to a tathāgata family (alternatively called a buddha family), reflecting the division of the Buddhist pantheon into families. In the Kriyātantras there are four main tathāgata families: the tathāgata, lotus, jewel, and vajra families.

In the context‌ of the present text, this term denotes the heritage or family of bodhisattvas following the Great Vehicle.\nWhen refering a son or daughter enlightened heritage, the expressions kula putra ({rigs kyi bu}) and kula duhitā ({rigs kyi bu mo}) are terms of endearment with which a teacher may address his or her own students. See the definition in Zhang Yisun et al (1975): 2686. In the context‌ of the present sūtra, these terms therefore denote a male or female follower of the Great Vehicle, distinct from the adherents of the lesser vehicles. This may be suggested in the translation “children of enlightened heritage,” which other interpretative renderings, such as “son of a noble family” or “son of a good family,” would lack.
The name of a sitting place built for the Buddha in the northern region.
A vase commonly used in brahminical rituals; a vase used to store drinking water.
Mother of the buddha Supārśva.
An implement used by brahmins for pūjā.
A vase commonly used in brahminical rituals; a vase used to store drinking water.
The sense, which ordinarily binds us, of the “objective” solidity and physical reality of things.
A large hall in the traditional Buddhist vihāra used for monastic assemblies.
The seven netherworlds are the seven subterranean realms inhabited by nāgas and asuras.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
Symptom that may be evidence of an illness considered an impediment to ordination.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1011 .

Ca. late tenth–early eleventh century. An important Indian monastic scholar who commented on both Mahāyāna and Vajrayāna texts.

The list of seven precious things varies. Either they are gold, silver, turquoise, coral, pearl, emerald, and sapphire; or else they are ruby, sapphire, beryl, emerald, diamond, pearls, and coral.

The usual list is: (1) the precious golden wheel (Skt. cakraratna; Tib. {'khor lo rin po che}); (2) the precious jewel (Skt. maṇiratna; Tib. {nor bu rin po che}); (3) the precious queen (Skt. strīratna; Tib. {btsun mo rin po che}); (4) the precious minister (Skt. puruṣaratna or pariṇāyakaratna; Tib. {blon po rin po che}); (5) the precious elephant (Skt. hastiratna; Tib. {glang po rin po che}); (6) the precious horse (Skt. aśvaratna; Tib. {rta mchog rin po che}); and (7) the precious general (Skt. khaḍgaratna or senāpatiratna; Tib. {dmag dpon rin po che}). Here the precious queen is substituted by a precious woman (Tib. {bud med rin po che}) and the precious general is substituted by a precious householder (Tib. {khyim bdag rin po che}). However, in this text they appear listed slightly differently (see https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-076-001.html#UT22084-076-001-269 ). Here the precious queen is substituted by a precious woman (Tib. {bud med rin po che}), and the precious general is substituted by a precious householder (Tib. {khyim bdag rin po che}).

He can be identified with the Tathāgata Ratnasaṃbhava, one of the five major buddhas of the Guhya samāja tantra.

The abbreviated name of a tathāgata who presides over the buddhafield Full of Pearls. The name of a bodhisattva. The full name of this tathagata in this work is King of Jewels Devoid of Desire Whose Supreme Emanation Has Arisen from the Expanse of Phenomena, Who Is Ornamented by Boundless Sunlight from the Top of His Crown Protuberance and by an Aspiration Like Moonlight, Whose Body Is Bedecked and Elegantly Ornamented with Offerings of Excellent Perfumes, Who Has a Body Like a Lotus Flower Lovely as a Resplendent Blue Beryl Gemstone, the Light of the Good Qualities of Whom Are as Beautiful as a Glorious Pure Sky Free of Dust.

The list of seven precious materials varies. Either they are gold, silver, turquoise, coral, pearl, emerald, and sapphire; or else they are ruby, sapphire, beryl, emerald, diamond, pearls, and coral.

The seven precious things in this context‌ comprise the seven precious metals and stones, namely, gold, silver, turquoise, coral, pearl, emerald, and sapphire. More generally‌, they may also comprise the symbols of royal dominion, namely, the wheel, gem, queen, minister, elephant, general, and horse. See Dudjom Rinpoche (1991), vol. 2, p. 156.

In this sūtra they are specified to be gold, silver, beryl, white coral, emerald, red pearl, and chrysoberyl. When associated with the seven heavenly bodies, and therefore the seven days of the week, they are the seven jewels: ruby for the sun; moonstone or pearl for the moon; coral for Mars; emerald for Mercury; yellow sapphire for Jupiter; diamond for Venus; and blue sapphire for Saturn. An alternative list is: gold, silver, beryl, crystal, coral, emerald, and white coral.

The seven precious substances in this context are the seven precious metals and stones: gold, silver, turquoise, coral, pearl, emerald, and sapphire. More generally, they may also be the symbols of royal dominion: the wheel, gem, queen, minister, elephant, general, and horse.

Seven possessions of a universal monarch: the precious lady, precious jewel, precious wheel, precious elephant, precious horse, precious minister, and precious general or, as described in this text, precious master of the household. See also the detailed description in https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-068-021.html#UT22084-068-021-145 .

The seven royal substances or treasures of a universal emperor: precious wheel ({'khor lo rin po che}), precious jewel ({nor bu rin po che}), precious queen ({btsun mo rin po che}), precious minister ({blon po rin po che}), precious elephant ({glang po rin po che}), precious excellent horse ({rta mchog rin po che}), and precious army officer ({dmag dpon rin po che}).

When associated with the seven heavenly bodies, and therefore the seven days of the week, they are ruby for the sun, moonstone or pearl for the moon, coral for Mars, emerald for Mercury, yellow sapphire for Jupiter, diamond for Venus, and blue sapphire for Saturn. There are variant lists not associated with the heavenly bodies but retaining the number seven, which include gold, silver, and so on. In association with a cakravartin the seven jewels can refer, according to the Abhidharma, to his magical wheel, elephant, horse, wish-fulfilling jewel, queen, minister, and leading householder. In the Tibetan maṇḍala offering practice, the householder is replaced by a general.

The seven possessions of a cakravartin including the precious wheel, the precious elephant, the precious horse, the precious jewel, the precious woman, the precious steward, and the precious minister. In some forms of the list the steward or minister is variably replaced by the precious general (senāpatiratna; {dmag dpon rin po che}) or the precious sword (khaḍgaratna; {ral gri rin po che}). A more detailed description of these seven can be found in Toh 95, The Play in Full, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh95.html#UT22084-046-001-92–https://read.84000.co/translation/toh95.html#UT22084-046-001-103. There is also a detailed description of the seven treasures and the corresponding causal conditions for obtaining them in Toh 4087, the Kāraṇaprajñapti, folio 111.bhttps://read.84000.co/translation/toh4087.html. The term should not be confused with seven precious substances, a set of seven precious stones or minerals, which is a term found elsewhere but also rendered {rin po che sna bdun}.

The usual list is: (1) the precious golden wheel (Skt. cakraratna; Tib. {'khor lo rin po che}); (2) the precious jewel (Skt. maṇiratna; Tib. {nor bu rin po che}); (3) the precious queen (Skt. strīratna; Tib. {btsun mo rin po che}); (4) the precious minister (Skt. puruṣaratna or pariṇāyakaratna; Tib. {blon po rin po che}); (5) the precious elephant (Skt. hastiratna; Tib. {glang po rin po che}); (6) the precious horse (Skt. aśvaratna; Tib. {rta mchog rin po che}); and (7) the precious general (Skt. khaḍgaratna or senāpatiratna; Tib. {dmag dpon rin po che}). Here the precious queen is substituted by a precious woman (Tib. {bud med rin po che}) and the precious general is substituted by a precious householder (Tib. {khyim bdag rin po che}). However, in this text they appear listed slightly differently (see https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-076-001.html#UT22084-076-001-269 ). Here the precious queen is substituted by a precious woman (Tib. {bud med rin po che}), and the precious general is substituted by a precious householder (Tib. {khyim bdag rin po che}).

The theme of an ocean island rich in jewels appears frequently in Buddhist narratives.

The physical remains or personal objects of a previous tathāgata, arhat, or other realized person that are venerated for their perpetual spiritual potency. They are often enshrined in stūpas and other public monuments so the Buddhist community at large can benefit from their blessings and power.

Literally “those who have gone to the afterlife.” A synonym or interlinear gloss for preta; ghost in Exposition of Karma. Pretas are a class of sentient beings belonging to the “bad” or “unfortunate rebirth destinies” (Skt. apāya); see “animal.” In the commentary to the Petavatthu (the seventh book of the Khuddakanikāya of the Pāli Canon), the former term is explained as “having gone to the beyond or the afterlife” (Pāli paralokagata), which is effectively the same as Sanskrit preta and Pāli peta; departed, dead. The meaning of durāgata or dūraṃgama (“far-going,” “going here and there”) may refer to the belief that the ghosts of the deceased are able to move freely and quickly through space because they do not have physical bodies, and that the realm of the ghosts does not, in fact, exist in a fixed location but is everywhere. As the stories of the Petavatthu illustrate, the worlds of ghosts and humans often intertwine.

The Sanskrit word means literally, “world of the dead;” one the five (or six) rebirth destinies belonging to the unfortunate (or lower) realms of rebirth; according to Indian Buddhist sources, Yama as the Lord of Death presides over the realm of the (hungry) ghosts (Skt. preta). See also preta.

Literally “those who have gone to the afterlife.” A synonym or interlinear gloss for preta; ghost in Exposition of Karma. Pretas are a class of sentient beings belonging to the “bad” or “unfortunate rebirth destinies” (Skt. apāya); see “animal.” In the commentary to the Petavatthu (the seventh book of the Khuddakanikāya of the Pāli Canon), the former term is explained as “having gone to the beyond or the afterlife” (Pāli paralokagata), which is effectively the same as Sanskrit preta and Pāli peta; departed, dead. The meaning of durāgata or dūraṃgama (“far-going,” “going here and there”) may refer to the belief that the ghosts of the deceased are able to move freely and quickly through space because they do not have physical bodies, and that the realm of the ghosts does not, in fact, exist in a fixed location but is everywhere. As the stories of the Petavatthu illustrate, the worlds of ghosts and humans often intertwine.

Lit. “Far Reaching.” The seventh level of accomplishment pertaining to bodhisattvas. See “ten bodhisattva levels.”

One of the five Sakya patriarchs. He was the son of Sachen Kunga Nyingpo ({sa chen kun dga' snying po}, 1092–1158) and the younger brother of Sönam Tsemo ({bsod nams rtse mo}, 1142–82).

A Tibetan translator and scholar (1147–1216), the third of the five Sakya forefathers and teacher of Sakya Paṇḍita; he translated and compiled a collection of 245 sādhanas in the Tengyur under the title Ocean of Sādhanas (sgrubs thabs rgya mtsho).
A yakṣiṇī invoked in magical rites.
A member of the merchant caste.
A respectful address used by a wife to her husband.
A member of the merchant caste.
One of the four castes, that of merchants.
Third of the four classes of traditional Indian society.
The merchant caste in the fourfold division of the society.
The caste of merchants and farmers of classical Indian society.
The second lowest of the four classes in the Indian caste system, it generally includes the merchants and farmers.
A member of the merchant caste.
The third of the four classes in the Indian caste system. It generally includes merchants and farmers.

One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A realization characteristic of the sixth ground of bodhisattvas, arising as a result of analysis of the essential nature of phenomena.
A particular realization attained by a bodhisattva on the sixth bodhisattva level. This realization arises as a result of analysis of the essential nature of phenomena (dharmas).
A particular realization attained by a bodhisattva on the sixth bodhisattva level. This realization arises as a result of analysis of the essential nature of phenomena (dharmas).
Also translated as “well-organized.”
One of the eight great yakṣiṇīs.
In nyi khri and ’bum byams pa “love”
In Buddhism, inference is one of the two sources of valid knowledge (pramāṇa), the other being direct perception (pratyakṣa).

Mindfulness of the Buddha, mindfulness of the Dharma, mindfulness of the Saṅgha, mindfulness of morality, mindfulness of giving away, mindfulness of the gods, mindfulness of disgust, mindfulness of death, mindfulness of what is included in the body, and mindfulness of breathing in and out.

The ten recollections, as presented in https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-182 , are: (1) recollection of the Buddha, (2) recollection of the Dharma, (3) recollection of the Saṅgha, (4) recollection of ethical discipline, (5) recollection of renunciation, (6) recollection of the god realms, (7) recollection of quiescence, (8) recollection of respiration, (9) recollection of physicality, and (10) recollection of death.
Remembrance of the Buddha, the Dharma, the Saṅgha, relinquishing, discipline, and the gods.
These are six things to keep in mind: the Buddha, the Dharma, the Saṅgha, morality (śīla), generosity (tyāga), and deities (devatā).
Six things to keep in mind: the Buddha, the Dharma, the Saṅgha, generosity, morality, and the gods. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-057-006.html#UT22084-057-006-202

The six recollections are (1) recollection of the Buddha, (2) recollection of the Dharma, (3) recollection of the Saṅgha, (4) recollection of giving, (5) recollection of moral discipline, and (6) recollection of the gods.
The act of bringing something to mind or being mindful of something.
Second of the eleven aspects of knowledge.

This term appears in reference to Su bhūti who is considered to be an “emulator” of Lord Buddha, in the sense that he appears to imitate him. This is, of course, not to be understood in the sense of rivalry or competition.
One of the bodhisattva great beings.
The eighth of the ten nonvirtuous actions (see ten nonvirtuous courses of action).
A type of worm ({srin bu}) that lives in and feeds on the body.
A physical condition considered an impediment to ordination.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Suvayas.

The king who captured one hundred kings but released them after listening to King Sutasoma, the last of his captives, and developing faith in his teachings, especially the precepts on being true to one’s word. Various versions of this Sutasoma Jātaka are found in Buddhist literature, from the Pali canon onward.

The cannibal prince who was born from the rape of king Sudāsa by a ferocious lioness and developed a taste for the flesh of human children. In the story alluded to here, the cannibal prince sets out to imprison one thousand princes to slaughter, but the bodhisattva Prince Candra intervenes and manages to turn the cannibal prince’s mind toward virtue so that he releases all his captives. This version of the story is found in Āryaśūra’s Jātakamālā, Jātaka 31, Toh 4150, folio 118.a.https://read.84000.co/translation/toh4150.html
One of the sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Heat.
One of the garuḍa kings.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Oghajaha.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
Birthplace of the buddha Vasuśreṣṭha.
Four qualities that eliminate negative factors: zeal, vigor, attention (Tib. {sems pa}, Skt. citta), and investigation (Tib. {dpyod pa}, Skt. mīmāṃsā).
One of the kings of Nepal.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A son of King Ikṣuvāku.
Symptom that may be evidence of an illness considered an impediment to ordination.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1011 .
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Vikrāntagāmin.
The measure of an object’s value that makes taking it without permission an act of stealing.
Someone who pretends to have been ordained though they have not. One class of person barred from joining the renunciate order.
A member of an oceangoing ship’s crew whose job was to dive for pearls. Can also mean “fisherman.”
One of subtle body’s three primary channels, most often described as either white or red, depending on the system of practice.
A being who attains victory (i.e. awakening) through specific circumstances. Almost certainly a synonym for a solitary buddha.
Refers to a pratyekabuddha. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-057-004.html#UT22084-057-004-583 .
I.e., the pratyeka tradition.
Another name for the solitary buddha vehicle.
A type of gem, presumably red as in the blossoms of the kiṃśuka tree.
The concomitant circumstances and influences in a causal process.
(1) A lake on Equal Peaks ({rlabs rab tu 'jug pa}). (2) A river to the south of Jambudvīpa ({rlabs ldan}). (3) A river on Saṅkāśa ({rlabs 'byung ba}).
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Praśāntamala (777 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
(1) An ocean far off the coast of Jambudvīpa ({rlabs chen po}). (2) A river in the south of Jambudvīpa ({rlabs chen}).
(1) A lake on Equal Peaks ({rlabs rab tu 'jug pa}). (2) A river to the south of Jambudvīpa ({rlabs ldan}). (3) A river on Saṅkāśa ({rlabs 'byung ba}).
A bodhisattva.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
(1) A lake on Equal Peaks ({rlabs rab tu 'jug pa}). (2) A river to the south of Jambudvīpa ({rlabs ldan}). (3) A river on Saṅkāśa ({rlabs 'byung ba}).
One of the Buddha’s foremost hearer disciples.
One of the first five disciples of the Buddha.

One of the Five Excellent Companions, with whom Siddhārtha Gautama practiced asceticism near the Nairañjanā River and who later heard the Buddha first teach the Four Noble Truths at the Deer Park in Sarnath.

The father of the wife of a Vārāṇasī merchant in The Hundred Deeds.\nNot to be confused with the Vāṣpa who was among the group of five monks (bhadravargīya) that received the Buddha’s teaching on the four noble truths.

One of the five companions of Śākyamuni in asceticism and later one of his first five pupils, attaining the state of a stream entrant. After the Buddha’s death he is said to have headed the great council of ten thousand that established a canon of the Buddha’s teachings (while Kāśyapa was the head of a smaller council elsewhere who did the same).
Make assumptions about, based on, or on account of something.
One of the four parasites that are said to be inside the birth canals of women.
A forest of the asuras.

The Tibetan {rlung brgyad} (“eight winds”) translates literally the Chinese 八風 (bafeng), which is a Chinese Buddhist term for the eight “winds” or influences that stimulate affliction. These are commonly known as the eight worldly concerns or dharmas ({'jig rten gyi chos brgyad}, aṣṭa loka dharma) consisting of: hoping for happiness, fame, praise and gain; and fearing suffering, insignificance, blame and loss.
The ancient cosmology maintained that the cosmos was encircled by an atmosphere of fierce winds of impenetrable intensity (see Lamotte, p. 255, n. 15).
The seventy-seventh buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Anilavegaśirī.
Lit. “limitless wind element.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
The god of wind.
The deity of the air and the wind.
One of the eight guardians of the directions, Vāyu guards the northwest quarter.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
(1) Alternative name for Enjoying the Wind ({rlung gi rgyu}). (2) One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife ({rlung gi rgyu ba}).
The 414th buddha in the first list, 413th in the second list, and 407th in the third list.
Father of the buddha Dhyānarata.
A realm of the vessel-bearer gods. Also known as Movement of Wind.
First of the four kinds of disease.
A class of spirits causing excess wind (the humor).
Name of a bodhisattva.
The Vedic gods of wind.
God or spirit of wind (usually plural).
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Bhavāntadarśin.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi; one of the great yakṣiṇīs.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
A disease caused by an imbalance of wind as one of the humors of the body.
One of the great mātṛs.
Son of the buddha Sucittayaśas
A nāga king.
The wind; the god of wind.
Fifty-ninth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
One of the four elements that constitute all matter, or one of the three primary humors (doṣa) of the body.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya guru vaiḍūrya prabha rāja sūtra.
One of the three vital substances in the body, along with phlegm and bile, which result in good health when balanced and illness or less than optimal health when imbalanced.
Lit. “wind,” one of the four elements that constitute all matter, including the physical body, and one of the three primary humors (doṣas) in the Āyuvedic medical traditions.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode; one of the five Pañcarakṣā goddesses.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode; also a short form of Mahāmāyūrī.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
The 831st buddha in the first list, 830th in the second list, and 820th in the third list.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Suvayas (299 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
An area in Kuru.
A mountain on Videha.
Fifteenth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
The 692nd buddha in the first list, 691st in the second list, and 682nd in the third list.
The 822nd buddha in the first list, 821st in the second list, and 811th in the third list.
Son of the buddha Yaśaḥkīrti.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
The 895th buddha in the first list, 894th in the second list, and 885th in the third list.
One of the nine aspects of the Dharma according to this sūtra. More commonly there are said to be twelve that include these nine.
Birthplace of the buddha Prajñādatta.
One of the “twelve branches of excellent speech.”
One of the twelve branches of Buddhist scriptures.
As one of the twelve aspects of the wheel of Dharma, it means descriptions of miracles.
One among the twelve sections of scripture.
Tenth of the twelve branches of the scriptures.
Birthplace of the buddha Arhadyaśas.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
A rākṣasī on Sumeru Rival.
Father of the buddha Vimuktacūḍa.
One of the great piśācīs.
Son of householders in the country of Śūrpāraka. During the time of the Buddha, he was also known as Covered.
An alternate name for the yakṣa Kubera.
A name of a spirit or class of spirits; variously identified as a type of demon that lives in magical weapons or that causes illness.
The third of the five hinderances to attainment of the first dhyāna.
Third of the five obscurations.
A land in the east of Jambudvīpa.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the eighteen constituents.
Sixth of the eighteen sensory elements.
King of Kanyakubja before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
One of the vidyārājñīs attending the delivery of the MMK.
Name of a yakṣa general.
One of the eight great bhūtinīs.
Seventy-seventh of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
Seventy-fifth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
Name of a yakṣa general.
Fourth of the eighteen sensory elements.
Second of the twelve sense fields.
“One who has yoga,” meaning “one who has mastery of the practice of meditation.”
A term used to describe the later tantras of the Yoga class that incoporated more transgressive pactices and a wrathful aesthetic. Typified by the Guhya samāja tantra and Guhya garbha tantra.
Practitioner of deity yoga; also a class of semidivine beings.
One of the sages (ṛṣi).

A class of Buddhist tantra focused upon the figure of the yoginī and the meditative manipulation of the subtle energetic anatomy of the physical body. This genre is typified by the Hevajra tantra, Cakra saṃvara tantra, and Mahāmāyātantra.

The last development of Buddhist tantra in India; focused upon the figure of the yoginī and the meditative manipulation of the subtle energetic anatomy of the physical body. Typified by the He vajra tantra, Cakrasaṃvaratantra and the Mahā māyā tantra.
In the sūtra and Kriyātantra literature, a yoginī is a female spirit of the lower order.

With a long history in South Asian folklore and religious traditions, yoginīs are liminal, trangressive and often ferocious semi-divine female figures associated with the bestowal of temporal and transcendent spiritual accomplishment. In Buddhist tantra they are identical to ḍākinīs.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Rāhudeva.
The Tibetan means “one united with the genuine state,” in other words, “one who has attained the supreme accomplishment.”
“The one who is united,” a succesful practitioner who has attained realization. The Tibetan means “one who is united with the genuine nature.”
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Candrapradīpa (565 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Influential philosophical school belonging to Mahāyāna Buddhism.
A “practitioner of yoga” meaning one dedicated to meditation practice. It can be synonymous with yogin. This is not reference to the Yogācāra school of thought that developed within the Mahāyāna.

Literally, a “practitioner of yoga,” meaning one dedicated to meditation practice. It can be synonymous with yogin. This is not a reference to the Yogācāra school of thought that developed within the Mahāyāna.
Literally “union” in Sanskrit; Tibetan specifies “union with the natural state.”

A term which is generally used to refer to a wide range of spiritual practices. It literally means to be merged with or “yoked to,” in the sense of being fully immersed in one’s respective discipline. The Tibetan specifies “union with the natural state.”
The term refers variously to a literary genre, a period in the development of tantra, or, when written with lower case, an individual work belonging to this genre.
One of the rāśis.
‟Prosperity,” one of the eight great bhūtinīs.
One of the garuḍa kings.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Name of a nāga king; name of a yakṣa; name of Rāvaṇa's brother in the Rāmāyaṇa.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Viniścitamati.
Son of the buddha Vigatabhaya.
Son of the buddha Sucintitārtha.
The 698th buddha in the first list, 697th in the second list, and not listed in the third list.
A kalpa in the distant past.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Jñānin (685 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Nirjvara (240 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
“Completely Pure Faith.” The daughter of King Prasenajit.
A bodhisattva.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Adbhutayaśas (432 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A bhikṣu who was a pupil of Śāriputra.
Father of the buddha Suvrata.
Attendant of the buddha Kṛtavarman.
A buddha field in the future where the bodhisattva Immaculately Moved by Beings attains buddhahood as Candraprabha.
A bodhisattva.
Birthplace of the buddha Vibhakta jñā svara.
Son of the buddha Jyeṣṭhavādin.
The 539th buddha in the first list, 539th in the second list, and 532nd in the third list.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Vegajaha (985 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
One of the pratyeka buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Mahā prajñā tīrtha (736 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A world system.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ratna.
Used adverbially, this term indicates that a given teaching has been skillfully adapted by the Buddha for the audience and therefore is not to be taken literally or definitively.

In the sūtra, paryāya is used to denote (1) an expedient or a trick in the context of illusions produced by a magician; (2) a method, an approach through which one can practice in accordance with a teaching; or (3) a scripture, a teaching regarding a specific aspect.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Ratnapāṇi (673 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.

This term seems to refer to any ritual device in itself sufficient to produce liberation; it may thus refer to the entire text of the AP, to an individual rite, to a mantra or a mudrā, or to a set of a corresponding mudrā and mantra.
The 608th buddha in the first list, 607th in the second list, and 601st in the third list.

This term seems to refer to any ritual device in itself sufficient to produce liberation; it may thus refer to the entire text of the AP, to an individual rite, to a mantra or a mudrā, or to a set of a corresponding mudrā and mantra.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Laḍitāgragāmin.
The 665th buddha in the first list, 664th in the second list, and 656th in the third list.
Indian commentator (fl. early sixth century).
The 624th buddha in the first list, 623rd in the second list, and 616th in the third list.
Son of the buddha Ojodhārin.
Father of the buddha Śāntagati.
Attendant of the buddha Priyaprasanna.
The state of freedom from suffering and saṃsāra that is the goal of the Buddhist path.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha in the past.
Fourth of the eight progressive sections of clear realization.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
(1) A city at the fourth asura level, Immovable. (2) A lake on Equal Peaks. (3) A pond on Lofty Mound ({rnam par mdzes pa}). (3) Refers to Dwelling in Beauty ({rnam mdzes}).
First of the eight progressive sections of clear realization.
The 346th buddha in the first list, 345th in the second list, and 340th in the third list.
Son of the buddha Ugratejas.
An absorption.
Name of the eighty-fifth meditative stability.
Lit. “not forsaking any aspect.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A forest in Continuous Movement.
Name of the eighty-fourth meditative stability.
Lit. “single aspect.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Name of the sixty-fifth meditative stability.
Lit. “without features.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Name of the eighty-third meditative stability.
Lit. “accomplishing aspects.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
One of the twenty-seven realms of the Heaven Free from Strife.
A river in Majestic Trees.
Lit. “total illuminator.” Name of a meditative stabilization.

A term which, in the commentaries of the third turning of the doctrinal wheel, is interpreted to mean that consummate buddha attributes are extraneously empty of all imaginary and dependent attributes.\n(See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-982 ).
Name of the ninety-second meditative stability.
Lit. “furnished with the supreme of all aspects.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A description of the mode of omniscience in which all possible phenomena as well as their ultimate nature are known.
Name of the ninety-fourth meditative stability.
A forest on Saṅkāśa.
Second of the nine contemplations of impurity.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Prabhākara.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Bhavapuṣpa (972 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Vajrasaṃhata (738 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Birthplace of the buddha Velāmaprabha.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Siṃhagātra.
A buddha.
The name of a karmic wind involved in the formation of an embryo in its ninth week.
The 198th buddha in the first list, 197th in the second list, and 197th in the third list.
The name of this unidentified legendary mountain may be inspired by Vipula Mountain by Rājgir.
“Remover of Obstacles”; the Buddhist version of Gaṇeśa.
One of the seven golden mountains.
(See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1963 ).
One of the kings of the rākṣasas; also, the name of a yakṣa.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Name of the forty-fifth meditative stability.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the kings of the rākṣasas.
A bodhisattva.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Jñānaprāpta.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Guṇavisṛta.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ajitagaṇa.
The name of a bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Aśoka.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Laḍitavikrama.
A rākṣasī known only from this sūtra.
Seventh of the nine contemplations of impurity.
Name of the sixtieth meditative stability.
Lit. “strewing.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A wind deity referred to as king of the wind.
First of the nine contemplations of impurity.
An Indian seer.
A buddha.
An absorption.
A forest in Total Pleasure.
A river in Moving in Vast Environments.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Vimalarāja.
One of the worlds in the distant past.
A great bodhisattva.
Birthplace of the buddha Janendrakalpa.
Birthplace of the buddha Laḍita.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Vyūhā (Ornamented) is a buddhafield inhabited by the Buddha Sarvābhijñāmati rāja.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Puṇyapriya.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A bodhisattva present in the circle around Śākyamuni.
A buddha realm.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A king and great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
One of the bodhisattvas attending this teaching.
The opposite of ‘totally afflicted.’
The purification of affliction (saṃkleśa).
Another term for nirvāṇa, this is the counterpart of “defilement.”
The process of liberation from saṃsāra through the application of the path.

A term meaning purity or purification and broadly referring to the process of purifying the mind of what obscures it in order to attain spiritual awakening. It is often paired with its opposite saṃkleśa, meaning “pollution.”
This term has the connotation of something being agreed upon, represented, arranged, settled, decreed, or established. Also translated here as “established” and “posited.”

Probably a variant of the Buddha’s five observations (pañcadarśana), the five predeterminations of Buddha Śākyamuni before he came to this world: (1) {dus la gzigs pa}, observation of the time for his appearance; (2) {rus la gzigs pa}, observation of the family of his birth; (3) {rigs la gzigs pa}, observation of the caste of his lineage; (4) {yum la gzigs pa}, observation of the mother to whom he would be born; and (5) {yul la gzigs pa}, observation of the land in which to disseminate his doctrine (Rigzin 366).
The future buddha Samantadarśin’s buddha field.
A bodhisattva.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one He Who Attained the Perfectly Pure State of Universal Illumination.
A buddha.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A buddha.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Subuddhi.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Amṛtaprasanna.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
The name of a past eon.
Father of the buddha Kṛtāntadarśin.
One of the gods from the realm of the Pure Abode.
The pure aspect (usually a particular Buddhist category) of a ritual implement or any ordinary entity.
The pure category, usually beyond the mundane, represented by any ritual implement, iconographic feature, or any other tangible element of worship.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Dhyānarata.
A buddha realm.
Birthplace of the buddha Pūritāṅga.

The four presentations are (1) a presentation of doctrine representations (the divisions of the Buddha’s teachings), (2) a presentation of truth representations (one, two, four, up to an infinite number of truths), (3) a presentation of reasoning ({rig}/{rigs pa}, yukti) representations (from contingency, function, logical proof, and the nature of things), and (4) a presentation of vehicles (three).\nPāli vavatthāna; Ñāṇamoli 1976 “definition”; Thurman 2004 “classification.”
Third of the nine contemplations of impurity.
A buddha.
Birthplace of the buddha Śāntārtha.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Anupamavādin.
A head merchant’s son in Dhanyākara.
This term is used with specific reference to the subjugation of physical, emotional, and psychological factors that disturb the mind.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha.
The twenty-ninth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Vikrāntagamin.
A tathāgata mentioned here as one of the thirty-five buddhas of confession.
Father of the buddha Pradīpa.
Vikrama or Vikramāditya is another name of the Gupta emperor Candragupta II.
A great bodhisattva.
Father of the buddha Bhavāntadarśin.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Vighuṣṭaśabda.
One of the uṣṇīṣa kings attending the delivery of the MMK.
Son of the buddha Jyotiṣmat.
Attendant of the buddha Ratnagarbha.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Prabhaṃkara.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Sthita vega jñāna.
One of the vidyārājas dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Uccaratna.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Father of the buddha Garjitasvara.
Birthplace of the buddha Vigata mohārtha cintin.
Twelfth of the eighteen distinct qualities of the buddhas.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Siṃhadaṃṣṭra.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.

This term seems to refer to any ritual device in itself sufficient to produce liberation; it may thus refer to the entire text of the AP, to an individual rite, to a mantra or a mudrā, or to a set of a corresponding mudrā and mantra.
Fourth of the five definitive aggregates.
One of the five uncontaminated aggregates.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Arciṣmat.
Fifth of the five definitive aggregates.
One of the five uncontaminated aggregates.
The translators perhaps understood “insight into knowledge of liberation.”
A great bodhisattva.
The interlocutor for Vajra garbha in The Ten Bhumis. He appears in passing in a few other sūtras, but not in any tantras. On two occasions in verse he is referred to as Mokṣa candra.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Pratibhāna cakṣus.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Somaraśmi.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Cāritratīrtha.
This denotes emancipation or withdrawal from worldly life. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-8 .

In its most general sense, this term refers to the state of freedom from suffering and cyclic existence, or saṃsāra, that is the goal of the Buddhist path. More specifically, the term may refer to a category of advanced meditative attainment known as the “eight deliverances”; for an explanation of these, see https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-029-001.html#UT22084-029-001-1102 and https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-029-001.html#UT22084-029-001-4868 .

In early Buddhism the first of seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. The first three buddhas—Vipaśyin, Śikhin, and Viśvabhuk—appeared in a kalpa earlier than our Bhadra kalpa, and therefore Śākyamuni is more commonly referred to as the fourth buddha.

The five false imaginations are enumerated in The Extensive Exegesis of the Transcendent Perfection of Discriminative Awareness in One Hundred Thousand Lines, Twenty-five Thousand Lines, and Eighteen Thousand Lines (Śata sahāsrikā pañca viṃśati sāhasrikā-ṣṭādaśa sāhasrikā prajnā pāramitā bṛhaṭ ṭīkā, KPD 55: 1217). Therein, the five false imaginations which may confront reversible bodhisattvas are (1) wondering whether they are engaged in the emptiness of the transcendent perfection of wisdom and the transcendent perfection of wisdom ({ci shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i stong pa nyid/ shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la spyod dam}), (2) wondering whether they are exclusively engaged in something other than the transcendent perfection of wisdom ({ci shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa las 'ba' zhig spyod dam}), (3) wondering whether they are engaged in the transcendent perfection of wisdom ({'on te shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la spyod dam}), (4) wondering whether they are engaged in emptiness ({'on te stong pa nyid spyod dam}), or (5) wondering whether they are engaged in something other than emptiness ({'on te stong pa nyid las gzhan pa zhig spyod dam}).
A “conceptual sign” should here be understood to refer to those signs that arise through conceptual engagement with the phenomenon under examination or discussion. See also “sign.”
Any type of dualistic concept or idea.
According to Buddhist epistemology, to conceptualize is to cognize in such a way that language is involved as a medium.

A mental function that tends to superimpose upon reality, either relative or ultimate, a conceptualized dualistic perspective fabricated by the subjective mind. It is often opposed to direct perception ({pratyakṣa}, {mngon sum}).

This brings up another important group of words that has never been treated systematically in translation: vikalpa, parikalpa, samāropa, adhyāropa, kalpanā, samjñā, and prapāñca. All of these refer to mental functions that tend to superimpose upon reality, either relative or ultimate, a conceptualized reality fabricated by the subjective mind. Some translators have tended to lump these together under the rubric “discursive thought,” which leads to the misleading notion that all thought is bad, something to be eliminated, and that sheer “thoughtlessness” is “enlightenment,” or whatever higher state is desired. According to Buddhist scholars, thought in itself is simply a function, and only thought that is attached to its own content over and above the relative object, i.e., “egoistic” thought, is bad and to be eliminated. Therefore we have chosen a set of words for the seven Skt. terms: respectively, “conceptualization,” “imagination,” “presumption,” “exaggeration,” “construction,” “conception” or “notion,” and “fabrication.” This does not mean that these words are not somewhat interchangeable or that another English word might not be better in certain contexts; it only represents an attempt to achieve consistency with the original usages.
Son of the buddha Mārakṣayaṃkara.
Name of a bodhisattva, the main interlocutor of Maitreya’s Setting Out.
A nāga king.
The name of a bodhisattva. “Playful One.”
