A reference to the last three of the ten bhūmis, (Tib. {sa bcu}); the bhūmis, often called the “grounds” or “levels,” are the successive stages through which a bodhisattva’s realization evolves.
One of the māras.
A buddha.
The 911th buddha in the first list, 910th in the second list, and 901st in the third list.
A bodhisattva.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Name of a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Father of the buddha Samantadarśin.
A female lay practitioner.
Father of the buddha Jayanandin.
The chief consort of King Śaṅkha.
The name of the twenty thousand channels on the front of the body.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Alpha Librae in the occidental tradition.
During the Buddha’s time, a certain lay vow holder in Śrāvastī. Elsewhere there is also the Viśākha who was the son of King Prasenajit’s minister.

Son of King Prasenajit’s minister Mṛgāra, betrothed to the non-returner Dharmadinnā. His fiancée fled their imminent marriage by a display of miracles at what was to be their wedding, receiving his assent for her to go forth instead. The text also tells of a certain female lay vow holder with a similar name Vaiśākhā on https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-073-001.html#UT22084-073-001-213 .
Attendant of the buddha Praśāntagāmin.
That is to say, the animal realm, the realm of anguished spirits and the denizens of the hells.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Śrīprabha (375 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A city in Godānīya.
A class of vidyādharas.
A mountain range in the Deccan.
A country in the Deccan.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Amṛtaprasanna.
A term used for a courtesan. In the Bhūta ḍāmara Tantra this term refers to a class of nonhuman female beings.
A species of tree.
A village. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-3131 .
A dynasty in south India whose rule ended in the third century ce.
A buddha.
Father of the buddha Dṛḍha.
A village.
The name given to Khotan by prince Suckler of the Earth Breast.
Another name for the prince Kunāla, Kustana, or Gostana, biological son of Aśoka and adopted prince of China.
A royal capital in another world realm in the distant past. In prose, its long form is Ratna sāla vyūha megha pradīpā.
A village.
Vatica robusta.
Son of the buddha Ananta rati kīrti.
Alluvial gold; gold dust. Pali suvannacunna.
This could be the name or an epithet of one of the goddesses; its meaning is unclear.

Literally “coming together,” samaya refers to precepts given by the teacher, the corresponding commitment by the pupil, and the bond that results, which can also be the bond between the practitioner and the deity or a spirit. It can also mean a special juncture or circumstance, or an ordinary time or season.
Father of the buddha Siṃhasvara.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Praśāntadoṣa (144) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
The son of the god Brahmā.
A type of soil (?)
Crotalaria juncea.
An acceptable form of shelter for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
Son of King Udayana of Vatsa, he went forth by Venerable Kātyāyanaputra.
Another name of the Indus River.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Ratnagarbha (440 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
The name of a nakṣatra.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Vimala.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Arcturus in the occidental tradition.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Śrīdeva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A merchant in Maitreya’s birthplace.
The solidified resin of Garcinia morella.
The ḍākinī associated with the channels of the subtle body.
A type of ḍākinī (literally, “earth traveller”).
A mountain.
Indra’s elephant.
A nāga king.
Śakra’s elephant.
The name of Indra’s elephant.
The elephant of Indra.
One of the kings of Nepal.
Another name of the Pāla dynasty.
More often called Gopāla, the ruler of Bengal around the middle of the eighth century.
A bodhisattva.
A river. Possibly a phonetic approximation of Saritā, as in the river Saritā.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Udāragarbha.
Mother of the buddha Gandhahastin.
A nāga.
The 196th buddha in the first list, 195th in the second list, and 195th in the third list.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ghoṣadatta.
The fifty-fifth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Dharaṇi teja śirī.
The name of the earth deity.
Birthplace of the buddha Jñānaśūra.

An enigmatic term that refers to a crust or deposit left on the earth after it is saturated by a fluid. When used together with a term for cremation ash, it seems to refer to the earth beneath the fire that has been saturated by the ghee used in the fire as well as by the melted bodily constituents.
One of the seven subterranean semiparadises, the abode of nāgas and asuras.
One of the seven subterranean semiparadises, the abode of dānavas.

The underworlds, of which there are said to be seven, include the realms of the daityas and yakṣas. The lowest is the realm of the nāgas. They are said to be pleasant and free from distress and even more beautiful than the higher realms.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-037-007.html#UT22084-037-007-4920 .
A great bodhisattva.
Mother of the buddha Padmapārśva.
Father of the buddha Sthāmaprāpta.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
The buddha realm of Earth Deity.
A buddha in the distant past.
A bodhisattva.
Lit. “limitless earth element.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
The goddess of the earth.
The goddess of wealth; a goddess in one of the paintings of Śākyamuni.
The goddess of the earth.
A buddha who lives in the direction below in a buddha realm called Earth Melody.
A great bodhisattva.
A location in Khaṣa.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A bodhisattva.
One among a list of eight uṣṇīṣa buddhas mentioned in this text that do not appear elsewhere in the canon.
A buddha realm.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
One of the celestial bodhisattvas.
An important bodhisattva disciple of the Buddha.
One of the sixteen great bodhisattvas. The content of the list varies from text to text.
A mountain in Kuru.
A mountain that is home to The Terrifying Forest ({'jigs byed ma'i tshal}) and a deer park where Devadatta’s disciple Kokālika is said to have lived.
An acceptable form of shelter for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
A buddha in the past.

Also commonly known by the names Senalek Jingyön ({sad na legs mjing yon}) and Mutik Tenpo ({mu tig bstan po}), he was a Tibetan king who reigned ca 800/804–15. He was the youngest son of King Trisong Detsen ({khri srong lde btsan}, r. 742–98).
Refers to the throbbing sensation in the vagina before and during orgasm; also to the throbbing of an erect penis.
Attendant of the buddha Merudhvaja.
A mountain in Kuru.
A bodhisattva in a distant realm.
A buddhafield in the southern direction of the Tathāgata Countless Qualities Precious Courage.
A bodhisattva.
A wealthy householder from Śrāvastī who fathered Saṅgharakṣita.
An epithet of the buddhas.
Epithet of Buddha Śākyamuni and general way of addressing the enlightened ones. See “Lord” or “Blessed One.” (See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-121 ).
A bodhisattva.
Mother of the buddha Siṃhacandra.
(c. fourth century). A great Mādhyamika master, who was later regarded as the founder of the Prāsaṅgika sub-school.
A great bodhisattva.
Birthplace of the buddha Subuddhi.
A great bodhisattva.

The term can mean “teachings of the Buddha” or “buddha qualities.” In the latter sense, it is sometimes used as a general term, and sometimes it refers to sets such as the ten strengths, the four fearlessnesses, the four discernments, the eighteen distinct qualities of a buddha, and so forth; or, more specifically, to another set of eighteen: the ten strengths; the four fearlessnesses; mindfulness of body, speech, and mind; and great compassion.
Mother of the buddha Mokṣadhvaja.
A world system.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Janendrakalpa (524 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
A bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva, “Intellect-Splendor.” However, the Tibetan suggests “Buddha-” rather than “Buddhi-,” which would then mean “Buddha-Splendor.”
A buddha.
A world realm in the eastern direction.
A term used to denote the teachings of the Buddha, which in the case of this sūtra can be anything that the Buddha taught or any statement that precisely accords with what the Buddha taught.
Eighteen special features of a buddha’s physical state, realization, activity, and insight that are not shared by ordinary beings.
This refers to eighteen properties/qualities that are unique to buddhas, “property” being one of the possible meanings of the term dharma.
The eighteen characteristics of a fully realized being not shared by ordinary beings, namely that he never stumbles, never raises his voice, never loses mindfulness, and so forth.

Eighteen distinctive features unique to buddhas. These are grouped as follows: the ten powers of the tathāgatas, the four states of fearlessness, the three states of mindfulness, and great compassion. See also the ten powers of the tathāgatas and the four states of fearlessness.

They are as follows: (1) he never makes a mistake; (2) he is never boisterous; (3) he never forgets; (4) his concentration never falters; (5) he has no notion of distinctness; (6) his equanimity is not due to lack of consideration; (7) his motivation never falters; (8) his endeavor never fails; (9) his mindfulness never falters; (10) he never abandons his concentration; (11) his wisdom (prajñā) never decreases; (12) his liberation never fails; (13) all his physical actions are preceded and followed by wisdom (jñāna); (14) all his verbal actions are preceded and followed by wisdom ({jñAna}); (15) all his mental actions are preceded and followed by wisdom (jñāna); (16) his wisdom (jñāna) and vision perceive the past without any attachment or hindrance; (17) his wisdom (jñāna) and vision perceive the future without any attachment or hindrance; and (18) his wisdom (jñāna) and vision perceive the present without any attachment or hindrance.

Eighteen qualities that are exclusively possessed by a buddha. These are listed in the Dharma saṃgraha as follows: The tathāgata does not possess (1) confusion; (2) noisiness; (3) forgetfulness; (4) loss of meditative equipoise; (5) cognition of distinctness; or (6) nonanalytical equanimity. A buddha totally lacks (7) degeneration of motivatedness; (8) degeneration of perseverance; (9) degeneration of mindfulness; (10) degeneration of samādhi; (11) degeneration of prajñā; (12) degeneration of complete liberation; and (13) degeneration of seeing the wisdom of complete liberation. (14) A tathāgata’s every action of body is preceded by wisdom and followed through with wisdom; (15) every action of speech is preceded by wisdom and followed through with wisdom; (16) a buddha’s every action of mind is preceded by wisdom and followed through with wisdom. (17) A tathāgata engages in seeing the past through wisdom that is unattached and unobstructed and (18) engages in seeing the present through wisdom that is unattached and unobstructed.
Eighteen special features of a buddha’s behavior, realization, activity, and wisdom that are not shared by other beings.

They are as follows: (1) he never makes a mistake; (2) he is never boisterous; (3) he never forgets; (4) his concentration never falters; (5) he has no notion of distinctness; (6) his equanimity is not due to lack of consideration; (7) his motivation never falters; (8) his endeavor never fails; (9) his mindfulness never falters; (10) he never abandons his concentration; (11) his insight (prajñā) never decreases; (12) his liberation never fails; (13) all his physical actions are preceded and followed by wisdom (jñāna); (14) all his verbal actions are preceded and followed by wisdom; (15) all his mental actions are preceded and followed by wisdom; (16) his wisdom (jñāna) and vision perceive the past without any attachment or hindrance; (17) his wisdom and vision perceive the future without any attachment or hindrance; and (18) his wisdom and vision perceive the present without any attachment or hindrance.

Eighteen qualities that are exclusively possessed by a buddha. These are listed in the as follows: The tathāgata does not possess (1) confusion, (2) noisiness, (3) forgetfulness, (4) loss of meditative equipoise, (5) cognition of distinctness, or (6) nonanalytical equanimity. A buddha totally lacks (7) degeneration of zeal, (8) degeneration of vigor, (9) degeneration of mindfulness, (10) degeneration of absorption, (11) degeneration of insight, (12) degeneration of complete liberation, and (13) degeneration of seeing the wisdom of complete liberation. (14) A tathāgata’s every action of body is preceded by wisdom and followed through with wisdom; (15) every action of speech is preceded by wisdom and followed through with wisdom; (16) a buddha’s every action of mind is preceded by wisdom and followed through with wisdom; and (17) a tathāgata engages in seeing the past through wisdom that is unattached and unobstructed and (18) engages in seeing the present through wisdom that is unattached and unobstructed.

Eighteen special features of a buddha’s behavior, realization, activity, and wisdom that are not shared by other beings. They are as follows: (1) he never makes a mistake, (2) he is never boisterous, (3) he never forgets, (4) his concentration never falters, (5) he has no notion of distinctness, (6) his equanimity is not due to lack of consideration, (7) his motivation never falters, (8) his endeavor never fails, (9) his mindfulness never falters, (10) he never abandons his concentration, (11) his insight never decreases, (12) his liberation never fails, (13) all his physical actions are preceded and followed by wisdom (jñāna), (14) all his verbal actions are preceded and followed by wisdom, (15) all his mental actions are preceded and followed by wisdom, (16) his wisdom and vision perceive the past without any attachment or hindrance, (17) his wisdom and vision perceive the future without any attachment or hindrance, and (18) his wisdom and vision perceive the present without any attachment or hindrance.
Can refer to the teaching of the Buddha as well as the dharmas that constitute an awakened being.

This term can refer to the general qualities of a buddha or to specific sets such as the ten strengths, the four fearlessnesses, the four discernments, and the eighteen unique buddha qualities; or even more specifically to another set of eighteen: the ten strengths; the four fearlessnesses; mindfulness of body, speech, and mind; and great compassion.

The specific qualities of a buddha; may sometimes be used as a general term, and sometimes referring to sets such as the ten strengths, the four fearlessnesses, the four discernments, the eighteen distinct qualities of a buddha, and so forth; or, more specifically, to another set of eighteen: the ten strengths; the four fearlessnesses; mindfulness of body, speech, and mind; and great compassion.\nAlternatively, in the context of this sūtra, see https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-055-001.html#UT22084-055-001-425 - https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-055-001.html#UT22084-055-001-429 .
A great bodhisattva.
Fifth of the five eyes. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1129 .
A buddha who does not possess the thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks.
The name of an absorption.
The name of a dhāraṇī.
One of the twelve retentions of the bodhisattvas.
A buddha realm in the upward direction.

Lit. “family” or “lineage of the Buddha.” One becomes a member on the first bodhisattva stage. In another sense, all living beings belong to this exalted family because all have the capacity to wake up to enlightenment, conceiving its spirit within themselves and thenceforward seeking its realization (see ).
The name of a bodhisattva stage.
The tenth and last of the ten levels traversed by all practitioners, from the level of an ordinary person until reaching buddhahood. See “ten levels.”
One of the twelve retentions of the bodhisattvas.

One of the five “eyes,” or qualities of vision, possessed by a buddha, viz., the eye made of flesh (māṃsacakṣus), the divine eye (divyacakṣus), the eye of insight (prajñācakṣus), the eye of Dharma (dharmacakṣus), and the buddha-eye. The buddha-eye is the omniscience seeing both how things are ultimately and how they manifest in their variety.
According to the Lotus Sūtra the one true way to buddhahood, equivalent to the Mahāyāna, which is the only teaching given by buddhas who do not live in a degenerate eon.
A bodhisattva.
Attendant of the buddha Smṛtiprabha.
“The Voice That Reveals the Range of Countless Buddhas.” The name of a ray of light.
The name of a tathāgata absorption.
A buddha realm.
A buddha.
“The Perception of the Speech Emitted by All the Pure Buddha Realms.” The name of a ray of light.
The field of activity of a particular buddha.
The realm permeated by a buddha’s teaching and blessing.
The realm influenced by the activity of a specific buddha.
A buddhafield is the particular world system over which a specific buddha presides. There are innumerable such fields in Mahāyāna Buddhist cosmology.

A pure realm manifested by a buddha or advanced bodhisattva through the power of their great merit and aspirations. Examples include Sukhāvatī (the domain of the Buddha Amitābha) and Abhirati (the domain of the Buddha Akṣobhya).

Roughly, a synonym for “universe,” although Buddhist cosmology contains many universes of different types and dimensions. “Buddhafield” indicates, in regard to whatever type of world-sphere, that it is the field of influence of a particular Buddha. For a detailed discussion of these concepts, see Lamotte, Appendice, Note I.

The list of eighteen unshared qualities in the Ananta mukhapariśo dhana nirdeśa varies slightly from other canonical lists. Elsewhere, the first quality is that the buddhas are “consistent in their actions.” The list in the Ananta mukhapariśo dhana nirdeśa also includes an additional member at position thirteen: “their liberated wisdom vision never wanes.” The eighteen are generally given as: (1) their actions are consistent; (2) their speech is not jarring; (3) they are not forgetful; (4) their state of cessation is not a state of indifference; (5) their perception is not discursive; (6) their minds are always composed; (7) their diligence never wanes; (8) their recollection never wanes; (9) their effort never wanes; (10) their meditative absorption never wanes; (11) their insight never wanes; (12) their liberation never wanes; (13) their physical actions are guided by wisdom and are in alignment with wisdom; (14) their verbal actions are guided by wisdom and are in alignment with wisdom; (15) their mental actions are guided by wisdom and are in alignment with wisdom; (16) their wisdom vision is unobstructed and unaffected by the past; (17) their wisdom vision is unobstructed and unaffected by the future; and (18) their wisdom vision is unobstructed and unaffected by the present.
The five, in the CMT system, are Akṣobhya (in the centre), Vairocana (in the east), Ratnasambhava (in the south), Amitābha (in the west), and Amoghasiddhi (in the north).
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha in the distant past.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
A collection of forty-five sūtras presented as a single, long sūtra, although many of its chapters are independent works.
Here, the name of a particular state of concentration (but also the title of a composite Mahāyāna sūtra or “family” of sūtras, Toh 44).
Presented as a single, long sūtra, many of its 45 chapters are independent works. See table of contents of https://read.84000.co/section/O1JC114941JC14666.html.
A great bodhisattva.
The first king of the “yakṣa” dynasty, most likely Kadphises I.

The best known of many sets of past buddhas, including Śākyamuni as the seventh, his three predecessors in this eon (Krakucchanda, Kanakamuni, and Kāśyapa), and the three last buddhas of the eon that preceded the present one (Vipaśyin, Śikhin, and Viśvabhū).
First of the ten recollections.

The Sanskrit term buddhānusmṛti (Pali buddhānussati), meaning “mindfulness or recollection of the Buddha,” is a common practice in all Buddhist traditions that involves taking a buddha such as the Buddha Śākyamuni or Amitābha as one’s meditative object.
First of the seven buddhas of the past.

Eighteen qualities that are exclusively possessed by a buddha. These are listed in the Dharma saṃgraha as follows: The tathāgata does not possess (1) confusion; (2) noisiness; (3) forgetfulness; (4) loss of meditative equipoise; (5) cognition of distinctness; or (6) nonanalytical equanimity. A buddha totally lacks (7) degeneration of motivation; (8) degeneration of perseverance; (9) degeneration of mindfulness; (10) degeneration of samādhi; (11) degeneration of prajñā; (12) degeneration of complete liberation; and (13) degeneration of seeing the wisdom of complete liberation. (14) A tathāgata’s every action of body is preceded by wisdom and followed through with wisdom; (15) every action of speech is preceded by wisdom and followed through with wisdom; (16) a buddha’s every action of mind is preceded by wisdom and followed through with wisdom. (17) A tathāgata engages in seeing the past through wisdom that is unattached and unobstructed and (18) engages in seeing the present through wisdom that is unattached and unobstructed.
The tenth and last of the ten levels traversed by all practitioners, from the level of an ordinary person until reaching buddhahood. See “ten levels.”
Literally “buddha body,” it is another term for the state of buddhahood, which can be subdivided into two or three bodies (kāya).
Tibetan short form of Bhaiṣajya guru vaiḍūrya prabha, also known as the Medicine Buddha.
“The Eye of the Buddha,” one of the mantra deities.
Goddess invoked in divination and soothsaying.
Literally “The Eye of the Buddha,” a female deity in the esoteric Buddhist pantheon.
A synonym for bodhisattva.
Unidentified.
A yakṣa in Heaped Up. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2468 .
A bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A realm in the distant past.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A pure realm manifested by a buddha or advanced bodhisattva through the power of their great merit and aspirations.

A pure realm manifested by a buddha in which beings may follow the path to awakening without fear of falling into lower realms. In many sources it is said to be brought to manifestation through a buddha or bodhisattva’s merit and aspiration.
Epithet of Buddha Śākyamuni and general way of addressing the enlightened ones.
A fully realized (“awakened”) being; when referring to a particular buddha or tathāgata, this term is capitalized.
Literally “Awakened One” in Sanskrit, the Tibetan translation interprets this as one who is “purified and perfected.”
A fully awakened being; when spelled with a capital letter it refers to the Buddha Śākyamuni, one of the Three Jewels, unless another buddha is specified.

Lit. “awakened one.” Title of one who has attained the highest attainment possible for a living being. “The Buddha” often designates Śākyamuni because he is the buddha mainly in charge of the buddhafield of our Sahā universe.

The Indic term buddha means "The Awakened One" and is used in Buddhism as an epithet for the historical Buddha Siddhārtha Gautama as well as other spiritually enlightened beings in general.\n“Buddha” is the past participle of the Sanskrit root budh, meaning "to awaken," “to understand," or “to become aware.”
One of the sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Heat.
A river.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Guṇaprabha.
Another name of Candra, the god of the moon.
One of the two auxiliary melāpakas.
Level of the realization of a bodhisattva; according to the general Mahāyāna, there are ten bodhisattva levels; according to Vajrayāna, thirteen.
In its technical usage this term, which literally means “ground” or “level,” refers to any of the ten levels of the realization of a bodhisattva.
The path of a bodhisattva is divided into ten stages of spiritual attainment called grounds. The eleventh ground corresponds to complete enlightenment.
Earth (Tib. sa, Skt. bhūmi) is the Indian goddess representing Mother Earth. She goes by various other names including Vasundharā (“holder of the riches”).

Literally “grounds” in which qualities grow, and also it means “levels.” Bhūmi refers specifically to levels of enlightenment, especially the ten levels of the enlightened bodhisattvas. Also translated here as “level.”

This is literally the “ground” in which qualities grow like plants, and it also means a “level.” As an untranslated term, bhūmi is used specifically to refer to levels of enlightenment, especially the seven or ten levels of the enlightened bodhisattvas. Sūtras such as the Perfection of Wisdom sūtras teach the seven bhūmis. The teaching of ten bhūmis was found in the Mahāsāṃghika tradition and particularly in the Daśa bhūmika Sūtra (Toh 44, ch. 31, https://read.84000.co/translation/toh44-31.html ), which is the thirty-first chapter in the Tibetan version of the Avataṃsaka Sūtra.
A land in the south of India.
Cancer (zodiac sign and constellation).
A great bodhisattva.
Second name given to Deluded.
A perfumer, the father of Upagupta.
Son of the buddha Susthita.
Attendant of the buddha Bhavāntadarśin.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A river in Enjoyment of Scents.
A brahmin statesman.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Sovereign King of Nāgas.
Attendant of the buddha Vasudeva.
A forest in Dwelling in One Direction.
Mother of the buddha Amoghadarśin.
Father of the buddha Śrīdeva.
The 487th buddha in the first list, 486th in the second list, and 480th in the third list.
A brahmin statesman.
Son of the buddha Yajñasvara.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Dṛḍhavrata.
An acceptable form of medicine for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual. Also used to translate the Sanskrit “madhu.”
Great lay follower of Buddha Śākyamuni.
One of the sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Heat.
A river.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
“Two-faced snake.”
A village.
A variety of sandalwood. The name means “snake essence” because snakes were said to live in the forests of those trees because they were attracted to their scent.
One kind of Indian sandalwood (Santalum album) said to be “blue” on the inside. The name “essence of snakes” is said to come from snakes being particularly attracted to those trees.
A class of mischievous spirits.
A mountain off Videha.
A place near Vairambhya in Śūrasena.
A yakṣiṇī. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2571 .
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.

Ascetic practices that are optional for monks and nuns or undertaken only for a defined time period. They are traditionally listed as being twelve in number: (1) wearing rags (pāṃśukūlika, {phyag dar khrod pa}), (2) (in the form of only) three religious robes (traicīvarika, {chos gos gsum}), (3) (coarse in texture as) garments of felt (nāma[n]tika, {'phyings pa pa}), (4) eating by alms (paiṇḍapātika, {bsod snyoms pa}), (5) having a single mat to sit on (aikāsanika, {stan gcig pa}), (6) not eating after noon (khalu paścād bhaktika, {zas phyis mi len pa}), (7) living alone in the forest (āraṇyaka, {dgon pa pa}), (8) living at the base of a tree (vṛkṣamūlika, {shing drungs pa}), (9) living in the open (ābhyavakāśika, {bla gab med pa}), (10) frequenting cemeteries (śmāśānika, {dur khrod pa}), (11) sleeping sitting up (naiṣadika, {cog bu pa}), and (12) accepting whatever seating position is offered (yāthāsaṃstarika, {gzhi ji bzhin pa}); this last of the twelve is sometimes interpreted as not omitting any house on the almsround, i.e. regardless of any reception expected. Mahāvyutpatti, 1127-39.
A bodhisattva.
The qualities associated with the observance of ascetic practices.

The twelve ascetic virtues comprise wearing clothing from a dust heap, owning only three robes, wearing felt or woolen clothes, begging for food, eating one’s meal at a single sitting, restricting the quantity of food, staying in solitude, sitting under trees, sitting in exposed places, sitting in charnel grounds, sitting even during sleep, and staying wherever one happens to be.\nFor the Sanskrit and Tibetan terms, see Mahā vyutpatti 127–39; also Dudjom Rinpoche (1991), vol. 2: 169.

These consist of (1) wearing rags (pāṃśukūlika, {phyag dar khrod pa}), (2) (in the form of only) three religious robes (traicīvarika, {chos gos gsum}), (3) (coarse in texture as) garments of felt (nāma[n]tika, {'phyings pa pa}), (4) eating by alms (paiṇḍapātika, {bsod snyoms pa}), (5) having a single mat to sit on (aikāsanika, {stan gcig pa}), (6) not eating after noon (khalu paścād bhaktika, {zas phyis mi len pa}), (7) living alone in the forest (āraṇyaka, {dgon pa pa}), (8) living at the base of a tree (vṛkṣamūlika, {shing drungs pa}), (9) living in the open (not under a roof) (ābhyavakāśika, {bla gab med pa}), (10) frequenting burning grounds (Indian equivalent of cemeteries) (śmāśānika, {dur khrod pa}), (11) sleeping sitting up (in meditative posture) (naiṣadika, {cog bu pa}), and (12) accepting whatever seating position is offered (yāthāsaṃstarika, {gzhi ji bzhin pa}). Mahāvyutpatti, 1127-39.
These are listed as twelve at https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-029-001.html#UT22084-029-001-3716 .

Usually this term refers to a set of thirteen ascetic practices that can be taken up optionally by monks to further their moral discipline. Here, it refers to the practice of ascetic purification in general.

An optional set of thirteen practices (with some variations among sources) that monastics can adopt in order to cultivate greater detachment. They consist of (1) wearing patched robes made from discarded cloth rather than from cloth donated by laypeople; (2) wearing only three robes; (3) going for alms; (4) not omitting any house while on the alms round, rather than begging only at those houses known to provide good food; (5) eating only what can be eaten in one sitting; (6) eating only food received in the alms bowl, rather than more elaborate meals presented to the Saṅgha; (7) refusing more food after indicating one has eaten enough; (8) dwelling in the forest; (9) dwelling at the foot of a tree; (10) dwelling in the open air, using only a tent made from one’s robes as shelter; (11) dwelling in a charnel ground; (12) being satisfied with whatever dwelling one has; and (13) sleeping in a sitting position without ever lying down.

An optional set of practices that monastics can adopt in order to cultivate greater detachment. The list of practices varies in different sources. When thirteen practices are listed, they consist of (1) wearing patched robes made from discarded cloth rather than from cloth donated by laypeople; (2) wearing only three robes; (3) going for alms; (4) not omitting any house while on the alms round, rather than begging only at those houses known to provide good food; (5) eating only what can be eaten in one sitting; (6) eating only food received in the alms bowl, rather than more elaborate meals presented to the saṅgha; (7) refusing more food after indicating one has eaten enough; (8) dwelling in the forest; (9) dwelling at the root of a tree; (10) dwelling in the open air, using only a tent made from one’s robes as shelter; (11) dwelling in a charnel ground; (12) having satisfaction with whatever dwelling one has; and (13) sleeping in a sitting position without ever lying down.

Ascetic practices that are optional for monks and nuns or undertaken only for a defined time period. They are traditionally listed as being twelve in number: (1) wearing rags (pāṃśukūlika, {phyag dar khrod pa}), (2) (in the form of only) three religious robes (traicīvarika, {chos gos gsum}), (3) (coarse in texture as) garments of felt (nāma[n]tika, {'phyings pa pa}), (4) eating by alms (paiṇḍapātika, {bsod snyoms pa}), (5) having a single mat to sit on (aikāsanika, {stan gcig pa}), (6) not eating after noon (khalu paścād bhaktika, {zas phyis mi len pa}), (7) living alone in the forest (āraṇyaka, {dgon pa pa}), (8) living at the base of a tree (vṛkṣamūlika, {shing drungs pa}), (9) living in the open (ābhyavakāśika, {bla gab med pa}), (10) frequenting cemeteries (śmāśānika, {dur khrod pa}), (11) sleeping sitting up (naiṣadika, {cog bu pa}), and (12) accepting whatever seating position is offered (yāthāsaṃstarika, {gzhi ji bzhin pa}); this last of the twelve is sometimes interpreted as not omitting any house on the almsround, i.e. regardless of any reception expected. Mahāvyutpatti, 1127-39.

An optional set of practices that monastics can adopt in order to cultivate greater detachment. The list of practices varies in different sources. When twelve practices are listed, they consist of (1) wearing rags (pāṃśukūlika, {phyag dar khrod pa}), (2) (in the form of only) three religious robes (traicīvarika, {chos gos gsum}), (3) (coarse in texture as) garments of felt (nāma[n]tika, {'phyings pa pa}), (4) eating by alms (paiṇḍapātika, {bsod snyoms pa}), (5) having a single mat to sit on (aikāsanika, {stan gcig pa}), (6) not eating after noon (khalu paścād bhaktika, {zas phyis mi len pa}), (7) living alone in the forest (āraṇyaka, {dgon pa pa}), (8) living at the base of a tree (vṛkṣamūlika, {shing drungs pa}), (9) living in the open (ābhyavakāśika, {bla gab med pa}), (10) frequenting cemeteries (śmāśānika, {dur khrod pa}), (11) sleeping sitting up (naiṣadika, {cog bu pa}), and (12) accepting whatever seating position is offered (yāthāsaṃstarika, {gzhi ji bzhin pa}); this last of the twelve is sometimes interpreted as not omitting any house on the alms round, i.e., regardless of any reception expected. Mahāvyutpatti, no. 1127–39.

Ascetic practices that are optional for monks and nuns or undertaken only for a defined time period. They are traditionally listed as being twelve in number: (1) wearing rags (pāṃśukūlika, {phyag dar khrod pa}), (2) (in the form of only) three religious robes (traicīvarika, {chos gos gsum}), (3) (coarse in texture as) garments of felt (nāma[n]tika, {'phyings pa pa}), (4) eating by alms (paiṇḍapātika, {bsod snyoms pa}), (5) having a single mat to sit on (aikāsanika, {stan gcig pa}), (6) not eating after noon (khalu paścād bhaktika, {zas phyis mi len pa}), (7) living alone in the forest (āraṇyaka, {dgon pa pa}), (8) living at the base of a tree (vṛkṣamūlika, {shing drungs pa}), (9) living in the open (ābhyavakāśika, {bla gab med pa}), (10) frequenting cemeteries (śmāśānika, {dur khrod pa}), (11) sleeping sitting up (naiṣadika, {cog bu pa}), and (12) accepting whatever seating position is offered (yāthāsaṃstarika, {gzhi ji bzhin pa}); this last of the twelve is sometimes interpreted as not omitting any house on the almsround, i.e. regardless of any reception expected. Mahāvyutpatti, 1127-39.
A nāga king.

De Jong points out that “the word {sbyaṅ} is recorded in Sumatiratna’s Tibetan-Mongolian Dictionary, II, (Ulanbator, 1959), p. 357: rtsva daṅ ‘bru-la sogs-pa ’jog-pa’i gnas-te sgo daṅ skar-khuṅ med-pa/yaṅ baṅ-ba ’am rdzaṅ yaṅ źes-pa sbyaṅ “a place without doors and windows where herbs and grains are stored; also a store-room or a box” (De Jong 1975, p. 117). (We thank James Gentry for pointing out the sense of “granary.”)\nThe term {sbyang}, if it may indeed be understood as something akin to a “box,” could rather match the term mutoḍī (see Edgerton 1993, p. 436), reported by Samtani as the reading of ANe Comy (the manuscript of the Nibandhana commentary), and also appearing (as mūtoḍī) in the relevant Śikṣāsamuccaya parallel (see Samtani 1971, p. 24, n. 2), rather than the term koṣṭhāgāra in the printed edition. The term mutoḍī matches the Pāli putoỊī/mūtoỊī/mutoli found in Pāli passages parallel to this and explained as follows:\n“A putoḷi is a circular container made by tying together clothes and so forth in the shape of a sack” (vatthādīhi pasibbakākārena bandhitvā kataṃ āvāṭanaṃ putoḷi, ṭīkā on the Mahāsatipaṭṭhānasutta, Mahāvagga, Dīghanikāya; vatthādīhi pasibbakākārena bandhitvā kataṃ āvaṭanaṃ putoḷi, ṭīka on the Mahāsatipaṭṭānasutta, Mūlapaṇṇāsa, Majjhima nikāya; here we take it that āvāṭanam/āvaṭanam = āvaṭṭanam).
A buddha.
The 340th buddha in the first list, 339th in the second list, and 334th in the third list.
The 497th buddha in the first list, 496th in the second list, and 490th in the third list.
Son of the goddess Diti.
Mother of the buddha Tiṣya.
Mother of the buddha Śailendrarāja.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the muhūrtas.
A person who gives alms, an offerer of a gift, or a donor. In the context of the text it is the person who orders an artist to produce the Tathāgata’s image and offers it to the monastic community.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Brahmadatta.

In general, a term for a pure monk or ascetic (or the saṅgha as a whole) who can be considered as a field of merit (Skt. puṇyakṣetra) due to his or her (innate) ability to karmically reciprocate acts of generosity and kindness toward him or her.
First of the six transcendent perfections.
An ascetic statesman.
The first of the six perfections (Skt. pāramitā).
One of the six perfections, the five perfections, and the means of attraction.
The practice of giving or making offerings to others. One of the six perfections of the bodhisattva.
First of the four attractive qualities of a bodhisattva. However, in the context‌ of the transcendent perfections, generosity is the first of the six transcendent perfections.

The first of the six or ten perfections, often explained as the essential starting point and training for the practice of the others. In this text, it exemplifies merit, the most prized quality of human beings.

The act of giving motivated by the wish to attain awakening for all sentient beings. It is the first of the six or ten perfections, often explained as the essential starting point and training for the practice of the others perfections. Also translated here as “giving.”
Father of the buddha Janendrakalpa.
The 952nd buddha in the first list, 951st in the second list, and 942nd in the third list.
A great bodhisattva.
Ritual oblation offered into the fire. Unlike bali, homa in a tantric ritual is a repetitive act performed a prescribed number of times.
This refers to a form of ritual that dates back to the early Vedic period of Indian civilization, involving the offering of substances into fire.
In “The Chapter on Going Forth,” this is presumably a reference to Vedic sacrifices, which brahmins offered to, and hence burned in, a sacred fire.
An oblation offered into a ritual fire; the repeated act of casting an offering into the fire, where each throw is accompanied by a single repetition of the mantra.
A fire sacrifice where the practitioner offers an oblation a specified number of times; when this term refers to an individual oblation, it has been translated as “oblation.”

The casting of a prescribed offering into a ritual fire. The practice of homa is first attested in pre-Buddhist Vedic literature and serves as a core, pervasive ritual paradigm in exoteric and esoteric rites in both Buddhist and non-Buddhist traditions into modern times. In Buddhist esoteric rites, the ritual offerings are made repeatedly, with each throw accompanied by a single repetition of the respective mantra.
A great bodhisattva.
The first of the six or ten perfections, often explained as the essential starting point and training for the practice of the others.
The second class of tantra in most systems of tantra classification (the other classes being, in the fivefold classification, Kriyātantra, Yogatantra, Yogottaratantra, and Yoganiruttaratantra).
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Most likely these refer to (1) desire ({'dod pa}), (2) existence ({srid pa}), (3) view(s) ({lta ba}), and (4) ignorance ({ma rig pa}).

The four bonds, according to Nordrang Orgyan (2008): 808, have eight distinct enumerations, among which they are identified in the commentarial tradition of the Abhi dharma kośa with the four torrents, which immediately follow in https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-875 .
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
In the sūtra and Kriyātantra literature, a yoginī is a female spirit of the lower order.
Likely refers to the activities of body, speech, and mind.
An absorption.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Siṃhadhvaja.
Gemini (zodiac sign and constellation).
One of the subtle channels in the body.
Birthplace of the buddha Duṣpradharṣa.
Second of the five paths.
In the sūtra and Kriyātantra literature, a yoginī is a female spirit of the lower order.
To associate something with something.

The village where the village headman’s daughters, Nandā and Nandabalā (elsewhere known as Sujata and her sister) nursed Siddhārtha Gautama after his six years of austerities and where he later convinced them of the Truths.
A buddha realm.
Gods, nāgas, yakṣas, gandharvas, asuras, garuḍas, kinnaras, and mahoragas.
A minister, brother of Sena.
Son of the buddha Jñānaruta.
Father of the buddha Vajrasena.
One of the pratyeka buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK; a vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A minister, brother of Susena.
Mother of the buddha Amitābha.
(1) The wife of the householder Mahāsena and lay follower of the Buddha. (2) The wife of a householder in a former life of a person with the same name.
King of the city of Ayodhyā before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.\nNot to be confused with Mahendra or Mahendrasena.
A king based in Ujjain, contemporary of the Buddha.
(1) A householder and lay follower of the Buddha. (2) A householder in a former life of a person with the same name.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
A king.
A scholar steeped in study of the Tripiṭaka.
The three collections of the Buddhist teachings: Sūtra, Vinaya, and Abhidharma.

The “three (scriptural) baskets” of Dharma teachings: (1) the basket of teachings on moral discipline (Vinaya) (vinayapiṭaka, {'dul ba'i sde snod}), (2) the basket of teachings in discourses (Sūtra) (sūtrapiṭaka, {mdo sde'i sde snod}), and (3) the basket of teachings on knowledge (Abhidharma) (abhidharmapiṭaka, {mngon pa'i sde snod}).
Literally, the “baskets,” or collections containing the Buddha’s teachings.

A collection of canonical texts according to subject, the piṭakas are usually Vinaya, Sūtra, and Abhidharma. It can also refer, as in this sūtra, to the collection of the Mahāyana teachings, which is known as the bodhisattva-piṭaka. The word originates from the term “baskets,” originally used to contain these collections.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Bhāgīrathi (309 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Unguis odoratus, or sweet hoof (blattes de byzance): the operculus of certain sea snails (McHugh, 2008, p 180 n33).
Mother of the buddha Prabhāsthita kalpa.
A great bodhisattva.
Alternative name of Suṣeṇa.
A householder bodhisattva.
A city.
The name of a demon said to reside in Para nirmitavaśavartin.
A demonic being who resides in the Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations. An epithet of Māra.
Demonic being (his name means “the wicked one”) who resides in the Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations.
One of the sixteen great bodhisattvas. The content of the list varies from text to text.
One of seven grounds for suspension from the saṅgha community.
A city near Rājagṛha.
The name of a world system in the northwestern direction.

The five negative actions comprise killing, stealing, lying, sexual misconduct, and intoxication. A less likely interpretation would equate this enumeration with the {sdig to las lnga}, which are listed in Kalyāṇamitra’s https://read.84000.co/translation/toh4113.html (Toh 4113, ’dul ba, tsu, 196b) as slaying a brahman, slaying a cow, stealing gold, dallying with the wife of a spiritual teacher, and drinking alcohol. See Nordrang Orgyan (2008): 1112.
A class of impure spirits.
Name of a demon who lived in the past.
Scorpio (zodiac sign and constellation).
A class of malevolent serpent-beings.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi; one of the great piśācīs.
A ritual hand gesture (mudrā) of pointing the forefinger of the right hand menacingly.
A female slave of King Ikṣuvāku.
The 48th buddha in the first list, 48th in the second list, and 49th in the third list.
The restraint of the body, speech, and mind.
In Great Vehicle treatises, the vows of a layperson or monk (prātimokṣa), the vows of a solitary buddha, and the vows of a bodhisattva.

Though the precise reference is unclear from the context, in an Indian Mahāyāna sūtra such as The Ten Bhūmis, the term trisaṃvara does not refer to the triad of prātimokṣa vows, bodhisattva commitments, and tantric pledges, but rather may refer to a set known from the Bodhisattvabhūmi: prātimokṣa discipline, engaging in virtuous acts, and providing assistance and care to all beings.

There are two common sets of “the three vows.” The first set refers to the pratimokṣa, bodhicitta, and mantra vows, and this schema was perhaps most famously promoted in Tibet by the thirteenth-century Tibetan polymath Sakya Paṇḍita. The second set, which is likely the set of three vows referred to here, consists of (1) the pratimokṣa vows (Tib. {so thar gyi sdom pa}) of the desire realm, (2) the dhyāna vows (Tib. {sam gtan gyi sdom pa}) of the form realm, and (3) the uncontaminated vows (Tib. {zag med kyi sdom pa}) maintained by those who have transcended the three realms and are at the level of a noble being.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the goddesses in the retinue of Heruka.
Refers to unconventional practices of a tantric yogin.
A buddha realm.
Attendant of the buddha Cīrṇaprabha.
Name of a rākṣasī and Dharma protector.
Restraint from unwholesome deeds, generally engendered by observance of the three levels of vows.
Mother of the buddha Dṛḍhakrama.
An acceptable form of medicine for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
Father of the buddha Saṃpannakīrti.
Very hot hell. Probably a variation of Pratāpana (Tib. {rab tu tsha ba}), as the name occurs in no other sūtra.
A royal capital in another world in the distant past.

The https://read.84000.co/translation/toh44-45.html (Toh 44-45) is an important Sanskrit sūtra that traces the journey of the young pilgrim Sudhana toward awakening. It was later incorporated into the large scriptural omnibus Buddhāvataṃsaka sūtra as its forty-fifth chapter.
One of the four kings of the kinnaras. Translated in other sūtras as {ljon pa} and {shing rlon}.

King of the kinnaras. See the introduction https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-058-006.html#UT22084-058-006-816 .\nHis name has been translated into Tibetan both as “{sdong po}” and “{ljon pa}.”
One of the subtle channels in the body.
‟Divinely Beautiful,” one of the eight goddesses of offerings in the Bhūtaḍāmara maṇḍala; also the name of one of the eight great yakṣiṇīs.
Son of the buddha Śreṣṭharūpa.
One of the great piśācīs.
Lit. “collect,” i.e., gather together into the Mahāyāna.
First of the four noble truths.
Second of the six aspects of perception.
The suffering experienced as actual pain, the suffering of change, and potential suffering.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment. This hell is the same as Wrapped in Every Possible Pain.
Third of the four misconceptions.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Satyakathin.
Fifth of the eleven aspects of knowledge.
One of the rāśis.

The term “suffering” includes all essentially unsatisfactory experiences of life in cyclic existence, whether physical or mental. These comprise (1) the suffering of suffering, i.e., the physical sensations and mental experiences which are self-evident as suffering and toward which spontaneous feelings of aversion arise; (2) the suffering of change, i.e., all experiences which are normally recognised as pleasant and desirable, but which are nonetheless suffering in that persistent indulgence in these always results in changing attitudes of dissatisfaction and boredom; and (3) the suffering of the pervasive conditioning underlying the round of birth, aging, and death.
Birthplace of the buddha Laḍitavikrama.
Mother of the buddha Śrī.
Son of the buddha Janendrakalpa.
Attendant of the buddha Arthakīrti.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Śrīprabha.
Name of a buddha realm in the east where the buddha Glorious Supremely Renowned Intense Subduer resides.
Attendant of the buddha Aśoka.
One of the pratyeka buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Father of the buddha Kusumaraśmi.
Third of the eight aspects of liberation.
Literally, “release from pleasant states.”
Literally, the “notion of pleasantness;” fourth of the four misconceptions.
Attendant of the buddha Anupama.
Birthplace of the buddha Ojodhārin.
Name of a hell.
Blyxa octandra (?)
A unit of time measuring the time it takes to snap one’s fingers.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A certain village during the Buddha’s time, home to Nandā and Nandabalā.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
Attendant of the buddha Ugratejas.
Father of the buddha Sucintita.
Attendant of the buddha Yaśadatta.
A class of malevolent spirits.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
The determination to attain unsurpassed, perfect awakening for the sake of all sentient beings.

Lit. “Perceptionless Beings.” A heavenly realm listed in this text between the twelfth heaven of the form realm, Bṛhatphala, and the five Pure Abodes of the form realm, known collectively as Śuddhāvāsa.
A great bodhisattva.
The hundred-and-eighth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: sattvāśayaiḥ sama śarīri śiri.
A particular hell.
Also called the hot hells because beings born there suffer from heat and burning.
A denizen of the hells. See “five destinies.”

One of the five or six classes of sentient beings, hell beings are engendered by anger and powerful negative actions. They are dominated by great suffering and said to dwell in eight different hells, each with specific characteristics.
The name of a bodhisattva in the Buddha’s audience.
A buddha.
Mother of the buddha Sthitārtha buddhi.

The dung dkar tshig mdzod chen mo lists the nine as (1) among those with different ({tha dad}) bodies and perceptions, such as humans and some gods, (2) among those with different bodies and a single perception, such as the Brahmakāyika gods, (3) among those with a single body and different perceptions, such as the Ābhāsvara gods, (4) among those with a single body and a single perception, such as the Śubhakṛtsna gods, and (5) among beings in Asaṃjñisattva, (6) in the station of endless space, (7) in the station of endless consciousness, (8) in the station of nothing-at-all, and (9) in the station of neither perception nor nonperception.
A buddha.
The world as it is perceived by ordinary beings.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha.
Sixth or fifth of the ten powers of the tathāgatas.
Fifth or sixth of the ten powers of the tathāgatas.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Padmaśrī.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A buddha.
A night goddess.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Puṇyarāśi.
A buddha in the distant past.
Sixty-seventh of the eighty minor marks.
A god.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Mahāprabha.
“The Voice That Ripens the Karma of All Beings.” The name of a ray of light.
A rākṣasī known only from this sūtra.
The name of a meditative absorption (samādhi) of a bodhisattva in this text.
A bodhisattva.
An absorption.
The name of a meditative absorption (samādhi) of a bodhisattva in this text.
Lit. “following the knowledge of sounds of all beings.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Lit. “that produces the sounds of all beings.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A buddha.
The name of Mahāprajāpatī when she becomes a buddha in the future. Also the name of a bodhisattva.
A buddha who resides in the eastern buddha realm called Blazing Glory.
Lit. “that delights all beings.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A buddha.
“The Voice That Gives Rise to Joy, Delight, and Aspiration in All Beings.” The name of a ray of light.
“The Lamp That Removes the Dust from All Beings.” The name of a ray of light.
Name of a Mahābrahmā in the eastern direction.
A buddha.
A place in Ultimate Torment.
Name of a bodhisattva.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
Lit. “overcomes all beings.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A king; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Often rendered simply as “being.”
Any living being in one of the six realms.
The exact meaning of this term is uncertain; it could mean mental clarity or calmness.
Birthplace of the buddha Kusumanetra.
A buddha.
“Great being”; a frequent epithet of bodhisattvas.
“Great being.” An epithet for an accomplished bodhisattva.
Literally “great being.” An epithet for a bodhisattva of great accomplishment.
This translation follows the Tib. (lit. “great mind- hero”), whose translation from Skt. derives from the {lo tsA ba}’s analysis of sattva as meaning “hero,” rather than simply “being.”

An epithet of advanced bodhisattvas, often defined as having attained at least the seventh bhūmi and the path of vision. These bodhisattvas have several special qualities that bodhisattvas on the lower bhūmis do not have.

An epithet for an accomplished bodhisattva. The White Lotus of Compassion Sutra goes further and says only those praying to attain buddhahood in an impure realm during a kaliyuga deserve the title, even though the early part of the sūtra uses it for all accomplished bodhisattvas.
A great bodhisattva.
Sitting posture when the right shank is placed on top of the left shank; there is also a standing version of this posture.
Sitting posture with the left foot drawn to one’s perineum and the other one extended slightly (typically, the posture of Tārā).
Attendant of the buddha Ketumat.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Vajradhvaja.
Name of the fifty-second meditative stability.
Lit. “stability of mind.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Mother of the buddha Hutārci.
Mother of the buddha Śaśin.
Son of the buddha Asaṅgakīrti.
Father of the buddha Brahmavāsa.
Attendant of the buddha Dharmavikrāmin.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Pradīpa.
A land in Godānīya.
A bodhisattva; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
A high level of absorption reached through mastery of concentration.
Father of the buddha Maṅgala.
Son of the buddha Mokṣatejas.
A bodhisattva who is the primary interlocutor for the “Scale of Life” chapter (Ch. 37) of the Buddhāvataṃsaka.
One of the four types of presence of recollection.
Third of the four applications of mindfulness. For a description, see https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-952 .
Third of the four supports for miraculous abilities.
An absorption.

The essentially pure nature of mind is obscured and afflicted by various psychological defilements known as the afflicted mental states, which destroy the mind’s peace and composure. Included among them are the primary afflictions of fundamental ignorance, attachment, aversion, pride, doubt, and twenty subsidiary afflictions.

The fourth of the four states of imperturbability or formless meditative absorptions or attainments (Skt. ārūpya samāpatti), which leads to rebirth in the formless realm (Skt. ārūpyadhātu) as a deva without form.
Name of the seventy-third meditative stability.
Lit. “firm without mind.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Name of the thirty-third meditative stability.
Lit. “without thoughts.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A sense of reverence proves that a convert has rejected his old religious sentiments in favor of new ones. The term suggests humility.
Mother of the buddha Samantadarśin.
Forth or fifth of the eighteen distinct qualities of the buddhas.
A state of mind that regards all being equally and is without hostility or malice towards any being.
Mother of the buddha Anāvilārtha.
Mother of the buddha Kṣemottamarāja.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Maṇicaraṇa.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Mokṣavrata.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ratnaskandha.
Third of the four nourishments.
One of the grahas.
One of the four bases of miraculous power.
One of the vidyārājñīs attending the delivery of the MMK.

In later texts, among the ever-present mental factors that underlie and constitute all conscious states; the Sarvāstivāda Abhidharma lists ten such factors (mahābhūmika, {sa chen po pa}), while Yogācāra theory identifies five (sarvatraga, {kun 'gro}). In that context, volition orients the mind towards objects in ways that may be virtuous, non-virtuous or neutral. In this sūtra, however, the term seems to denote a less specific, manifest aspect of consciousness.
A state in which the mind is focused on a single object.
Birthplace of the buddha Jagatpūjita.
One of the bodhisattvas attending this teaching.
One of the kinnara kings.
Mother of the buddha Gaṇimukha.
Attendant of the buddha Sthitamitra.
A city in Godānīya.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Askhalita buddhi (913 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.

The setting of the mind on enlightenment for the sake of all sentient beings, which marks the onset of the bodhisattva path and culminates in the actual attainment of buddhahood, distinguishes the compassionate bodhisattva path from that of the śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas who are both preoccupied with their own emancipation from cyclic existence. See Dayal (1932): 50–79, Williams (1989): 197–204, and Padmakara Translation Group (1994): 218–234.\n(See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-8 ).
A great bodhisattva.
One of the four bases of magical power.
First of the eighty minor marks.
A wandering ascetic whose dialogue with the Buddha is mentioned in many canonical texts. His name means “Long-Nailed.” Also known as Koṣṭhila, Kauṣṭhila, Mahākauṣṭhila, and Agnivaiśyāyana.
A brahmin disciple of the Buddha. Also known as Koṣṭhila, Kauṣṭhila, Mahākauṣṭhila, and Agnivaiśyāyana. See introduction, https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-074-003.html#UT22084-074-003-10 .

“He Who Has Long Fingernails,” Koṣṭhila’s name after he joined an order of wandering ascetics to continue his studies of Lokāyata philosophy. He later joined the Buddhist order and was known as Koṣṭhila again.
The 978th buddha in the first list, 977th in the second list, and 968th in the third list.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Mahābala (14) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
One of the Buddha’s former rebirths.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Siṃhavikrāmin.
A figure from an unidentified avadāna narrative.
One of the buddhas who teach the Tathāgata guhyaka on certain occasions in Vimalakīrti’s house.
The name of a tathāgata presiding over a buddhafield at the nadir below the buddhafield Full of Pearls.
An absorption.
Indian commentator (fl. late eighth century).
A village. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2043 .
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Śaśivaktra (201 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ratnākara.
A king in South India.
A bodhisattva.
An ancient city, probably corresponding to the modern Panchakesari in Orissa.
A great bodhisattva.
The name of a bodhisattva.
One of the eight great bhūtinīs.
A lion-faced goddess in the retinue of Jñānaḍākinī.
Lit. “lion’s roar.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A bodhisattva who is attending the Buddha’s teaching in this sūtra.
A four-continent world in the distant past.
Mother of the buddha Ratnāgni.
A buddha in the distant past when Śākyamuni was Prince Mati.
The eighty-third buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Harisumeruśirī.

Having the “gait of a lion” is included in the list of the eighty excellent signs (asītyānuvyañjana), a subset of the 112 physical characteristics of both buddhas and cakravartins.

Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Yaśaketu.

Name of a bodhisattva.

Lit. “Lion Crest.” The bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly who requests a discourse from Dhāraṇīśvara rāja.

The 1002nd buddha in the first list, 1001st in the second list, and 992nd in the third list.
Bhikṣuṇī pupil of the Buddha, who is only known from this sūtra.

Birthplace of the buddha Upakāragati.

An island in the sea west of Jambudvīpa.
Father of the buddha Ojaṅgama.
Son of the buddha Gaṇiprabhāsa.
A Licchavi inhabitant of Vaiśālī and the father of Ratnadatta.
The bodhisattva who will become sixth buddha of the fortunate eon.
The 563rd buddha in the first list, 563rd in the second list, and 556th in the third list.
A Licchavi king, contemporary of the Buddha; a dynasty in Orissa contemporary of Prakaṭāditya.

Siṃha (Lion) is a buddha who inhabits a buddhafield. This buddhafield is specifically said to be Excellent Lamp (Tib. {sgron ma bzang po}) in http://read.84000.co/translation/toh44-37.html#UT22084-036-008-62 and Pradīpā in http://read.84000.co/translation/toh104.html#UT22084-048-004-79

In The Hundred Deeds, a certain army chief in Vaiśālī by this name appears twice (in part 4: “ https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-073-001.html#UT22084-073-001-2238 ” and in part 5: “ https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-073-001.html#UT22084-073-001-2604 ”). It is not clear whether this army chief refers the same person or not.\nIn the first story, he is the father of a ugly and stinking son who heard the Dharma from the Blessed One, went forth, and was healed of his afflictions. In the second story, he is the father of Good Compassion who was sentenced to death but was released and went forth under the Buddha.
One of the seven golden mountains.
Acaia catechu according to the Pandanus Database of Plants.
A monk (bhikṣu) and disciple of the Buddha.
Acacia catechu; cutch tree, kutch tree.
Monier-Williams s.v. khadira: “Acacia Catechu (having very hard wood, the resin of which is used in medicine, called ‘Catechu,’ ‘Khayar,’ ‘Terra japonica’).”
The 986th buddha in the first list, 985th in the second list, and 976th in the third list.
A bodhisattva.
The 433rd buddha in the first list, 432nd in the second list, and 426th in the third list.
A buddha.
King of Kapilavastu. His children were Amṛtā, Droṇā, Śuklā, Śuddhā, Amṛtodana, Droṇodana, Śuklodana, and Śuddhodana.
The daughter of the brahmin Agnidatta.
One among a list of eight uṣṇīṣa buddhas mentioned in this text that do not appear elsewhere in the canon.
A buddha realm.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
A buddha.
A Hindu goddess, unidentified. McCombs (p. 128) suggests that the Sanskrit name for this goddess might be Pītā or Vāruṇī.
A famous nun who was the wife of Mahākāśyapa for twelve years prior to their ordination.
The city in which Buddha Śākyamuni was born, located in present day southern Nepal.
Lit. “The One with Yellow-Green Hair.”
One of the wrathful goddesses, prominent also in Śaiva Śakta traditions.
Name of a yakṣa.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
A young brahmin.
The Buddha’s hometown. Also translated elsewhere as {ser skya'i grong}.
The capital city of the Śākya kingdom, where the Buddha had grown up as Prince Siddhārtha.
Near the Himālayas, the city that was home to the Śākya clan into which Buddha Śākyamuni was born.
The capital city of the Śākya kingdom, which is where the Bodhisattva (i.e., Siddhārtha Gautama before his awakening) grew up.
The hometown of Śākyamuni Buddha. There are two sites, one on either side of the present border between Nepal and India, that have been identified as its remains. Also known as “Kapilāhvaya.”

An ancient city, capital of the Śākya state, where Siddhārtha Gautama (the Buddha Śākyamuni) lived until the age of twenty-nine when he renounced worldly life. Later, some years after his awakening, the Buddha returned to Kapilavastu, where his cousins Ānanda and Devadatta, his half-brother Nanda, his barber Upāli, and his son Rāhula joined the monastic community.
A town.
The city in the Śākyan kingdom where Gautama Buddha grew up. It is located on the northern side of the Gangetic plain near Lumbini.
The Buddha’s home town.
The city of the Śākyans.
One of the eight great nāgas.
The right channel above the navel.
The city where Śākyamuni was born.
A Śaiva deity, an attendant of Śiva.
The capital city of the Śākya kingdom, where the Bodhisattva grew up.
The name of a sage. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-033.html#UT22084-072-033-29 .
The city of the Śākyans.
The Śākya capital, where Siddhārtha Gautama was raised.
One of twenty or twenty-four so-called secondary mental defilements or afflictions.
A deity representing the faculty of touch.
A deity personifying the true nature of the faculty of touch.
An afflictive emotion.
One of one of twenty or twenty-four so-called secondary mental defilements or afflictions.
In this text, miserliness is one of the three factors at odds with the true Dharma because it impedes generosity and thus destroys merit.
The mental state of stinginess, matsara is sometimes translated as “miserliness” or “avarice.” It is classified as one of the twenty subsidiary afflictions (upakleśa).
A former buddha in this eon.
A buddha realm.
Zingiber officinale.

Gampopa Sonam Rinchen ({sgam po pa bsod nams rin chen}, 1079–1153). A disciple of Milarepa, and the founder of the monastic Kagyu tradition; also known as Dakpopa ({dwags po pa}) or Dakpo Lharjé ({dwags po lha rje}).

A certain king during the time of Buddha Prabhāvan who ordered the torture and slaughter of five hundred arhats, precipitating his rebirth in the Hell of Ceaseless Agony. Also his name in a previous birth as a certain king.
Zingiber officinale.
Zingiber officinale
Financial records or accounts. Also means “door panel”.
A city in South India.
A capital city in the distant past.
An acceptable form of shelter for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
Name of a buddha realm in the east where the buddha Skill of the Completely Victorious in Battle resides.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
A buddha in a southwestern realm.
A buddha field in the future where the bodhisattva Supreme Wisdom attains buddhahood as the tathāgata Supreme Sun of Bliss.
One of the fourfold classification of ways in which beings are born.
One of the four modes of birth (caturyoni; {skes gnas bzhi}).

The six perfections: the perfection of generosity, the perfection of discipline, the perfection of patience, the perfection of diligence, the perfection of concentration, and the perfection of insight.
Heliotropium indicum.
Son of the buddha Vidyutprabha.
Fourth of the five paths, preceded by the paths of provisions, connection, and insight, and followed by the path of no-more-learning.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Jñānin.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Acquainting the mind with a virtuous object or mentally contemplating the Buddha’s teachings (Rigzin 75). Also translated here as “meditation.”
Acquainting the mind with a virtuous object. Often translated as “meditation” and “familiarization.”
Second of the four modes of birth.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.

An Indian seer.
The Buddha’s son.
Son of Siddhārtha Gautama.
(1) Another name of Rāhula. (2) The son of a future Buddha whose name is Śākyamuni.

A great bodhisattva.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Howling Hell.
A king in the past.

A garuḍa, king of birds, who lived on Mount Meru, and eventually went for refuge and took the fundamental precepts. He was the previous incarnation of the great king Vaiśravaṇa.
Attendant of the buddha Śuddhaprabha.

Śākyamuni Buddha’s own son, who became a distinguished disciple. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-060-005.html#UT22084-060-005-945 .

The 610th buddha in the first list, 609th in the second list, and 603rd in the third list.
