Mother of the buddha Śuddhasāgara.
The 801st buddha in the first list, 800th in the second list, and 790th in the third list.
The 976th buddha in the first list, 975th in the second list, and 966th in the third list.
The 362nd buddha in the first list, 361st in the second list, and 356th in the third list.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Subāhu.
The Buddha’s son who became a monk (bhikṣu) and his disciple.
Śrāvaka arhat, one of the sixteen sthavira arhats (see “elder”).
An asura king. He is said to cause eclipses by seizing or blocking the sun and moon.
The Buddha’s son who became the first novice monk and a prominent member of his monastic saṅgha.
Son of Prince Siddhārtha Gautama, who, when the latter attained awakening as the Buddha Śākyamuni, became a monk and eventually one of his foremost śrāvaka disciples.

Rāhula is the name of Śākyamuni Buddha’s physical son. Edgerton reports from different sources that he miraculously descended from Tuṣita heaven into his mother’s womb, and insisted on becoming a monk when he found out that the Buddha was his father. He was ordained by Śāriputra.
The 913th buddha in the first list, 912th in the second list, and 903rd in the third list.
One of the kings of asuras; the demon who is thought to cause an eclipse.
A demon who is supposed to seize the sun and moon and thus cause eclipses.
The 271st buddha in the first list, 270th in the second list, and 270th in the third list.
The celestial demon of the eclipse, regarded as the leader, or one of the leaders, of the asuras.
Śākyamuni Buddha’s son who became the first novice monk and a prominent member of his monastic saṅgha.
Eminent among the long-life gods, he is said to have on different occasions seized the sun and moon, only releasing them on the Buddha’s order.
The 511th buddha in the first list, 511th in the second list, and 504th in the third list.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Jyeṣṭhavādin.
A realm of the vessel-bearer gods.
A king of the past.
A northwestern buddha realm.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Pārthiva (600 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Father of the buddha Dharmeśvara.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Supraṇaṣṭamoha.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode. The Tib. has been emended to correct the non-sensical {skra mdzas ma}.
Lit. “in which all that is soundless and with sounds comes together”; alternatively, “in which all with affliction comes together in what is without affliction.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
(1) A country ({sgra ngan}). (2) A continent in the north ({sgra mi snyan}).
(1) The continent to the north of Mount Sumeru. (2) A land to the north of Jambudvīpa.
The northern continent of the human world according to traditional Indian cosmology, characterized as “unpleasant sound.”
In ancient Buddhist cosmology, the northern of the four continents in the cardinal directions, that of “Unpleasant Sound.”
In Buddhist cosmology, it refers to (1) the continent to the north of Mount Sumeru, and (2) a land to the north of Jambudvīpa.

The continent to the north of Mount Meru according to Buddhist cosmology. In the Abhidharmakośa, it is described as square in shape and its human inhabitants enjoy a fixed lifespan, namely a thousand years, and do not hold personal property or marry.
Attendant of the buddha Brahmavāsa.
(1) A country ({sgra ngan}). (2) A continent in the north ({sgra mi snyan}).
A night goddess.
A bodhisatva great being.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A brahmin; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Unidentified. The Tib. reflects a different Skt. reading.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Name of a rākṣasī and Dharma protector.
One of the kings of the rākṣasas.
Refers to rṣi Guṃjika’s abode, a place near Nādikā, a village in the country of Vṛji.
(1) A yakṣa in Kashmir; see also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2418 . (2) A ṛṣi.
Attendant of the buddha Yaśaḥkīrti.
Name of an absorption.
Son of the buddha Sulocana.
(1) A buddha in the past ({sgra snyan dbyangs}). (2) A king who was Mahāpraṇāda’s father ({rab sgrogs}).
Birthplace of the buddha Brahmaghoṣa.
A realm of the triple-lute-bearer gods.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Ananta rati kīrti.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Amitabuddhi.
A buddha.
Name of a buddha realm located in the northern direction during the time of the Buddha Śākyamuni. Also called Manifestation of All Perfumes.
One of the goddesses in the maṇḍala of Vajrasattva.
A buddha in the distant past.
Fifth of the eighteen sensory elements.
Eighth of the twelve sense fields.
A goddess.
A great bodhisattva.
The name of a bodhisattva in the Buddha’s audience.
Part of the Tibetan translation of a Skt. stock phrase for the expression of esteem. See glory, good reputation.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A garuḍa, king of birds, who lived on Mount Meru, and eventually went for refuge and took the fundamental precepts. He was the previous incarnation of the great king Virūpākṣa.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Kāśyapa.
Mother of the buddha Brahmagāmin.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Puṣpaprabha (788 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A buddha.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Vratatapas.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Candra.
The name of a bodhisattva.
A buddha field in the future where the bodhisattva Unobscured Lamp attains buddhahood as Supreme Wisdom.
A set of mental factors that hinder discipline, concentration, and insight.
These are (1) wishing for sense pleasures, (2) ill will, (3) sleep and torpor, (4) agitation and regret, and (5) doubt.
Longing for desires (kāmacchanda), malice (vyāpāda), sloth and torpor (styānamiddha), excitement and remorse (auddhatya kaukṛtya) and doubt (vicikitsā).

These are five mental impediments that hinder meditation: impediments of desire (kāmacchanda), malice (vyāpāda), depression and sloth (styānamiddha), wildness and excitement (auddhatya kaukṛtya), and doubt, or perplexity (vicikitsa).

The five obscurations, as found in https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-2531 , comprise longing for sensual pleasure, agitation and regret, harmful intention, dullness and sleepiness, and hesitation. See also Kimura IV: 182.

Five impediments to meditation: sense desire ({'dod pa la 'dun pa}, kāmacchanda), ill will ({gnod sems}, vyāpāda), drowsiness and torpor ({rmugs pa dang gnyid}, styānamiddha), agitation and guilt ({rgod pa dang 'gyod pa}, auddhatya kaukṛtya), and doubt ({the tshom}, vicikitsā).
Attendant of the buddha Muniprasanna.
Birthplace of the buddha Amohavihārin.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Candra.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Cīrṇabuddhi.
Name of a dhāraṇī.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Vajra.
Birthplace of the buddha Amoghagāmin.
Lit. “reached a freedom without obscuration.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A bodhisattva who seeks a prophecy from Śākyamuni.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Prasanna.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Hitaiṣin.
Son of the buddha Dṛḍha.
A sage; former incarnation of the Buddha.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Dṛḍha.
Birthplace of the buddha Samantadarśin.
A bodhisattva from a buddha realm in the downward direction. Also called Sarvāvaraṇa vikiraṇa jñāna vikrāmin.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
One of the sixteen great bodhisattvas. The content of the list varies from text to text.
A great bodhisattva, visitor from the distant buddhafield of Padmanetra, and the Buddha Śākyamuni’s main interlocutor in this text.

One of the eight great bodhisattvas. In particular, he has an important role in the Lotus Sūtra, in which Buddha Śākyamuni sends him to Vārāṇasī to see Avalokiteśvara. This is paralleled in the Kāraṇḍavyūha, in which he is sent to Vārāṇasī to obtain Avalokitesvara’s mahāvidyā.
One of the celestial bodhisattvas.
That which obscurs insight into reality.
The five hindrances are sensual desire, ill will, sloth and torpor, excitement and remorse, and doubt.
Defilements that obstruct liberation and omniscience. This term refers both to affective (or “afflictive”) and cognitive obscurations.

Usually a reference to five hindrances: longing for sense pleasures (Skt. kāmacchanda), malice (Skt. vyāpāda), sloth and torpor (Skt. styānamiddha), excitement and remorse (Skt. auddhatyakaukṛtya), and doubt (Skt. vicikitsā).

In this sūtra it is stated that there are five obscurations. This must be referring to the list in the early Mahāyāna sūtra The Patience Trained by the Color of Space Sūtra: (1) desire’s craving; (2) malice; (3) dullness and sleepiness; (4) laziness and agitation; and (5) doubt.

The obscurations to liberation and omniscience. They are generally categorized as two types: affective obscurations (kleśāvaraṇa), the arising of afflictive emotions, and cognitive obscurations (jñeyāvaraṇa), those caused by misapprehension and incorrect understanding about the nature of reality.
To superimpose inherent existence upon something that does not exist inherently.

A term that refers to the activity of superimposition or imputing characteristics to things that they do not possess. A paradigm case in Buddhism is the imputation of a singular, self-existent, enduring self to the transient bundle of skandhas that make up a person.

To superimpose existence upon something which does not exist; adherents of eternalist views superimpose existence upon something which does not exist. They grasp at a concrete reality. The opposite is the view of nihilists which denies the existence of phenomena.
A great bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Brahmavāsa.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Meruraśmi.
A buddha realm.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A wrathful form of the goddess Tārā.
Lit. “the Saviouress.”
The Buddhist goddess of compassion.
Female bodhisattva of compassion; also one of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A goddess whose name can be translated as “Savior.” She is known for giving protection and is variously presented in Buddhist literature as a great bodhisattva or a fully awakened buddha.
Female bodhisattva of compassion; the chief goddess of the activity family, personifying the true nature of the element wind; one of the five goddesses personifying the five “hooks of gnosis.”

A measure of capacity or volume, and sometimes of weight, roughly equivalent to 5 liters or 9.5 kilograms. It can also be used to denote a vessel or container of that capacity, hence the Tibetan translation here sgrom, “box” or “chest,” which is a little misleading in the passage in this text.
Birthplace of the buddha Sūryaprabha.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Viniścitamati (340 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Sugandha (265 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Name of the eighty-ninth meditative stability.
Lit. “fire meteor.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A buddha.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Sūryaraśmi.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Pradīpa.
Son of the buddha Meruyaśas.
Mother of the buddha Nandeśvara.
Excellent Lamp is a buddhafield inhabited by the Buddha Siṃha.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
The 137th buddha in the first list, 137th in the second list, and 137th in the third list.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Mahāprabha (19 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Attendant of the buddha Vidyuddatta.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Kṣemaṃkara.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Acala.
Mother of the buddha Mahāmitra.
Birthplace of the buddha Vidhijña.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Yaśaḥkīrti (915 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A buddha.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Raśmirāja.
A buddha realm.
Attendant of the buddha Sārathi.
Birthplace of the buddha Rāhugupta.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Ojastejas.
Name of a bodhisattva.
Father of the buddha Svaracodaka.
A buddha who resides in the eastern buddha realm called Famous.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Yaśottara (204 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Birthplace of the buddha Puṇyapradīpa.
A distant world.
Son of the buddha Satyaketu.
Father of the buddha Ṛṣiprasanna.
Attendant of the buddha Dṛḍhasvara.
The 222nd buddha in the first list, 221st in the second list, and 221st in the third list.
A buddha realm.
The 515th buddha in the first list, 515th in the second list, and 508th in the third list.
Twenty-third of the eighty minor marks.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One who performs a sādhana.
The person who performs a sādhana or a ritual aimed at a particular result.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Formal practice done in sessions; in the context of the AP this can be any ritual practice aiming for a particular result.
Practice involving mantra and visualization.
A formal practice usually organized into sessions, which involves mantra and visualization.
The method of practice. Experiential methods for actualizing spiritual attainments and liberation.
Ritual practice organized into sessions and dedicated to a particular goal; the act of achieving or accomplishing one’s purpose in general.

A certain monk of the Buddha’s order whose vile deeds committed against his mother in a previous life ripened into a series of hell births. Finally attaining a human birth, he had a curved spine and went hungry, then drank ash-gruel and passed into parinirvāṇa.
A physical condition considered an impediment to ordination.
Attendant of the buddha Nārāyaṇa.
(1) The Buddha’s mother. (2) The mother of a future Buddha whose name is also Śākyamuni.

The female central deity of the Mahā māyā Tantra who appears in the form of the male Heruka. She was also a popular form of the Brahmanical great goddess (Mahādevī), to whom the Buddhist figure is intimately related. Also rendered here as “Great Illusion.”

Buddha Śākyamuni’s mother. She and her sister Māyā both married King Śuddhodana of Kapilavastu. Here she is said to be the daughter of Śākya Suprabuddha. In other stories, Mahā māyā is alternatively said to be the daughter of King Āñjāna of Devaḍaha. Also called “Mahā māyādevī” and “Māyādevī.”
Mother of the buddha Śākyamuni.

Buddha Śākyamuni’s aunt, and the daughter of Śākya Suprabuddha. She and her sister Mahā māyā (Buddha Śākyamuni’s mother) both married King Śuddhodana of Kapilavastu. Somewhat confusingly, in other stories she is identified as Mahā prajāpatī Gautamī, q.v., while Māyā is often used as a short form of the name of the Buddha’s mother Mahā māyā.
A goddess.
The realization that all phenomena are illusory and empty, which occurs when a bodhisattva understands the unborn nature of phenomena.
Lit. “where illusion has been eliminated.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A buddha realm to the east.
Father of the buddha Amitayaśas.
These include writing and mathematics, and also different sports, crafts, dancing, acting, and the playing of various instruments.

The sixty-four crafts, as enumerated in the Mahā vyutpatti, comprise the thirty designated arts, the eighteen requisites of musical performance, the seven harmonious tones of the musical scale, and the nine dramatic moods.\nSee https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-2129 .
A Sāṃkhya teacher with whom Siddhārtha studied.
According to Edgerton: śaṭhya.
A land to the north of Jambudvīpa.
A yakṣa that was the protective deity for the Śākya clan, which was the Buddha’s clan. The Śākyas had a temple devoted to him and he is represented in sculpture as being present at his birth.
Literally, “the Bull of the Śākyas.” This is similar to Śākyamuni, “the Sage of the Śākyas,” the Śākyas being the Buddha’s clan.
An epithet of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
The buddha of this eon and world.
The name of the buddha of our era, the fourth buddha of this Bhadraka eon.
The name of the historical Buddha, Siddhārtha Gautama; he was a muni (sage) from the Śākya clan.
Lit. “Sage of the Śākya.” In Great Vehicle literature, this is one of the most common epithets of the historical Buddha, the buddha of our time, also known as Gautama Buddha.
The buddha in the realm of Enduring, who is the historical Buddha, Siddhārtha Gautama. He was a muni (sage) from the Śākya clan.\nAlso a buddha in the realm of Joy and in the realm of Jñānabala.

An epithet for the historical Buddha, Siddhārtha Gautama: he was a muni (“capable one”) from the Śākya clan. Usually counted as the fourth of the first four buddhas of the present Good Eon, the other three being Krakucchanda, Kanakamuni, and Kāśyapa. He will be followed by Maitreya, the next buddha in this eon.
An epithet of the Buddha.
Name of the clan into which the Buddha was born.
One of the Buddha’s chief disciples, more commonly known as Śāriputra.
One of the closest disciples of the Buddha, known for his pure observance of discipline.

One of the major śrāvaka disciples, paired with Maudgalyāyana, and noted for having been praised by the Buddha as foremost of the wise; hence, the most frequent target for Vimalakīrti’s attacks on the śrāvakas and on the Hinayāna in general.\n(See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-060-005.html#UT22084-060-005-902 )
Māṭhara’s daughter and mother of Upatiṣya (aka Śāriputra).
The mother of Śāriputra.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The wisest of Buddha’s disciples. Śāriputra’s father Tiṣya named him Śāriputra, “Śārikā’s Son,” to honor Śāriputra’s mother Śārikā.
One of the foremost disciples of the Buddha, renowned for his wisdom and regarded by the tradition as a principal compiler of the Abhidharma.
Also known as Śāradvatīputra. He was one of the closest disciples of the Buddha, known for his pure discipline and, of the hearer disciples, considered foremost in wisdom.
Along with Maudgalyāyana, one of Buddha Śākyamuni’s two foremost disciples, known for his erudition. His full given name is Śāriputra Upatiṣya; also rendered here as Upatiṣya.

Along with Maudgalyāyana, Śāriputra was one of the two main disciples of the Buddha. Known as a great arhat, he requested some important teachings such as the Prajnāpāramitā sūtras, and is particularly famous for his discriminating insight (prajñā).

One of the principal hearer disciples of the Buddha, paired with Maudgalyā yana, he was renowned for his discipline and for having been praised by the Buddha as foremost of the wise. His father, Tiṣya, named him Śāriputra, “Śārikā’s Son,” to honor Śāriputra’s mother Śārikā.
Māṭhara’s daughter and mother of Upatiṣya (aka Śāriputra).
The name of an important translator who was active during the early Sarma ({gsar ma}) period (c. 11th century).
A buddha.
The identity of this person is unknown.
The name of an eon in which the Buddha Glorious Array of Eloquence in All Teachings resides.
In the sūtra this term used by non-Buddhists to refer to Buddhists.
King of Vṛji, father of Buddha Śākyamuni’s mother Mahā māyā. See “Suprabuddha.”
One of the epithets of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
“Śākya lion.” Synonymous with Śākyamuni, “Śākya sage.”
In Sanskrit, “Lion of the Śākyas,” an epithet for the Buddha.
Literally, “Lion of the S̄ākyas,” this is the name under which Buddha Śākyamuni was prophesied for awakening by Buddha Dīpaṃkara.

An epithet for the historical Buddha, Siddhārtha Gautama: he was a muni (“capable one”) from the Śākya clan. In this text and elsewhere, he is counted as the fourth of the first four buddhas of the present Good Eon, the other three being Krakucchanda, Kanakamuni, and Kāśyapa. He will be followed by Maitreya, the next buddha in this eon. In the first list an alternative epithet of his, “Supreme of the Śākyas” ({shAkya skyes mchog}) is used. He is counted as the 4th buddha in all three lists found in this sūtra.
The name of the historical Buddha, Siddhārtha Gautama; he was a muni (able one) from the Śākya clan.
The name of the historical Buddha, Siddhartha Gautama. In The White Lotus of the Good Dharma he is said to be in the northeast of the Sahā universe.
A common epithet of the historical Buddha, Siddhārtha Gautama, meaning “the sage (muni) of the Śākya clan.” Here mentioned as one of the thirty-five buddhas of confession.
Lit. “Sage of the Śākya.” In Great Vehicle literature, this is one of the most common epithets of the historical Buddha, the buddha of our time, also known as Gautama Buddha.
The buddha in the realm of Enduring, who is the historical Buddha, Siddhārtha Gautama. He was a muni (sage) from the Śākya clan.\nAlso a buddha in the realm of Joy and in the realm of Jñānabala.

An epithet for the historical Buddha, Siddhārtha Gautama: he was a muni (“capable one”) from the Śākya clan. In this text and elsewhere, he is counted as the fourth of the first four buddhas of the present Good Eon, the other three being Krakucchanda, Kanakamuni, and Kāśyapa. He will be followed by Maitreya, the next buddha in this eon. In the first list an alternative epithet of his, “Supreme of the Śākyas” ({shAkya skyes mchog}) is used. He is counted as the 4th buddha in all three lists found in this sūtra.
The name of the historical Buddha, Siddhartha Gautama. He was a muni (“sage”) from the Śākya clan.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Śākyamuni (4 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.

Śākya Yeshé, commonly known by the title Drokmi Lotsāwa, was a Tibetan translator and important figure in the Lamdré (Tib. {lam 'bras}) lineage. Drokmi’s dates are uncertain, but Tibetan literature offers a range of possible dates beginning in 990 and ending in 1074.\nFor a hagiography of Drokmi, see Stearns 2010, pp. 83–101. For an academic appraisal of his life and works, see Davidson 2005, pp. 161–209.
An ally of King Śrī.
The disciples of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
The clan from which the Buddha was descended.
The family into which the Buddha Śākyamuni was born.
Name of the clan into which the Buddha Śākyamuni was born.
The name of the family clan into which the Buddha Śākyamuni was born.
Name of the clan in Northern India in which the Buddha Śākyamuni was born as prince Siddhārtha.
Name of the tribe dwelling in Northern India in which Gautama, or Śākyamuni, Buddha was born as prince Siddhārtha.
An Indian paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.
The river Śītā, also spelled Sītā (personified).
A land in the east of Jambudvīpa.
A skin disorder characterized by a loss of pigmentation.
An illness considered an impediment to ordination. Can translate both sitapuṣpika and kilāsa.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1011 .
A skin disorder characterized by a loss of pigmentation.
Appears in The Hundred Deeds as the name of a king and a people dwelling in the “barbaric outlying region” south of Jambudvīpa.
Candied sugar.
Streblus asper.
One of the rāśis.
Achyranthes triandra.
An acceptable form of cloth for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
Householder who lived in the past at the time of the buddha King of All Qualities’ Light Rays.
One of the two closest disciples of the Buddha, known for his pure observance of discipline.
An elder monk in the Buddha’s retinue, known for his pure observance of discipline and unparalleled knowledge of the teachings.
Lit. “Son of Śāri,” also known as “Śāriputra,” one of two main male disciples of the Buddha.
One of the closest disciples of the Buddha, renowned for his pure observance of discipline. Also known as Śāriputra.
More widely known as Śāriputra. He was one of the closest disciples of the Buddha, known for his pure discipline and, of the hearer disciples, considered foremost in wisdom.
More widely known as Śāriputra—the contracted version of his name—he was one of the Buddha’s foremost hearer disciples. Renowned for his pure discipline and unparalleled knowledge of the teachings.

Lit. “Son of Śāradvatī or Śāri,” more widely known as Śāriputra‍—the contracted version of his name‍—he was one of the Buddha’s foremost hearer disciples. Renowned for unparalleled wisdom and knowledge of the teachings.

Along with Maudgalyāyana, Śāradvatīputra (also known as Śāriputra) was one of the two main disciples of the Buddha. He was renowned for his pure discipline and was praised by the Buddha as being foremost in terms of insight.
Tephrosia purpurea.
Albizzia lebbeck Benth. (Acacia Sirissa.)
Close Śravaka disciple of the Buddha.
“The son of Śāri,” the Buddha’s principal pupil, who passed away before the Buddha.
One of the closest disciples of the Buddha, known for his pure observance of discipline.
“Carrion eater,” a class of flesh-eating spirits.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the great piśācīs.
A female member of a class of nonhuman beings traditionally associated with the wild, remote places of the earth. They are considered particularly violent and are known to devour flesh.
Female piśāca.
A female member of a class of semidivine beings traditionally associated with the wild, remote places of the earth. They are considered particularly violent and known to devour flesh.
“Demoness of the Ear,” female spirit who reveals hidden facts or the future by whispering them into one’s ear; very likely another name for Śravaṇa piśācī.
A class of demons. Literally “flesh eaters.”
A class of flesh-eating and shape-shifting demons.
A type of malevolent ghost, considered to belong to the preta realm. Tibetan translates the term as “flesh-eaters.”

A class of nonhuman beings traditionally associated with the wild, remote places of the earth. They are considered particularly violent and known to devour flesh. Thus the term was translated into Tibetan as “flesh eater.”

A flesh-eating demon, or a demon who can possess the body of a human and cause various illnesses or insanity. They are often depicted as red-eyed, dark-skinned, bulging-eyed creatures, although they seem to be able to assume many shapes.

A spirit that haunts the night, feeds on corpses, and is fatal to see. The Tibetan means “flesh eater.” The Sanskrit does not have “eat” as part of the name, but piśa means “flesh.” An alternative etymology is that they are called piśāca because they are yellow in color, from the Sanskrit piśita, meaning “yellow.”
First of the five eyes. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1114 .
A legendary mountain in Khotan.
A goddess invoked to counter the effects of poison.
Thirty-eighth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
Salmalia malabarica.
“Forest of Silk Cotton Trees,” one of the hot hells (the thorns of a silk cotton tree are supposed to be used in torture).
Bombax heptaphyllum or Salmalia malabarica (a lofty and thorny tree).

Bombax ceiba. Also known as the red cotton tree. It has red flowers and ripened capsules that contain cotton-like fibers. In particular, the trunk is covered in spikes to deter climbing animals, and therefore it is an iron version of this tree that is found in the hells.

The hell of the Simul trees, also called cotton trees, that have vicious thorns. The Tibetan had a corrupted, transliterated version of the name. This is classed among the neighboring hells. It is where beings continually climb up and down the trees in search of a loved one.

One of a Buddhist monk’s three robes. The term {sham thabs} (nivāsana) is the most widespread and is the one used throughout this text, except in https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-2935 and https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-925 where the alternative term {mthang gos} (antarvāsa) is used.
A short form of Śaṅkaroṣṇīṣa; also another name of Śiva.
A type or stone or shell. Pali sankhasilā.
Also translated “partridge.”
Different kinds of partridge: swamp partridge (Skt. tittiri), grey partridge (Skt. kapiñjala), Greek partridge (Skt. jīva).
Chukar partridge (Alectoris chukar, also known as the Greek partridge). In later times in China and Tibet this became a legendary half-human bird, or a two-headed bird.
A mythical two-headed bird that is said to live in the snowy mountains. It is described in Buddhist texts as having a melodious song and is depicted in Buddhist art as resembling a pheasant.

In particular the Chukar partridge (Alectoris chukar) also known as the Greek partridge. The name comes from its call of rapidly repeated three notes. In later times, in China and Tibet this became a legendary half-human bird, or a two-headed bird.

Some times translated as “pheasant.” The Sanskrit, jīvaṃjīva refers to the chukar partridge (Alectoris chukar). In Tibet and China, this became a mythical bird depicted as a half human and half bird, or as a bird with two heads. Here its image is the seventeenth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
A mythical two-headed bird that is said to live in the snowy mountains. It is described in Buddhist texts as having a melodious song and is depicted in Buddhist art as resembling a pheasant.

This term may refer to any country in the east of India; in some contexts, however, it seems to refer to a specific country of this name.

Manu is the archetypal human and the progenitor of humanity in Indian lore. Thus, “son of Manu” is a synonym for humanity in general. Also rendered “born of Manu.”

Manu being the archetypal human, the progenitor of mankind, in the Mahā bhārata, the Purāṇas, and other Indian texts, “son of Manu” is a synonym of “human being” or mankind in general. Also rendered “born of Manu.”

In the Indian tradition, Manu, similar to Noah in the Biblical tradition, was the survivor of a flood that covered the world, and so is the ancestor of all humans. On divine advice, he built a boat in which he saved his family and all the plants, seeds, and animals necessary to reintroduce to the world after the flood had diminished.
Literally “born from Manu,” considered the first ancestor of all humans.

Manu being the archetypal human, the progenitor of mankind, in the Mahā bhārata, the Purāṇas, and other Indian texts, “born of Manu” is a synonym of “human being” or mankind in general. Also rendered “son of Manu.”

Name of a child born into a merchant family in Vaiśālī, whose story is told in this sūtra. In his previous life, he was a god who foresaw his own rebirth as a pig. Seeking help from the Buddha, he goes for refuge in the Three Jewels, and succeeds to be reborn as a human. According to the Buddha’s prophecy, he will become the buddha known as King of Foremost Knowing.

The term jñāna is formed by the root jñā, meaning “to know,” “to know of,” “to understand,” “to be aware of,” with the addition of the pratyaya lyuṭ, which can be interpreted as having different values (the instrument of awareness, its agent, or the action of awareness). We have chosen “awareness” as it was the only that seemed to fit for two important (and not unrelated) contexts wherein jñāna is used: awareness of something, and nonobjective, nonconceptual awareness. In Tibetan the two senses are sometimes distinguished by using {shes pa} and {ye shes}, respectively, but the distinction in the usage of these two terms is not clearly marked in works that are translations from the Sanskrit, and hence it is less relevant for the Kangyur than it may be for indigenous Tibetan works. The nature of jñāna and its relationship with “wisdom” (prajñā) is the topic of one of the chapters of the Abhidharmakośa https://read.84000.co/translation/toh4089.html and is also thematized in a number of Mahāyāna sūtras and śāstras.

As the sixth of the six perfections, it refers to the profound understanding of the emptiness of all phenomena, the realization of ultimate reality—also sometimes rendered as wisdom. In other contexts it refers to the mental factor responsible for ascertaining specific qualities of a given object, such as its characteristics or whether it should be taken up or rejected.

[The female element of the coupling pair in sexual yoga. Here, the term “consort” has been used to render slighty different concepts or views of the female consort, most important of them are: mudrā, vidyā, and prajñā.\nMudrā emphasizes the symbolic form of the female consort, while vidyā and prajñā emphasize the wisdom, or insight, aspect that the female principle embodies, (also rendered here as “wisdom consort.”]

The female element of the coupling pair in sexual yoga. In this translation the term “consort” has been used to render different terms with slighty different concepts of the female consort, the most important being mudrā, vidyā, and prajñā. Mudrā emphasizes the symbolic form of the female consort, while vidyā and prajñā emphasize the wisdom, or insight, aspect that the female principle embodies (see also “wisdom consort”).

The term prajñā is formed by adding the prefix pra, usually understood as meaning “excellent,” to the root jñā, meaning “to know,” “to know of,” “to understand,” “to cognize,” “to be aware of,” etc. Prajñā is used in more mundane contexts as referring to something very akin to “wisdom,” while in a Buddhist context it is often defined as dharma-pravicaya, the classification or analysis of entities, predicated upon a recognition of their specific nature. It is thus also a synonym of abhidharma and of “insight” or “clear sight” (vipaśyanā).

In this text {shes rab} seems to mean primarily knowledge (defined as insight and understanding one has gained through studying and experience), specifically knowledge of the teachings of the Buddha in general, and of karmic cause and effect in particular (Cf. Edgerton, BHSD, s.v. prajñā: “(Skt., and Pāli paññā), knowledge: three kinds, śrutamayī, cintāmayī, and bhāvanāmayī”, i.e., knowledge consisting in listening to the teachings, reflecting on them, and meditation (cultivating or internalizing the teachings). Also translated here as “knowledge of the Dharma.”\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-039.html#UT22084-072-039-104 .

In the context‌ of the transcendent perfections, wisdom is the sixth of the six transcendent perfections.\nThe translation of prajñā ({shes rab}) by “wisdom” here defers to the precedent established by Edward Conze in his writings. It has a certain poetic resonance which more accurate renderings—“discernment,” “discriminative awareness,” or “intelligence”—unfortunately lack. It should be remembered that in Abhidharma, prajñā is classed as one of the five object-determining mental states (pañca viṣaya niyata, {yul nges lnga}), alongside “will,” “resolve,” “mindfulness,” and “meditative stability.” Following A saṅga’s Abhi dharma sam uccaya, Jamgon Kongtrul (TOK, Book 6, Pt. 2, p. 498), defines prajñā as “the discriminative awareness that analyzes specific and general characteristics.” Therefore “wisdom” in this context is to be understood in the cognitive or analytical Germanic sense of witan or weis (Dayal 1932: 136) and not as an abstract “body of knowledge,” or in any aloof and mysterious theosophical sense. Nor indeed is there any association with the Greek sophia.\nAlso translated here as “discriminative awareness.”

A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi; one of the kings of rākṣasas.
A hill in the town of Tosala in South India.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A buddha in the distant past.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the five pure abodes within the realm of form.
A class of gods who inhabit the fourth of the “pure abodes.”
The second highest of the Śuddhāvāsa paradises, the highest paradises in the form realm.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, fourth of the five so-called pure realms of the form realm.

The third highest of the Pure Abodes in the form realm; non-returners and those who have mastered the fourth meditative absorption are reborn there. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-282 .

Lit. “Those Who See Well.” The sixteenth of the seventeen heavens of the form realm; also the name of the gods living there. In the form realm, which is structured according to the four concentrations and pure abodes‍, or Śuddhāvāsa‍, it is listed as the fourth of the five Pure Abodes.
One of the five pure abodes.
Fourth of the pure abodes, meaning “extreme insight.”
The fourth of five realms associated with the fourth concentration into which only noble beings are born.
Sixteenth god realm of form, meaning “Great Vision,” it is the fourth of the five heavens that make up the “pure abodes.”
Both the foremost in terms of insight and foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Dharmeśvara.
The second highest of the seventeen paradises in the form realm, and therefore the second highest of the five Śuddhāvāsika (pure abode) paradises.
Father of the buddha Ratnadhara.
The 117th buddha in the first list, 117th in the second list, and 118th in the third list.
One of the seven golden mountains that surround Mount Sumeru.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Devaraśmi.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
A great bodhisattva.
(1) A nāga king ({rab brtan}). (2) The king of banyan trees ({shin tu rab gnas}).
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
Attendant of the buddha Mañjughoṣa.
Twelfth of the twelve branches of the scriptures.

This could refer to the Ratnakūṭa collection of sūtras as it is known in the Kangyur and Chinese canons; however, as the collection is not known to have existed, as such, in earlier times, this could also be either a general term covering Mahāyāna sūtras as a category, or a synonym for the Kāśyapa parivarta.
One among the twelve sections of scripture.
One of the “twelve branches of excellent speech,”
One of the twelve branches of Buddhist scriptures.
As an adjective for a sūtra it refers to one of the twelve classes of sūtra teaching, and refers to sūtras of great length.
As one of the twelve aspects of the Dharma, it means an extensive teaching on a subject.\nSee also “twelve wheels of the Dharma.”

Literally “extensive”/“elaborate,” it is a denomination applied to a limited number of important sūtras, including the https://read.84000.co/translation/toh95.html , the Suvarṇaprabhāsa https://read.84000.co/translation/toh556.html https://read.84000.co/translation/toh557.html, and a few others.

One of the twelve branches of scripture. Literally meaning “vast” or “extensive,” it refers to a particular set of lengthy sūtras or collections of sūtras that each provide a comprehensive overview of Buddhist thought and practice. This category includes individual works such as the https://read.84000.co/translation/toh95.html and https://read.84000.co/translation/toh113.html and collections such as the Mahā sannipāta, Buddhāvataṃsaka, Ratnakūta, and Prajñāpāramitā.
Attendant of the buddha Vidyutketu.
A great bodhisattva.
Attendant of the buddha Guṇaratna.
Birthplace of the buddha Vibhaktatejas.
A past buddha realm where the buddha Dīptavīrya resided.
A buddha realm.
Father of the buddha Bodhana.
A buddha realm.
“Utterly, Completely Pure,” the name of this world when it will be the buddha realm of Pūrna Maitrāyaṇī putra when he is Buddha Dharmaprabhāsa.
Suniścita padma phullitagātra (Lotus Body Blooming with Utter Certainty) is a buddha who inhabits the buddhafield Avaivartika cakra nirghoṣā.
A buddha who resides in the eastern buddha realm called Joyous Delights.
A tathāgata mentioned here as one of the thirty-five buddhas of confession.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Jñānakośa.
A buddha in the distant past.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Prajñādatta.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Mahāraśmi.
One of the bodhisattvas who received from the Buddha a prophecy of his future awakening.
Birthplace of the buddha Vajra.
A buddha realm above this world.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Source of All Good Qualities/ Source of All Attributes of Good Qualities.
A bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
The fifth bodhisattva level.
Lit. “Invincible.” The fifth level of accomplishment pertaining to bodhisattvas. See “ten bodhisattva levels.”
The fifth bodhisattva bhūmi.
The name of a bodhisattva stage.
The fifth ground of the bodhisattvas.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Deva.
One of the seven limbs of enlightenment.
Fifth of the seven branches of enlightenment.
A state in which body and mind engage with ease in virtuous activities.
A mental factor that renders the mind capable of pursuing virtuous factors.
A state in which one is empowered to employ the body and mind in virtuous activities.
The daughter of a courtesan in another world in the distant past. A previous life of Gopā. The name as given in verse. In prose she is called Sucalita rati prabhāsa śrī.
Birthplace of the buddha Lokajyeṣṭha.
A buddha realm.

Fifth among the branches of perfect awakening (Skt. sambodhyaṅga); a condition of calm, clarity, and composure in mind and body that serves as an antidote to negativity and confers a mental and physical capacity that facilitates meditation and virtuous action.
The name of a karmic wind involved in the formation of an embryo in its twentieth week.
Attendant of the buddha Mahauṣadhi.
The 725th buddha in the first list, 724th in the second list, and 714th in the third list.
One of the eight hot hells.

Father of the buddha Praśānta.

Identified in the Mahābhārata and https://read.84000.co/translation/toh95.html as a variety of date tree.

One of a number of lifestyles that Buddhist monks might adopt, it is particularly conducive to practicing meditation and is thus associated with monks who valued meditation as an integral part of their lives as ascetics.
An acceptable form of shelter for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
A class of spirit being.
A generic term for a tree under which a tathāgata sits and a synonym for the Bodhi tree.
In chapter 36 the name of a buddha in the distant past ({shing rgyal}). In chapter 44 the name of one of the future buddhas in this kalpa ({shing gi rgyal po}).
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
The fiftieth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
Another name of Bhavila, a half brother of Pūrṇa from Sūrpāraka.
A ṛṣi who became the Buddha’s disciple. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-693 .
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
Meyna spinosa.
The wood of Nerium odorum.
Ferula nartex, or Ferula foetida.
Ferula nartex (Boiss.), Ferula foetida (Regel.)
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
A grove in Dwelling in Essence of Jewels.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
A showy tree (Saraca indica) of the family Leguminosae of tropical Asia that is cultivated for its orange scarlet flowers and is used to decorate temples.

A grove of banyan trees (Skt. nyagrodha, Tib. {nya gro dha}) near Kapilavastu where the Buddha sometimes took residence. It was a gift to the Buddhist community by King Śuddhodana, the father of the Buddha.
A tree, Ficus benghalensis, native to the Indian subcontinent, that can cover large areas by putting down aerial roots that become subsidiary trunks.
Butea frondosa.
One of the great piśācīs.
One of the sages (ṛṣi).
In chapter 36 the name of a buddha in the distant past ({shing rgyal}). In chapter 44 the name of one of the future buddhas in this kalpa ({shing gi rgyal po}).
Father of the buddha Rāhu sūrya garbha.

“The son of Daśaratha” is actually Rāma. At the point in the Kāraṇḍavyūha where Nārāyaṇa, really Viṣṇu, rescues the kṣatriyas, he is inexplicably called by this name, which may reference a Rāma story. Rāma came to be viewed as one of the ten incarnations of Nārāyaṇa.
One of the emperors of the royal Ikṣvāku line.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Dhārmika.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Jagadraśmi (233 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Father of the buddha Kathendra.
Son of the buddha Supraṇaṣṭamoha.
Birthplace of the buddha Susthita.

One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A species of tree; Vatica robusta.
A future solitary buddha.
A buddha in the past.

One of the four heavenly groves outside the city of Sudarśana on Mount Meru. It owes its name to the fact that it was constructed by the king of the gandharvas, Citraratha (“He Who Has a Brightly-Colored Chariot”), for Kubera, king of yakṣas and god of wealth.
“The Garden of Chariots”; one of the four parks in Sudarśana city, home of Śakra (Indra) and his thirty-two gods, located on the summit of Mount Meru.
(1) A forest on the eastern face of Sumeru. (2) Śakra’s arsenal.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
(1) A forest on the eastern face of Sumeru. (2) Śakra’s arsenal.
A forest in Living on the Peak.
A buddha in the past.
This can refer to either to the sal (or sala) tree (Shorea robusta) or to a great (mahā) household (śāla). The Buddha was said to have been born and died beneath a sāla tree.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
A hardwood tree, Shorea robusta, widespread on the Indian subcontinent.
Usually identified as Shorea robusta, this is known as the kind of tree under which the Buddha was born and passed away.
Usually identified as Shorea robusta, known as the kind of tree under which the Buddha was born and passed away.
A forest located to the north of the city of Ujjayinī. The śiṃśapā is identified as the tree D albergia sissoo or Indian Rosewood in the Atharva Veda (Monier-Williams 1069.3).
Prosopis spicigera or Mimosa suma.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
Caves on the northern border of the Middle Country in a past eon.
Equivalent to Albizia lebbeck according to the Pandanus Database of Plants.
Cloth made from the bark of the valkala tree was worn by Indian ascetics but forbidden to Buddhist monks and nuns.
A realm that neighbors the Hell of Intense Heat.
The name of several types of tree.
A specific kind of mangosteen.
A buddha realm.
Maudgalyāyana’s birthplace.
A goddess of the night at the bodhimaṇḍa.
Ficus Glomerata according to the Pandanus Database of Plants.

A flowering tree that grows in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three, with flowers that can be seen from fifty leagues away and a fragrance that can be smelled from one hundred leagues away. The blossoms of this tree delight the gods of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three, who eagerly watch and rejoice in each stage of their development. The kovidāra tree is glossed as Bauhinia variegata, which also bears the common names “orchid tree” or “purple orchid tree.” The Sanskrit name of this tree indicates that it is a “purple orchid tree” (kovidāra) for either “one who circumambulates” or “one who goes on pilgrimage” (pāriyātraka).
Acacia sirissa (Monier-Williams).
(1) A river in the Swan Forest ({shis pa'i chu}). (2) A river in Godānīya ({chu bzang}).

The term usually refers to a unit of metrical verse, most commonly in Sanskrit literature a couplet of two sixteen-syllable lines (pāda) each of which can be subdivided into two half-lines of eight syllables. In the Tibetan translations a śloka is usually rendered as a four-line verse. However, the term is also used (especially in catalogues of canonical works) as a unit measuring the length of texts written in prose or in a mixture of prose and verse, in which case it simply measures thirty-two syllables. The titles of the principal Prajñā pāramitā sūtras, most of which are written in prose, identify them by including mention of their length in ślokas, usually translated in English as “in nnn lines.” The original titles, even in their long form, include only the number itself, and that this refers to the length in ślokas is by convention inferred.
Moringa oleifera.
Oroxylum indicum.
One of the epithets of Lakṣmī.
Acacia sirissa.
Symptom that may be evidence of an illness considered an impediment to ordination.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1011 .
Acorus calamus; sweet flag.
The medicinal plant Acorus calamus.
According to the Pāli Canon, a young man of the brahmin caste, son of the brahmin Taudeya (Pāli: Todeyya) of Tudigāma. He converted to Buddhism after hearing a discourse by the Buddha.
The word śukra may also refer to the female sexual fluid.
Resplendent or clear liquid; here, referring specifically to the seminal drop residing at the crown of all human bodies.
Reincarnation of Damaśrī, prince living in the past at the time of the buddha Merugandha.
A region in South India.
A country south of modern Delhi.
Lit. “having one hundred flowers,” Monier-Williams notes this term is used in the Āyurvedic work Suśrutasaṃhitā to denote the plant Anethum sowa, also known as dill.
Indian editor of the sūtra.
Son of the buddha Gandhahastin.
Also known as Wild Himalayan Cherry, Sour Cherry, and Costus Speciosus.
A buddha.
A māra; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Madhuvaktra.
The 590th buddha in the first list, 589th in the second list, and 583rd in the third list.
The 995th buddha in the first list, 994th in the second list, and 985th in the third list.
A nāga king.
The ninety-sixth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
The 368th buddha in the first list, 367th in the second list, and 362nd in the third list.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Sundarapārśva.
A bodhisattva.
A garuḍa lord. Also called Mahā bala vega sthāma.
A bodhisattva.
A river to the south of Jambudvīpa.
Son of the buddha Pratimaṇḍita locana.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Lord of the garuḍas. Also called Mahāvegadhārin.
A nāga king.
The 792nd buddha in the first list, 791st in the second list, and 781st in the third list.
A king.
The twenty-fifth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
“Unimpeded Power.” The name of a cakravartin’s precious wheel.
A nāga king.
A buddha in the distant past.
A bodhisattva; former incarnation of the Buddha.
A certain town (or sometimes two different towns) during the time of the Buddha.
A river in Jambudvīpa.
The river Śītā, also spelled Sītā (personified).
A river.
Sacred river in India.
Unidentified river. Tibetan texts refer to the source of the Indus by this name.
The editor of the Degé Kangyur (1700–1774).
Tibetan polymath, founder of Palpung (dpal spungs) Monastery (1700–1774).
A traditional Indian classification of musical instruments enumerates non-membranous percussion, membranous percussion, wind-blown, plucked string, and bowed string.
A forest in Engaging in Clarification.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Boundless Melody.
A traditional Indian classification of musical instruments enumerates non-membranous percussion, membranous percussion, wind-blown, plucked string, and bowed string.
One of the charnel grounds.
Sindh (the country around the Indus).
Vitex negundo. A member of the verbena family. Also known in English as the Chinese chaste tree, the five-leaved chaste tree, and horseshoe vitex.
Lit. “The Mountain of Sindhu.” A king of the ancient Darada kingdom, which lay in the Gilgit region of larger Kashmir, the mountainous area through which the river Indus (Sindhu) flows.
An area located in present day Pakistan.
A river.
Another name of Laṅkā.
One of the eight yakṣa generals.

Sri Laṅka, formerly Ceylon. The Rāmāyaṇa epic specified that Laṅka is inhabited by rākṣasas. Siṃhala was the name by which Laṅka was referred to in the Mahābhārata. The indigenous Buddhist population and their language is still called Singhalese.
The island of Lanka.
Present-day Śrī Laṅkā; the capital city of this island.
In Indian culture, the sound expressive of sexual excitement or pleasure.
The editor of this discourse.
A famous Tibetan translator and monk of the eighth to the ninth century.
One of the greatest Tibetan translators. He lived in the eighth to ninth century. Also known as Paltsek Rakṣita. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-058-006.html#UT22084-058-006-827 .

Literally means “open an opportunity”; it refers to the pravāraṇa, or the “lifting of restrictions” ceremony held at the end of each summer rains retreat, in which monks are given an “opportunity,” otherwise prohibited, to oppose and debate what was heard, seen, or suspected while undertaking a rains retreat.

Literally, “verbal root,” with “root” ({byings}) being a grammatical term for the word stem that forms the basis of a word. Here it refers to the Buddha’s derivation of the word bhikṣu from the term for “ornament.”
Seventh of the eight progressive sections of clear realization.
A unit of time; ten kṣaṇas equals one muhūrta.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Surūpa (92 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.

The ninth-century revision and codification of translational equivalents and procedure in Tibet. It was undertaken during the reigns of Senalek ({sad na legs}, d. 815 ᴄᴇ) and Ralpachen ({ral pa can}, r. 815–838) and resulted in the Mahāvyutpatti and Drajor Bampo Nyipa ({sgra sbyor bam po gnyis pa}), the very influential manuals of translation from Sanskrit to Tibetan.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
Mother of the buddha Rativyūha.
One of the kinnara kings.
Son of the buddha Garjitasvara.
Attendant of the buddha Yajñasvara.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Guṇasañcaya.

The name of a nakṣatra.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Alpha Hydrae in the occidental tradition.
Mother of the buddha Satya.
Son of the buddha Maṇiprabha.
“One’s fortune” in this phrase refers to the realm of birth (gati) that one experiences currently or will experience in the future as the maturation of karma, both positive and negative.
The 643rd buddha in the first list, 642nd in the second list, and 634th in the third list.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Son of the buddha Pūjya.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Arthakīrti (261 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Mother of the buddha Rāhudeva.

Mother of the buddha Puruṣadatta.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Ugra.
Mother of the buddha Ūrṇa.

Son of the buddha Jñānaśrī.
Mother of the buddha Rāhudeva.
“Fortunate Chariot,” an epithet of the Ganges.
Another name for Mahābhāgīratha, a buddha in the past.
The 315th buddha in the first list, 314th in the second list, and 309th in the third list.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Samudradatta (496 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
The current time period, thus named because a thousand buddhas will manifest during this eon.
Our present eon in which over a thousand buddhas will appear. The meaning is “good” because of the number of buddhas that will appear. In the sūtra, it is usually called bhadraka.

Literally an “incalculable eon,” though precise numbers are given for its duration. The Abhidharmakośa https://read.84000.co/translation/toh4089.html states that its name does not mean that it is in fact incalculable. The number of years in this eon differs in various sūtras. For example, it is said to be 10 to the power of 49, or 10 to the power of 63 years. Also, twenty intermediate eons (antarakalpa) are said to be one asaṃkhyeya eon, and four asaṃkhyeya eons are said to form one great eon (mahākalpa). In that case those four asaṃkhyeya eons represent the eons of the creation, presence, destruction, and absence of a world. However, it is also used, as apparently in this sūtra, to refer to the longest of all eons, including all others.
The 950th buddha in the first list, 949th in the second list, and 940th in the third list.
A deity.
Mother of the buddha Pūjya.
The name of a brahmin youth who appears in the Buddhist Jātakas.
A buddha in the past.
Birthplace of the buddha Suprabha.
Refers to the king Jyotiṣprabha in verse.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Ratnadeva.
The 711th buddha in the first list, 710th in the second list, and 700th in the third list.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Dharmeśvara (107 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
An asura city.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
Attendant of the buddha Praśāntagati.
Son of the buddha Śreṣṭha.
Name of a tathāgata.
Birthplace of the buddha Velāma.
A bodhisattva.
Name of a buddha.
A sage, originally a devotee of Maheśvara.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The 757th buddha in the first list, 756th in the second list, and 746th in the third list.
The name of an Eon in the future.
Lit. “Starlike.” Name of a future eon.

An eon following the eon called Great Renown, during which time eighty thousand ministers of the universal monarch Vast Mind (a previous incarnation of the buddha Dīpaṅkara) will awaken to buddhahood.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Shining Gem.

A precious gem that, when cut, shows a luminous star shape. This includes such gems as star sapphires, star rubies, and star topazes. In some Kangyurs written incorrectly as {sgra snang ba} and with a wide variety of other spelling renditions. Jyotīrasa is translated as {skar ma mdog} in https://read.84000.co/translation/toh113.html (Toh 113, Saddharma puṇḍarīka).
The southwestern constellation symbolizing earth.

A precious gem that, when cut, shows a luminous star shape. This includes such gems as star sapphires, star rubies, and star topazes. In some Kangyurs written incorrectly as {sgra snang ba} and with a wide variety of other spelling renditions. Jyotīrasa is translated as {skar ma mdog} in https://read.84000.co/translation/toh113.html (Toh 113, Saddharma puṇḍarīka).
Birthplace of the buddha Sudarśana.
A deva in Brahmā’s paradise.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
Attendant of the buddha Asaṅgakīrti.
Birthplace of the buddha Bhāgīrathi.
A king in another world in the distant past. A past life of King Śuddhodana. Also called Jyotiḥprabha in verse.
A buddha in an eastern realm.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.

One of the three main varieties of chrysoberyl, the third-hardest gemstone. The cat’s-eye gem (cymophane) is light green or yellow and contains the distinctive appearance of a band of light, resembling a cat’s eye. It has been mined since ancient times in India and particularly in Sri Lanka. Jyoti can mean both “light” and “star,” and in describing this jewel the Sanskrit more likely means “banner of light.” However, the Tibetan translates the term as “banner of stars.”
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one King of Sāla.
A bodhisattva present at the sūtra’s teaching. Known only from this sūtra.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva present at the sūtra’s teaching.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Cīrṇabuddhi (540 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Birthplace of the buddha Puṇyaraśmi.
A class of demons.
One of the grahas.
Son of the buddha Pradīparāja.
The name of various mythical beings.
Attendant of the buddha Niyatabuddhi.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
Mother of the buddha Subuddhi.
Attendant of the buddha Dharmakūṭa.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Madhuvaktra.
Attendant of the buddha Supakṣa.

A pupil of the Buddha who had miraculous powers. Also said to be the younger brother of Śāriputra. There were at least three pupils of the Buddha who had the name Cunda, but in this sūtra it is Mahācunda, “Great Cunda.” Not to be confused with the layperson Cunda, who gave the Buddha his last meal.

Aruṇa is the deity of the dawn in Indian mythology, personified as the sun’s charioteer, and the name refers to the morning star Venus, according to de Visser (1931), p. 24, n. 1. In this context, Aruṇa functions as a messenger for Ākāśagarbha.
A buddha realm.
Bignonia suaveolens. The Indian species of bignonia. They have trumpet-shaped flowers and the small trees are common throughout India.
A bodhisattva.
The Buddha, Dharma, and Saṅgha.
The three refuges of the Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saṅgha.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Jīvaka.

A wealthy merchant in the town of Śrāvastī who became a patron of the Buddha Śākyamuni. He bought Prince Jeta’s park, the Jetavana, to be the Buddha’s first monastery, a place where the monks could stay during the monsoon. Although his Sanskrit name is Anāthapiṇḍada, he is better known in the West by the alternative form Anāthapiṇḍika. Both mean “one who gives food to the destitute.” Pali: Anāthapiṇḍika.
Refuge taken in the Buddha, his teaching, and the assembly of followers.
A reference to the Buddha, Dharma, and Saṅgha, the “Three Jewels of Refuge.”
A kind of absorption.
A term for a bodhisattva held back from buddhahood by only a single remaining lifetime, as exemplified by Maitreya.
A kind of absorption.
A bodhisattva.

Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Vāsanottīrṇa gati.

The 975th buddha in the first list, 974th in the second list, and 965th in the third list.

Father of the buddha Kusumanetra.
The 311th buddha in the first list, 310th in the second list, and 305th in the third list.
The Buddha’s aunt and the first ordained nun.

Siddhārtha Gautama’s aunt, who raised him following his mother’s death and who later became the first woman to go forth as a member of Buddha Śākyamuni’s monastic saṅgha. Also rendered here as “Mahā prajāpatī.”

The Buddha’s mother’s sister and his step-mother. She was the mother of Nanda. She became the first bhikṣuṇī after the death of the Buddha’s father. Gautamī is the family name, the female equivalent to Gautama. The family line is said to descend from the Gautama who was one of the seven rishis that established the religion and culture of India. His sūtra specifies that a renunciant should be called a bhikṣu, have a shaved head, and wear yellow robes. Also rendered here simply as “Mahāprajāpatī.”
The Buddha’s aunt and stepmother, who became the first nun.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The maternal aunt and adoptive mother of the Buddha as well as the first woman to be ordained.
The step-mother and maternal aunt of Śākyamuni Buddha who became a nun (bhikṣuṇī) and his disciple.

Siddhārtha Gautama’s aunt, who raised him following his mother’s death and who later became the first woman to go forth as a member of Buddha Śākyamuni’s monastic saṅgha. Also rendered here as “Mahā prajāpatī.”
A god.
Name of a god (deva).
A legendary king before the time of the Buddha.
One of the five goddesses personifying the five “hooks of gnosis.”
The “lord of creatures,” a Hindu god presiding over procreation and the protector of life.
A god.
The mythical preceptor of the gods.
Son of the buddha Pūrṇacandra.
Attendant of the buddha Pramodyakīrti.
These comprise six inner sense fields and six outer sense fields. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-148 and respective glossary entries.

Twelve collections of similar dharmas under which all compounded and uncompounded dharmas may be included: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, mind, and their objects—visible forms, sounds, smells, flavors, tangibles, and dharmas.
The fifth of the twelve links of dependent origination. See “dependent origination.”
Each field comprises one of the six senses with its respective sense-consciousness and the range of objects accessible to it.
The five senses and their objects, plus the mind and phenomena known to the mind. Together they comprise the fifth of the twelve links of dependent origination.

The six sense organs of eyes, ears, nose, tongue, tactile sense, and mind, together with their respective objects of forms, sounds, smells, flavors, tactile objects, and mental objects. See also “sense source.”

Six sets of similar dharmas under which all compounded and uncompounded dharmas may be included: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, mind, and their objects‍—visible forms, sounds, smells, flavors, tangibles, and dharmas.

Fifth of the twelve links of dependent origination, it consists of the six sense organs (eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, and thinking mind) together with their respective objects (forms, sounds, smells, tastes, touch, and dharmas).
Lit. “their gates to the sense fields are excellent;” thirty-sixth of the eighty minor marks.
A bodhisattva.
Sixteenth of the eighty minor marks.

Sometimes translated “sense field” or “base of cognition,” the term usually refers to the six sense faculties and their corresponding objects, i.e. the first twelve of the eighteen constituents (Skt. dhātus). Along with the aggregates (Skt. skandhas) and the constituents, one of the three major categories in the taxonomy of phenomena in the sūtra literature.

The six bases of sensory perception are the six sensory faculties: the eyes, nose, ear, tongue, body, and mind, which form in the womb but as yet have no contact with the external six bases of sensory perception: form, smell, sound, taste, touch, and phenomena. In another context in this sūtra, āyatana refers to the four formless meditations (see “liberations”).

Twelve bases of sensory perception: the six sensory faculties (the eyes, nose, ear, tongue, body, and mind), which form in the womb and eventually have contact with the external six bases of sensory perception (form, smell, sound, taste, touch, and phenomena). This can also refer to the four meditative states associated with the formless realm: (1) infinite space, (2) infinite consciousness, (3) nothingness, and (4) neither perception nor nonperception.

The sense spheres are a collective list of the six sense objects (forms, sounds, odors, tastes, textures, mental phenomena) with their respective senses (eye, ear, nose, tongue, tactile sense, and mind) totaling twelve and indicating their interdependence. In this sūtra, they are equated to an “empty city.” This most likely denotes the fact that there is no self independent of the interaction of these or perceiver independent of the process of perception.

The twelve sense-media are eye-medium (cakṣurāyatana), form-medium (rūpa-), ear-medium (śrotra-), sound-medium (śabda-), nose-medium (ghrāna-), scent-medium (gandha-), tongue-medium (jihvā-), taste-medium (rasa-), body-medium (kāya-), texture-medium (spraṣṭavya), mental-medium (mana-), and phenomena-medium (dharmāyatana). In some passages they are enumerated as six, the object-faculty pair being taken as one, and it is this set of six that is the fifth member of the twelve links of dependent origination. The word āyatana is usually translated as “base,” but the Skt., Tib., and Ch. all indicate “something through which the senses function” rather than a basis from which they function; hence “medium” is suggested.

These can be listed as twelve or as six entrances (sometimes also called sense sources, sense fields, bases of cognition, or simply āyatanas):\nIn context of epistemology, it is one way of describing experience and the world in terms of twelve sense sources, which can be divided into inner and outer sense sources, namely: 1-2) eye and form, 3-4) ear and sound, 5-6) nose and odor, 7-8) tongue and taste, 9-10) body and touch, 11-12) mind and mental phenomena. (These are subsumed in the eighteen bases or elements, where to the twelve sense sources, the six consciousnesses are added.)\nIn the context of the twelve links of dependent origination, only six sense sources are mentioned and they are the inner sense sources (similar to the six faculties) of eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
A demon leader.

Six sets of similar dharmas under which all compounded and uncompounded dharmas may be included: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, mind, and their objects—visible forms, sounds, smells, flavors, tangibles, and dharmas. The fifth of the twelve parts of dependent arising. Another name for the “twelve entrances.”
A great bodhisattva.
A forest of the asuras.
One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife.
A grove in Supreme Strength.
One of the auxiliary charnel grounds.
A virtuous nāga king who was a bodhisattva.
The first of the two stages of tantric practice focused on the visualized development of the tantric maṇḍala and its deities and the recitation of mantra.
Birthplace of the buddha Sudarśana.
A virtuous nāga king.
A race of beings said to live in the Himalayas who have bodies of lions and human heads.
Mother of the buddha Dṛḍha.

A variation on the more usual set of 32 such marks; this set is mentioned only in this sūtra and in three others: the Gaṇḍa vyūha (ch. 45 of Toh 44), the Tathā gatācintya guhya nirdeśa (Toh 47), and the longest Sāgara mati paripṛcchā (Toh 153). None of these texts give a list.
For their enumeration in this text, see https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-029-001.html#UT22084-029-001-5641 .
The main identifying physical characteristics of both buddhas and universal monarchs, to which are added the so-called “eighty minor marks.”
The thirty-two major signs of a buddha that manifest as specific physical attributes to indicate the perfection of the awakened state of buddhahood.
Thirty-two of the 112 identifying physical characteristics of both buddhas and universal monarchs, in addition to the so-called “eighty minor marks.” For a detailed list see Berzin (2012).
The set of thirty-two physical marks that identify both a buddha and a universal monarch (cakravartin); in the case of the former they indicate the perfection of the awakened state of buddhahood.

Thirty-two of the 112 identifying physical characteristics of both buddhas and cakravartins, in addition to the eighty excellent signs. There are significant variations found in this list from source to source. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-060-001.html#UT22084-060-001-74 .

Thinking that one will (1) eliminate the suffering of beings, (2) lead beings to wealth and affluence, (3) benefit beings with one’s own flesh and blood, (4) benefit beings even if it means remaining in the hells for a long time, and (5) never be reborn with wealth or power that does not benefit beings, that focuses solely on the ultimate, or that causes harm to beings; (6) that beings’ negative actions will ripen upon oneself, and one’s positive actions will ripen upon them; (7) that one will fulfill the wishes of beings through great worldly and supramundane riches; and (8) that one will become a buddha and thus deliver beings from suffering.
Someone who will become a buddha or a cakravartin, whose bodies are adorned with the thirty-two major marks and the eighty minor signs.

A list of sixteen bodhisattvas headed by Bhadrapāla, mentioned in many sūtras as present in the audience. Unlike many other great bodhisattvas, they are all householders. Their names are—according to https://read.84000.co/translation/toh113.html#UT22084-051-001-164 (Toh 113): Bhadrapāla, Ratnākara, Susārthavāha, Naradatta, Guhyagupta, Varuṇadatta, Indradatta, Uttaramati, Viśeṣamati, Vardhamānamati, Amoghadarśin, Susaṃprasthita, Su vikrānta vikrāmiṇ, Anupamamati, Sūryagarbha, and Dharaṇīṃdhara.
Listed in the audience of bodhisattvas present in the retinue attending Śākyamuni. Their identity is unknown.
Another name of the Rāṣṭrapāla paripṛcchā sūtra.
An epithet for the Buddha. Also the ideal man, a good or wise man.
The 707th buddha in the first list, 706th in the second list, and 696th in the third list.
This refers stream enterers, once-returners, non-returners, and arhats, along with those practicing to attain the realizations of those states.
The 245th buddha in the first list, 244th in the second list, and 244th in the third list.
A synonym for the wood splint used as a sundial to mark time in ordination ceremonies.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Jagatpūjita.
The 555th buddha in the first list, 555th in the second list, and 548th in the third list.
Someone born with both male and female sexual organs. One of the five types of person labeled a paṇḍaka, all of whom are barred from joining the renunciate order.
A great bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Praśāntagati.
A buddha.
One among the twelve sections of scripture.
One of the “twelve branches of excellent speech.”
One of the twelve branches of Buddhist scriptures.
Particularly the former lives of Lord Buddha.
The canonical narratives of the Buddha’s previous births.
The Buddha’s accounts of his own previous lifetimes, listed as one of the twelve aspects of the wheel of Dharma.
As one of the twelve aspects of the Dharma, it means accounts of the Buddha’s previous lifetimes.\nSee also “twelve wheels of the Dharma.”

A man, a male; in Sāṃkhya philosophy this term denotes that aspect of consciousness that is separate and independent from matter. Outside of this context, puruṣa (Tib. {skyes bu}) has been translated as “man” or “human.”
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Vikrama.
Eighth of the twelve branches of the scriptures.
A story of one of the Buddha’ s former lives.
The Buddha’s accounts of his own previous lifetimes. One of the nine aspects of the Dharma according to this sūtra. More commonly there are said to be twelve that include these nine.
Mother of the buddha Dṛḍhasaṃdhi.

In this ninth-century Tibetan translation, Dhanyākara is translated as “Source of Happiness.” More common is the translation {'bras spung}, meaning “Rice Heap.” The famous Gelugpa monastery Drepung takes its name from this city, which was the capital of the kingdom of the Satavahana dynasty that ruled South India from the first to third century ce. Known primarily as Dhānyakaṭaka, the present remains are in the village of Dharaṇikoṭa, a few miles from the site of the great Amarāvatī stupa, in Andhra Pradesh on the southeastern coast of India. Before 1953 this was in the state of Madras.
Symptom that may be evidence of an illness considered an impediment to ordination.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1011 .
There are two versions of ardhaparyaṅka posture—one sitting, the other dancing. In the CMT, this term refers to the former.
There are two versions of the ardhaparyaṅka posture—one sitting, the other dancing.
A realm of the triple-lute-bearer gods.

There are two versions of ardhaparyaṅka posture: the first is sitting with one foot drawn in and the other extended, and the second is dancing. Wrathful deities, such as Krodharāja, tend to assume the latter. In this posture the deity is standing on the tips of their toes with their left leg slightly bent, while the right leg, with the knee pointing to the right, kicks upward to the height of the left knee.
Name of a buddha realm in the east where the buddha Intent on Accomplishing Aims through Steadfast Skill resides.
An ocean between Godānīya and Videha.
An acceptable form of food for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
A buddha.
Father of the buddha Sūryānana.
A bodhisattva.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
Birthplace of the buddha Prahāṇakhila.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Akṣobhyavarṇa.
While “immaturity” (āma, {skyon}) suggests rawness—something that is uncooked, unrefined, and flawed— here the term “maturity” implies certitude, refinement, cooking, softening, and flawlessness.
A buddha.
Attendant of the buddha Vimalaprabha.
Son of the buddha Āśādatta.
A forest in Moving Mind.
Attendant of the buddha Baladatta.
This word is also understood as equivalent to niyāma (“certain”).
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Ratnakrama.
Attendant of the buddha Bhasmakrodha.
