Birthplace of the buddha Arajas.
Attendant of the buddha Sadgaṇin.
Father of the buddha Atula pratibhāna rāja.
The 730th buddha in the first list, 729th in the second list, and 719th in the third list.
While “immaturity” (āma, {skyon}) suggests rawness—something that is uncooked, unrefined, and flawed— here the term “maturity” implies certitude, refinement, cooking, softening, and flawlessness.
The 144th buddha in the first list, 144th in the second list, and 144th in the third list.
Birthplace of the buddha Adoṣa.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Sujāta.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Guṇārci (222 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.

In this case, “guardians” seems to refer to the Four Great Kings of the cardinal directions, namely, Vaiśravaṇa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, Virūḍhaka, and Virūpākṣa, who pledged to protect the Dharma and practitioners.
This term suggests rawness—something that is uncooked, unrefined, and flawed—while “maturity” (niyāma, {skyon ma mchis pa}) implies certitude, refinement, cooking, softening, and flawlessness.
A realm of the triple-lute-bearer gods.
Phyllanthus emblica.
Emblic myrobalan, Phyllanthus emblica.
The Indian gooseberry (Phyllanthus emblica).

The Indian gooseberry, or emblic myrobalan. The simile of an āmalakī in the palm of one’s hand is used to illustrate yogic perception (yogipratyakṣa) where the clarity aspect (compared to a crystal) is emphasized. See, e.g., Dharmottara’s Nyāyabindhuṭīkā 1.11. It is also used to illustrate omniscience, or seeing all aspects of things, probably on the analogy of being able to see through the semi-transparent skin of the berry into its interior structure.
Symptom that may be evidence of an illness considered an impediment to ordination\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1011 .
Sour gruel.

Among other things, this term is applied to the sour fermented remainder from beer brewing, certain types of lemons, and the sour part of yogurt. Here it refers to overly sour liquids in general, such as overly fermented vinegar.
Name of the bhūmis from the path of seeing on, from which point there is no regression.
Female attendants who normally assisted the wife of a wealthy householder.
Tinaspora cordifolia.
A city.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Thus-Gone King, Guru of Immeasurably Many.
Lit. “The tight fist of the [bad] teacher.”
Literally “not being a tight-fisted teacher,” this term denotes a teacher who freely gives appropriate teachings to their disciples.
Teacher or master, especially a spiritual master. The term is rendered elsewhere in this translation as “ācārya.”
In early Buddhism, a teacher who teaches the Dharma and Vinaya to novices and new monks, and who can replace the preceptor (Skt. upādhyāya), if one loses one’s preceptor.
A spiritual teacher, meaning one who knows the conduct or practice (carya) to be performed. It can also be a title for a scholar, though that is not the context in this sūtra.
Instructor or spiritual teacher. Usually refers either to an accomplished master of meditation practice or to a learned scholar. The title of an official position in a monastery.

A traditional Indian title denoting a person who has authority because of superior knowledge, spiritual training, or position. In the Buddhist context, it is most often used for a scholar of great renown.

Along with the position of preceptor, this is one of two official positions created by the Buddha to ensure that new monks would receive sufficient training. The Buddha specified five types of instructor: instructors of novices, privy advisors, officiants, givers of instruction, and recitation instructors.
Son of the brahmin Agnidatta in the country of Pāṭaliputra, a monk and Tripiṭaka master whose murder at the hands of Sūrata’s disciples hastens the Dharma’s disappearance from this world.
Those who belong to any of the first to seventh of the eight stages of spiritual achievement, the eighth being that of an arhat, who needs no further training.
The state of a person who has not yet attained arhatship.
A captain; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Those with a particular physical condition considered an impediment to ordination.
Literally, “cannot be disliked.”
The realm of the Buddha Protector of Glory.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Cārulocana.
One of five types of disciplinary acts meted out by the saṅgha.
A buddha realm.
The 915th buddha in the first list, 914th in the second list, and 905th in the third list.
Solanum xanthocarpum.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A pore on Avalokiteśvara’s body.
Twenty-fourth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata. This term is applied to a number of different medicinal herbs or herb mixtures.
A minister who was the Buddha in a former life.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Padma.
The 534th buddha in the first list, 534th in the second list, and 527th in the third list.

Name of a bodhisattva, a hero of a jātaka who was a learned advisor to a king. In the Ummagga jātaka, he skillfully employs violence, but only when it is absolutely necessary to safeguard his country and its people.
Birthplace of the buddha Mahauṣadhi.
The buddha of medicine.
Teacher of Medicine, King of Vaiḍūrya Light.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the eight tathāgatas.
A short form of the name of Bhaiṣajya guru vaiḍūrya prabha, the Medicine Buddha.
Son of the buddha Ratna.
A buddha who resides in the eastern buddha realm called Possessing Immutability.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Name of a bodhisattva, “King of Medicine.”
A bodhisattva present at the sūtra’s teaching.
Literally, “King of Medicine.” Name of a bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Vajrasena.

Lit. “King of Healers.” In the story of Śākyamuni’s former life in this sūtra, he is the tathāgata of the universe Mahāvyūha, during the eon called Vicaraṇa, who taught Prince Candracchattra about Dharma-worship. In later Buddhism, this buddha is believed to be the supernatural patron of healing and medicine.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva.
Father of the buddha Vidyutketu.
Attendant of the buddha Puṇyapriya.
Father of the buddha Lokasundara.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Yaśoratna.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A great bodhisattva.
A highly skilled healer and personal physician of Buddha Śākyamuni, he figures into many stories of the Buddha, his disciples, and other associates.
Father of the buddha Acyuta.
The last of five hundred buddhas in a kalpa in the distant future.
The 239th buddha in the first list, 238th in the second list, and 238th in the third list.
Father of the buddha Mahendra.
The 33rd buddha in the first list, 33rd in the second list, and 34th in the third list.
Inula racemosa.
The 536th buddha in the first list, 536th in the second list, and 529th in the third list.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Dhārmika.
Name of a bodhisattva, “Medicine-Risen Up.”
One of the bodhisattva great beings.
A bodhisattva present at the sūtra’s teaching.
A bodhisattva.
The name of a karmic wind involved in the formation of an embryo in its twenty-seventh week.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
Father of the buddha Ratnākara.
Birthplace of the buddha Vidyutprabha.

In the Cakra saṃvara-tantra, rocanā is a medical concretion or bezoar stone found within the organs of certain animals (Gray, 2007, p 207 n3). Alternatively, Monier-Williams identifies it as “a particular yellow pigment,” or even a plant. It is unclear to us what the term refers to in this particular context.
A goddess.
Universe of the Buddha Duṣprasāhā.
A world system that existed thirty eons ago.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
Son of Śiva and a Hindu god of war.
The name of a nakṣatra.
Divine son of Śiva and Pārvatī.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Pleiades in the occidental tradition.

Gyurme Dorje ({'gyur med rdo rje}), the first throneholder of Mindroling ({smin grol gling}), also known as Terdak Lingpa ({gter bdag gling pa}), a great scholar, author, and discoverer of spiritual treasures (1646–1714).
One of the vidyārājñīs attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the marks of a buddha. A tuft of hair between the eyebrows capable of projecting a very bright light.

Listed in The Question of Mañjuśrī as the fifth of the thirty-two signs of a great being. The ūrṇā or the “hair-treasure” ({mdzod spu}) is the circlet of hair between the Buddha’s eyebrows. In the Mahāvyutpatti this sign is expressed without mention of the eyebrows, (ūrṇākeśa; {mdzod spu}).
A town in Videha.
A hypothetical buddha.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha countless eons in the past.
The four aspirations of bodhisattvahood defined variously in East Asian Mahāyāna works.
The ninety-eighth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS in verse: Mahā praṇidhi vega śiri.
A great bodhisattva.
The term for aspirations such as helping all beings, generating a buddhafield, bringing all beings to perfect awakening, and so forth that a bodhisattva makes while practicing bodhisattva conduct.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Glory of the Protection by Knowledge.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Amitābha.
Mañjuśrī's future buddha realm when he awakens as Samantadarśin.
A bodhisattva from King Jewel Mound’s buddha realm.
The buddha realm of Fully Illuminated Oceanic King of Many Hundreds of Virtues.
A future buddha.
Son of the buddha Aśoka.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Adīnaghoṣa (553 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A buddha.
The name of the eighty-first buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Praṇidhāna sāgara prabhāsa śirī.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A great bodhisattva.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Priyacandra (770 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A buddha.
One of the ten perfections.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Abhijñāketu.
A declaration of one’s aspirations and vows, and/or an invocation and request of the buddhas, bodhisattvas, etc. It is also one of the ten perfections.
One of the three gateways to liberation.
A bodhisattva.
The third of the three doorways to liberation. The other two are emptiness (śūnyatā; {stong pa nyid}) and signlessness (animitta; {mtshan ma med pa}).
The absence of any conceptual goal that one is focused upon achieving, knowing that all composite phenomena create suffering. One of the three doorways to liberation.
The ultimate absence of any wish, desire, or aspiration, even those directed towards buddhahood. One of the three gateways to liberation; the other two are emptiness and signlessness.
One of the three gateways to liberation, it is the absence of any conceptual goal one may be focused on achieving; it comes about from knowing that all composite phenomena create suffering.

Third of the Three Doors of Liberation (see glossary). Objectively, it is equivalent to voidness; subjectively, it is the outcome of the holy gnosis of voidness as the realization of the ultimate lack of anything to wish for, whether voidness itself, or even Buddhahood. See “emptiness.”

Emptiness ({stong pa nyid}), signlessness ({mtshan ma med pa}), and wishlessness ({smon pa med pa}) are known as the “three doors to deliverance” (triṇi vimokṣa mukhāni) or the “three concentrations” (trayaḥ samādhyaḥ) and as a set appear in both mainstream Buddhist sūtras and Mahāyāna sūtras. See Conze 1962, pp. 59–69; Lamotte 1944, pp. 1213–15; and Deleanu 2000, pp. 74–78.
Mother of the buddha Amitadhara.
One of the six outsider teachers.
One of the six teachers at the time of the Buddha.
One of the six philosophical extremists who lived during the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
One of the six philosophical extremists who lived during the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
A brahmin.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya guru vaiḍūrya prabha rāja sūtra.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Dharmākara.
Mother of the buddha Siṃhaghoṣa.
Birthplace of the buddha Arthavādin.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Prasannabuddhi.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Mahāraśmi.
Birthplace of the buddha Kathendra.
Birthplace of the buddha Harivaktra.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Vikrīḍitāvin.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The 603rd buddha in the first list, 602nd in the second list, and 596th in the third list.
A two-headed hand drum that is played horizontally, wider in the middle with one drum head smaller than the other. Seventy-second of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
The name of a nakṣatra.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Antares in the occidental tradition.
A forest in the territory ruled by King Bimbisāra.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A wheel-turning king in the past.
The 463rd buddha in the first list, 462nd in the second list, and 456th in the third list.
Mother of the buddha Mahādatta.
Mother of the buddha Lokaprabha.
(1) A disciple of the Buddha. (2) A buddha in the past.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Viṣāṇin.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Gagana (755 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.

Child of householders in Śrāvastī, eventually ordained. At the time of his entrance into the womb and again upon his birth a rain of jasmine flowers fell. He went on to attain arhatship and various spiritual qualities from the cause of having scattered loose jasmine petals over, and having made offerings and prayers to reliquary stūpas in a previous life.
May also mean a type of jasmine.
Jasminum grandiflorum. Also known as Spanish or Catalonian jasmine, even though it originates from South India. Particularly used as offerings in both Buddhist and Hindu temples.
Chief editor of the Tibetan translation of The White Lotus of the Good Dharma and the translation program from the late eighth to early ninth century in Tibet. From the Nanam ({sna nam}) clan.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Meruprabha (873 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Birthplace of the buddha Ratnaketu.
A great bodhisattva.
(1) A king in the past ({thams cad kyi bshes gnyen}). (2) A rṣi in the past ({sna tshogs bshes}).
Son of the buddha Śāntimati.
A certain householder of the country of Mithilā.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Keturāṣṭra (665 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Kṣatriya (653 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
The twenty-third buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Citrārtha-indra .
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Dharaṇīśvara (195 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Somacchattra (498 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
“Omnifarious One” is the name/epithet of various deities, but in particular of Viṣṇu in his viśvarūpa aspect.
A town near the Himalayan mountains which is one of the settings of this sūtra.
A pore on Avalokiteśvara’s body.
Name of a buddha realm in the east where the buddha Glory of Being Renowned for Superior Skill That Is Noble like Mount Meru resides.
Birthplace of the buddha Atula pratibhāna rāja.
A buddha.
Name of a bodhisattva.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
Two crossed vajras.
A buddha realm.
The name of a goddess.
Birthplace of the buddha Girīndrakalpa.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the eight nāga ladies.
Son of the buddha Prabhāsthita kalpa.
Son of the buddha Yaśoratna.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the groves of the Trāyastriṃśa (Heaven of the Thirty-Three) gods.
An absorption.
A king of vidyādharas.
One of the seven kings mentioned in the story of Govinda.
A river.
A buddha realm.
(1) A grove in Lateral ({sna tshogs}). (2) A forest at Sudharma ({bkra ba}).
(1) A realm of the ever-infatuated gods. (2) A river in Dwelling on Summits.
A prominent nose, i.e. with a high nasal root, was considered an attractive feature in ancient India. This may refer to an aquiline nose.
Seventh of the eighteen sensory elements.
Ninth of the eighteen sensory elements.
One of the eighteen constituents.
Third of the twelve sense fields.
A nāga king. This might be another name for the attested nāga king Upakambala. See Edgerton (1985).
Curtains of pearl necklaces suspended from the walls of the inner rectangle of the maṇḍala.
Monks’ robes are to be sewn into large sections from small patches of cloth rather than bolts of cloth.
One of a Buddhist monk’s three robes
The outer robe put over the other garments. One of the three Dharma robes ({chos gos gsum}, tricīvara).
One of the three robes of a monk. This robe is a shawl with thirty-two patches, allowed for fully ordained monks.
One of the three robes of a Buddhist monastic, which is worn on occasions such as almsbegging and the community’s formal meeting.

The outer robe worn by fully ordained monks on formal occasions, including teachings and begging for alms, is fashioned of patches, their number indicative of the monastic order to which they belong‌. See, e.g., Zhang Yisun et al (1985): 1594–1595.
A deity in the retinue of Śakra.
The name of an eon in the past.
Refers to night goddess Pramudita nayana jagad virocanā.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Raśmijāla (687 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A bodhisattva in, and principle protagonist of, The Teaching by the Child Inconceivable Radiance. This is also the name he will have as a buddha in the future, as prophesied by the Buddha.
Name of the thirty-sixth meditative stability.
Lit. “light maker.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Arthavādin.
Mother of the buddha Sucandra.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Vilocana.
One of the mahoraga kings.
A buddha realm.
A world system.
Mother of the buddha Rāhucandra.
The realm of the Buddha Illuminator.
The realm where Adorned with Various Jewels will become a buddha.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Image of Mount Sumeru.
The world of the past buddha King Rhythm of a Lion’s Roar.
A great bodhisattva.

The name of the eon in the future in which Siṃha and his attendants are prophesied to become buddhas by the Buddha Śākyamuni. This name varies significantly in the Chinese versions of Siṃha’s Questions (see https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-044-001.html#UT22084-044-001-167 ).
The lowest of the three paradises that correspond to the second dhyāna in the form realm. The lowest of the paradises that are never destroyed at the end of the kalpa but continue through all kalpas.
Name of the forty-eighth meditative stability.
Lit. “pure and radiant.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
A buddhafield in the western direction of the Tathāgata Illuminator.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one King of the Drum’s Melody.
Birthplace of the buddha Candra.
The 887th buddha in the first list, 886th in the second list, and 877th in the third list.
The 1004th buddha in the first list, 1003rd in the second list, and 994th in the third list.
Mother of the buddha Devasūrya.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Praśāntagāmin.
Mother of the buddha Anihata.
Birthplace of the buddha Ābhāsaraśmi.
Name of the thirty-fifth meditative stability.
A great bodhisattva.
Birthplace of the buddha Avabhāsadarśin.
A buddha who lives in a western buddha realm called Excellence.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Tejorāśi.
The Buddha of boundless light; one of the five Tathāgatas in Tantrism; a visitor in Vimalakīrti’s house, according to the goddess’s report.
More commonly known as Amitāyus in the sūtras, he is the buddha of the western realm of Sukhāvatī. Rebirth in that realm has been an important goal since early Mahāyāna.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
A buddha in the distant past. BHS verse: Obhāsa sāgara viyūha.
Father of the buddha Ābhāsaraśmi.
“Attainment of Light,” the world in which Kāśyapa will become a buddha.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with Immaculate Light.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha in the distant past. BHS verse: Obhāsayanta prabha rājā.
The 649th buddha in the first list, 648th in the second list, and 640th in the third list.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Raśmirāja.
A bodhisattva.
The guardian deity of the Buddha’s monastery in Veṇuvana.
A buddha in the distant past.
Father of the buddha Jyotiṣprabha.
The sixty-fourth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha who lives in a buddha realm below called Vast Expanse.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Siṃharaśmi (664 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Asita (443 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Jñānarāja.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Pradīparāja.
A buddha in the distant past.
The name of the eighth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. Also the name of the twenty-seventh buddha in a different kalpa in the distant past. BHS: Obhāsarāja.
A bodhisattva residing in a buddha realm in the western direction during the time of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
Birthplace of the buddha Candrānana.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Candrānana.
Birthplace of the buddha Ketumat.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Roca.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Adoṣa (719 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
“Display of Radiance,” the name of a certain kalpa in the distant past.
A buddha realm.
One of the mahoraga kings.
Attendant of the buddha Arthavādin.

The last buddha of the Bhadra kalpa, which according to The White Lotus of Compassion Sūtra (Toh 111, Mahā karuṇā puṇḍarīka sūtra,https://read.84000.co/translation/toh111.html where it was translated as {gsal mdzad}) is the thousand-and-fifth buddha. The Buddha Ratnagarbha prophesied that the youngest of the thousand Vedapāṭhaka pupils of Brahmin Samudrarenu would be the Buddha Roca. In present times it is most commonly translated as {mos pa}.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Indrama.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha.
Attendant of the buddha Jñānarata.
Son of the buddha Prajñāna vihāsa svara.
A bodhisattva in attendance as the Buddha delivers this teaching.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Ratnābhacandra.
Attendant of the buddha Tiṣya.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Ratnaskandha (796 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Son of the buddha Acala.
Father of the buddha Cīrṇabuddhi.
Attendant of the buddha Anāvilārtha.
The 416th buddha in the first list, 415th in the second list, and 409th in the third list.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Ajitagaṇa (326 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A future buddha.
One of the tathāgatas.
The universal buddha from whom all the buddhas emanate.
Mentioned by the Buddha as the last of the thousand buddhas of this eon.
The 1004th buddha in the first list, 1003rd in the second list, and 994th in the third list.
The last buddha to come in the present Fortunate Eon, according to https://read.84000.co/translation/toh94.html (Bhadrakalpikasūtra), Toh 94.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The wife of the Moon.
The name of a nakṣatra.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Aldebaran in the occidental tradition.
Prognostication, foreshadowing.
Mother of the buddha Suvarṇacūḍa.
A class of vidyādharas.
One of ten different kinds of verbal phrase or statement (Skt. pada) mentioned in this text.
Another name for the Vajrayāna.
One of the three vehicles of Buddhism.
The “Mantra Vehicle,” which is another name for Vajrayāna.
Knot which has been incanted with the mantra while being tied.
A practitioner of mantra; a follower of the Mantra Vehicle.
Words of power; incantation; lit. “mind-protector”; single or combined Sanskrit syllables repeated as invocations, based on the power of sound (Rigzin 98).

Literally “an instrument of thought,” it is usually a brief verbal formula used with multiple repetitions, usually beginning with oṃ and in essence a salutation to a particular deity. It can also be used as a healing spell, which is the meaning here.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
A householder.
Name of a former incarnation of Devadatta in a story the Buddha tells.
One of the yakṣiṇīs.
Son of the buddha Gaṇiprabha.
A river on Flocking Peacocks.
A great bodhisattva.
A period of formal practice, usually lasting six months, before the practitioner can employ the mantra for specific purposes.
“Preliminary practice,” pūrvasevā, is a six-month period of formal practice to be performed before one can start employing the mantra for specific purposes.
The early ordination rite, later adapted to include stricter criteria for admission and introduce the intermediate step, between joining the order and ordination, of induction into the novitiate.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
Fifth of the six extrasensory powers.
One of the five supernormal knowledges.
Ninth of the ten powers of the tathāgatas.
A buddha in the distant past.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A king; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
A buddha field in the future where the bodhisattva Saffron Color attains buddhahood as Precious Light.
Name of a yakṣa.
An ocean off Jambudvīpa.
A brahmin.
The name of Prince Kuśa disguised as a cook.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
Lit. “become a vessel.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
The twelfth of the eighteen special qualities of a bodhisattva.
Lit. “nonsequential.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Lit. “topsy-turvy”; in a mixed order. Also translated here as “loosely organized” and “perverted.” See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-057-006.html#UT22084-057-006-156 .
The name of a nakṣatra.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Lambda Scorpii in the occidental tradition.
In this context, a ritual object used in rituals of enthrallment.
The term is also rendered in this translation as “apūpa.”
A pastry made of flour. Also rendered in this translation as “pastry.”
A type of worm ({srin bu}) that lives in and feeds on the body.
Son of the buddha Pūrṇamati.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Praśāntagātra (628 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Attendant of the buddha Amitasvara.
The name of the Tathāgata Aparimitāyus’ attendant.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Arhatkīrti.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
Birthplace of the buddha Brahmagāmin.
The name of an eon (kalpa).
A head merchant in the distant past.
A location in Mutual Liking.
Father of the buddha Padmagarbha.
Son of the buddha Vikrīḍitāvin.
A buddha.
A monk.
The 17th buddha in the first list, 17th in the second list, and not listed in the third list.
Mother of the buddha Puṇya.
Son of the buddha Satyaketu.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Saṃpannakīrti (512 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Siṃhapakṣa (303 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Prasanna.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Prasanna.
Birthplace of the buddha Mokṣavrata.
Attendant of the buddha Sarvatejas.
Son of the buddha Vajrasena.
Mother of the buddha Ratnayaśas.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Maruttejas.
The 925th buddha in the first list, 924th in the second list, and 915th in the third list.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Vidyutprabha.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
One of the four means of attraction.
Second of the four attractive qualities of a bodhisattva.
Son of the buddha Ratnaprabha.
Mother of the buddha Sudarśana.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Manoratha.
A buddha realm.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

Along with the Ṛgveda, Yajurveda, and Atharvaveda, one of the four Vedas, the most ancient Sanskrit religious literature of India. It primarily contains melodic notations for the chanting of Vedic hymns.
The last and worst of the four ages (yuga), the present age of degeneration.
Five types of degeneration pertaining to lifespan, affliction, beings, time, and views.
Five signs that the later era of an eon has arrived: degenerate views, afflictions, beings, lifespan, and time.
The five degenerations are those of the lifespan, of views, of afflictions, of sentient beings, and of the age.
Five particular aspects of life that indicate the degenerate nature of a given age. They are the impurities of views, of afflictions, of sentient beings, of life, and of time.
The five degenerations: (1) degeneration of lifespan, (2) degeneration of view or thoughts, (3) degeneration of the five afflictions, (4) degenerate sentient beings, (5) degenerate times.

In this text, the five degenerations are: (1) the degeneration of time, (2) the degeneration of sentient beings, (3) the degeneration of place, (4) the degeneration of lifespan, and (5) the degeneration of mental afflictions. This differs from other presentations of this list in which the degeneration of views replaces the degeneration of place.
Refers to the five degenerations: (1) degeneration of lifespan, (2) degeneration of view or thoughts, (3) degeneration of the five afflictions, (4) degenerate sentient beings, (5) degenerate times.
Name of a buddha realm located in the southern direction during the time of the Buddha Śākyamuni.

Also known as “five contaminations or degenerations” ({snyigs ma lnga}, pañcakaṣāya). They are: (1) degeneration of lifespan, (2) degeneration of view or thoughts, (3) degeneration of the five afflictions, (4) degeneration of sentient beings, (5) degeneration of time.
Refers to the five degenerations: (1) degeneration of lifespan, (2) degeneration of view or thoughts, (3) degeneration of the five afflictions, (4) degenerate sentient beings, (5) degenerate times.
The 867th buddha in the first list, 866th in the second list, and 856th in the third list.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

The exact place where every buddha in this world will manifest the attainment of buddhahood. In our world, it is the spot beneath the Bodhi tree in the village presently known as Bodhgaya. Literally, “the essence of enlightenment.” Also translated elsewhere as {byang chub kyi snying po}.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A buddha realm.
The realm of the Buddha Heart of the Doctrine.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Sublime Golden Light.
Name of the 100th meditative stability.
Lit. “having a core.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Emanating Light.
One among a list of eight uṣṇīṣa buddhas mentioned in this text that do not appear elsewhere in the canon.

The identity of the five essences is uncertain; they are only a few mentions of the term in Kangyur, none of which identify what they are. According to most Tibetan dictionaries, such as the dung dkar tshig mdzod chen mo, they are honey ({sbrang rtsi}), raw sugar ({bu ram}), salt ({tshwa}), ghee ({zhun mar}), and sesame oil ({til mar}). Rotman notes that Ayurveda sources also list the five essences as “milk, sugar, honey, ghee, and long pepper (Piper longum).” See Rotman (2017), p. 543, n. 571.
Birthplace of the buddha Arthadarśin.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Siddhārtha.
Attendant of the buddha Kusumadeva.
Birthplace of the buddha Candra.
A buddha.
Lit. “following all essences.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
The second Mauryan emperor, son of Candragupta.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Well-Settled Ocean.
Name of a buddha realm located in the western direction during the time of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
A buddha.
“Accumulation of Essences.” The name of a kalpa in the distant past.
Lit “heart” or “marrow.”
Attendant of the buddha Amitalocana.
The most essential mantra of a deity.
Literally “heart,” this term means the heart essence or the essence of the deity and can refer to its mantra, mudrā, or maṇḍala.
The name of a kalpa in the distant past.

Son of the Vaiśālī army chief Siṃha at the time of the Buddha’s stay there, he was sentenced to death for the murder of a prostitute. The Buddha secured his release, ordained him, and he attained arhatship.

This name refers to two people in this text: (1) A captain; a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva. (2) A prince; a former incarnation of the buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
A divine being from the Brahmā world.
A bodhisattva in the southwestern buddhafield Virtuous Eye.
A prince who was a pupil of Buddha Abhāva samudgata countless eons ago.
A great bodhisattva.
The seventieth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS in verse: Mahā karuṇa megha śirī.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
Son of the buddha Padmakośa.
A realm that neighbors the Hell of Intense Heat.
A specific state of mind resulting from the four abodes of Brahma and defined as the wish to liberate all beings from suffering.

This refers to one of the two central qualities of buddhas or high bodhisattvas: their feeling born of the wish for all living beings to be free of suffering and to attain the supreme happiness. It is important to note that this great compassion has nothing to do with any sentimental emotion such as that stimulated by such a reflection as “Oh, the poor creatures! How they are suffering!” On the contrary, great compassion is accompanied by the clear awareness that ultimately there are no such things as living beings, suffering, etc., in reality. Thus it is a sensitivity that does not entertain any dualistic notion of subject and object; indeed, such an unlimited sensitivity might best be termed “empathy.”
Father of the buddha Brahmagāmin.
A bodhisattva great being present in the audience of this sūtra.
Birthplace of the buddha Brahmagāmin.
One of the kinnara kings.
A realm that neighbors the Hell of Intense Heat.
Youngest son of the universal monarch Nimiṃdhara.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Brahmaghoṣa.
Mother of the buddha Puṇyabala.
Mother of the buddha Akṣobhya.
One of the two pīlavas.
Second of the four immeasurable aspirations.
One of the vidyārājñīs attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the abodes of Brahmā, the other being: loving kindness or love, equanimity, and joy.
One of the four practices of spiritual practitioners and one of the four immeasurables (the others being loving-kindness or love, sympathetic joy, and equanimity).

One of the four immeasurables of the Mahāyāna, known in early Buddhism as “pure abodes” (Skt. brahmavihāra), which comprise (1) loving kindness, (2) compassion, (3) empathetic joy, and (4) impartiality. Immeasurable compassion arises from the wish for all living beings to be free from suffering and the causes of suffering.
Son of the buddha Ojobala.
Attendant of the buddha Arhaddeva.
Son of the buddha Puṇyabala.
A prince.
One of the three principles or forces of nature, as known in the Sāṃkhya philosophy, characterized by lightness.
The 946th buddha in the first list, 945th in the second list, and 936th in the third list.
A technical term referring to a meditative state attained through the practice of concentration.

One of the synonyms for the meditative state. The Tibetan translation interpreted it as sama-āpatti, which brings in the idea of being “equal” or “level,” whereas it may very well be, like “samādhi,” sam-āpatti, with the similar meaning of concentration, but also of completion.
A state of mental equilibrium derived from deep concentration.
A bodhisattva.
Meditative equipoise or evenness of mind. Another synonym for meditation, this also refers to a category of advanced meditative attainments.

A technical term referring to a meditative state attained through the practice of concentration. (The word “attainment” is also used here to translate non-technical words that have the sense of “obtain” or “acquire.”)

One of several common terms that are used to describe meditative states. The four states of meditative attainment refer here to the states of infinite space, infinite consciousness, nothingness, and neither perception nor absence of perception.

One of the synonyms for the meditative state. The Tibetan translation interpreted it as sama-āpatti, which brings in the idea of “equal,” or “level,” whereas it may very well be like “samādhi,” sam-āpatti, with the similar meaning of concentration. Unlike samādhi, however, it also occurs with the meaning of “completion,” “attainment,” and “diligent practice.”

One of the synonyms for the meditative state, in tems of both the state itself and the various meditative states that serve as attainments along the path. The Tibetan translation interprets it as sama-āpatti, which brings in the idea of “equal,” or “level;” however, it can also be parsed as sam-āpatti, in which case it would have the sense of “concentration,” or “absorption,” much like “samādhi,” but with the added sense of “completion.”

A technical term referring to a meditative state attained through the practice of concentration. Usually a reference to the nine gradual attainments (navānupūrvavihārasamāpatti, {mthar gyis gnas pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa dgu}) that include the four attainments of the form realm, the four formless attainments, and the attainment of the state of cessation. (The word “attainment” is also used here to translate non-technical words that have the sense of “obtain” or “acquire.”)

“Absorption” has been translated as “meditation,” “contemplation,” “attainment,” etc., and any of these words might serve. The problem is to establish one English word for each of the important Sanskrit words samāpatti, dhyāna, samādhi, bhāvanā, etc., so as to preserve a consistency with the original. Therefore, I have adopted for these terms, respectively, “absorption,” “contemplation,” “concentration” and “realization” or “cultivation,” reserving the word “meditation” for general use with any of the terms when they are used not in a specific sense but to indicate mind-practice in general.

One of the synonyms for the meditative state. The Tibetan translation interpreted it as sama-āpatti, which brings in the idea of “equal,” or “level,” whereas it may very well be like “samādhi,” sam-āpatti, with the same meaning.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Mahāmitra (869 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A state of mental equilibrium derived from deep concentration.
A rākṣasī known only from this sūtra.
Mother of the buddha Maṇivajra.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Anantatejas.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.

Having “forty even and white teeth” is included in the thirty-two signs of a great being. Depending on the list, this sign is often divided into two separate signs of having “forty teeth” and having “white teeth.” In the Sanskrit parallel of The Questions of Dīrghanakha the Wandering Mendicant, this quality is described as having “very beautiful and very bright teeth” (suśobhana dantaḥ sudīpta dantaḥ).

Listed in The Question of Mañjuśrī as the seventh of the thirty-two signs of a great being. In the Mahāvyutpatti and other lists this is represented as two separate signs: “forty teeth” (catvāriṃśaddanta; {tshems bzhi bcu mnga' ba}) and “close-fitting teeth” (aviraladanta; {tshems thags bzang ba}).
Another name of Candra, the god of the moon.
One of the bodhisattva great beings.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Sumanas.
Mother of the buddha Vasudeva.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Viṣāṇin.
One of the rāśis.

The vows of moral discipline which are followed by monks and nuns. The term “prātimokṣa” can be used to refer both to the disciplinary rules themselves and to the texts from the Vinaya that contain them.
The four correct understandings are the mastery of meaning, the mastery of Dharma, the mastery of language, and the mastery of courageous eloquence.
Genuine discrimination with respect to meaning, phenomena, language, and eloquence.
Correct or genuine discrimination with respect to Dharma, meaning, language, and confident eloquence.
The knowledge of the meaning, the knowledge of phenomena, the knowledge of interpretation, and the knowledge of eloquence.
A list of special cognitive abilities that characterize realized beings. They are the special knowledges of meaning, of dharmas, of explanations, and of brilliancy.

The four correct and unhindered discriminating knowledges of (1) the doctrine or Dharma, (2) meaning, (3) language, and (4) brilliance or eloquence. These are the essential means by which the buddhas impart their teachings.

These four kinds of exact knowledge—the essentials through which the buddhas impart their teachings—comprise (1) exact knowledge of meanings, (2) exact knowledge of dharmas, (3) exact knowledge of their language and lexical explanations, and (4) exact knowledge of their eloquent expression. See https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-253 .\nOn the philological origins of these four kinds of exact knowledge, see Konow (1941): 40, and the reconstructed Sanskrit on p. 107; also Dayal (1932): 259–267, and Sparham (2012 IV): 78–79.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s assembly.
One of the twelve retentions of the bodhisattvas.
An absorption.
The name of a dhāraṇī.
Genuine discrimination with respect to dharmas, meaning, language, and eloquence.
There are four: the discernments of meaning, phenomena, definitions, and eloquence.
When given as an enumeration, this refers to the four: the discernments of meaning, phenomena, definitions, and eloquence.
The discrimination of dharma, the discrimination of things, the discrimination of expression, and the discrimination of eloquence.

The modes of knowledge attained on the ninth bodhisattva level. There are four such modes: the correct analytical knowledge of phenomena (dharma; {chos}), of meaning (artha; {don}), of language or etymology (nirukti; {nges pa'i tshig}), and of eloquence (pratibhāna; {spobs pa}).

Four specific types of discernment. The four ways in which a bodhisattva knows distinct features, characteristics, and states of phenomena: (1) discrimination of dharma (dharmapratisaṃvid, {chos so so yang dag rig pa}); (2) discrimination of things (arthapratisaṃvid, {so so yang dag rig pa}); (3) discrimination of expression (niruktipratisaṃvid, {nges tshig so so yang dag rig pa}); (4) discrimination of eloquence (pratibhāna pratisaṃvid, {spobs pa so so yang dag rig pa}) (Rigzin 288, with slight adjustments to terminology in translation).

The four correct and unhindered discriminating knowledges of the doctrine of Dharma, of meaning, of language, and of brilliance or eloquence. These are the essential means by which the buddhas impart their teachings.
A person who has not had a perceptual experience of the truth and has therefore not achieved the state of a noble being.
Anyone who has not entered the “Path of Seeing” (i.e., has no stable direct realization of selflessness) is an ordinary person as opposed to a noble one.
A buddha realm.
The least severe of five types of offenses a monk can incur. There are four types of offense requiring personal confession, which are expunged through personal confession.
To welcome a visitor with pleasantries.
Sixth of the eighteen distinct qualities of the buddhas. Also rendered here as as “without indifference that does not make distinctions.”

The four correct and unhindered discriminating knowledges of the doctrine or Dharma, of meaning, of language, and of brilliance or eloquence. These are the essential means by which the buddhas impart their teachings.
One of the five wisdoms corresponding to the tathāgata Amitābha.
The term {so sor rtog pa} has two meanings in our text: (1) analysis (pratyavekṣa) and (2) comprehension, realization, awakening (pratibodha).

The regulations and rules that constitute Buddhist discipline. The number and scope of the vows differs depending on one’s status (lay, novice monastic, or full monastic) and whether one is a monk or a nun.
The rules of conduct that lead to liberation.
The collection of monastic rules, which is supposed to be recited at the formal meeting of monastics every fortnight.

“Prātimokṣa” is the name given to the code of conduct binding on monks and nuns. The term can be used to refer both to the disciplinary rules themselves and to the texts from the Vinaya that contain them. There are multiple recensions of the Prātimokṣa , each transmitted by a different monastic fraternity in ancient and medieval India. Three remain living traditions, one of them the Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya of Tibetan Buddhism. Though the numbers of rules vary across the different recensions, they are all organized according to the same principles and with the same disciplinary categories. It is customary for monastics to recite the Prātimokṣa Sūtra https://read.84000.co/translation/toh2.html fortnightly. According to some Mahāyana sūtras, a separate set of prātimokṣa rules exists for bodhisattvas, which are based on bodhisattva conduct as taught in that vehicle.
Correct understanding of meaning, Dharma, language, and eloquence.

The modes of knowledge attained on the ninth bodhisattva level. There are four such modes: the comprehensive knowledge of phenomena (dharma; {chos}), of meaning (artha; {don}), of language or etymology (nirukti; {nges pa'i tshig}), and eloquence (pratibhāna; {spobs pa}).
One of the cold hells.
Name of one of the eight cold hells. It is named for the sounds its inhabitants make while enduring unthinkable cold.
Third of the eight cold hells of Buddhist cosmology. It is named for the sounds its inhabitants make while enduring unthinkable cold.
A previous ruler of the Heaven Free from Strife.
A rākṣasa.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
Lit. “Without a Straw.” A nāga king, who was the brahmin Agnidatta in a former life.
A nāga king.
Nāga king who became a pupil of the Buddha.
A bodhisattva.
Pledging not to repeat past negative actions.
Seventy-sixth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata. More specifically, it is a “finger ring.”
Ninth of the eighty minor marks.
4th of the thirty-two major marks.
Listed in The Question of Mañjuśrī as the twentieth of the thirty-two signs of a great being.

The Buddha is said to have long and webbed fingers and toes. This is one of the signs included in the thirty-two signs of a great being; sometimes “long” and “webbed” are listed as two separate signs.
Eleventh of the eighty minor marks.
Tenth of the eighty minor marks.
The rules of conduct that lead to liberation.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Ugra (83 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Attendant of the buddha Vidvat.
An acceptable form of food for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
A great bodhisattva.
A sub-type of offense of which there are thirty varieties. These are expunged through communal confession and the forfeiting of the object that caused the transgression.
A hunter.
An acceptable form of shelter for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
Nardostachys jatamansi, Nardostachys grandiflora.
A great bodhisattva.
The planet Saturn.
A rishi of ancient India, the son of Rishi Bhṛgu, known for having become a youth again after he had reached an old age.

A specific kind of ancient Indian ornament, probably meaning “flower on the front” or “face with a flower.” It was made by metallurgists, presumably from gold. The Tibetan has a definition which involves a woman’s face. It is probably a central feature of a necklace, in which there is a face and a flower—possibly a face within a flower as is seen on ancient stūpa railings such as those in Bodhgaya.

A period of probation imposed by the saṅgha if a monk incurs a saṅgha stigmata offense and confesses it straight away. During the period of probation, the offending monk loses many privileges and is barred from participating in official acts of the saṅgha, such as ordination ceremonies.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1173 .
Official acts of saṅgha enacted when a monk incurs a saṅgha stigmata offense.\nSee also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1173 .
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Guṇakīrti.
Mother of the buddha Kusumadatta.
Name of a bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Vikrama.
The name of an eon in which the Buddha He Who Attained Awakening after Countless Millions of Eons resides.
Name of a buddha realm in the east where the buddha Departed by Completely Subduing from the Precious Lotus resides.
Lit. “Heap of Eloquence.”
A great bodhisattva and Dharma teacher.
A bodhisattva present in the circle around Śākyamuni.
The name of a bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s retinue.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Arthasiddhi.
A bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva.
Father of the buddha Arthamati.
A great bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Arhatkīrti.

A bodhisattva who appears mainly in chapters 11 and 12 of this sūtra. In the Chinese version, like other bodhisattvas who appear in the second half of the sūtra, considered to be of a later date than the first half, he is not in the initial list of bodhisattvas given in the first chapter.
The 108th buddha in the first list, 108th in the second list, and 109th in the third list.
The name of a buddha in the northern direction.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
Name of Vīrasena when he becomes a buddha.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Cūḍa.
The 281st buddha in the first list, 280th in the second list, and 280th in the third list.
Father of the buddha Dharmakūṭa.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
The 943rd buddha in the first list, 942nd in the second list, and 933rd in the third list.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva present in the Buddha’s assembly. His name means, “Magical Voice like a Victory Banner of Infinite Eloquence.”
A Dharma teacher.
A bodhisattva present in the circle around Śākyamuni.
Lit. “endless confidence.” Name of a meditative stabilization.
The 933rd buddha in the first list, 932nd in the second list, and 923rd in the third list.
Name of a bodhisattva.
Name of the seventy-sixth meditative stability.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
A bodhisattva present during the delivery of the King of the Array of all Dharma Qualities.
The 984th buddha in the first list, 983rd in the second list, and 974th in the third list.
A great bodhisattva.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Dharma pradīpākṣa.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
One of the four kinds of knowledge.
Fourth of the four kinds of exact knowledge. Eloquent expression here, also translated in the text as “inspired eloquence,” is the means by which the teachings are expressed.
Mother of the buddha Jñānin.
A great bodhisattva.
Mother of the buddha Deva.
A merchant of the city of Śrāvastī who is the primary interlocutor in this sūtra.
Son of the buddha Anihata.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Varabuddhi.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Pratibhāna varṇa.
Short name of the buddha Proclaimer of the Melodious Thundering Roar of the Ornamental Beauty of Eloquence.
Birthplace of the buddha Jñānakrama.
Son of the buddha Udgata.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Anihata.
The 734th buddha in the first list, 733rd in the second list, and 723rd in the third list.
Birthplace of the buddha Pratibhāna varṇa.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Kṣemottamarāja.
A buddha of the past.
Mother of the buddha Tiṣya.
A bodhisattva in the buddhafield at the nadir called Appearing as Illumination.
The name of a tathāgata presiding over a buddhafield to the south of the buddhafield Full of Pearls.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Ratnacandra.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Pratibhāna cakṣus.
The 739th buddha in the first list, 738th in the second list, and not listed in the third list.
A buddha of the past.
The 772nd buddha in the first list, 771st in the second list, and 761st in the third list.
Inspiration, presence of mind, self-confidence, or quick-wittedness, particularly as manifested in speech.
Inspiration and courage that manifests in particular in one’s endowment with brilliant abilities in oration.
Intelligence or inspiration that allows one to talk in the most appropriate way even for very long stretches of time.
The Tibetan word literally means “confidence” or “courage” but it refers to confident speech, to being perfectly eloquent, especially in expressing the Dharma.
The quality of intelligence, inspiration, and confident knowledge that allows one to teach and talk in the most appropriate way, even for very long stretches of time.

The translation is meant to somehow echo the etymology of prati + bhāna (“forth” + “shine”), and the term does mean something like “intelligence,” “inspiration,” or “eloquence,” often referring to the intelligent presence of mind that allows one to speak in the most appropriate way, even for very long stretches of time.

Four types of right effort consisting in (1) abandoning existing negative mind states, (2) abandoning the production of such states, (3) giving rise to virtuous mind states that are not yet produced, and (4) letting those states continue.

The Nibandhana explains that this refers to a standard list of eight assembled factors: zest (chanda), effort (vyāyāma), faith (śraddhā), mindfulness (smṛti), discerning awareness (saṁprajanya), intention (cetanā), and equanimity (upekṣā) (Samtani 1971, p. 221).
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Mokṣavrata (852 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Father of the buddha Kṛtārtha.
A country.
A temple on Mount Gośṛṅga.
A name assumed by Prince Kuśa, the Buddha in a former life.

One of the sixteen principal mahājanapadas (great countries) of ancient India, and a confederacy of eight or nine clans. It extended from the north bank of the Ganges opposite Pāṭaliputra up to the Madhesh regions of present southern Nepal.

Literally “perfumed chamber,” this was the name given to the Buddha’s personal room at the Jetavana monastery. The term was then later applied to the room in any monastery where an image of the Buddha was installed to signify his presence. In the context of an Action Tantra, the term seems to refer generically to a shrine chamber, perhaps one specifically enshrining the deity that is the focus of a given rite.
A buddha.
A buddha in a southeastern buddha realm.
Mother of the buddha Sugandha.
A buddha.
A park in another world in the distant past.

A legendary mountain north of the Himalayas, with Lake Anavatapta, the source of the world’s great rivers, at its base. It is said to be south of Mount Kailash, though both have been identified with Mount Tise in western Tibet. In other sūtras translated as {spos ngad can}, {spos ngad ldang}, and {spos nad ldan}.
A buddha realm.
A mountain east of Mount Sumeru.
A mountain to the east of Mount Sumeru.
A mountain or mountain range closely associated with solitary buddhas.
One of the pratyeka buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the eight chief pratyeka buddhas.
Name of a mountain.
A mountain known for its incense trees.

Buddha of the universe Sarva gandha sugandhā, from whom Vimalakīrti’s emanation-bodhisattva obtains the vessel of ambrosial food that magically feeds the entire assembly without diminishing in the slightest.

A legendary mountain north of the Himalayas, with Lake Anavatapta, the source of the world’s great rivers, at its base. It is said to be south of Mount Kailash, though both have been identified with Mount Tise in west Tibet.
Name of a mountain range, better known as Gandhamādana.

A legendary mountain north of the Himalayas, with Lake Anavatapta, the source of the worlds great rivers, at its base. It is said to be south of Mount Kailash, though both have been identified with Mount Tise in west Tibet.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Ugrasena (517 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.

A legendary mountain north of the Himalayas, with Lake Anavatapta, the source of the world’s great rivers, at its base. It is said to be south of Mount Kailash, though both have been identified with Mount Tise in west Tibet.

Universe of the Buddha Gandhottama kūṭa; a universe wherein the Dharma is taught through the medium of scent. According to Lamotte, p. 319, n. 2, this universe is mentioned in the Śikṣāsamuccaya, the Laṇkāvatāra, and the Prasannapadā. However, In the Prasannapadā, this universe is said to be ruled by Samantabhadra, not Gandhottama kūṭa (see Lamotte, p. 320, n. 3).
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Jewel Light.
Name of a buddha realm located in the northern direction during the time of the Buddha Śākyamuni. Also called Manifestation of All Sounds.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Beta Leonis in the occidental tradition.
Sesbania grandiflora.
A forest of the asuras.
A pond in the city of Vaiśālī.
The “monkey pond” near Vaiśālī.
Literally “Monkey Pond,” the name of a pond and/or caitya at, or near, Vaiśālī (Edgerton 420.1).
The name of a karmic wind involved in the formation of an embryo in its twenty-fourth week.

994–1043; Indian (possibly Bengali) paṇḍita who visited Tibet three times; teacher of Drokmi Śākya Yeshé; a complex personality and a key figure in the transmission to Tibet of the Hevajra materials later incorporated in the Lamdré ({lam 'bras}) tradition.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Hitaiṣin.

A buddha.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.

In the Sarvāstivāda tradition, the lowest of the three paradises that correspond to the fourth dhyāna in the form realm.
The realm of the Buddha Cloud King.

A mountain in Kuru, the same as White Cloud Keeper.

Two different individuals in this sūtra: (1) a son of King Sarvārthasiddha and (2) a bodhisattva disciple of King of the Lunar Lamp.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Sucīrṇavipāka (878 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
In chapter 4, the kalyāṇamitra bhikṣu in South India. In chapter 36, the name of a buddha in the distant past. In chapter 44, this is the name of a future buddha in this kalpa. BHS verse: Meghaśiri.
A world system.
A past buddha.
A forest on the northern border of the Middle Country earlier in the current eon, during the time of the Buddha Krakucchanda.
A nāga who visits Saṅkāśa Mountain.
A monk.
A buddha
A bodhisattva.
The 758th buddha in the first list, 757th in the second list, and 747th in the third list.

A horse king who was the Buddha in a former life.
(1) A forest in Draped with Jewels. (2) A forest on Flocking Peacocks.

A king.

Son of the buddha Sāra.
Attendant of the buddha Supraṇaṣṭamoha.
Birthplace of the buddha Amoghavikramin.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Siṃha.
A forest in Dwelling on Summits.
First of three heavens of gods on the fourth concentration level.
The tenth heaven of the realm of form; also the name of the gods living there.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, first of three levels of the fourth dhyāna realm.
Tenth god realm of form, meaning “cloudless,” it is the lowest of the three realms in the fourth dhyāna heaven in the form realm.

The tenth of the heavens of the form realm. Rebirth there is the karmic result of accomplishing the third or, according to the Mvy, fourth meditative absorption. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-269 .

Lit. “Cloudless.” The tenth of the seventeen heavens of the form realm; also the name of the gods living there. In the form realm, which is structured according to the four concentrations and pure abodes‍‍, or Śuddhāvāsa, it is listed as the first of the three heavens that correspond to the fourth of the four concentrations.
A common epithet for a buddha.
A virtuous nāga king.
A virtuous nāga king.
A lotus pool in Lateral.
Foremost in terms of miraculous abilities among the followers of the buddha Aparājita dhvaja.
A class of vidyādharas.
A buddha.
A buddha in the distant past.
A buddha in the northern direction.
A buddha in the northern direction. Also the name of millions of buddhas in the distant past.
A brahmin.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Always Fragrant
The 965th buddha in the first list, 964th in the second list, and 955th in the third list.
A park where the buddha Voice Proclaiming the Cloud of Dharma resided.
Son of the buddha Velāmarāja.
A nāga lady from a previous time.
A mountain on the continent of Kuru.
A Dravidian, the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 7.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
Forty-sixth of the eighty designs on the palms and soles of the Tathāgata.
One of the bodhisattva great beings.
Free from concepts or mental fabrications.

A term used and translated variously in Indian and Buddhist literature. Closely related to being free of conceptualization, it refers here to the simple nature of phenomena, their emptiness without the conceptualization of the mind that is imposed upon them.
Also called “constructs,” “mental constructs,” “mental fabrication,” or “proliferations.”
This term denotes the presence of discursive or conceptual thought processes. Their absence or deconstruction is characteristic of the realization of emptiness or ultimate reality.

An etymologically obscure term, which can mean elaboration, diffusion, or expansion, but is basically describing the mind’s conceptualization, and is always connected to the words for notions and ideas, and mental fabrications.

This term often refers to the mental elaborations that characterize the conceptual mind, but in this text it also carries the sense of meaningless talk.\nThis less technical sense of “pointless speculation” is captured in Bodhiruci’s Chinese translation, where xilun 戲論 has the meaning of “intellectual frivolity” and “frivolous discourse,” as well as being the Chinese rendering of the more technical senses of prapañca.
A realm in the distant past.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
One of the gods’ realms; also used as the name of the gods living there.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Free of Poverty.
The energy center (cakra) in the navel.
A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
The body of a buddha visible to ordinary sentient beings.
The “body of transformation,” one of the three (sometimes four) bodies of the Buddha.
A body manifested by a tathāgata perceivable by ordinary senses; one of the two “form bodies” (rūpakāya).
Nirmāṇakāya or body of manifestation. Aspect of buddhahood perceptible to ordinary individuals with good karma.

The buddha body of emanation is the visible and usually physical manifestation of fully enlightened beings which arises spontaneously from the expanse of the buddha body of reality, whenever appropriate‌, in accordance with the diverse dispositions of sentient beings.
A buddha in the distant past. BHS in verse: Nirmita megha susvara śiri.
This refers to the miraculous power of the buddhas, and bodhisattvas at a certain stage of spiritual development, to project emanations of themselves in order to develop and teach sentient beings.

One of the classes of beings barred from joining the renunciate order. The word {sprul pa} denotes a wide range of phenomena—emanations, apparitions, conjurings, shape-shifting creatures, etc.—all united by their tendency to morph through their own agency or another’s. We have therefore translated {sprul pa} according to context as “emanation” or “shape shifter.”

This refers to the miraculous power of the Buddha and bodhisattvas of a certain stage to emanate apparently living beings in order to develop and teach living beings. This power reaches its culmination in the nirmāṇa kayā, the “incarnation body,” which is one of the three bodies of buddhahood and includes all physical forms of all buddhas, including Śākyamuni, whose sole function as incarnations is the development and liberation of living beings.
The name of a karmic wind involved in the formation of an embryo in its twelfth week.
A vulture king.
“Razor Blade,” one of the hells.
The Maitraka dynasty that started from Dharasena I.
Fifty-second of the eighty minor marks.
Listed in The Question of Mañjuśrī as the thirteenth of the thirty-two signs of a great being.
Fifty-first of the eighty minor marks.
A buddha.
Fortieth of the eighty minor marks.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Moon Light.
Understandings of what {spug} might refer to vary, but it could be musāragalva (Pali masāragalla), i.e., a green precious stone, a cat’s eye, or pukh as in pukhraj, i.e., yellow sapphire.

Musāragalva is fossilized coral that has undergone transformation under millions of years of underwater pressure. It appears in one version of the list of seven precious materials. The Tibetan tradition describes it as being formed from ice over a long period of time. It can also refer to tridacna (Tridacnidae) shell, which is also presently referred to by the name musaragalva. Attempts to identify musāragalva have included sapphire, cat’s eye, red coral, conch, and amber.

White coral is fossilized coral. It appears in one version of the list of seven precious materials. The Tibetan tradition describes it as being formed from ice over a long period of time. It is coral that has undergone transformation under millions of years of underwater pressure. It can also refer to tridacna (Tridacnidae) shell, which is also presently referred to by the name musaragalva. Attempts to identify musalagalva have included sapphire, cat’s eye, red coral, conch, and amber.
A city or village.
caryācaritāvin in the https://read.84000.co/translation/toh107.html .
A buddha.
A buddha in the distant past listed in chapter 33; also the name of a future buddha of this kalpa listed in chapter 44.
A buddha.
One of the sixteen great bodhisattvas. The content of the list varies from text to text.
Name of a teacher; a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A buddha in the distant past.
Twenty-ninth of the thirty-two major marks.
A buddha.
Father of the buddha Priya cakṣurvaktra.
Not listed in the first list, the 11th buddha in the second list, and 11th in the third list.
The five kinds of eyes possessed by a thus-gone one: the eye of flesh, the divine eye, the eye of Dharma, the eye of insight, and the eye of a buddha.
The “five types of vision” are the physical, divine, prajñā, Dharma, and jñāna eyes.
The five kinds of eyes possessed by a tathāgata. Namely, the eye of flesh, the divine eye, the eye of Dharma, the eye of insight, and the eye of a buddha.
The chief goddess of the jewel family, personifying the true nature of the element of earth.
The uṣṇīṣa goddess of the Tathāgata family; also one of the vidyārājñīs attending the delivery of the MMK.
A female deity in one of the variants of the maṇḍala of Caṇḍa mahā roṣaṇa; also the name of the consort of Ratna sambhava.
A buddha.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Amohavihārin (810 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Cāritraka (882 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
A buddha.
(1) A buddha in the past. (2) A non-Buddhist teacher, an ascetic.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the eight tathāgatas.
The 522nd buddha in the first list, 522nd in the second list, and 515th in the third list.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
The king of the nāgas (one of the four great kings of the directions).
A buddha.

Listed in The Question of Mañjuśrī as the sixth of the thirty-two signs of a great being. This matches the list found in the Mahāvyutpatti, no. 240, but in other lists this is represented as two separate signs: “dark blue eyes” and “bovine eyelashes.”
Twenty-eighth of the thirty-two major marks.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Laḍitavikrama (302 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A tathāgata.
The bodhisattva of compassion; one of the bodhisattvas in the retinue of the Buddha.
One of the main bodhisattva disciples of the Buddha Śākyamuni, praised for his compassion.
One of the most popular bodhisattvas in the Mahāyāna Buddhist pantheon and one of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha, the embodiment of compassion.
Bodhisattva embodying the compassion of all the buddhas.\nFor the reason why he received this name, see https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-051-002.html#UT22084-051-002-40 .

A bodhisattva who first appears in the Sukhāvatī vyūha sūtra (https://read.84000.co/translation/toh115.html) and then in a number of other Mahāyāna sūtras such as the Sad dharma puṇḍarīka (https://read.84000.co/translation/toh113.html). Avalokiteśvara develops into a great bodhisattva who embodies compassion with multiple forms in Indian, Chinese, and Tibetan Buddhism.

First appeared as a bodhisattva beside Amitābha in the Sukhāvatī vyūha Sūtra ( https://read.84000.co/translation/toh115.html , Toh 115). The name has been variously interpreted. In its meaning as “the lord of avalokita,” avalokita has been interpreted as “seeing,” although, as a past passive participle, it is literally “lord of what has been seen.” One of the principal sūtras in the Mahāsāṃghika tradition was the Avalokita Sūtra, which has not been translated into Tibetan, in which the word is a synonym for enlightenment, as it is “that which has been seen” by the buddhas. In the early tantras, he was one of the lords of the three families, as the embodiment of the compassion of the Buddhas. The Potalaka Mountain in South India became important in Southern Indian Buddhism as his residence in this world, but Potalaka does not feature in the Kāraṇḍa vyūha Sūtra ( https://read.84000.co/translation/toh116 , Toh 116), which is the most important sūtra dedicated to Avalokiteśvara.

One of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha, the embodiment of compassion. He first appeared as a bodhisattva beside Amitābha in the Sukhāvatī Sūtra. The name has been variously interpreted. In his name meaning “the lord of avalokita,” avalokita has been interpreted as “seeing,” although as a past passive participle, it is literally “lord of what has been seen.” One of the principal sūtras in the Mahāsamghika tradition, not translated into Tibetan, was the Avalokita Sūtra, in which the word is a synonym for awakening, as it is “that which has been seen” by the buddhas. In the early tantras, he is one of the lords of the three families, as the embodiment of the compassion of the buddhas.
A buddha.
One of the main bodhisattva disciples of the buddha Śākyamuni, praised for his compassion.

A bodhisattva emblematic of the great compassion; of great importance in Tibet as special protector of the religious life of the country and in China, in female form, as Kwanyin, protectress of women, children, and animals.
A great bodhisattva.
The bodhisattva who is the epitome of compassion.
The deified bodhisattva of compassion; one of the original sixteen bodhisattvas.
Bodhisattva of compassion. One of the eight main bodhisattvas, the heart sons of the Buddha.
One of the main bodhisattva disciples of the Buddha Śākyamuni, he is renowned for his compassion.
The bodhisattva who embodies compassion, also mentioned in this text as Āryāva loki teśvara, the noble Avaloki teśvara.

First appeared as a bodhisattva beside Amitābha in the Sukhāvati vyūha. The name has been variously interpreted. “The lord of Avalokita,” Avalokita has been interpreted as “seeing,” although, as a past passive participle, it is literally “lord of what has been seen.” One of the principal sūtras in the Mahā sāṃghika tradition was the Avalokita Sūtra, which has not been translated into Tibetan, in which the word is a synonym for enlightenment, as it is “that which has been seen” by the buddhas. In the early tantras he was one of the lords of the three families, as the embodiment of the compassion of the buddhas. The Potalaka Mountain in South India became important in Southern Indian Buddhism as his residence in this world, but Potalaka does not feature in the Kāraṇḍa vyūha.
A buddha.
The 556th buddha in the first list, 556th in the second list, and 549th in the third list.
The 759th buddha in the first list, 758th in the second list, and 748th in the third list.
Buddha in the presence of whom the buddha Bhadravaktra (862 according to the third enumeration) first gave rise to the mind of awakening.
A buddha.
Fifty-third of the eighty minor marks.
Twenty-seventh of the thirty-two major marks.
A deity.
The chief goddess of the jewel family, personifying the true nature of the element of earth.
One of the goddesses in the maṇḍala of Mañjuśrī. Her name is rendered elsewhere in this translation as “Locanā.”
A technical astrological expression indicating that the aspect of the planet that “looks” is exercising influence on the planet it looks upon, and, indirectly, also on the affected person.
Another name for Māndhātṛ, a wheel-turning king who was the Buddha in a former life. See also https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-3140 .
One of the wrathful emanations of Vajrapāṇi.
Location visited for pleasure by Śakra and his entourage.

Seventy-first of the eighty minor marks in this text, although it does not figure in other lists of the minor marks. It is considered as a feature of the crown extension (uṣṇīṣa) in some texts and an additional, separate mark of a tathāgata in others. See also Unseen Pinnacle.
A feature of the uṣṇīṣa whereby its top, or its upward extent, cannot be seen.
Name of the seventh meditative stability. See also Pinnacle of their crown cannot be seen.

Seventy-first of the eighty minor marks in this text, although it does not figure in other lists of the minor marks. It is considered as a feature of the crown extension (uṣṇīṣa) in some texts and an additional, separate mark of a tathāgata in others. See also Unseen Pinnacle.

One of the features of a tathāgata, sometimes included as an additional characteristic of the uṣṇīṣa (q.v.) and sometimes as a separate sign, either within the major and minor marks or in addition to them. Although sometimes explained with the sense almost of a prohibition against looking down on a tathāgata from above, it is more usually linked to the idea that the uṣṇīṣa extends upwards so far that its top is literally out of sight. Its mention in this text relates to the overall stature of a tathāgata, presumably in more than one sense.
Lit. “seeing from the top of the head.” Name of a meditative stabilization. (Kimura has avalokita mūrdhā)
A realm of the vessel-bearer gods.
One of the mantra deities.
This is listed on https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-2379 as the last (33rd) of the major marks.

One of the thirty-two marks of a great being, in its simplest form it is a pointed shape to the head (like a turban), or more elaborately a dome-shaped protuberance, or even an invisible protuberance of infinite height.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
A village.
A settlement / village in the country of Vṛji. According to a commentary on the Mahāvaṃsa, the Vaṃsatthappakāsinī, it is one gāvuta (about two miles) away from the river Ganges.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
A great bodhisattva.
The practice of giving or making offerings to others. One of the six perfections of the bodhisattva.
Inauguration through sprinkling water on the head; a custom used for anointing kings in ancient India.
The 922nd buddha in the first list, 921st in the second list, and 912th in the third list.
A general term for non-Buddhist religious mendicants, often occurring together with parivrājaka and nirgrantha in stock lists of followers of non-Buddhist movements.
The 875th buddha in the first list, 874th in the second list, and 865th in the third list.
Walking, standing, sitting, and lying down.
The four acceptable norms of behavior concern posture while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down. See Nordrang Orgyen (2008), 718–719.
Mother of the buddha Yaśoratna.
Foremost in terms of insight among the followers of the buddha Vikrīḍitāvin.
Eighteenth of the eighty minor marks.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
Sitting, standing, lying down, walking.
‟Impetuous One,” one of the eight demonesses who inhabit the eight great charnel grounds.
A non-Buddhist wanderer, often grouped with the Parivrājakas.
In Buddhist usage, a general term for non-Buddhist religious mendicants, paired with parivrājaka in stock lists of followers of heretical movements..

According to the list in Madhyānta vibhāga 5.9, the ten practices are writing out, worshiping, making a gift of, listening to, reading, taking up in the mind, explicating, reciting to oneself what one has memorized of, contemplating, and meditating on the perfection of wisdom.
Name of a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
